zh: “啊！对了——我非常确信，除了个别例外的情况，海边的天气总是对人有益的。去年春天，雪莉博士得了一场大病，毫无疑问，这海边的空气对他起了很大的作用。他自己说，到莱姆的一个月对他的益处超过了他吃下的所有药物。而且在海边总能使他感觉到自己又年轻了。现在我不禁遗憾他不能长住海边了。我确实认为他最好彻底离开阿珀克罗斯，到莱姆定居。安妮，你说呢？你不同意我的说法吗？这种做法对他来说是再好不过了，对他自己和雪莉太太都有好处。你知道，雪莉太太在这儿有几位表兄，还有几位熟人，这会使她很快乐。而且我敢肯定，为了防止雪莉博士病情发作，雪莉太太很高兴到一个可以随时就医的地方。我觉得，雪莉博士夫妇这样一生行善的好人，却只能在阿珀克罗斯这样的地方度过晚年，确实十分遗憾。在那里，除了我们家以外，他们几乎完全与世隔绝。我希望他的朋友们能向他提这个建议。我的确认为他们应该这么做。至于说能否获准，凭雪莉博士的年龄和人格，是不会有困难的。我唯一担心的是能否说服他离开自己的教区。他的思想太严格谨慎了；我得说，他太谨慎了。安妮，难道你不认为他太谨慎了吗？你不觉得一位牧师为了恪尽职守而牺牲自己的健康是一种很错误的观点？他那些工作别人也可以做好。而且莱姆离阿珀克罗斯只有十七英里，如果教区内有人感到不满，那雪莉博士就在附近，他完全可以听得到。”
en: “Oh! yes,—I am quite convinced that, with very few exceptions, the sea-air always does good.There can be no doubt of its having been of the greatest service to Dr Shirley, after his illness, last spring twelve-month.He declares himself, that coming to Lyme for a month, did him more good than all the medicine he took; and, that being by the sea, always makes him feel young again.Now, I cannot help thinking it a pity that he does not live entirely by the sea.I do think he had better leave Uppercross entirely, and fix at Lyme.Do not you, Anne?Do not you agree with me, that it is the best thing he could do, both for himself and Mrs. Shirley?She has cousins here, you know, and many acquaintance, which would make it cheerful for her, and I am sure she would be glad to get to a place where she could have medical attendance at hand, in case of his having another seizure.Indeed I think it quite melancholy to have such excellent people as Dr and Mrs. Shirley, who have been doing good all their lives, wearing out their last days in a place like Uppercross, where, excepting our family, they seem shut out from all the world.I wish his friends would propose it to him.I really think they ought.And, as to procuring a dispensation, there could be no difficulty at his time of life, and with his character.My only doubt is, whether anything could persuade him to leave his parish.He is so very strict and scrupulous in his notions; over-scrupulous I must say.Do not you think, Anne, it is being over-scrupulous?Do not you think it is quite a mistaken point of conscience, when a clergyman sacrifices his health for the sake of duties, which may be just as well performed by another person?And at Lyme too, only seventeen miles off, he would be near enough to hear, if people thought there was anything to complain of.”

zh: 亨里埃塔讲这番话的时候，安妮不止一次地暗自微笑，她接过话茬说了几句。她这么做既是同情这位年轻姑娘的感情，也是同情那位小伙子的感情，不过也只是轻描淡写，因为除了一般的默认，还能做什么呢？她对此事提出了一些合乎情理而又十分得体的看法。她觉得雪莉博士的确应该休息了，她当时也只能这么说。她还说雪莉博士最好能够聘请一位积极的、正派的年轻人做常驻牧师，她还礼貌地暗示，这样的常驻牧师最好是已婚男子。
en: Anne smiled more than once to herself during this speech, and entered into the subject, as ready to do good by entering into the feelings of a young lady as of a young man, though here it was good of a lower standard, for what could be offered but general acquiescence?She said all that was reasonable and proper on the business; felt the claims of Dr Shirley to repose as she ought; saw how very desirable it was that he should have some active, respectable young man, as a resident curate, and was even courteous enough to hint at the advantage of such resident curate’s being married.

zh: “我希望，”亨里埃塔颇为满意地对安妮说，“我希望拉塞尔夫人住在阿珀克罗斯，成为雪莉博士的密友。我一直听说拉塞尔夫人是一位对所有人都能产生影响的女人！我一向认为她能劝说任何人去做任何事！我怕她，就像我以前跟你说过的，我相当怕她，因为她太聪明了。不过我非常尊重她，希望我们在阿珀克罗斯也有这样一位邻居。”
en: “I wish,” said Henrietta, very well pleased with her companion, “I wish Lady Russell lived at Uppercross, and were intimate with Dr Shirley.I have always heard of Lady Russell as a woman of the greatest influence with everybody!I always look upon her as able to persuade a person to anything!I am afraid of her, as I have told you before, quite afraid of her, because she is so very clever; but I respect her amazingly, and wish we had such a neighbour at Uppercross.”

zh: 亨里埃塔这种表达感激的方式让安妮觉得很有趣，让她觉得有趣的还有，事态的发展和亨里埃塔当前所关心的事情竟然会使她的朋友得到马斯格罗夫家族某一成员的赏识。她刚刚给出了一般性的回答，希望在阿珀克罗斯能找到另一位这样的女人，不过话就这样中断了，只见路易莎和温特沃思上校朝她们走了过来。他们也想趁着在早饭准备好之前出来溜达溜达。但是路易莎随后马上想起要去商店里买点东西，便邀请他们陪她一起回镇上去。大家都接受了她的提议。
en: Anne was amused by Henrietta’s manner of being grateful, and amused also that the course of events and the new interests of Henrietta’s views should have placed her friend at all in favour with any of the Musgrove family; she had only time, however, for a general answer, and a wish that such another woman were at Uppercross, before all subjects suddenly ceased, on seeing Louisa and Captain Wentworth coming towards them.They came also for a stroll till breakfast was likely to be ready; but Louisa recollecting, immediately afterwards that she had something to procure at a shop, invited them all to go back with her into the town.They were all at her disposal.

zh: 他们正要登上从海滩通往高处的石级时，一位刚准备往下走的绅士彬彬有礼地往后一退，停下来给他们让路。他们拾级而上，从他身边走过。这时安妮的脸庞吸引了他的注意，他带着某种真挚的爱慕看着安妮，安妮对此不会毫无察觉。她看上去特别动人。她那端庄秀丽的面庞经微风一吹拂，又焕发出青春的红润与清新，眼睛也充满了活力。这位绅士（从举止上看完全是位绅士）显然对她极为倾慕。温特沃思上校马上转头朝她望去，表明他注意到了这一点。他瞥了她一眼，和颜悦色地瞥了她一眼，仿佛在说：“那位绅士对你着迷了，连我在这个时刻也觉得你又有些像安妮•埃利奥特了。”
en: When they came to the steps, leading upwards from the beach, a gentleman, at the same moment preparing to come down, politely drew back, and stopped to give them way.They ascended and passed him; and as they passed, Anne’s face caught his eye, and he looked at her with a degree of earnest admiration, which she could not be insensible of.She was looking remarkably well; her very regular, very pretty features, having the bloom and freshness of youth restored by the fine wind which had been blowing on her complexion, and by the animation of eye which it had also produced.It was evident that the gentleman, (completely a gentleman in manner) admired her exceedingly.Captain Wentworth looked round at her instantly in a way which shewed his noticing of it.He gave her a momentary glance, a glance of brightness, which seemed to say, “That man is struck with you, and even I, at this moment, see something like Anne Elliot again.”

zh: 他们陪路易莎买好了东西，又逛了一会儿，才回到旅馆。后来安妮从卧室匆匆向餐厅走去的时候，差点撞上了那位绅士，因为他这时正从旁边的套房中出来。安妮起先猜测他同他们一样是从外地来的，当他们回旅馆时，安妮看到在两间旅馆之间有一位英俊的马夫在散步，便断定那是他的仆人。主仆两人都在服丧，这就更证实了她的猜想。现在证实他同安妮住在同一个旅馆。第二次撞见尽管只有一刹那，但绅士的目光又再一次表明，他认为安妮是一个非常可爱的姑娘，而且从他那爽快得体的道歉中，可以看出他是一位颇有风度的绅士。他约摸三十岁，虽说并不算英俊，但也挺讨人喜欢。安妮觉得她想知道他是谁。
en: After attending Louisa through her business, and loitering about a little longer, they returned to the inn; and Anne, in passing afterwards quickly from her own chamber to their dining-room, had nearly run against the very same gentleman, as he came out of an adjoining apartment.She had before conjectured him to be a stranger like themselves, and determined that a well-looking groom, who was strolling about near the two inns as they came back, should be his servant.Both master and man being in mourning assisted the idea.It was now proved that he belonged to the same inn as themselves; and this second meeting, short as it was, also proved again by the gentleman’s looks, that he thought hers very lovely, and by the readiness and propriety of his apologies, that he was a man of exceedingly good manners.He seemed about thirty, and though not handsome, had an agreeable person.Anne felt that she should like to know who he was.

zh: 大家快吃完早饭的时候，一阵马车声（这几乎是他们来到莱姆以后第一次听到马车的声音）将半数人吸引到窗口去了。这是一位绅士的马车，一辆双轮轻便马车，只不过是从马车场驶到前门来的。准是有人要走了。驾车的是个正在服丧的仆人。
en: They had nearly done breakfast, when the sound of a carriage, (almost the first they had heard since entering Lyme) drew half the party to the window.It was a gentleman’s carriage, a curricle, but only coming round from the stable-yard to the front door; somebody must be going away.It was driven by a servant in mourning.

zh: 一听说是双轮轻便马车，查尔斯•马斯格罗夫便跳了起来，他想将这辆马车同自己的那辆比比看。服丧的仆人激起了安妮的好奇心，马车的主人在旅馆主人一家哈腰送行下走到门口，登上马车出发时，他们六个人全都聚在一起张望了。
en: The word curricle made Charles Musgrove jump up that he might compare it with his own; the servant in mourning roused Anne’s curiosity, and the whole six were collected to look, by the time the owner of the curricle was to be seen issuing from the door amidst the bows and civilities of the household, and taking his seat, to drive off.

zh: “啊！”温特沃思上校马上嚷道，同时瞥了安妮一眼，“这就是我们刚才遇到的那个人。”
en: “Ah!” cried Captain Wentworth, instantly, and with half a glance at Anne, “it is the very man we passed.”

zh: 两位马斯格罗夫小姐表示同意。大家友好地目送那人朝山上驶去，知道看不见了他们才回到餐桌旁。过了一会儿，招待走了进来。
en: The Miss Musgroves agreed to it; and having all kindly watched him as far up the hill as they could, they returned to the breakfast table.The waiter came into the room soon afterwards.

zh: “请问，”温特沃思上校马上问道，“你能告诉我们刚才离开的那位绅士的姓名吗？”
en: “Pray,” said Captain Wentworth, immediately, “can you tell us the name of the gentleman who is just gone away?”

zh: “好的，先生，他是埃利奥特先生，一位非常有钱的绅士，昨晚从希德茅斯来的。先生，你们昨天吃晚饭的时候一定听见了马车声。现在他是要到克鲁克恩去，接着还要去巴斯和伦敦。”
en: “Yes, Sir, a Mr. Elliot, a gentleman of large fortune, came in last night from Sidmouth.Dare say you heard the carriage, sir, while you were at dinner; and going on now for Crewkherne, in his way to Bath and London.”

zh: “埃利奥特！”大家面面相觑，一些人还重复着这个名字，过了一会儿，大家才明白全部含义，连那个机灵的招待都猜出了其中的奥秘。
en: “Elliot!”Many had looked on each other, and many had repeated the name, before all this had been got through, even by the smart rapidity of a waiter.

zh: “天哪！”玛丽大声嚷道，“那一定是我们的堂兄。那一定是我们的埃利奥特先生，一定是的，真的！查尔斯，安妮，对吗？在服丧，你们瞧，我们那埃利奥特先生也应该这样。真凑巧！就和我们住在同一个旅馆里。安妮，他不正是我们那位埃利奥特先生？爸爸的继承人？请问，先生，”她转脸问那位招待，“你有没有听到他的仆人说起他是凯林奇家族的人？”
en: “Bless me!” cried Mary; “it must be our cousin; it must be our Mr. Elliot, it must, indeed!Charles, Anne, must not it?In mourning, you see, just as our Mr. Elliot must be.How very extraordinary!In the very same inn with us!Anne, must not it be our Mr. Elliot? my father’s next heir?Pray sir,” turning to the waiter, “did not you hear, did not his servant say whether he belonged to the Kellynch family?”

zh: “没有，太太，他没有提起过具体的家族名称。但是他说过他的主人是个非常有钱的绅士，有朝一日会成为准男爵。”
en: “No, ma’am, he did not mention no particular family; but he said his master was a very rich gentleman, and would be a baronight some day.”

zh: “啊！你们瞧！”玛丽兴奋地嚷道，“就像我说的！沃尔特•埃利奥特爵士的继承人！我就知道，若是真的如此，总会有人知道的。相信我好了，不管他走到哪儿去，他的仆人们都要有意宣扬这一点。不过，安妮，你想想，这事多不同寻常！我真希望我刚才能多看他几眼。我们要是早些知道他是谁就好了，那样我们就可以结识他了。真可惜，我们竟然没有彼此介绍一下！你觉得他的面貌像埃利奥特家的人吗？我几乎没怎么看她，只顾看他的两匹马了。不过我觉得他的面貌有几分像埃利奥特家的人，真奇怪，他的徽章竟然没有引起我的注意！哦！他的那件厚大衣正好搭在车板上，遮住了徽章，就是这么回事。否则我肯定会看到的，还有那制服。那个仆人要是不穿丧服，别人一看他的制服就能看出来。”
en: “There! you see!” cried Mary in an ecstasy, “just as I said!Heir to Sir Walter Elliot!I was sure that would come out, if it was so.Depend upon it, that is a circumstance which his servants take care to publish, wherever he goes.But, Anne, only conceive how extraordinary!I wish I had looked at him more.I wish we had been aware in time, who it was, that he might have been introduced to us.What a pity that we should not have been introduced to each other!Do you think he had the Elliot countenance?I hardly looked at him, I was looking at the horses; but I think he had something of the Elliot countenance, I wonder the arms did not strike me!Oh! the great-coat was hanging over the panel, and hid the arms, so it did; otherwise, I am sure, I should have observed them, and the livery too; if the servant had not been in mourning, one should have known him by the livery.”

zh: “从这些凑巧的事情来看，”温特沃思上校说道，“我们必须把你们没有同堂兄结识这件事看作是上帝的安排。”
en: “Putting all these very extraordinary circumstances together,” said Captain Wentworth, “we must consider it to be the arrangement of Providence, that you should not be introduced to your cousin.”

zh: 等到玛丽愿意倾听别人的话时，安妮才平静地劝她，要她相信，根据多年来她们父亲同埃利奥特先生的关系，想同他结识是不合时宜的。
en: When she could command Mary’s attention, Anne quietly tried to convince her that their father and Mr. Elliot had not, for many years, been on such terms as to make the power of attempting an introduction at all desirable.

zh: 不过，这时安妮心中倒窃喜能遇见她的堂兄，知道凯林奇未来的主人无疑是位绅士，而且显得很讲情理。她无论如何不会提起自己与他的第二次相遇。幸亏玛丽对他们清晨散步时同他擦身而过的一幕没有怎么在意，但是如果知道安妮在走廊里几乎同他撞了个满怀，并且收到了他非常有礼貌的道歉，而玛丽自己却从未接近过他，玛丽会感到受到了很大的委屈。不，对堂兄妹之间那次短暂的会面一定要绝对保密。
en: At the same time, however, it was a secret gratification to herself to have seen her cousin, and to know that the future owner of Kellynch was undoubtedly a gentleman, and had an air of good sense.She would not, upon any account, mention her having met with him the second time; luckily Mary did not much attend to their having passed close by him in their earlier walk, but she would have felt quite ill-used by Anne’s having actually run against him in the passage, and received his very polite excuses, while she had never been near him at all; no, that cousinly little interview must remain a perfect secret.

zh: “当然，”玛丽说，“下次你往巴斯写信的时候一定要提一下我们遇见了埃利奥特先生。我觉得父亲当然应该知道这件事情，一定要把有关他的一切都告诉他。”
en: “Of course,” said Mary, “you will mention our seeing Mr. Elliot, the next time you write to Bath.I think my father certainly ought to hear of it; do mention all about him.”

zh: 安妮没有直接回答，不过她认为这个情况不仅没有必要提起，而且应该避而不谈。她知道，许多年以前，他曾经得罪过父亲。她猜想，他尤其得罪了伊丽莎白。因此，毫无疑问，一提起埃利奥特先生，他们两个人一定会很生气。玛丽自己从来都不往巴斯写信，因而同伊丽莎白之间进行拖拖拉拉、不怎么令人满意的通信就落在了安妮的身上。
en: Anne avoided a direct reply, but it was just the circumstance which she considered as not merely unnecessary to be communicated, but as what ought to be suppressed.The offence which had been given her father, many years back, she knew; Elizabeth’s particular share in it she suspected; and that Mr. Elliot’s idea always produced irritation in both was beyond a doubt.Mary never wrote to Bath herself; all the toil of keeping up a slow and unsatisfactory correspondence with Elizabeth fell on Anne.

zh: 早饭吃过不久，哈维尔上校和本威克舰长就来看他们了。他们约定要最后逛一下莱姆。他们应该在一点钟离开这里去阿珀克罗斯，这一段时间应尽量一起在户外度过。
en: Breakfast had not been long over, when they were joined by Captain and Mrs. Harville and Captain Benwick; with whom they had appointed to take their last walk about Lyme.They ought to be setting off for Uppercross by one, and in the mean while were to be all together, and out of doors as long as they could.

zh: 安妮发现，他们一走到街上，本威克舰长就凑到了她身边。他们头天晚上的谈话并没有使他不愿再接近她。他们在一起走了一会儿，就像以前那样，谈谈司各特和拜伦伯爵，同其他任何两位读者一样，对于这两位作家的评价，他们还是同以前那样，无法取得一致的意见。后来出了点什么事，几乎使他们所有人重新组合一次，于是安妮身边走的不是本威克舰长，而是哈维尔上校了。
en: Anne found Captain Benwick getting near her, as soon as they were all fairly in the street.Their conversation the preceding evening did not disincline him to seek her again; and they walked together some time, talking as before of Mr. Scott and Lord Byron, and still as unable as before, and as unable as any other two readers, to think exactly alike of the merits of either, till something occasioned an almost general change amongst their party, and instead of Captain Benwick, she had Captain Harville by her side.

zh: “埃利奥特小姐，”哈维尔上校略略压低声音说，“你做了件好事，让那可怜的人讲了这么多话。但愿他能常有你这样的伙伴。我知道，像他这样把自己封闭起来，对他自己也没有什么好处。可是我们能做什么呢？我们分不开啊。”
en: “Miss Elliot,” said he, speaking rather low, “you have done a good deed in making that poor fellow talk so much.I wish he could have such company oftener.It is bad for him, I know, to be shut up as he is; but what can we do?We cannot part.”

zh: “不，”安妮说，“我完全相信这不可能。不过，也许有一天——我们知道时间对所有悲痛所起的作用。你应该知道，哈维尔上校，你朋友才失去亲人不久——我想是在今年夏天吧。”
en: “No,” said Anne, “that I can easily believe to be impossible; but in time, perhaps—we know what time does in every case of affliction, and you must remember, Captain Harville, that your friend may yet be called a young mourner—only last summer, I understand.”

zh: “唉，确实如此，”（伴着一声长叹）“就在六月。”
en: “Ay, true enough,” (with a deep sigh) “only June.”

zh: “他当时也许没有马上得知这一消息。”
en: “And not known to him, perhaps, so soon.”

zh: “他直到八月份的第一个星期才知道，当时他正从好望角回来，刚刚调到‘格斗者号’。当时我在普利茅斯，很害怕听到他的消息。他写了好几封信来，可是“格斗者号”奉命开往朴茨茅斯。应该在那里把消息告诉他，可是由谁去说呢？我可不会去。我宁愿让别人把我赶到帆桁顶端上去。谁也干不了，除了那位好人以外。”（指了指温特沃思上校。）“而‘拉科尼亚号’在一个星期以前就已经到达普利茅斯，不会再奉命出海了。温特沃思上校顾不上其他事情，向他的上司打了个请假报告，没等接到答复便日夜兼程赶到朴茨茅斯去了。一到那里就马上划船到‘格斗者号’去了，整整一个星期都没有离开他那可怜的朋友。这就是他做的，别人可拯救不了可怜的詹姆斯。你可以想一想，埃利奥特小姐，他对我们是不是很亲爱！”
en: “Not till the first week of August, when he came home from the Cape, just made into the Grappler.I was at Plymouth dreading to hear of him; he sent in letters, but the Grappler was under orders for Portsmouth.There the news must follow him, but who was to tell it?not I. I would as soon have been run up to the yard-arm.Nobody could do it, but that good fellow” (pointing to Captain Wentworth.)“The Laconia had come into Plymouth the week before; no danger of her being sent to sea again.He stood his chance for the rest; wrote up for leave of absence, but without waiting the return, travelled night and day till he got to Portsmouth, rowed off to the Grappler that instant, and never left the poor fellow for a week.That’s what he did, and nobody else could have saved poor James.You may think, Miss Elliot, whether he is dear to us!”

zh: 安妮对此事确实认真思考了一下，根据自己的真实感情和哈维尔上校能够接受的程度给出了充分的回答，因为哈维尔上校实在是太动情了，无法重提这个话题。等他再次开口时，说的就完全是另外一件事了。
en: Anne did think on the question with perfect decision, and said as much in reply as her own feeling could accomplish, or as his seemed able to bear, for he was too much affected to renew the subject, and when he spoke again, it was of something totally different.

zh: 哈维尔太太提了个意见，觉得回家的路已经够她丈夫步行的了，所以为他们的最后一次散步确定了一条路线。大家陪他们走到门口，然后返回来，准备出发。根据他们的计算，恐怕只剩下这么一点时间了，但当他们走近科布的时候，大家都希望再去那里走一遭，所有人都有这种愿望，路易莎更是十分坚决，大家都认为只不过相差一刻钟，没有多大关系。于是在一片惜别、邀请和承诺声中，他们让哈维尔夫妇和本威克上校在门口留步，本威克舰长还陪着他们，似乎要陪他们到最后一刻。他们继续往前走，正式向科布告别。
en: Mrs. Harville’s giving it as her opinion that her husband would have quite walking enough by the time he reached home, determined the direction of all the party in what was to be their last walk; they would accompany them to their door, and then return and set off themselves.By all their calculations there was just time for this; but as they drew near the Cobb, there was such a general wish to walk along it once more, all were so inclined, and Louisa soon grew so determined, that the difference of a quarter of an hour, it was found, would be no difference at all; so with all the kind leave-taking, and all the kind interchange of invitations and promises which may be imagined, they parted from Captain and Mrs. Harville at their own door, and still accompanied by Captain Benwick, who seemed to cling to them to the last, proceeded to make the proper adieus to the Cobb.

zh: 安妮发现本威克上校又一次走到她身旁。眼前的景色自然使他们提到了拜伦伯爵的“深蓝色的海洋”。安妮十分高兴地尽量把她的注意力全部集中在他身上。可是不一会儿，她便不由自主地给吸引到别处去了。
en: Anne found Captain Benwick again drawing near her.Lord Byron’s “dark blue seas” could not fail of being brought forward by their present view, and she gladly gave him all her attention as long as attention was possible.It was soon drawn, perforce another way.

zh: 因为风大，女士们呆在新科布的高处觉得不舒服，所以大家都同意沿着石阶往下走。她们都安静而小心地沿着陡峭的石阶往下走，只有路易莎例外。她要温特沃思上校扶着她从石阶上跳下去。在他们以前多次散步中，她总让温特沃思上校扶着她从栅栏边的梯级上跳下去。她觉得这样的感觉很惬意。眼下，上校觉得这里的地面太硬，对路易莎的双脚不利，所以不太愿意这么做。但是，他还是扶着她跳了。她安然无恙地跳下来，为了显示她爱这么做，她马上又跑上去，想再跳一次。温特沃思上校劝她不要这么做，觉得震动太大了。但是不行，他再怎么讲理和劝说都无济于事，她笑吟吟地说：“我下定了决心，一定要跳。”他伸出了双手，不过路易莎早起跳了半秒钟，摔倒在科布低处的路面上，等人们扶起她时，她已经失去了知觉。她身上没有伤口，没有流血，也没有看到擦伤的地方，但是她双眼紧闭，没有呼吸，脸色像死人一样。当时站在旁边的人都给吓坏了！
en: There was too much wind to make the high part of the new Cobb pleasant for the ladies, and they agreed to get down the steps to the lower, and all were contented to pass quietly and carefully down the steep flight, excepting Louisa; she must be jumped down them by Captain Wentworth.In all their walks, he had had to jump her from the stiles; the sensation was delightful to her.The hardness of the pavement for her feet, made him less willing upon the present occasion; he did it, however.She was safely down, and instantly, to show her enjoyment, ran up the steps to be jumped down again.He advised her against it, thought the jar too great; but no, he reasoned and talked in vain, she smiled and said, “I am determined I will:” he put out his hands; she was too precipitate by half a second, she fell on the pavement on the Lower Cobb, and was taken up lifeless!There was no wound, no blood, no visible bruise; but her eyes were closed, she breathed not, her face was like death.The horror of the moment to all who stood around!

zh: 温特沃思上校把她扶起来，抱着她跪在那里，他望着路易莎，默默地忍受着痛苦，脸色同她一样苍白。“她死了！她死了！”玛丽抓住了丈夫，尖声叫道，这就加剧了查尔斯本人的恐惧，使他动弹不得。不一会儿，亨里埃塔相信了玛丽的话，晕了过去，要不是本威克舰长和安妮一边一个扶住她，她会摔倒在石阶上。
en: Captain Wentworth, who had caught her up, knelt with her in his arms, looking on her with a face as pallid as her own, in an agony of silence.“She is dead!she is dead!” screamed Mary, catching hold of her husband, and contributing with his own horror to make him immoveable; and in another moment, Henrietta, sinking under the conviction, lost her senses too, and would have fallen on the steps, but for Captain Benwick and Anne, who caught and supported her between them.

zh: “难道就没有人来帮帮我吗？”这是温特沃思带着绝望的口气说出的第一句话，看来他自己一点力气也没有了。
en: “Is there no one to help me?” were the first words which burst from Captain Wentworth, in a tone of despair, and as if all his own strength were gone.

zh: “快过去，快过去，”安妮喊道，“看在上帝的份上快过去吧。我一个人可以扶住亨里埃塔。别管我，你去帮忙。揉揉她的手，揉揉她的太阳穴。这里有盐，拿着，拿着。”
en: “Go to him, go to him,” cried Anne, “for heaven’s sake go to him.I can support her myself.Leave me, and go to him.Rub her hands, rub her temples; here are salts; take them, take them.”

zh: 本威克舰长听从她的指挥，查尔斯这时也离开了妻子一起来到温特沃思上校前。他俩把路易莎扶起来，牢牢地架住，温特沃思上校将安妮提的几点都做了一遍，可是毫无用处。这时温特沃思上校跌跌撞撞地扶住墙壁，悲痛欲绝地喊道：
en: Captain Benwick obeyed, and Charles at the same moment, disengaging himself from his wife, they were both with him; and Louisa was raised up and supported more firmly between them, and everything was done that Anne had prompted, but in vain; while Captain Wentworth, staggering against the wall for his support, exclaimed in the bitterest agony—

zh: “啊！天哪！他父母那儿怎么办！”
en: “Oh God! her father and mother!”

zh: “去找外科医生！”安妮说道。
en: “A surgeon!” said Anne.

zh: 温特沃思一听这话，似乎猛地惊醒过来，只说了句：“对，对，马上去找外科医生。”然后拔腿便跑，这时安妮急忙提出：
en: He caught the word; it seemed to rouse him at once, and saying only—“True, true, a surgeon this instant,” was darting away, when Anne eagerly suggested—

zh: “本威克舰长，让本威克舰长去岂不是更好？他知道哪儿能够找到一位外科医生。”
en: “Captain Benwick, would not it be better for Captain Benwick?He knows where a surgeon is to be found.”

zh: 每一个清醒的人都觉得这个主意好，顷刻间，（这一切都是在顷刻间完成的）本威克舰长将那可怜的姑娘交给他哥哥照料，自己飞快地朝镇上跑去。
en: Every one capable of thinking felt the advantage of the idea, and in a moment (it was all done in rapid moments) Captain Benwick had resigned the poor corpse-like figure entirely to the brother’s care, and was off for the town with the utmost rapidity.

zh: 至于说到留在原地的三个神智完全清醒的人：温特沃思上校、安妮、还是查尔斯，很难说谁最痛苦。查尔斯的确是个亲如手足的哥哥，他低头看着路易莎，悲痛地抽泣着。他只能将眼睛从这个妹妹的身上转过去看另一位不省人事的妹妹，或者看看歇斯底里发作的妻子，妻子喊他去照顾她，他却不能过去。
en: As to the wretched party left behind, it could scarcely be said which of the three, who were completely rational, was suffering most: Captain Wentworth, Anne, or Charles, who, really a very affectionate brother, hung over Louisa with sobs of grief, and could only turn his eyes from one sister, to see the other in a state as insensible, or to witness the hysterical agitations of his wife, calling on him for help which he could not give.

zh: 安妮一面凭着直觉尽力热忱地照顾着亨里埃塔，一面还要不时地设法安慰别人，劝玛丽安静下来，鼓励查尔斯，宽慰温特沃思上校。这两个人似乎都在等待她的指令。
en: Anne, attending with all the strength and zeal, and thought, which instinct supplied, to Henrietta, still tried, at intervals, to suggest comfort to the others, tried to quiet Mary, to animate Charles, to assuage the feelings of Captain Wentworth.Both seemed to look to her for directions.

zh: “安妮，安妮，”查尔斯喊道，“下一步怎么办？天哪，下一步怎么办？”
en: “Anne, Anne,” cried Charles, “What is to be done next?What, in heaven’s name, is to be done next?”

zh: 温特沃思上校也将目光投向了她。
en: Captain Wentworth’s eyes were also turned towards her.

zh: “是不是把她抱到旅馆去要好一点？是的，我想是的，轻轻地把她抱到旅馆里去吧。”
en: “Had not she better be carried to the inn?Yes, I am sure: carry her gently to the inn.”

zh: “对，对，抱到旅馆里去，”温特沃思上校重复着，他相对镇定了一些，急切地想做点什么。“我来抱她。马斯格罗夫，你来照顾其他人。”
en: “Yes, yes, to the inn,” repeated Captain Wentworth, comparatively collected, and eager to be doing something.“I will carry her myself.Musgrove, take care of the others.”

zh: 这时，出事的消息传遍了科布附近的工人和船员，许多人聚在他们身旁，想在需要时帮点忙。不管怎么样，可以看一看一位死去的年轻姑娘，不，是两位死去的年轻姑娘，因为事实证明这比起初的消息更为吸引人。他们把亨里埃塔托付给好心人中看上去比较体面的人，她虽然已经苏醒过来，但还非常虚弱。于是，安妮走在亨里埃塔旁边，查尔斯照顾着妻子，一行人就这样出发了。刚才就在几分钟前，大家还十分高兴地走过这片土地，但现在往回走时，一个个却忧心如焚。
en: By this time the report of the accident had spread among the workmen and boatmen about the Cobb, and many were collected near them, to be useful if wanted, at any rate, to enjoy the sight of a dead young lady, nay, two dead young ladies, for it proved twice as fine as the first report.To some of the best-looking of these good people Henrietta was consigned, for, though partially revived, she was quite helpless; and in this manner, Anne walking by her side, and Charles attending to his wife, they set forward, treading back with feelings unutterable, the ground, which so lately, so very lately, and so light of heart, they had passed along.

zh: 他们还没有离开科布，哈维尔夫妇便赶来了。原来，他们看见本威克舰长从屋旁飞奔而过，一看那慌张的神色，就知道出了事。于是马上出门，一路上听人连说带比划就找来了。哈维尔上校虽说十分震惊，但他的见识和胆量马上就起了作用。他和妻子交换了一下眼色，当即决定了应该怎么办。必须把路易莎带到他们家，所有人也必须到他们家去，在那里等待外科医生的到来。他们夫妇俩根本不考虑别人的顾虑。大家就听从了哈维尔上校，都来到了他家里。在哈维尔太太的指挥下，路易莎被抱上楼，放在她自己的床上，她丈夫也在跟着帮忙，又是镇静剂，又是苏醒剂，谁需要就给谁。
en: They were not off the Cobb, before the Harvilles met them.Captain Benwick had been seen flying by their house, with a countenance which showed something to be wrong; and they had set off immediately, informed and directed as they passed, towards the spot.Shocked as Captain Harville was, he brought senses and nerves that could be instantly useful; and a look between him and his wife decided what was to be done.She must be taken to their house; all must go to their house; and await the surgeon’s arrival there.They would not listen to scruples: he was obeyed; they were all beneath his roof; and while Louisa, under Mrs. Harville’s direction, was conveyed up stairs, and given possession of her own bed, assistance, cordials, restoratives were supplied by her husband to all who needed them.

zh: 路易莎的眼睛睁开了一次，但是没有明显的知觉，就又闭上了。不过，这倒证明她还活着，这一点对亨里埃塔是个鼓舞。尽管亨里埃塔和她姐姐还不能呆在同一间屋子里，但她有了希望，还有几分恐惧，激动之下没有再昏厥过去。玛丽也逐渐镇定了下来。
en: Louisa had once opened her eyes, but soon closed them again, without apparent consciousness.This had been a proof of life, however, of service to her sister; and Henrietta, though perfectly incapable of being in the same room with Louisa, was kept, by the agitation of hope and fear, from a return of her own insensibility.Mary, too, was growing calmer.

zh: 外科医生很快就来了，真出人意料。他检查的时候，大家都吓得心惊胆跳，但医生没有绝望。病人的头部受到了剧烈的震动，但是比这更重的病他都治好过。他一点也不绝望，说话的口气还很乐观。
en: The surgeon was with them almost before it had seemed possible.They were sick with horror, while he examined; but he was not hopeless.The head had received a severe contusion, but he had seen greater injuries recovered from: he was by no means hopeless; he spoke cheerfully.

zh: 医生并没有认为这是一个绝望的病例，他没有说路易莎会在几个小时之后死亡，这都出乎大多数人的意料。人们先是对上帝表达了多么热诚的感激，接着便深沉不语地欣喜起来，这高兴劲头可想而知。
en: That he did not regard it as a desperate case, that he did not say a few hours must end it, was at first felt, beyond the hope of most; and the ecstasy of such a reprieve, the rejoicing, deep and silent, after a few fervent ejaculations of gratitude to Heaven had been offered, may be conceived.

zh: 安妮觉得她永远也不会忘记温特沃思上校喊“谢天谢地”时的声调和神色，也忘不了后来他倚在桌旁，脸埋在交抱的双臂时的形象。看样子，他已经被心中的忧伤所击倒，因而力图通过祈祷和冥思来稳定情绪。
en: The tone, the look, with which “Thank God!” was uttered by Captain Wentworth, Anne was sure could never be forgotten by her; nor the sight of him afterwards, as he sat near a table, leaning over it with folded arms and face concealed, as if overpowered by the various feelings of his soul, and trying by prayer and reflection to calm them.

zh: 路易莎的四肢没有受伤。除了头部，其他部位都没有受伤。
en: Louisa’s limbs had escaped.There was no injury but to the head.

zh: 当下大家有必要考虑如何处理整个局面才好。现在他们能够交换意见和商量问题了。路易莎必须留在这里，这一点毫无疑问，尽管她的朋友们对于给哈维尔夫妇增添这么多麻烦，心中很是不安。路易莎是不能移动的。哈维尔夫妇打消了大家的顾虑，尽可能婉言拒绝了大伙的感激之情。他们没等别人开始想到，就着手安排好了一切。本威克舰长把房间让给他们，到别的地方铺一张床。所有的问题就解决了。他们担心的倒是这屋子里住不下更多的人。不过也许可以“让孩子们住到女仆的房间里，或者在别的地方挂一只吊床，”可还有两三个愿意留下的人无处安顿，这使主人十分焦急。至于对马斯格罗夫小姐的照顾，大家尽可以放心地把这事托付给哈维尔太太。哈维尔太太过去是一位经验很丰富的护士，而同她一起住了很久，随时伺候在她身旁的那个带孩子的保姆，也是一名好护士。有了她们两个，她就不需要被别人日夜看护了。这番话说得真挚而诚恳，使人感到盛情难却。
en: It now became necessary for the party to consider what was best to be done, as to their general situation.They were now able to speak to each other and consult.That Louisa must remain where she was, however distressing to her friends to be involving the Harvilles in such trouble, did not admit a doubt.Her removal was impossible.The Harvilles silenced all scruples; and, as much as they could, all gratitude.They had looked forward and arranged everything before the others began to reflect.Captain Benwick must give up his room to them, and get another bed elsewhere; and the whole was settled.They were only concerned that the house could accommodate no more; and yet perhaps, by “putting the children away in the maid’s room, or swinging a cot somewhere,” they could hardly bear to think of not finding room for two or three besides, supposing they might wish to stay; though, with regard to any attendance on Miss Musgrove, there need not be the least uneasiness in leaving her to Mrs. Harville’s care entirely.Mrs. Harville was a very experienced nurse, and her nursery-maid, who had lived with her long, and gone about with her everywhere, was just such another.Between these two, she could want no possible attendance by day or night.And all this was said with a truth and sincerity of feeling irresistible.

zh: 参与商量的三个人是查尔斯、亨里埃塔和温特沃思上校。说是商量，但有一阵子只是你表示一筹莫展，他表示害怕而已。“阿珀克罗斯，一定要派人到阿珀克罗斯去通报一下。但是怎样才能对默斯格罗夫先生和太太说清楚呢，上午的时间已经过去不少了，他们本该一小时之前就出发的。现在已不可能及时赶到那里。”起初，他们只是你一言我一语的，想不出好主意。但是，过了一小会儿，温特沃思上校强打精神说：
en: Charles, Henrietta, and Captain Wentworth were the three in consultation, and for a little while it was only an interchange of perplexity and terror.“Uppercross, the necessity of some one’s going to Uppercross; the news to be conveyed; how it could be broken to Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove; the lateness of the morning; an hour already gone since they ought to have been off; the impossibility of being in tolerable time.” At first, they were capable of nothing more to the purpose than such exclamations; but, after a while, Captain Wentworth, exerting himself, said—

zh: “我们必须果断一点，一分钟也不能耽误了。每一分钟都十分宝贵。必须马上派人到阿珀克罗斯去。马斯格罗夫，不是你去就是我去。”
en: “We must be decided, and without the loss of another minute.Every minute is valuable.Some one must resolve on being off for Uppercross instantly.Musgrove, either you or I must go.”

zh: 查尔斯同意这一意见，但表示他绝不离开这里。他不愿给哈维尔夫妇增添麻烦，但看到他妹妹目前的处境，他不应该，也不愿意离开她。到目前为止，事情就这么定下来了。亨里埃塔最初也是这么说的。不过，她很快就被说服，改变了主意。她留下有什么用！何况让她留在路易莎的房间里，让她看到路易莎，都只会使她比无助更糟糕！她不得不承认自己帮不上忙，可依然不愿意离开，后来她想起了自己的父母亲，感到一阵难过，这才放弃了留下的念头，急着想回家了。
en: Charles agreed, but declared his resolution of not going away.He would be as little incumbrance as possible to Captain and Mrs. Harville; but as to leaving his sister in such a state, he neither ought, nor would.So far it was decided; and Henrietta at first declared the same.She, however, was soon persuaded to think differently.The usefulness of her staying!She who had not been able to remain in Louisa’s room, or to look at her, without sufferings which made her worse than helpless!She was forced to acknowledge that she could do no good, yet was still unwilling to be away, till, touched by the thought of her father and mother, she gave it up; she consented, she was anxious to be at home.

zh: 他们正谈到这一步，这时安妮从路易莎房中轻轻地走下来，不免听到这番谈话，因为客厅门开着。
en: The plan had reached this point, when Anne, coming quietly down from Louisa’s room, could not but hear what followed, for the parlour door was open.

zh: “那么就这样定了，马斯格罗夫，”温特沃思上校高声说道，“你留下，我送你妹妹回家。至于其他人，如果需要有人留下帮助哈维尔太太，我想一个人就足够了。查尔斯•马斯格罗夫太太当然想回去照看孩子。但是如果安妮愿意留下来，那没有人比她更合适，更能干了。”
en: “Then it is settled, Musgrove,” cried Captain Wentworth, “that you stay, and that I take care of your sister home.But as to the rest, as to the others, if one stays to assist Mrs. Harville, I think it need be only one.Mrs. Charles Musgrove will, of course, wish to get back to her children; but if Anne will stay, no one so proper, so capable as Anne.”

zh: 安妮听到对自己的这番评价，心情十分激动。她停下脚步，想镇定一下。其他两个人齐声赞同温特沃思上校的意见，这时安妮才走上前去。
en: She paused a moment to recover from the emotion of hearing herself so spoken of.The other two warmly agreed with what he said, and she then appeared.

zh: “你一定愿意留下的，我可以肯定。你愿意留下看护她的，”温特沃思上校转身朝她大声说的时候虽很激动，但是态度很温和，仿佛恢复了旧日的友情。安妮满脸通红。温特沃思上校控制住自己的感情，走了开去。安妮表示她自己非常愿意留下，而且早就准备留下，很高兴留下。“她就是这么想的，希望大家能让她留下。她在路易莎房间的地板上搭个地铺就可以了，只要哈维尔太太愿意就行。”
en: “You will stay, I am sure; you will stay and nurse her;” cried he, turning to her and speaking with a glow, and yet a gentleness, which seemed almost restoring the past.She coloured deeply, and he recollected himself and moved away.She expressed herself most willing, ready, happy to remain.“It was what she had been thinking of, and wishing to be allowed to do.A bed on the floor in Louisa’s room would be sufficient for her, if Mrs. Harville would but think so.”

zh: 再办一件事情，一切似乎都安排就绪了。虽然稍稍迟一些回去比较理想，因为这样一来，马斯格罗夫先生和太太就会预感到情况不妙。但是他们乘坐阿珀克罗斯的马车回去，需要的时间会大大延长二老的焦虑。因此，温特沃思上校提出，他最好是从旅馆借一辆轻便马车，把马斯格罗夫先生的车马留下，明天一早再派人送回家。这样做的另一个好处是可以把当天晚上路易莎的情况捎回去。查尔斯•马斯格罗夫同意这一办法。
en: One thing more, and all seemed arranged.Though it was rather desirable that Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove should be previously alarmed by some share of delay; yet the time required by the Uppercross horses to take them back, would be a dreadful extension of suspense; and Captain Wentworth proposed, and Charles Musgrove agreed, that it would be much better for him to take a chaise from the inn, and leave Mr. Musgrove’s carriage and horses to be sent home the next morning early, when there would be the farther advantage of sending an account of Louisa’s night.

zh: 这时，温温特沃思上校忙着出去做自己的准备工作，过一会儿再同两位女士汇合。可是当人们把这一计划告诉玛丽时，她一听就吵个不停。她很沮丧，言辞激烈，大声抱怨说，让她回去而把安妮留下是不公平的。安妮跟路易莎什么关系都不是，而她是路易莎的嫂嫂，最有权利代替亨里埃塔留下！她为什么不能像安妮一样有用呢？再说，她回家时还得撇下她的丈夫查尔斯！不，这太不尽人情了。总之，她说了一通，她的丈夫简直招架不住。既然她丈夫无能为力，其他人更不便反对了。结果，不得不让安妮替换玛丽。
en: Captain Wentworth now hurried off to get everything ready on his part, and to be soon followed by the two ladies.When the plan was made known to Mary, however, there was an end of all peace in it.She was so wretched and so vehement, complained so much of injustice in being expected to go away instead of Anne; Anne, who was nothing to Louisa, while she was her sister, and had the best right to stay in Henrietta’s stead!Why was not she to be as useful as Anne?And to go home without Charles, too, without her husband!No, it was too unkind.And in short, she said more than her husband could long withstand, and as none of the others could oppose when he gave way, there was no help for it; the change of Mary for Anne was inevitable.

zh: 对于玛丽这一愚蠢而嫉妒的要求，安妮虽然顺从了，但是从来没有这么勉强，可是现在只能这么做了。于是他们一行就朝镇上走去，查尔斯照顾着他妹妹，本威克舰长照看着安妮。他们匆匆往前走的时候，安妮突然想起了今天早晨早些时候发生在同一地点的一些琐事。在这里她曾听到亨里埃塔要雪莉博士离开阿珀克罗斯的打算。后来，她第一次见到了埃利奥特，但是这些事情只是在安妮心中闪过了一下，因为眼下占据着她整个心灵的是路易莎和关心路易莎命运的人。
en: Anne had never submitted more reluctantly to the jealous and ill-judging claims of Mary; but so it must be, and they set off for the town, Charles taking care of his sister, and Captain Benwick attending to her.She gave a moment’s recollection, as they hurried along, to the little circumstances which the same spots had witnessed earlier in the morning.There she had listened to Henrietta’s schemes for Dr Shirley’s leaving Uppercross; farther on, she had first seen Mr. Elliot; a moment seemed all that could now be given to any one but Louisa, or those who were wrapt up in her welfare.

zh: 本威克舰长对安妮非常体贴。这一天的灾难似乎把大家都联系在一起了。安妮觉得对他的好感在不断增加，她甚至还高兴地想到这也许是继续发展彼此间友谊的机会。
en: Captain Benwick was most considerately attentive to her; and, united as they all seemed by the distress of the day, she felt an increasing degree of good-will towards him, and a pleasure even in thinking that it might, perhaps, be the occasion of continuing their acquaintance.

zh: 温特沃思上校正在等候她们，一辆轻便马车已经备好，停在街道的最低处，好让大家上车方便些。但是当他看到走过来的是姐姐而不是妹妹，显然感到非常惊讶和恼火。他一听查尔斯的解释，脸色顿时变了，目瞪口呆，想说什么又强压了下去，只是使对方不快地同安妮打了声招呼。或者至少使她觉得，自己被重视只是因为她对路易莎有用处。
en: Captain Wentworth was on the watch for them, and a chaise and four in waiting, stationed for their convenience in the lowest part of the street; but his evident surprise and vexation at the substitution of one sister for the other, the change in his countenance, the astonishment, the expressions begun and suppressed, with which Charles was listened to, made but a mortifying reception of Anne; or must at least convince her that she was valued only as she could be useful to Louisa.

zh: 她尽力使自己心平气和，尽力公正地看待这一切。即使不去模仿埃玛对亨利的感情，但看在温特沃思上校的面子上，她也会以超乎寻常的热忱照看路易莎的。她希望温特沃思上校不要老是这么不公正地看待她，以为她会毫无必要地逃避一个朋友应尽的责任。
en: She endeavoured to be composed, and to be just.Without emulating the feelings of an Emma towards her Henry, she would have attended on Louisa with a zeal above the common claims of regard, for his sake; and she hoped he would not long be so unjust as to suppose she would shrink unnecessarily from the office of a friend.

zh: 此时此刻，她已经上了马车。温特沃思上校把她们扶上车后，就坐在她们中间。于是就在这种情况下，安妮以满怀惊讶的心情离开了莱姆。她无法计算在路上要花多长时间，也无法估计这段路程会对他们的行程产生什么影响，更无法预计他们会在路上谈些什么。不过，一切都非常自然。他一心想着亨里埃塔，总是把脸转向她。他只要一说话，也总想着给亨里埃塔信心，给她鼓劲。总的来说，他的言谈举止都尽量平静。不让亨里埃塔忧虑似乎是他的主要原则。只有一次，当她为最后一次那失算的、倒霉的去科布散步感到伤心，后悔不该想这么个馊主意时，他好像再也忍受不住了，发作起来：
en: In the mean while she was in the carriage.He had handed them both in, and placed himself between them; and in this manner, under these circumstances, full of astonishment and emotion to Anne, she quitted Lyme.How the long stage would pass; how it was to affect their manners; what was to be their sort of intercourse, she could not foresee.It was all quite natural, however.He was devoted to Henrietta; always turning towards her; and when he spoke at all, always with the view of supporting her hopes and raising her spirits.In general, his voice and manner were studiously calm.To spare Henrietta from agitation seemed the governing principle.Once only, when she had been grieving over the last ill-judged, ill-fated walk to the Cobb, bitterly lamenting that it ever had been thought of, he burst forth, as if wholly overcome—

zh: “不要再说那个了，不要再说了，”他大声嚷道，“上帝呀！但愿在那关键时刻我没有屈从她就好了！要是照我该做的去做就好了！但是她是那样地急切，那样的坚决！啊，可爱的路易莎！”
en: “Don’t talk of it, don’t talk of it,” he cried.“Oh God! that I had not given way to her at the fatal moment!Had I done as I ought!But so eager and so resolute!Dear, sweet Louisa!”

zh: 安妮心想，不知道他眼下有没有怀疑他先前关于性格坚定的人总会走运、总会得到好处的看法。不知道他有没有认识到，就像人的其他气质一样，坚定的性格也有个分寸与极限。她认为他不可能不感觉到，有时听从劝导的好脾气也会像坚定的性格一样，也有利于得到幸福。
en: Anne wondered whether it ever occurred to him now, to question the justness of his own previous opinion as to the universal felicity and advantage of firmness of character; and whether it might not strike him that, like all other qualities of the mind, it should have its proportions and limits.She thought it could scarcely escape him to feel that a persuadable temper might sometimes be as much in favour of happiness as a very resolute character.

zh: 马车跑得很快。安妮惊讶这么快就看到了熟悉的山和熟悉的景物。马车的确跑得很快，加之他们对事情的结局怀着忐忑的心情，使得回去的路程看起来似乎比前天短了一半。不过，还没等他们来到阿珀克罗斯附近，天色已经很晚了，他们三个人沉默了好一会儿，亨里埃塔倚在车厢角落里，用一条披肩盖住自己的脸，希望哭一场后可以入睡。当马车驶上最后一个山岗时，安妮突然听见温特沃思上校在跟她说话。他用一种低沉，小心翼翼的声音说道：
en: They got on fast.Anne was astonished to recognise the same hills and the same objects so soon.Their actual speed, heightened by some dread of the conclusion, made the road appear but half as long as on the day before.It was growing quite dusk, however, before they were in the neighbourhood of Uppercross, and there had been total silence among them for some time, Henrietta leaning back in the corner, with a shawl over her face, giving the hope of her having cried herself to sleep; when, as they were going up their last hill, Anne found herself all at once addressed by Captain Wentworth.In a low, cautious voice, he said:—

zh: “我一直在考虑我们怎么做最好。一开始她不能进屋去。她会受不了的。我一直在想你是不是最好先跟她在车上呆一会儿，我先进去跟马斯格罗夫先生太太说清楚。你觉得这个办法好吗？”
en: “I have been considering what we had best do.She must not appear at first.She could not stand it.I have been thinking whether you had not better remain in the carriage with her, while I go in and break it to Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove.Do you think this is a good plan?”

zh: 安妮认为可以，温特沃思上校觉得满意，他们就没再说什么。但是一想到他征求她的意见，安妮就感到很愉快，这是友谊的证明，也是对她判断力的尊重，这对她来说是一件非常高兴的事。即使这番话意味着他们将要分手，但也没有减弱它的价值。
en: She did: he was satisfied, and said no more.But the remembrance of the appeal remained a pleasure to her, as a proof of friendship, and of deference for her judgement, a great pleasure; and when it became a sort of parting proof, its value did not lessen.

zh: 到阿珀克罗斯传达消息这一令人苦恼的差事完成了，温特沃思上校见到的路易莎的父母正像人们所希望的，他们表现得相当镇静，亨里埃塔同父母在一起，情绪上也安定了一些。温特沃思上校说他要乘坐同一辆马车返回莱姆。等马喂好，他就出发了。
en: When the distressing communication at Uppercross was over, and he had seen the father and mother quite as composed as could be hoped, and the daughter all the better for being with them, he announced his intention of returning in the same carriage to Lyme; and when the horses were baited, he was off.

zh: （第一卷完）
en: (End of volume one.)

zh: 第十三章
en: CHAPTER 13

zh: 安妮在阿珀克罗斯的时间只有两天了，她完全是在老宅里度过的。她满意地发现，她在这个家族里能起到极大的作用，既是一个近在眼前的伴侣，又是一个安排今后各项家务的能手，因为马斯格罗夫先生与太太正处于痛苦之中，要安排这些事情就难了。
en: The remainder of Anne’s time at Uppercross, comprehending only two days, was spent entirely at the Mansion House; and she had the satisfaction of knowing herself extremely useful there, both as an immediate companion, and as assisting in all those arrangements for the future, which, in Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove’s distressed state of spirits, would have been difficulties.

zh: 第二天清早，他们就得到了从莱姆传来的消息。路易莎病情依旧。没有恶化的症状。几个小时以后，查尔斯带来了较为详尽的最新消息。他倒挺乐观的。虽然不能希望马上把病治好，但是从种种迹象来看，情况还是这种病例中最好的。说到哈维尔夫妇，他对他们的关照似乎有说不尽的感激，特别是对哈维尔太太尽心尽力的护理。“她什么事也不留给玛丽干。昨天晚上她还劝我和玛丽早些回旅馆休息。今天早晨玛丽又歇斯底里地发作了。我出来时，她正要同本威克舰长出去散步，我希望这对她有好处。我前一天要是能说服玛丽回家就好了。但是事实上，哈维尔太太没有留下任何事情让别人做。”
en: They had an early account from Lyme the next morning.Louisa was much the same.No symptoms worse than before had appeared.Charles came a few hours afterwards, to bring a later and more particular account.He was tolerably cheerful.A speedy cure must not be hoped, but everything was going on as well as the nature of the case admitted.In speaking of the Harvilles, he seemed unable to satisfy his own sense of their kindness, especially of Mrs. Harville’s exertions as a nurse.“She really left nothing for Mary to do.He and Mary had been persuaded to go early to their inn last night.Mary had been hysterical again this morning.When he came away, she was going to walk out with Captain Benwick, which, he hoped, would do her good.He almost wished she had been prevailed on to come home the day before; but the truth was, that Mrs. Harville left nothing for anybody to do.”

zh: 查尔斯当天下午要回莱姆去，起初他父亲有点想同他一起去，但是几位女士不赞同。那样只会给别人增添麻烦，他自己也会更难过。接着大家想出了一个更好的方案，并且照此办理。他们从克鲁克恩要了一辆两轮轻便马车，查尔斯带回来一个很有用的人，她是这家的老保姆，家里所有的孩子都是她带大的，并眼看着最小的、玩心重的、最受宠的哈里少爷跟着哥哥去上了学。她现在住在空荡荡的婴儿室里，补补袜子，给周围的人治治脓包和伤口，因此一听说让她来照顾亲爱的路易莎小姐，她当然非常高兴。马斯格罗夫太太和亨里埃塔以前也曾隐隐感到要把萨拉送到那里去帮忙。但是，要是没有安妮，她们很难做出这样的决定并很快发现这一决定切实可行。
en: Charles was to return to Lyme the same afternoon, and his father had at first half a mind to go with him, but the ladies could not consent.It would be going only to multiply trouble to the others, and increase his own distress; and a much better scheme followed and was acted upon.A chaise was sent for from Crewkherne, and Charles conveyed back a far more useful person in the old nursery-maid of the family, one who having brought up all the children, and seen the very last, the lingering and long-petted Master Harry, sent to school after his brothers, was now living in her deserted nursery to mend stockings and dress all the blains and bruises she could get near her, and who, consequently, was only too happy in being allowed to go and help nurse dear Miss Louisa.Vague wishes of getting Sarah thither, had occurred before to Mrs. Musgrove and Henrietta; but without Anne, it would hardly have been resolved on, and found practicable so soon.

zh: 第二天，多亏了查尔斯•海特，他们了解到路易莎的详细情况，每24个小时就得到一次这样的消息，确实非常重要。他把去莱姆的事情当作己任，而且他带来的消息仍然是令人鼓舞的。他说路易莎神志清醒的时间越来越长，这一点越来越明显了。人们都说，温特沃思上校要在莱姆长住了。
en: They were indebted, the next day, to Charles Hayter, for all the minute knowledge of Louisa, which it was so essential to obtain every twenty-four hours.He made it his business to go to Lyme, and his account was still encouraging.The intervals of sense and consciousness were believed to be stronger.Every report agreed in Captain Wentworth’s appearing fixed in Lyme.

zh: 安妮明天就离开他们了，这是大家都担心的问题。“没有她，我们该怎么办？我们之间谁也安慰不了谁。”这种话大家说了好多，安妮觉得她只好帮大家挑明他们心中的共同心愿，动员他们马上就去莱姆。她没费多少唇舌，大家当即决定就要去。第二天就去，或者住进旅馆，或者住进公寓，怎么合适怎么住，直到亲爱的路易莎能够走动为止。他们一定能为照看路易莎的那些好心人减轻些负担。至少可以帮助哈维尔太太照顾一下她的孩子。总之，他们对这一决定感到高兴，安妮也为自己提出这个建议感到高兴。她为他们打点行李，一早送他们上路，觉得这是打发她在阿珀克罗斯最后一个上午的最好办法，然而她这么做的结果是自己孤零零地留在这个冷冷清清的家中。
en: Anne was to leave them on the morrow, an event which they all dreaded.“What should they do without her?They were wretched comforters for one another.”And so much was said in this way, that Anne thought she could not do better than impart among them the general inclination to which she was privy, and persuaded them all to go to Lyme at once.She had little difficulty; it was soon determined that they would go; go to-morrow, fix themselves at the inn, or get into lodgings, as it suited, and there remain till dear Louisa could be moved.They must be taking off some trouble from the good people she was with; they might at least relieve Mrs. Harville from the care of her own children; and in short, they were so happy in the decision, that Anne was delighted with what she had done, and felt that she could not spend her last morning at Uppercross better than in assisting their preparations, and sending them off at an early hour, though her being left to the solitary range of the house was the consequence.

zh: 除了庄上的两个小男孩以外，在那些曾经使这两处房子充满生气、为阿珀克罗斯带来欢声笑语的人中，安妮是留下来的最后一个人。几天功夫，这里就发生了巨大的变化！
en: She was the last, excepting the little boys at the cottage, she was the very last, the only remaining one of all that had filled and animated both houses, of all that had given Uppercross its cheerful character.A few days had made a change indeed!

zh: 要是路易莎痊愈了，一切又都会好起来的。这里会比以前更加欢乐。对路易莎康复之后出现的情况，安妮确信无疑。现在这里的情况这么凄凉，只有她一个人在默默地沉思。但是几个月以后，这里就可能又会充满幸福与欢乐，充满丰饶的爱情带来的灿烂景象，一切都与安妮•埃利奥特的情况完全不同。
en: If Louisa recovered, it would all be well again.More than former happiness would be restored.There could not be a doubt, to her mind there was none, of what would follow her recovery.A few months hence, and the room now so deserted, occupied but by her silent, pensive self, might be filled again with all that was happy and gay, all that was glowing and bright in prosperous love, all that was most unlike Anne Elliot!

zh: 11月阴暗的一天，蒙蒙细雨似乎遮住了原来在窗口依稀可见的景色，整整一个小时无所事事的遐想，使得拉塞尔夫人的车轮声更受欢迎。然而，尽管安妮很想走，但她离开老宅时，在临别前眺望庄上那湿漉漉的凄清黑阳台时，甚至通过朦胧的玻璃看村子尽头的几处简屋时，心中不禁感到十分悲伤。在阿珀克罗斯经历的一切，使她觉得这里特别珍贵。这里记载了很多痛苦的经历，这些痛苦一度是强烈的，但现在已经缓和了许多；这里记载了一些和解的感情、微弱的友谊和谅解，这一切再也觅不到了，但永远都会那么亲切。她把这一切的一切都留在这里了，剩下的只是对往事的回忆。
en: An hour’s complete leisure for such reflections as these, on a dark November day, a small thick rain almost blotting out the very few objects ever to be discerned from the windows, was enough to make the sound of Lady Russell’s carriage exceedingly welcome; and yet, though desirous to be gone, she could not quit the Mansion House, or look an adieu to the Cottage, with its black, dripping and comfortless veranda, or even notice through the misty glasses the last humble tenements of the village, without a saddened heart.Scenes had passed in Uppercross which made it precious.It stood the record of many sensations of pain, once severe, but now softened; and of some instances of relenting feeling, some breathings of friendship and reconciliation, which could never be looked for again, and which could never cease to be dear.She left it all behind her, all but the recollection that such things had been.

zh: 安妮自从9月离开拉塞尔夫人家以后，再也没有进入过凯林奇。没有这个必要，有几次她本可以到凯林奇府去的，但她都设法避开了。她这头一次回来就要在这套公寓现代而别致的房间里住下来，好给女主人增添点快乐。
en: Anne had never entered Kellynch since her quitting Lady Russell’s house in September.It had not been necessary, and the few occasions of its being possible for her to go to the Hall she had contrived to evade and escape from.Her first return was to resume her place in the modern and elegant apartments of the Lodge, and to gladden the eyes of its mistress.

zh: 拉塞尔夫人见到安妮，欣喜之中还掺杂着几分忧虑。她明白谁常去阿珀克罗斯。但是幸运的是，要么安妮变得更丰润更漂亮了，要么拉塞尔夫人认为她如此。安妮听到拉塞尔夫人的这番赞美，心中不无回味地把这些话同她堂兄默默的爱慕联系了起来，从而希望自己拥有青春与美丽的第二个春天。
en: There was some anxiety mixed with Lady Russell’s joy in meeting her.She knew who had been frequenting Uppercross.But happily, either Anne was improved in plumpness and looks, or Lady Russell fancied her so; and Anne, in receiving her compliments on the occasion, had the amusement of connecting them with the silent admiration of her cousin, and of hoping that she was to be blessed with a second spring of youth and beauty.

zh: 她们一开始聊天，安妮就觉察到了自己思想上的一些变化。她在离开凯林奇时萦绕在心头的一些事情，在马斯格罗夫家中没有得到重视，当时她不得不将它们深深地埋在心底。现在这些事已经落到了次要的位置。近来她甚至忘记了自己的父亲、姐姐和巴斯。她对他们的关心已经被阿珀克罗斯的一切淹没了。拉塞尔夫人谈起她们以前的那些希望和忧虑，谈到她对他们在卡姆登巷租下的房子感到满意，但对克莱太太还跟他们住在一起感到遗憾。安妮不好意思让拉塞尔夫人知道，她考虑得更多的是莱姆、路易莎和她在那里的所有熟人。对她来说，哈维尔夫妇和本威克舰长的家以及他们的友谊要比她父亲在卡姆登的房子或者她姐姐同克莱太太的亲近更有意思。她实际上是硬让自己去附和拉塞尔夫人，在她本该最关心的话题上表现出同样的焦虑。
en: When they came to converse, she was soon sensible of some mental change.The subjects of which her heart had been full on leaving Kellynch, and which she had felt slighted, and been compelled to smother among the Musgroves, were now become but of secondary interest.She had lately lost sight even of her father and sister and Bath.Their concerns had been sunk under those of Uppercross; and when Lady Russell reverted to their former hopes and fears, and spoke her satisfaction in the house in Camden Place, which had been taken, and her regret that Mrs. Clay should still be with them, Anne would have been ashamed to have it known how much more she was thinking of Lyme and Louisa Musgrove, and all her acquaintance there; how much more interesting to her was the home and the friendship of the Harvilles and Captain Benwick, than her own father’s house in Camden Place, or her own sister’s intimacy with Mrs. Clay.She was actually forced to exert herself to meet Lady Russell with anything like the appearance of equal solicitude, on topics which had by nature the first claim on her.

zh: 她们在谈起另外一个话题时，起初有点尴尬。她们必然要谈起莱姆的那场事故。拉塞尔夫人前一天刚回来不到五分钟，就有人把整个事情原原本本地告诉了她。但是这件事情还得谈一谈，拉塞尔夫人一定会提问题，一定会对那个轻率的行为表示遗憾，对事情的结果表示惋惜，她们一定会提起温特沃思上校的名字。安妮觉得她自己不如拉塞尔夫人坦然。她说不出他的名字，不敢直视拉塞尔夫人的目光，后来干脆采取权宜之计，谈起了她自己对温特沃思上校和路易莎之间感情的看法。说出这件事后，安妮在提到温特沃思上校时就不再感到不安了。
en: There was a little awkwardness at first in their discourse on another subject.They must speak of the accident at Lyme.Lady Russell had not been arrived five minutes the day before, when a full account of the whole had burst on her; but still it must be talked of, she must make enquiries, she must regret the imprudence, lament the result, and Captain Wentworth’s name must be mentioned by both.Anne was conscious of not doing it so well as Lady Russell.She could not speak the name, and look straight forward to Lady Russell’s eye, till she had adopted the expedient of telling her briefly what she thought of the attachment between him and Louisa.When this was told, his name distressed her no longer.

zh: 拉塞尔夫人安静地听着，并希望那一对年轻人幸福，但是内心里却感到既气愤又得意，既高兴又鄙视，觉得这个人在23岁时看起来还多少懂得安妮•埃利奥特的价值，可是八年之后居然被一位马斯格罗夫小姐迷住了。
en: Lady Russell had only to listen composedly, and wish them happy, but internally her heart revelled in angry pleasure, in pleased contempt, that the man who at twenty-three had seemed to understand somewhat of the value of an Anne Elliot, should, eight years afterwards, be charmed by a Louisa Musgrove.

zh: 最初的三四天，一切都很平静，没出现什么特别的情况，只是他们收到了从莱姆来的一两封短信，安妮也弄不清送信的人怎么知道她现在的地址，竟能把信送到。这些信带来了路易莎大为好转的消息。过了几天，拉塞尔夫人感到不能置礼节于不顾了，过去自我恐吓的心理也已经减弱，她坚决地说：“我得去拜访克罗夫特太太。我的确应该尽快去拜访她。安妮，你有勇气陪我去那所房子里拜访吗？这对我们两个人都将是一种考验。”
en: The first three or four days passed most quietly, with no circumstance to mark them excepting the receipt of a note or two from Lyme, which found their way to Anne, she could not tell how, and brought a rather improving account of Louisa.At the end of that period, Lady Russell’s politeness could repose no longer, and the fainter self-threatenings of the past became in a decided tone, “I must call on Mrs. Croft; I really must call upon her soon.Anne, have you courage to go with me, and pay a visit in that house?It will be some trial to us both.”

zh: 安妮对此丝毫没有退缩，相反，她心里想的跟她嘴上说的一样：
en: Anne did not shrink from it; on the contrary, she truly felt as she said, in observing—

zh: “我想，你可能是我们两个中较痛苦的一个。你的感情不像我这样能适应这种变化。我一直呆在这附近，我已经习惯了。”
en: “I think you are very likely to suffer the most of the two; your feelings are less reconciled to the change than mine.By remaining in the neighbourhood, I am become inured to it.”

zh: 她本来可以就此再多说几句，因为她事实上非常尊重克罗夫特夫妇，认为她父亲有这样的房客十分幸运，觉得教区有个好榜样，穷人会得到极好的照顾与救济。她家不得已搬走了，她不管感到多么遗憾和羞愧，但是从良心上说，没有资格留下的人走了，凯林奇府转到了比它的主人更适合的人手中。这些想法无疑是令人痛苦的，而且非常痛苦。但是它们使安妮不会有拉塞尔夫人重新走进这幢房子，重新走过熟悉的房间的那种痛苦。
en: She could have said more on the subject; for she had in fact so high an opinion of the Crofts, and considered her father so very fortunate in his tenants, felt the parish to be so sure of a good example, and the poor of the best attention and relief, that however sorry and ashamed for the necessity of the removal, she could not but in conscience feel that they were gone who deserved not to stay, and that Kellynch Hall had passed into better hands than its owners’.These convictions must unquestionably have their own pain, and severe was its kind; but they precluded that pain which Lady Russell would suffer in entering the house again, and returning through the well-known apartments.

zh: 在这样的时刻，安妮无法对自己说：“这些房间应该只属于我们。啊，它们的命运多么悲惨！现在被不相称的人住上了！一个名门世家就这样被赶走了！一些陌生人把这儿占据了！”不，只要她不想起自己的母亲，不想起母亲曾经坐在那里掌管家务，她就不会发出这样的叹息。
en: In such moments Anne had no power of saying to herself, “These rooms ought to belong only to us.Oh, how fallen in their destination!How unworthily occupied!An ancient family to be so driven away!Strangers filling their place!”No, except when she thought of her mother, and remembered where she had been used to sit and preside, she had no sigh of that description to heave.

zh: 克罗夫特太太对她一直都非常和蔼可亲，这使她很高兴，觉得克罗夫特太太喜欢她。这次克罗夫特太太是在凯林奇接待她，对她更是关怀备至。
en: Mrs. Croft always met her with a kindness which gave her the pleasure of fancying herself a favourite, and on the present occasion, receiving her in that house, there was particular attention.

zh: 发生在莱姆的那件不幸事件很快就成了大家的话题。她们在交换病人的最新消息时，发现两人得到的消息是昨天上午同一时间的情况。原来，温特沃思上校昨天来到了凯林奇（这是出事以后的第一次），并给她送来她先前不知道怎么送到她手中的最近的一封短信。他在这里呆了几个小时，然后又返回莱姆，目前不打算再离开那里了。安妮发现，他还专门问起过她。希望埃利奥特小姐没有累坏身体，还说那次安妮出了很多力。这真宽宏大度，没有什么比这能给她带来更多的快乐。
en: The sad accident at Lyme was soon the prevailing topic, and on comparing their latest accounts of the invalid, it appeared that each lady dated her intelligence from the same hour of yestermorn; that Captain Wentworth had been in Kellynch yesterday (the first time since the accident), had brought Anne the last note, which she had not been able to trace the exact steps of; had staid a few hours and then returned again to Lyme, and without any present intention of quitting it any more.He had enquired after her, she found, particularly; had expressed his hope of Miss Elliot’s not being the worse for her exertions, and had spoken of those exertions as great.This was handsome, and gave her more pleasure than almost anything else could have done.

zh: 对于那次倒霉的事故，两位稳重理智的女士只能根据事实判断。她们完全肯定，这是由于过分轻率和鲁莽造成的。并且后果非常严重，而且一想到不知多久马斯格罗夫小姐才能复原，一想到这次震动可能会给她留下后遗症，就叫人害怕！将军对此作了一个简短的总结：
en: As to the sad catastrophe itself, it could be canvassed only in one style by a couple of steady, sensible women, whose judgements had to work on ascertained events; and it was perfectly decided that it had been the consequence of much thoughtlessness and much imprudence; that its effects were most alarming, and that it was frightful to think, how long Miss Musgrove’s recovery might yet be doubtful, and how liable she would still remain to suffer from the concussion hereafter!The Admiral wound it up summarily by exclaiming—

zh: “嗯，这确实很糟糕。年轻人用砸破情人脑袋的办法来求爱，这难道是一种新式恋爱法，对吗，埃利奥特小姐？这真是叫摔破脑袋再上膏药啊！”
en: “Ay, a very bad business indeed.A new sort of way this, for a young fellow to be making love, by breaking his mistress’s head, is not it, Miss Elliot?This is breaking a head and giving a plaster, truly!”

zh: 克罗夫特将军的态度不太合拉塞尔夫人的意，但让安妮感到很高兴。他那善良的心地和朴实的性格叫人不由得受其吸引。
en: Admiral Croft’s manners were not quite of the tone to suit Lady Russell, but they delighted Anne.His goodness of heart and simplicity of character were irresistible.

zh: “不过，你一定很难过，”他沉思了一会儿，突然回过神来说，“让你上这儿来，看到我们住在这里。我以前没有想到这一点，不过，你一定觉得不好受。不过现在，你不要客气。你要是愿意的话，请起来到所有的房间里看一看吧。”
en: “Now, this must be very bad for you,” said he, suddenly rousing from a little reverie, “to be coming and finding us here.I had not recollected it before, I declare, but it must be very bad.But now, do not stand upon ceremony.Get up and go over all the rooms in the house if you like it.”

zh: “下次吧，先生，谢谢您，这次不看了。”
en: “Another time, Sir, I thank you, not now.”

zh: “好吧，你什么时候方便就请过来。你随时可以从灌木丛穿过来。你会发现，我们的雨伞就放在那里，挂在那扇门旁边。这地方不错，对吧？不过，”（停了一会儿），“你会觉得这地方不怎么样，因为你们的雨伞总是放在管家的房里。”哦，我想，情况总是这样。一个人的做事方式可能同另一个人一样好，可是大家更喜欢自己的做事方式。所以你得自己拿主意，是到处走走好呢，还是留在这儿好。
en: “Well, whenever it suits you.You can slip in from the shrubbery at any time; and there you will find we keep our umbrellas hanging up by that door.A good place is not it?But,” (checking himself), “you will not think it a good place, for yours were always kept in the butler’s room.Ay, so it always is, I believe.One man’s ways may be as good as another’s, but we all like our own best.And so you must judge for yourself, whether it would be better for you to go about the house or not.”

zh: 安妮发现她还是可以谢绝的，便这样做了，对此她十分感激。
en: Anne, finding she might decline it, did so, very gratefully.

zh: “我们也没有多大的变动，”将军想了一会儿接着说，“很少。我们在阿珀克罗斯同你谈起过洗衣房的那扇门。那是个很大的改进。那扇门以前这么长时间开关多不方便，奇怪的是人们竟能忍受这么久！你可以把我们重新装修的情况告诉沃尔特爵士，还可以告诉他，谢泼德先生认为那是这幢房子里最了不起的改进。真的，我也该为我们说句公道话，我们做的少量变动都不错。不过，这应该归功于我的妻子。我只做了一点事情，只是搬走了更衣室里的几面大镜子，那些东西是你父亲的。他是个好人，我认为他是典型的绅士。不过，我觉得，埃利奥特小姐，”（他带着深思的神情看一看），“我觉得，就他这样的年纪而言，他真可以算是一个讲究穿戴的男士。这么多穿衣镜！天哪！哪儿也躲不开自己的影子。于是我找索菲来帮忙，很快就把那些镜子搬走了。现在我就舒服多了，刮胡子的小镜子放在角落里，还有一面大镜子，但我从来没有接近它。”
en: “We have made very few changes either,” continued the Admiral, after thinking a moment.“Very few.We told you about the laundry-door, at Uppercross.That has been a very great improvement.The wonder was, how any family upon earth could bear with the inconvenience of its opening as it did, so long!You will tell Sir Walter what we have done, and that Mr. Shepherd thinks it the greatest improvement the house ever had.Indeed, I must do ourselves the justice to say, that the few alterations we have made have been all very much for the better.My wife should have the credit of them, however.I have done very little besides sending away some of the large looking-glasses from my dressing-room, which was your father’s.A very good man, and very much the gentleman I am sure: but I should think, Miss Elliot,” (looking with serious reflection), “I should think he must be rather a dressy man for his time of life.Such a number of looking-glasses!oh Lord!there was no getting away from one’s self.So I got Sophy to lend me a hand, and we soon shifted their quarters; and now I am quite snug, with my little shaving glass in one corner, and another great thing that I never go near.”

zh: 安妮不禁觉得这番话非常有趣，但又苦恼不知回答什么是好。而将军担心自己不够礼貌，接着话头又说下去：
en: Anne, amused in spite of herself, was rather distressed for an answer, and the Admiral, fearing he might not have been civil enough, took up the subject again, to say—

zh: “你下次给你父亲写信时，埃利奥特小姐，请替我和克罗夫特太太向他问好。请告诉他，我们很喜欢住在这里，对这里挑不出任何毛病。虽说早餐室里的烟囱有点漏洞，可那只是刮南风，而且刮得很厉害的时候，一冬也许碰不上三次。总的来说，我们看过了附近的大多数房子，可以断定，我们最喜欢的是你们这一家。请你如实地告诉他，并再次替我问候他。他听到这些会很高兴的。”
en: “The next time you write to your good father, Miss Elliot, pray give him my compliments and Mrs. Croft’s, and say that we are settled here quite to our liking, and have no fault at all to find with the place.The breakfast-room chimney smokes a little, I grant you, but it is only when the wind is due north and blows hard, which may not happen three times a winter.And take it altogether, now that we have been into most of the houses hereabouts and can judge, there is not one that we like better than this.Pray say so, with my compliments.He will be glad to hear it.”

zh: 拉塞尔夫人和克罗夫特太太对彼此都非常满意。但在当时，这次访问所开始的交往肯定还不能进一步发展，因为克罗夫特夫妇来回访时就说，他们打算出门几个星期，去拜访住在该郡北部的亲戚，也许在拉塞尔夫人去巴斯以前还不能回来。
en: Lady Russell and Mrs. Croft were very well pleased with each other: but the acquaintance which this visit began was fated not to proceed far at present; for when it was returned, the Crofts announced themselves to be going away for a few weeks, to visit their connexions in the north of the county, and probably might not be at home again before Lady Russell would be removing to Bath.

zh: 于是，安妮就不用担心在凯林奇府碰见温特沃思上校了，也不必担心看到他跟她的朋友在一起。一切都令人非常放心，安妮一想起以前的种种担忧都是白费心思，不禁觉得好笑。
en: So ended all danger to Anne of meeting Captain Wentworth at Kellynch Hall, or of seeing him in company with her friend.Everything was safe enough, and she smiled over the many anxious feelings she had wasted on the subject.

zh: 第十四章
en: CHAPTER 14

zh: 马斯格罗夫先生和太太到了莱姆以后，查尔斯和玛丽还在那里住了一阵子。安妮认为他们根本不需要在那里住那么久。不过，他们还算是一家中回来得最早的一批。他们一回到阿珀克罗斯，很快就来到拉塞尔夫人的寓所。他们离开莱姆时，路易莎已经可以坐起来了，不过她头脑虽然清醒了，身体还非常虚弱。她神经脆弱，还需要非常精心的照料。尽管可以认为她总的来说很好，但仍然说不准她哪一天可以经得起归家旅途的颠簸。即使在她父母及时回来迎接几个年幼子女回家过圣诞节时，也不见得有希望能够把她接回家来。
en: Though Charles and Mary had remained at Lyme much longer after Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove’s going than Anne conceived they could have been at all wanted, they were yet the first of the family to be at home again; and as soon as possible after their return to Uppercross they drove over to the Lodge.They had left Louisa beginning to sit up; but her head, though clear, was exceedingly weak, and her nerves susceptible to the highest extreme of tenderness; and though she might be pronounced to be altogether doing very well, it was still impossible to say when she might be able to bear the removal home; and her father and mother, who must return in time to receive their younger children for the Christmas holidays, had hardly a hope of being allowed to bring her with them.

zh: 他们大家都住在公寓里。马斯格罗夫太太尽量把哈维尔太太的孩子领开，尽量从阿珀克罗斯运去了能供应的一切用品，为的是减轻给哈维尔夫妇带来的不便，而哈维尔夫妇则坚持要他们天天去他们那里吃晚饭。总之，双方似乎一直在比赛，看哪一方更为大方和好客。
en: They had been all in lodgings together.Mrs. Musgrove had got Mrs. Harville’s children away as much as she could, every possible supply from Uppercross had been furnished, to lighten the inconvenience to the Harvilles, while the Harvilles had been wanting them to come to dinner every day; and in short, it seemed to have been only a struggle on each side as to which should be most disinterested and hospitable.

zh: 玛丽也有自己的苦恼。但总的来说，既然她在莱姆呆了那么久，显然她觉得愉快是多于痛苦的。查尔斯去莱姆的次数太多，使玛丽感到不愉快。他们到哈维尔夫妇家去吃饭时，只有一名女仆侍候他们。最初，哈维尔太太总是让马斯格罗夫太太坐上座，但是后来她得知玛丽是谁的女儿后，就非常客气地向玛丽表示歉意。玛丽也就成天来来回回，在他们的公寓和哈维尔夫妇家之间来回时又常可以散散步，还经常到图书馆借书和还书，所以玛丽当然就倾向于莱姆了。他们还带她去了查茅斯，她在那里游泳，上教堂做礼拜，在莱姆的教堂里看到的人比在阿珀克罗斯教堂看到的多得多。这一切再加上玛丽自以为在那里给别人帮了很多忙，确实使玛丽觉得这两周过得非常愉快。
en: Mary had had her evils; but upon the whole, as was evident by her staying so long, she had found more to enjoy than to suffer.Charles Hayter had been at Lyme oftener than suited her; and when they dined with the Harvilles there had been only a maid-servant to wait, and at first Mrs. Harville had always given Mrs. Musgrove precedence; but then, she had received so very handsome an apology from her on finding out whose daughter she was, and there had been so much going on every day, there had been so many walks between their lodgings and the Harvilles, and she had got books from the library, and changed them so often, that the balance had certainly been much in favour of Lyme.She had been taken to Charmouth too, and she had bathed, and she had gone to church, and there were a great many more people to look at in the church at Lyme than at Uppercross; and all this, joined to the sense of being so very useful, had made really an agreeable fortnight.

zh: 安妮问起了本威克舰长，玛丽的脸接着就沉下来了。查尔斯却笑了。
en: Anne enquired after Captain Benwick, Mary’s face was clouded directly.Charles laughed.

zh: “噢！我想本威克舰长的情况很好，但是他是一个非常古怪的年轻人。我不知道他想干什么。我们请他到我们家来一两天，查尔斯答应陪他去打猎，他看上去很高兴，而我呢，以为一切事情都已经定下来了。可是，你瞧！到了星期二的晚上，他找了个十分勉强的理由，说‘他从未打过猎’，说‘我们误解他了’，他还说已经答应了这样那样的事情，结果我发现他根本不想来。我想他是怕这里无聊。不过说真的，我认为，对于本威克舰长这样一个心碎的人来说，我们庄上的生活够活跃了。”
en: “Oh!Captain Benwick is very well, I believe, but he is a very odd young man.I do not know what he would be at.We asked him to come home with us for a day or two: Charles undertook to give him some shooting, and he seemed quite delighted, and, for my part, I thought it was all settled; when behold!on Tuesday night, he made a very awkward sort of excuse; ‘he never shot’ and he had ‘been quite misunderstood,’ and he had promised this and he had promised that, and the end of it was, I found, that he did not mean to come.I suppose he was afraid of finding it dull; but upon my word I should have thought we were lively enough at the Cottage for such a heart-broken man as Captain Benwick.”

zh: 查尔斯又笑了，说道：“现在玛丽非常明白这究竟是怎么一回事了。这全都是因为你。”（他转向安妮。）“他原以为，要是他同我们一起来，他会遇到你，他以为每个人都住在阿珀克罗斯。当他发现拉塞尔夫人家住在三英里以外时，他便泄了气，没有勇气来了。我以名誉担保，这就是事情的原委，玛丽是知道的。”
en: Charles laughed again and said, “Now Mary, you know very well how it really was.It was all your doing,” (turning to Anne.)“He fancied that if he went with us, he should find you close by: he fancied everybody to be living in Uppercross; and when he discovered that Lady Russell lived three miles off, his heart failed him, and he had not courage to come.That is the fact, upon my honour, Mary knows it is.”

zh: 但是玛丽并没有欣然地承认这一点，究竟是因为她认为本威克舰长的出身和地位配不上埃利奥特家的小姐，还是她不愿意相信安妮比她更能把别人吸引到阿珀克罗斯来，那就不得而知了。然而安妮的好意并没有因为听到这些话而削弱。她大胆地承认她听到这些话很荣幸，并且她还继续打听情况。
en: But Mary did not give into it very graciously, whether from not considering Captain Benwick entitled by birth and situation to be in love with an Elliot, or from not wanting to believe Anne a greater attraction to Uppercross than herself, must be left to be guessed.Anne’s good-will, however, was not to be lessened by what she heard.She boldly acknowledged herself flattered, and continued her enquiries.

zh: “啊！他经常谈起你，”查尔斯高声说，“听那措词——”玛丽打断了他。“我说，查尔斯，我在那里呆了这么久，从没听他提到过安妮两次。我敢说，安妮，他从来没有谈起过你。”
en: “Oh! he talks of you,” cried Charles, “in such terms—” Mary interrupted him.“I declare, Charles, I never heard him mention Anne twice all the time I was there.I declare, Anne, he never talks of you at all.”

zh: “不，”查尔斯承认，“我知道他从不泛泛地谈一通。但是很明显，他十分钦佩你。他脑子里装得满是你推荐给他的书，他还想跟你讨论一下读书心得。他在某一本书里发现了什么问题，他认为——哦！到底说的是什么我已忘了，这我不可能假装，反正说得十分精彩——我听见他同亨里埃塔谈论过这些，而且是用十分崇敬的口气提起‘埃利奥特小姐’！好了，玛丽，我想情况就是这样。这是当你在另一间屋子里时，我亲耳听见他说的。‘优雅、可爱、美丽。’哦！埃利奥特小姐有无穷无尽的魅力。”
en: “No,” admitted Charles, “I do not know that he ever does, in a general way; but however, it is a very clear thing that he admires you exceedingly.His head is full of some books that he is reading upon your recommendation, and he wants to talk to you about them; he has found out something or other in one of them which he thinks—oh!I cannot pretend to remember it, but it was something very fine—I overheard him telling Henrietta all about it; and then ‘Miss Elliot’ was spoken of in the highest terms!Now Mary, I declare it was so, I heard it myself, and you were in the other room.‘Elegance, sweetness, beauty.’ Oh! there was no end of Miss Elliot’s charms.”

zh: “我可以肯定，”玛丽激动地大声嚷道，“他即使这么说过，也没有什么值得称道的。哈维尔小姐六月份才去世。这种人的爱才不稀罕呢。你说是吧，拉塞尔夫人？我知道你一定会同意我的看法。”
en: “And I am sure,” cried Mary, warmly, “it was a very little to his credit, if he did.Miss Harville only died last June.Such a heart is very little worth having; is it, Lady Russell?I am sure you will agree with me.”

zh: “我要见到本威克舰长以后才能下结论。”拉塞尔夫人笑眯眯地说。
en: “I must see Captain Benwick before I decide,” said Lady Russell, smiling.

zh: “你大概很快就可以见到他，我可以告诉你，夫人，”查尔斯说。“尽管他没有勇气和我们一起来，随后也不敢再到这儿来进行正式访问，但是有朝一日他会单独来凯林奇的，这一点你相信我好了。我告诉了他距离和走法，我还告诉他，这里的教堂很值得一看，因为他喜欢这一类东西，我想这会是一个很好的借口，而且他已经心领神会。根据他的态度，我可以肯定他很快就会来这儿拜访。所以，我通知你了，拉塞尔夫人。”
en: “And that you are very likely to do very soon, I can tell you, ma’am,” said Charles.“Though he had not nerves for coming away with us, and setting off again afterwards to pay a formal visit here, he will make his way over to Kellynch one day by himself, you may depend on it.I told him the distance and the road, and I told him of the church’s being so very well worth seeing; for as he has a taste for those sort of things, I thought that would be a good excuse, and he listened with all his understanding and soul; and I am sure from his manner that you will have him calling here soon.So, I give you notice, Lady Russell.”

zh: “安妮的任何朋友我都欢迎。”拉塞尔夫人和蔼地回答道。
en: “Any acquaintance of Anne’s will always be welcome to me,” was Lady Russell’s kind answer.

zh: “哦！说到安妮的朋友，”玛丽说道，“我觉得不如说是我的朋友，因为在过去的两个星期里我天天见到他。”
en: “Oh!as to being Anne’s acquaintance,” said Mary, “I think he is rather my acquaintance, for I have been seeing him every day this last fortnight.”

zh: “好吧，既然你们都认识本威克舰长，那么我自然非常高兴见到他。”
en: “Well, as your joint acquaintance, then, I shall be very happy to see Captain Benwick.”

zh: “你不会在他身上发现任何令人愉快的地方，我向你保证，夫人。他是世上最枯燥无味的年轻人。有时，他陪我从沙滩的一端走到另一端，却一声不吭。他根本不是一个有教养的年轻人。我敢肯定你不会喜欢他。”
en: “You will not find anything very agreeable in him, I assure you, ma’am.He is one of the dullest young men that ever lived.He has walked with me, sometimes, from one end of the sands to the other, without saying a word.He is not at all a well-bred young man.I am sure you will not like him.”

zh: “在这一点上，我们的看法就不会一致了，玛丽。”安妮说道，“我认为拉塞尔夫人会喜欢他的。我认为拉塞尔夫人会非常喜欢他的见解，要不了多久，她就看不到他举止上的缺陷了。”
en: “There we differ, Mary,” said Anne.“I think Lady Russell would like him.I think she would be so much pleased with his mind, that she would very soon see no deficiency in his manner.”

zh: “我也这么觉得，安妮，”查尔斯说道。“我肯定拉塞尔夫人会喜欢他的。他正是拉塞尔夫人喜欢的那种人。给他一本书，他会看上一整天。”
en: “So do I, Anne,” said Charles.“I am sure Lady Russell would like him.He is just Lady Russell’s sort.Give him a book, and he will read all day long.”

zh: “对，他会这么做的！”玛丽大声地嘲讽道。“他会坐在那里一心一意地读书，有人跟他说话他也不知道，你把剪刀掉在地上他也不知道，不管出了什么事他都不知道。你们觉得拉塞尔夫人会喜欢这样的人吗？”
en: “Yes, that he will!” exclaimed Mary, tauntingly.“He will sit poring over his book, and not know when a person speaks to him, or when one drop’s one’s scissors, or anything that happens.Do you think Lady Russell would like that?”

zh: 拉塞尔夫人忍不住笑了。“我敢担保，”她说道，“我真没想到，我对一个人的看法竟会引起这么不同的猜测，我认为我是一个稳重而讲究实际的人。我确实非常好奇，想见见这么一个能引起截然不同看法的人。我希望你们能劝他到这里来。等他来了，玛丽，你肯定会知道我的看法的。不过在此之前，我决不会对他妄加评论的。”
en: Lady Russell could not help laughing.“Upon my word,” said she, “I should not have supposed that my opinion of any one could have admitted of such difference of conjecture, steady and matter of fact as I may call myself.I have really a curiosity to see the person who can give occasion to such directly opposite notions.I wish he may be induced to call here.And when he does, Mary, you may depend upon hearing my opinion; but I am determined not to judge him beforehand.”

zh: “你不会喜欢他的，我敢担保。”
en: “You will not like him, I will answer for it.”

zh: 拉塞尔夫人开始谈起别的事情来。玛丽激动地谈起了他们偶然遇见，或者更确切地说，他们错过了与埃利奥特先生结识的机会这件事。
en: Lady Russell began talking of something else.Mary spoke with animation of their meeting with, or rather missing, Mr. Elliot so extraordinarily.

zh: “他这个人，”拉塞尔夫人说道，“我倒不想见他。他不愿意同他族长中的长辈真诚相处，所以给我留下了非常不好的印象。”
en: “He is a man,” said Lady Russell, “whom I have no wish to see.His declining to be on cordial terms with the head of his family, has left a very strong impression in his disfavour with me.”

zh: 这番坚决的话给心头热切的玛丽泼了一盆冷水，以至于她对埃利奥特相貌的议论说到一半就戛然而止了。
en: This decision checked Mary’s eagerness, and stopped her short in the midst of the Elliot countenance.

zh: 说到温特沃思上校，尽管安妮没有冒失地再询问，但他们也主动提供了足够的信息。可以料想，他的情绪最近已经大大恢复了。随着路易莎病情的好转，他的情绪也改善了，同第一周相比，他已经判若两人了。他没有去探望路易莎，并非常害怕见面会给路易莎带来不利的影响，所以没有催促着去见她。相反，他正打算出门一星期或十天，等她头部的伤势更好些再说。他曾经说过要去普利茅斯住上一星期，想要劝说本威克舰长陪他一起去。但是查尔斯一直坚持认为，本威克舰长似乎更想乘马车到凯林奇去一趟。
en: With regard to Captain Wentworth, though Anne hazarded no enquiries, there was voluntary communication sufficient.His spirits had been greatly recovering lately as might be expected.As Louisa improved, he had improved, and he was now quite a different creature from what he had been the first week.He had not seen Louisa; and was so extremely fearful of any ill consequence to her from an interview, that he did not press for it at all; and, on the contrary, seemed to have a plan of going away for a week or ten days, till her head was stronger.He had talked of going down to Plymouth for a week, and wanted to persuade Captain Benwick to go with him; but, as Charles maintained to the last, Captain Benwick seemed much more disposed to ride over to Kellynch.

zh: 毋庸置疑，自从这次谈话起，拉塞尔夫人和安妮便时不时地想起本威克舰长。拉塞尔夫人一听见门铃声，就以为是他来了。而安妮每次在他父亲的田地里独自尽情地散步或在村里进行慈善访问回来，总想着能不能遇到他或者听到他的消息。可是，本威克舰长并没有来。或许他并不像查尔斯所说的那么想到这里来，或许他太羞涩。空盼了一星期之后，拉塞尔夫人便认定，不值得给这人这么大的关注，他并不像当初那么引人注意。
en: There can be no doubt that Lady Russell and Anne were both occasionally thinking of Captain Benwick, from this time.Lady Russell could not hear the door-bell without feeling that it might be his herald; nor could Anne return from any stroll of solitary indulgence in her father’s grounds, or any visit of charity in the village, without wondering whether she might see him or hear of him.Captain Benwick came not, however.He was either less disposed for it than Charles had imagined, or he was too shy; and after giving him a week’s indulgence, Lady Russell determined him to be unworthy of the interest which he had been beginning to excite.

zh: 马斯格罗夫夫妇回来了，从学校接回兴高采烈的孩子们，还把哈维尔太太的小孩们也带来了，阿珀克罗斯热闹了，而莱姆则清静了下来。亨里埃塔留在那里照顾路易莎。家中的其他人又都回到了府上。
en: The Musgroves came back to receive their happy boys and girls from school, bringing with them Mrs. Harville’s little children, to improve the noise of Uppercross, and lessen that of Lyme.Henrietta remained with Louisa; but all the rest of the family were again in their usual quarters.

zh: 拉塞尔夫人和安妮去看望过他们一次，安妮不得不感到阿珀克罗斯又十分热闹了。尽管亨里埃塔、路易莎、查尔斯•海特和温特沃思上校都不在，可是那里的情景同她最后一次见到的情况形成极强烈的对照。
en: Lady Russell and Anne paid their compliments to them once, when Anne could not but feel that Uppercross was already quite alive again.Though neither Henrietta, nor Louisa, nor Charles Hayter, nor Captain Wentworth were there, the room presented as strong a contrast as could be wished to the last state she had seen it in.

zh: 哈维尔家的孩子们紧紧地围在马斯格罗夫太太的身边，她小心翼翼地保护着他们，不让他们受到从乡舍上赶来逗他们的两个男孩的欺负。房间的一头是一张桌子，围着几个唧唧喳喳的女孩，正在剪绸子和金纸。房间的另一头是支架和托盘，支架被盘子里的腌猪肉和冷馅饼压弯了，一群喧闹的小孩子在那里嬉闹。整个场面少不了劈啪作响的圣诞炉火，尽管周围很嘈杂，但它似乎执意要大家听见它的声音。在马斯格罗夫太太和安妮来访问时，查尔斯和玛丽当然也来了，马斯格罗夫先生特意向拉塞尔夫人表示敬意，在她身边坐了有十分钟，大声同她闲谈。可是坐在他腿上的几个孩子吵个不停，拉塞尔夫人还是听不清他在说什么。这真是一场美好的家庭片。
en: Immediately surrounding Mrs. Musgrove were the little Harvilles, whom she was sedulously guarding from the tyranny of the two children from the Cottage, expressly arrived to amuse them.On one side was a table occupied by some chattering girls, cutting up silk and gold paper; and on the other were tressels and trays, bending under the weight of brawn and cold pies, where riotous boys were holding high revel; the whole completed by a roaring Christmas fire, which seemed determined to be heard, in spite of all the noise of the others.Charles and Mary also came in, of course, during their visit, and Mr. Musgrove made a point of paying his respects to Lady Russell, and sat down close to her for ten minutes, talking with a very raised voice, but from the clamour of the children on his knees, generally in vain.It was a fine family-piece.

zh: 从安妮的性情来判断，她会觉得路易莎的伤势一度使大家受到很大刺激，现在家里这么喧闹，对恢复平静的心境极为不利。却说马斯格罗夫太太，她把安妮拉到身边，一再地对她对大家的照顾表示热忱的感谢，最后她还简单谈了几句她当时痛苦的心情，然后高兴地环视了一下房间，又说，在经历这一切变故之后，现在家里有了一点平静的欢乐氛围，这对她是最好不过了。
en: Anne, judging from her own temperament, would have deemed such a domestic hurricane a bad restorative of the nerves, which Louisa’s illness must have so greatly shaken.But Mrs. Musgrove, who got Anne near her on purpose to thank her most cordially, again and again, for all her attentions to them, concluded a short recapitulation of what she had suffered herself by observing, with a happy glance round the room, that after all she had gone through, nothing was so likely to do her good as a little quiet cheerfulness at home.

zh: 路易莎现在恢复得很快。她的母亲甚至觉得她能够参加她的弟妹开学前的家宴。哈维尔夫妇答应，不管路易莎什么时候回来，他们都会陪她来阿珀克罗斯住上一段时间。眼下，温特沃思上校到什罗普郡看望他哥哥去了。
en: Louisa was now recovering apace.Her mother could even think of her being able to join their party at home, before her brothers and sisters went to school again.The Harvilles had promised to come with her and stay at Uppercross, whenever she returned.Captain Wentworth was gone, for the present, to see his brother in Shropshire.

zh: “我希望我今后能记住，”她们一坐进马车，拉塞尔夫人就说，“不要在圣诞节期间来访问阿珀克罗斯。”
en: “I hope I shall remember, in future,” said Lady Russell, as soon as they were reseated in the carriage, “not to call at Uppercross in the Christmas holidays.”

zh: 对于喧闹声，如同对其他事物一样，各人有各人的看法。各种声音是无害还是令人苦恼，取决于其性质而不是音量大小。此后不久，在一个雨后的下午，拉塞尔夫人来到了巴斯，马车沿着长长的街道从老桥往卡姆登巷驶去，挤在川流不息的各种车辆之间，大小货车发出沉重的隆隆声，卖报的、卖松饼的和卖牛奶的都在高声叫喊，没完没了的木鞋的叮当声，她也没有抱怨。不，这是冬天里给人们带来乐趣的声音；听到这些声音，拉塞尔夫人反倒感到精神振奋。她像马斯格罗夫太太一样，虽然嘴上不说，心里却觉得，在乡下呆了那么久，现在这一片平静的欢乐气氛，对她来说是最好不过了。
en: Everybody has their taste in noises as well as in other matters; and sounds are quite innoxious, or most distressing, by their sort rather than their quantity.When Lady Russell not long afterwards, was entering Bath on a wet afternoon, and driving through the long course of streets from the Old Bridge to Camden Place, amidst the dash of other carriages, the heavy rumble of carts and drays, the bawling of newspapermen, muffin-men and milkmen, and the ceaseless clink of pattens, she made no complaint.No, these were noises which belonged to the winter pleasures; her spirits rose under their influence; and like Mrs. Musgrove, she was feeling, though not saying, that after being long in the country, nothing could be so good for her as a little quiet cheerfulness.

zh: 安妮没有这样的感觉。她虽然没有作声，但是对巴斯却仍然十分反感。她瞧了一眼在蒙蒙细雨中一片鳞次栉比的建筑物，一点儿也不想细看了。尽管马车在街上行驶令人很不舒服，但是又嫌马车跑得太快了。因为她来了以后谁见到她会高兴呢？她带着眷恋惆怅的心情，回想着阿珀克罗斯的热闹和凯林奇的幽静。
en: Anne did not share these feelings.She persisted in a very determined, though very silent disinclination for Bath; caught the first dim view of the extensive buildings, smoking in rain, without any wish of seeing them better; felt their progress through the streets to be, however disagreeable, yet too rapid; for who would be glad to see her when she arrived?And looked back, with fond regret, to the bustles of Uppercross and the seclusion of Kellynch.

zh: 伊丽莎白在最近的一封信中提到了一则比较有趣的消息。埃利奥特先生在巴斯。他到卡姆登巷拜访了一次，又去了第二次、第三次，显得十分殷勤。如果伊丽莎白和她父亲没有自欺欺人的话，埃利奥特先生就像过去拼命怠慢他们一样，现在又在拼命巴结他们，而且他还明确表示这种交往的重要价值。如果情况果真如此，那倒不错。拉塞尔夫人对埃利奥特先生既有一种友好的好奇又有一种困惑不解，她已经放弃了不久前对玛丽说过的“她不想见这个人”的看法。她很想见见他。如果埃利奥特先生真想寻求和解，成为家族中尽职的一支，那大家就应该原谅他以前从家族中分裂出去的行为。
en: Elizabeth’s last letter had communicated a piece of news of some interest.Mr. Elliot was in Bath.He had called in Camden Place; had called a second time, a third; had been pointedly attentive.If Elizabeth and her father did not deceive themselves, had been taking much pains to seek the acquaintance, and proclaim the value of the connection, as he had formerly taken pains to shew neglect.This was very wonderful if it were true; and Lady Russell was in a state of very agreeable curiosity and perplexity about Mr. Elliot, already recanting the sentiment she had so lately expressed to Mary, of his being “a man whom she had no wish to see.”She had a great wish to see him.If he really sought to reconcile himself like a dutiful branch, he must be forgiven for having dismembered himself from the paternal tree.

zh: 安妮对这个情况并不这么乐观，不过她觉得她不妨再见见埃利奥特先生，而对住在巴斯的很多人，她却连见都不想见。
en: Anne was not animated to an equal pitch by the circumstance, but she felt that she would rather see Mr. Elliot again than not, which was more than she could say for many other persons in Bath.

zh: 她在卡姆登巷下车；拉塞尔夫人则继续朝自己在里弗斯街的住所驶去。
en: She was put down in Camden Place; and Lady Russell then drove to her own lodgings, in Rivers Street.

zh: 第十五章
en: CHAPTER 15

zh: 沃尔特爵士在卡姆登巷租了一幢很好的房子，既高大又庄严，正符合一位重要人物的身份。他和伊丽莎白在那里住了下来，他们也感到很满意。
en: Sir Walter had taken a very good house in Camden Place, a lofty dignified situation, such as becomes a man of consequence; and both he and Elizabeth were settled there, much to their satisfaction.

zh: 安妮怀着沉重的心情走进屋去，一想到自己要在这里囚禁上几个月，便忧心忡忡地暗自思忖：“哦！什么时候我才能再离开这里啊？”然而，由于家人对她的接待中有几分意外的亲切，她的情绪有所好转。她的父亲和姐姐为了向她炫耀房子和家具，见到她很高兴，对她也很和气。他们坐下来吃饭时，发现现在是四个人了，觉得很满意。
