en: Anne entered it with a sinking heart, anticipating an imprisonment of many months, and anxiously saying to herself, “Oh! when shall I leave you again?” A degree of unexpected cordiality, however, in the welcome she received, did her good.Her father and sister were glad to see her, for the sake of shewing her the house and furniture, and met her with kindness.Her making a fourth, when they sat down to dinner, was noticed as an advantage.

zh: 克莱太太非常和颜悦色、笑容满面，不过她的礼貌和微笑是理所当然的。安妮总是觉得，她一到来，克莱太太就会装出一副得体的神态，不过其他人的恳切之情她却是万万没有预料到。他们显然情绪极佳，安妮马上就要听到其中的缘由了。他们不想听她说什么。他们只准备听听老邻居们怀念他们的恭维话，可是安妮却无可奉告，他们就随便问了几句，接下去便垄断了全部话题。阿珀克罗斯根本激不起他们的兴趣，凯林奇府也没有什么可谈，要谈的只有巴斯。
en: Mrs. Clay was very pleasant, and very smiling, but her courtesies and smiles were more a matter of course.Anne had always felt that she would pretend what was proper on her arrival, but the complaisance of the others was unlooked for.They were evidently in excellent spirits, and she was soon to listen to the causes.They had no inclination to listen to her.After laying out for some compliments of being deeply regretted in their old neighbourhood, which Anne could not pay, they had only a few faint enquiries to make, before the talk must be all their own.Uppercross excited no interest, Kellynch very little: it was all Bath.

zh: 他们高高兴兴地向安妮担保，巴斯处处比他们预料的要好。他们的房子无疑是卡姆登巷最漂亮的一幢。他们的客厅甚至比他们耳闻目睹过的其他客厅有更多明显的优点，而陈设和家具的选择也无不如此。人们都争先恐后地来同他们结识。人人都想来拜访他们。他们已经谢绝了很多引荐，但是仍然不断地有素不相识的人留下他们的名片。
en: They had the pleasure of assuring her that Bath more than answered their expectations in every respect.Their house was undoubtedly the best in Camden Place; their drawing-rooms had many decided advantages over all the others which they had either seen or heard of, and the superiority was not less in the style of the fitting-up, or the taste of the furniture.Their acquaintance was exceedingly sought after.Everybody was wanting to visit them.They had drawn back from many introductions, and still were perpetually having cards left by people of whom they knew nothing.

zh: 这真是无比的欣慰啊！安妮能对父亲和姐姐的幸福感表示惊讶吗？她也许不会惊讶，但是她肯定会叹息，父亲居然对他自己的变化不感到屈辱，对丧失地产所有者的责任和尊严并不感到任何遗憾，竟然在一个小城镇里发现这么多值得骄傲的东西！当伊丽莎白推开折门，得意地从一间客厅走到另一间，夸耀这些房间如何宽敞时，这时安妮不得不叹息，感到可笑和惊讶。伊丽莎白原是凯林奇府的女主人，居然会对两堵墙之间仅有三十英尺宽的房子感到自豪。
en: Here were funds of enjoyment.Could Anne wonder that her father and sister were happy?She might not wonder, but she must sigh that her father should feel no degradation in his change, should see nothing to regret in the duties and dignity of the resident landholder, should find so much to be vain of in the littlenesses of a town; and she must sigh, and smile, and wonder too, as Elizabeth threw open the folding-doors and walked with exultation from one drawing-room to the other, boasting of their space; at the possibility of that woman, who had been mistress of Kellynch Hall, finding extent to be proud of between two walls, perhaps thirty feet asunder.

zh: 但是，这不是让他们高兴的全部原因。其中还有埃利奥特先生。安妮听到他们大谈特谈埃利奥特先生。他不仅得到了他们的宽恕，而且还博得了他们的好感。他在巴斯住了两个星期左右。（11月份他去伦敦时曾路过巴斯，自然也听说了沃尔特爵士已在那里定居的消息，他虽然在那里逗留了24个小时，却未能利用这个机会去拜访。）不过他现在已经在巴斯呆了两个星期，他到达后的第一件事情就是到卡姆登留一下名片，接着便千方百计地寻见。他们见面时，他态度坦诚，爽快地为过去的事情表示歉意，恳请他们再次把他看作是一位亲戚。因此他们之间已经完全恢复了过去的友好关系。
en: But this was not all which they had to make them happy.They had Mr. Elliot too.Anne had a great deal to hear of Mr. Elliot.He was not only pardoned, they were delighted with him.He had been in Bath about a fortnight; (he had passed through Bath in November, in his way to London, when the intelligence of Sir Walter’s being settled there had of course reached him, though only twenty-four hours in the place, but he had not been able to avail himself of it;) but he had now been a fortnight in Bath, and his first object on arriving, had been to leave his card in Camden Place, following it up by such assiduous endeavours to meet, and when they did meet, by such great openness of conduct, such readiness to apologize for the past, such solicitude to be received as a relation again, that their former good understanding was completely re-established.

zh: 他们觉得他没有什么过错。他为自己过去的怠慢表现解释了一番，从而消除了大家的恶感。他说这完全是由误解造成的。他从未想过要脱离家族，倒是担心自己被抛弃了，但是又不知道原因，出于谨慎，他只有缄口不语。他们暗示他曾发表过不尊重或不喜欢这一家族和家族荣誉的言论，他听了感到十分愤慨。他一直炫耀自己是埃利奥特家族的一员，他有着极其传统的家族观念，这与当前流行的无视旧礼教的风气不太相称。他确实很震惊，不过他的性格和全部行为必然会驳倒这一误解。他可以请沃尔特爵士去询问所有认识他的人，而且他在这方面也在做出努力，一有机会就寻求和解，希望恢复亲戚和假定继承人的关系，这也有力地证明了他对此事的态度。
en: They had not a fault to find in him.He had explained away all the appearance of neglect on his own side.It had originated in misapprehension entirely.He had never had an idea of throwing himself off; he had feared that he was thrown off, but knew not why, and delicacy had kept him silent.Upon the hint of having spoken disrespectfully or carelessly of the family and the family honours, he was quite indignant.He, who had ever boasted of being an Elliot, and whose feelings, as to connection, were only too strict to suit the unfeudal tone of the present day.He was astonished, indeed, but his character and general conduct must refute it.He could refer Sir Walter to all who knew him; and certainly, the pains he had been taking on this, the first opportunity of reconciliation, to be restored to the footing of a relation and heir-presumptive, was a strong proof of his opinions on the subject.

zh: 他们发现，埃利奥特先生的婚事也情有可原。这可不是他自己说的，是他的一个非常亲密的朋友沃利斯上校透露的。这是个非常体面的人，是个十足的绅士（沃尔特爵士还补充说，长得也不错），住在莫尔伯勒，过着阔绰的生活，经他自己刻意要求，埃利奥特先生从中介绍，结识了沃尔特爵士，他提到了与这桩婚姻有关的一两件事情，因而大大减轻了此事的耻辱。
en: The circumstances of his marriage, too, were found to admit of much extenuation.This was an article not to be entered on by himself; but a very intimate friend of his, a Colonel Wallis, a highly respectable man, perfectly the gentleman, (and not an ill-looking man, Sir Walter added), who was living in very good style in Marlborough Buildings, and had, at his own particular request, been admitted to their acquaintance through Mr. Elliot, had mentioned one or two things relative to the marriage, which made a material difference in the discredit of it.

zh: 沃利斯上校很早就认识埃利奥特先生，与他的妻子也很熟悉，对整个事情非常了解。她当然不是出身名门，但却受过良好的教育，多才多艺，非常富有，而且对他的朋友极为钟情。这一点颇有魅力。她主动追求埃利奥特。要不是这样的吸引力，她再有钱也不能迷住埃利奥特先生，再说，她还向沃尔特爵士担保说，她是一位非常漂亮的女人。这些就使那桩婚事大为改观。一位非常漂亮、非常有钱的女人钟情于他！沃尔特爵士似乎承认，这么说来这件事可以完全谅解。伊丽莎白虽然对此事并不完全赞同，却觉得情有可原。
en: Colonel Wallis had known Mr. Elliot long, had been well acquainted also with his wife, had perfectly understood the whole story.She was certainly not a woman of family, but well educated, accomplished, rich, and excessively in love with his friend.There had been the charm.She had sought him.Without that attraction, not all her money would have tempted Elliot, and Sir Walter was, moreover, assured of her having been a very fine woman.Here was a great deal to soften the business.A very fine woman with a large fortune, in love with him!Sir Walter seemed to admit it as complete apology; and though Elizabeth could not see the circumstance in quite so favourable a light, she allowed it be a great extenuation.

zh: 埃利奥特先生三番五次地来拜访，同他们吃过一次晚餐，他显然为自己受到盛情邀请而高兴，因为他们一般不邀请别人吃饭。总之，他为自己受到伯父、堂妹的种种款待而高兴，并把自己的全部幸福寄托在同卡姆登巷的亲密关系上。
en: Mr. Elliot had called repeatedly, had dined with them once, evidently delighted by the distinction of being asked, for they gave no dinners in general; delighted, in short, by every proof of cousinly notice, and placing his whole happiness in being on intimate terms in Camden Place.

zh: 安妮听着这些话，但却不太明白。她知道，听他们的话应该打个折扣，而且要打很大的折扣。她听到的全部内容都经过了修饰润色。这一和解过程中，一切听起来夸大或者不合情理的地方，很可能毫无根据，仅仅是叙述者说说罢了。然而，她也觉得经过多年的间隔，埃利奥特先生又想博得他们的好感，似乎不那么简单。从世俗的眼光看来，埃利奥特先生同沃尔特爵士搞好关系既无利可图，而相互不合，他也不会失去任何东西。十有八九，他已经比沃尔特爵士富有了，而凯林奇庄园和爵位以后肯定会归他所有。一个聪明人，他看上去像一个很聪明的人，他为什么要这么做呢？她只能找到一个解释，也许是为了伊丽莎白。过去也许真的有好感，但是机会和意外的遭遇已把他推上了另外一条道路。现在既然他可以按自己的意愿行事了，就可能向伊丽莎白献殷勤。伊丽莎白当然很漂亮，很有教养，举止优雅，埃利奥特先生以前只在公开场合遇见她，当时他还很年轻，也许她的性格从没有被他看透过。埃利奥特先生现在生活阅历多了，眼光也敏锐了，伊丽莎白的脾气和见解是否还经得起他的审查可是另外一回事，而且也令人担心。安妮恳切地希望，埃利奥特先生要是为了伊丽莎白而来，那他最好不要过于挑剔，不要太善于观察。当他们谈到埃利奥特先生经常来访时，伊丽莎白和她的朋友克莱太太之间交换了一两次眼色，这表明伊丽莎白相信埃利奥特爵士看上了她，同时也表明她的朋友克莱太太支持这种想法。
en: Anne listened, but without quite understanding it.Allowances, large allowances, she knew, must be made for the ideas of those who spoke.She heard it all under embellishment.All that sounded extravagant or irrational in the progress of the reconciliation might have no origin but in the language of the relators.Still, however, she had the sensation of there being something more than immediately appeared, in Mr. Elliot’s wishing, after an interval of so many years, to be well received by them.In a worldly view, he had nothing to gain by being on terms with Sir Walter; nothing to risk by a state of variance.In all probability he was already the richer of the two, and the Kellynch estate would as surely be his hereafter as the title.A sensible man, and he had looked like a very sensible man, why should it be an object to him?She could only offer one solution; it was, perhaps, for Elizabeth’s sake.There might really have been a liking formerly, though convenience and accident had drawn him a different way; and now that he could afford to please himself, he might mean to pay his addresses to her.Elizabeth was certainly very handsome, with well-bred, elegant manners, and her character might never have been penetrated by Mr. Elliot, knowing her but in public, and when very young himself.How her temper and understanding might bear the investigation of his present keener time of life was another concern and rather a fearful one.Most earnestly did she wish that he might not be too nice, or too observant if Elizabeth were his object; and that Elizabeth was disposed to believe herself so, and that her friend Mrs. Clay was encouraging the idea, seemed apparent by a glance or two between them, while Mr. Elliot’s frequent visits were talked of.

zh: 安妮说起她在莱姆见过埃利奥特先生两眼，可是没人注意听。“啊！是的，那也许是埃利奥特先生。他们不知道。也许可能是他。”他们不愿意听安妮谈论埃利奥特先生。他们自己正在谈论他，尤其是沃尔特爵士。他公正地谈到埃利奥特先生很有绅士派头，风度优雅，衣着时髦，相貌端庄，眼神敏锐。但与此同时，“又必须遗憾地指出，他的下颌本来就过于突出，时间的流逝似乎更加深了这一缺陷，再说，他也不能违心地说，过了十年他还容颜依旧。埃利奥特先生却认为他（沃尔特爵士）看起来同上次他们分开时一模一样。”但使他尴尬的是，沃尔特爵士“不能用同样的赞美来回敬他。不过他并不想抱怨什么。沃尔特爵士的确比大多数人要潇洒。无论人们在哪里看到他跟沃尔特爵士在一块，他都不会介意的。”
en: Anne mentioned the glimpses she had had of him at Lyme, but without being much attended to.“Oh! yes, perhaps, it had been Mr. Elliot.They did not know.It might be him, perhaps.”They could not listen to her description of him.They were describing him themselves; Sir Walter especially.He did justice to his very gentlemanlike appearance, his air of elegance and fashion, his good shaped face, his sensible eye; but, at the same time, “must lament his being very much under-hung, a defect which time seemed to have increased; nor could he pretend to say that ten years had not altered almost every feature for the worse.Mr. Elliot appeared to think that he (Sir Walter) was looking exactly as he had done when they last parted;” but Sir Walter had “not been able to return the compliment entirely, which had embarrassed him.He did not mean to complain, however.Mr. Elliot was better to look at than most men, and he had no objection to being seen with him anywhere.”

zh: 整个晚上他们都在谈论埃利奥特先生和他在莫尔伯勒的朋友们。“沃利斯上校是如此急切地想结识他们！埃利奥特先生也急于让他这么做！”还有一位沃利斯太太，到目前为止他们只是听说她的情况，因为她最近就要分娩了。但是埃利奥特先生说她是“一位非常迷人，很值得介绍给卡姆登巷认识的女人，”等她一恢复，他们就会同她结识。沃尔特爵士很看好沃利斯太太，说她是一位非常美丽的女人，很漂亮。“他渴望见到她。他希望这位太太能弥补街上那些屡见不鲜的姿色平庸的女人对他所造成的遗憾。巴斯感到最糟糕的是，姿色平庸的女人太多。他并不是想说这里没有漂亮的女人，但是姿色平庸的女人比例太大。他散步时经常注意到，一张漂亮的脸蛋后面往往跟着30到35个丑八怪。一次，他在邦德街的一家商店里一个接一个地数着走过的87个女人，其中没有一个长相是过得去的。那是一个霜冻的早晨，确实是寒气逼人，一千个女人中也不见得有一个能受得了这种严寒的考验。但是巴斯的丑女仍然是多得可怕。说到男人就更糟了，要糟不知多少呢！满街都是骨瘦如柴的人！很显然，这里的女人很难见到一个像样的男人，这可以从相貌端正的男人引起的反应中看得明明白白。不论他同沃利斯上校（他是一个英俊的军人，只是黄头发略微泛红而已）臂挽臂走到哪里，总会发现所有女人的目光都在盯着他。的的确确所有女人的眼睛都在盯着沃利斯上校。”沃尔特爵士多么谦虚！可是别人也不会放过他。他的女儿和克莱太太会一同暗示说，沃利斯上校的同伴同样有漂亮的身材，而且绝对没有黄里透红的头发。
en: Mr. Elliot, and his friends in Marlborough Buildings, were talked of the whole evening.“Colonel Wallis had been so impatient to be introduced to them!and Mr. Elliot so anxious that he should!” and there was a Mrs. Wallis, at present known only to them by description, as she was in daily expectation of her confinement; but Mr. Elliot spoke of her as “a most charming woman, quite worthy of being known in Camden Place,” and as soon as she recovered they were to be acquainted.Sir Walter thought much of Mrs. Wallis; she was said to be an excessively pretty woman, beautiful.“He longed to see her.He hoped she might make some amends for the many very plain faces he was continually passing in the streets.The worst of Bath was the number of its plain women.He did not mean to say that there were no pretty women, but the number of the plain was out of all proportion.He had frequently observed, as he walked, that one handsome face would be followed by thirty, or five-and-thirty frights; and once, as he had stood in a shop on Bond Street, he had counted eighty-seven women go by, one after another, without there being a tolerable face among them.It had been a frosty morning, to be sure, a sharp frost, which hardly one woman in a thousand could stand the test of.But still, there certainly were a dreadful multitude of ugly women in Bath; and as for the men!they were infinitely worse.Such scarecrows as the streets were full of!It was evident how little the women were used to the sight of anything tolerable, by the effect which a man of decent appearance produced.He had never walked anywhere arm-in-arm with Colonel Wallis (who was a fine military figure, though sandy-haired) without observing that every woman’s eye was upon him; every woman’s eye was sure to be upon Colonel Wallis.”Modest Sir Walter!He was not allowed to escape, however.His daughter and Mrs. Clay united in hinting that Colonel Wallis’s companion might have as good a figure as Colonel Wallis, and certainly was not sandy-haired.

zh: “玛丽看上去怎么样啊？”沃尔特爵士高兴地问道。“上次我见到她时，她的鼻子通红，不过我想不至于天天如此吧。”
en: “How is Mary looking?” said Sir Walter, in the height of his good humour.“The last time I saw her she had a red nose, but I hope that may not happen every day.”

zh: “哦！不，那是非常偶然的。总的来说，她身体很好，而且自从米迦勒节以来，她的气色一直不错。”
en: “Oh! no, that must have been quite accidental.In general she has been in very good health and very good looks since Michaelmas.”

zh: “要不是我担心她会冒着刺骨的寒风外出，弄得皮肤粗糙不堪，我真想送一顶新帽子和一件皮上衣给她。”
en: “If I thought it would not tempt her to go out in sharp winds, and grow coarse, I would send her a new hat and pelisse.”

zh: 安妮正在想她是不是应该贸然建议，一件礼服或一顶帽子不至于被如此滥用吧，但一阵敲门声把一切都打断了。“有人敲门！这么晚了！这都十点了。会不会是埃利奥特先生？他们知道他去兰斯当克雷森特吃晚饭了。也许他会在回家路上顺便进来看望他们一下。他们想不到还会有别的人。克莱太太认定是埃利奥特先生在敲门。”克莱太太猜对了。在男管家兼男仆周到的陪同下，埃利奥特先生给引进了房间。
en: Anne was considering whether she should venture to suggest that a gown, or a cap, would not be liable to any such misuse, when a knock at the door suspended everything.“A knock at the door!and so late!It was ten o’clock.Could it be Mr. Elliot?They knew he was to dine in Lansdown Crescent.It was possible that he might stop in his way home to ask them how they did.They could think of no one else.Mrs. Clay decidedly thought it Mr. Elliot’s knock.”Mrs. Clay was right.With all the state which a butler and foot-boy could give, Mr. Elliot was ushered into the room.

zh: 就是那个人，一点不错，只不过是换了套衣服而已。安妮往后退了退，他在向别人表示问候，请她姐姐原谅在这么不适当的时候来访，但是“他既然在附近，就没法让自己不来了解一下她和她的朋友昨天晚上是否着凉了”等等，等等。他说话彬彬有礼，别人也都尽量有礼貌地听着，不过该介绍一下安妮了。沃尔特爵士谈起了自己的小女儿。“埃利奥特先生，请允许我将小女儿介绍给你”（这种时候他哪里想得起玛丽）。安妮羞红的脸上微微一笑，恰到好处地展示了埃利奥特先生根本不曾忘却的漂亮面孔，安妮当即发现他微微一怔，不禁觉得有些好笑，他居然一直不知道她是谁。他看上去大为惊讶，但是更多的还是高兴；他的眼睛在熠熠发光！他非常高兴能认识这样一位亲戚，还提起了过去的事情，诚恳地请求安妮把他当成老朋友。他还是像在莱姆一样相貌堂堂，说话时脸上更是容光焕发，一举一动都得体之至，潇洒至极，十分大方和气，安妮觉得他优美的风度只能同一个人相媲美。虽然他们的形象不同，但是他们可以说是同样优美。
en: It was the same, the very same man, with no difference but of dress.Anne drew a little back, while the others received his compliments, and her sister his apologies for calling at so unusual an hour, but “he could not be so near without wishing to know that neither she nor her friend had taken cold the day before,” &c. &c; which was all as politely done, and as politely taken, as possible, but her part must follow then.Sir Walter talked of his youngest daughter; “Mr. Elliot must give him leave to present him to his youngest daughter” (there was no occasion for remembering Mary); and Anne, smiling and blushing, very becomingly shewed to Mr. Elliot the pretty features which he had by no means forgotten, and instantly saw, with amusement at his little start of surprise, that he had not been at all aware of who she was.He looked completely astonished, but not more astonished than pleased; his eyes brightened!and with the most perfect alacrity he welcomed the relationship, alluded to the past, and entreated to be received as an acquaintance already.He was quite as good-looking as he had appeared at Lyme, his countenance improved by speaking, and his manners were so exactly what they ought to be, so polished, so easy, so particularly agreeable, that she could compare them in excellence to only one person’s manners.They were not the same, but they were, perhaps, equally good.

zh: 他同他们一起坐了下来，为他们的谈话增添了不少趣味。毫无疑问，他是个聪明人。十分钟就足以证明这一点。他的语气、神态、话题的选择、懂得适可而止；这一切都表明他既聪明又有洞察力。一有机会，他便同安妮谈起了莱姆，想比较一下双方对这个地方的看法，但是他特别想谈的是他们同时投宿于同一家旅馆的巧事；他谈了一些自己的行踪，了解了一下安妮的情况，并为失去了一个向安妮表示敬意的机会而感到遗憾。安妮简单地谈起了她的同伴和她们在莱姆的活动。埃利奥特先生越听越感到遗憾。他就在他们隔壁的房间里孤独地呆了整整一个晚上，听到了他们不断的欢笑声，心想他们一定是极快乐的一群，很想同他们在一起，但他当然丝毫没有想到他会有任何权利来自我介绍。他要是问一下这群人是谁就好了！马斯格罗夫这一姓氏足以向他说明一切。“好了，这将使我改掉从不在旅馆打听事的荒谬习惯，我年纪很小时就遵循好奇是缺乏教养的表现这一原则。”
en: He sat down with them, and improved their conversation very much.There could be no doubt of his being a sensible man.Ten minutes were enough to certify that.His tone, his expressions, his choice of subject, his knowing where to stop; it was all the operation of a sensible, discerning mind.As soon as he could, he began to talk to her of Lyme, wanting to compare opinions respecting the place, but especially wanting to speak of the circumstance of their happening to be guests in the same inn at the same time; to give his own route, understand something of hers, and regret that he should have lost such an opportunity of paying his respects to her.She gave him a short account of her party and business at Lyme.His regret increased as he listened.He had spent his whole solitary evening in the room adjoining theirs; had heard voices, mirth continually; thought they must be a most delightful set of people, longed to be with them, but certainly without the smallest suspicion of his possessing the shadow of a right to introduce himself.If he had but asked who the party were!The name of Musgrove would have told him enough.“Well, it would serve to cure him of an absurd practice of never asking a question at an inn, which he had adopted, when quite a young man, on the principal of its being very ungenteel to be curious.”

zh: “我想，一个二十一二岁的年轻人，”他说，“对需要具有怎样的风度才能赶上时髦的看法，要比世上其他任何年龄的人都更荒谬。他们常用的方法很愚蠢，而能与这种愚蠢的方法相比拟的是他们愚蠢的想法。”
en: “The notions of a young man of one or two and twenty,” said he, “as to what is necessary in manners to make him quite the thing, are more absurd, I believe, than those of any other set of beings in the world.The folly of the means they often employ is only to be equalled by the folly of what they have in view.”

zh: 但是他知道他不能只跟安妮一个人聊天；他很快便同其他人聊了起来，只是偶尔提一提莱姆。
en: But he must not be addressing his reflections to Anne alone: he knew it; he was soon diffused again among the others, and it was only at intervals that he could return to Lyme.

zh: 不过，他的询问终于促使安妮谈到他离开不久她在莱姆经历的事情。一提起“一次事故”，他就必须得听听原委。当他询问的时候，沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白也开始询问，但是你又不能不感觉到他们询问的方式是不同的。安妮只能把埃利奥特先生同拉塞尔夫人相比，他们都确实想了解到底出了什么事，关心安妮目睹这一事件时受的痛苦。
en: His enquiries, however, produced at length an account of the scene she had been engaged in there, soon after his leaving the place.Having alluded to “an accident,” he must hear the whole.When he questioned, Sir Walter and Elizabeth began to question also, but the difference in their manner of doing it could not be unfelt.She could only compare Mr. Elliot to Lady Russell, in the wish of really comprehending what had passed, and in the degree of concern for what she must have suffered in witnessing it.

zh: 他同他们呆了一个小时。壁炉架上那只精致的小钟“银铃般地敲了十一下，”同时远处也开始传来更夫的同样时辰的报告，这时埃利奥特本人或其他人似乎才感到他已经在这里呆了很长时间。
en: He staid an hour with them.The elegant little clock on the mantel- piece had struck “eleven with its silver sounds,” and the watchman was beginning to be heard at a distance telling the same tale, before Mr. Elliot or any of them seemed to feel that he had been there long.

zh: 安妮事先根本没有想到她在卡姆登巷的第一个晚上会过得这么愉快！
en: Anne could not have supposed it possible that her first evening in Camden Place could have passed so well!

zh: 第十六章
en: CHAPTER 16

zh: 如果安妮回到家后能确信她父亲没有爱上克莱太太，这会比她知道埃利奥特先生爱上了伊丽莎白更加欣慰。可是她在家才几个小时，就对这一点感到很不安。第二天早晨她下楼吃早饭时，就发现克莱太太正客气地假装要离开他们。安妮猜得出，克莱太太肯定是这样说，“现在安妮小姐回来了，我觉得这里就不再需要我了。”因为伊丽莎白正低声说，“这可算不上理由，真的。我向你保证这不是理由。同你想比，安妮对我来说算不了什么。”她父亲说的话，安妮全听到了，“亲爱的太太，千万别走。你在巴斯还没有怎么看看呢。你来这里只顾着帮忙了。你不能现在离开我们。你必须留下来见见沃利斯太太，那位漂亮的沃利斯太太。我知道，对于你这么一个情趣高雅的人，欣赏美貌对你来说是一种真正的满足。”
en: There was one point which Anne, on returning to her family, would have been more thankful to ascertain even than Mr. Elliot’s being in love with Elizabeth, which was, her father’s not being in love with Mrs. Clay; and she was very far from easy about it, when she had been at home a few hours.On going down to breakfast the next morning, she found there had just been a decent pretence on the lady’s side of meaning to leave them.She could imagine Mrs. Clay to have said, that “now Miss Anne was come, she could not suppose herself at all wanted;” for Elizabeth was replying in a sort of whisper, “That must not be any reason, indeed.I assure you I feel it none.She is nothing to me, compared with you;” and she was in full time to hear her father say, “My dear madam, this must not be.As yet, you have seen nothing of Bath.You have been here only to be useful.You must not run away from us now.You must stay to be acquainted with Mrs. Wallis, the beautiful Mrs. Wallis.To your fine mind, I well know the sight of beauty is a real gratification.”

zh: 他说得十分恳切，样子也很诚恳，在看到克莱太太偷偷地向她和伊丽莎白瞥了一眼时，安妮也就不以为奇了。安妮的神色可能显出一点警惕，但是情趣高雅这一赞美似乎却没有引起她姐姐的任何联想。在父女俩如此一致的请求下，克莱太太只好作出让步，答应留下来。
en: He spoke and looked so much in earnest, that Anne was not surprised to see Mrs. Clay stealing a glance at Elizabeth and herself.Her countenance, perhaps, might express some watchfulness; but the praise of the fine mind did not appear to excite a thought in her sister.The lady could not but yield to such joint entreaties, and promise to stay.

zh: 就在同一个上午，安妮偶然同父亲单独呆了一会儿，父亲赞扬她脸色好多了。表扬她“身体和脸颊不再那么消瘦；她的皮肤和脸色大为改观，更加白净、更加鲜嫩了。她是不是在用什么特殊的化妆品？”“没有，什么也没有用。”“只有高兰，”他猜道，“不，什么也没用。”“哈！这就叫我感到奇怪了，”他接着又说，“你能这样保持下去是再好不过了；最好能保持这样的身体状况；不然我就建议你用高兰，在春天最好经常使用高兰。克莱太太在我的建议下一直在用，你可以看到这对她很有好处。你瞧她的雀斑褪掉了好多。”
en: In the course of the same morning, Anne and her father chancing to be alone together, he began to compliment her on her improved looks; he thought her “less thin in her person, in her cheeks; her skin, her complexion, greatly improved; clearer, fresher.Had she been using any thing in particular?”“No, nothing.”“Merely Gowland,” he supposed.“No, nothing at all.” “Ha!he was surprised at that;” and added, “certainly you cannot do better than to continue as you are; you cannot be better than well; or I should recommend Gowland, the constant use of Gowland, during the spring months.Mrs. Clay has been using it at my recommendation, and you see what it has done for her.You see how it has carried away her freckles.”

zh: 要是伊丽莎白能听到这些话就好了！父亲对克莱太太的这种个人赞扬可能会使她警觉起来，尤其是在安妮看来，克莱太太脸上的雀斑根本没有减少。但是一切事情都要碰运气。如果伊丽莎白也要结婚的话，父亲同克莱太太结婚的坏处就会减少很多。至于她自己，她可以永远同拉塞尔夫人住在一起。
en: If Elizabeth could but have heard this!Such personal praise might have struck her, especially as it did not appear to Anne that the freckles were at all lessened.But everything must take its chance.The evil of a marriage would be much diminished, if Elizabeth were also to marry.As for herself, she might always command a home with Lady Russell.

zh: 在同卡姆登巷的交往中，拉塞尔夫人冷静的头脑和彬彬有礼的举止在这个问题上受到了某种考验。她看到克莱太太如此受宠、安妮却遭到如此冷落时，总是很生气。她虽然同所有在巴斯的人一样喝矿泉水、订购新书刊、结识很多人，但一有空，她总是为此事感到烦恼。
en: Lady Russell’s composed mind and polite manners were put to some trial on this point, in her intercourse in Camden Place.The sight of Mrs. Clay in such favour, and of Anne so overlooked, was a perpetual provocation to her there; and vexed her as much when she was away, as a person in Bath who drinks the water, gets all the new publications, and has a very large acquaintance, has time to be vexed.

zh: 拉塞尔夫人结识了埃利奥特之后，她对别人变得更加宽厚了，更加冷淡了。他的举止一下子给她留下了好印象。同他谈话时，她发现他表里完全一致，于是她告诉安妮，起初她差一点惊叫起来：“这会是埃利奥特先生吗？”她简直无法想象会有比他更和气、更值得尊敬的人。他身上综合了一切优点：善解人意、见解精辟、通达世故、为人热心。他有强烈的家族感情和家族荣誉感，既不傲慢也不怯懦；他过着一种富有而慷慨的生活，却不炫耀；他对一切重大问题都有自己的见解，但在世俗礼节方面从不违背公众的舆论。他稳重、机警、温和、坦率；从不因为情绪不好和自私而发脾气，尽管有人认为这是感情强烈的体现。然而他对可亲可爱的事情很敏感，很珍视幸福的家庭生活，自认为热情奔放的人和性格激烈冲动的人很少有这种品质。她确信他的婚姻并不美满。沃利斯上校这么说的，拉塞尔夫人也这么看。但是这种不幸并没有使他变得忧郁，也不影响他考虑第二种选择（这一点拉塞尔夫人很快就猜中了）。她对埃利奥特先生的满意驱散了克莱太太给她带来的所有烦恼。
en: As Mr. Elliot became known to her, she grew more charitable, or more indifferent, towards the others.His manners were an immediate recommendation; and on conversing with him she found the solid so fully supporting the superficial, that she was at first, as she told Anne, almost ready to exclaim, “Can this be Mr. Elliot?” and could not seriously picture to herself a more agreeable or estimable man.Everything united in him; good understanding, correct opinions, knowledge of the world, and a warm heart.He had strong feelings of family attachment and family honour, without pride or weakness; he lived with the liberality of a man of fortune, without display; he judged for himself in everything essential, without defying public opinion in any point of worldly decorum.He was steady, observant, moderate, candid; never run away with by spirits or by selfishness, which fancied itself strong feeling; and yet, with a sensibility to what was amiable and lovely, and a value for all the felicities of domestic life, which characters of fancied enthusiasm and violent agitation seldom really possess.She was sure that he had not been happy in marriage.Colonel Wallis said it, and Lady Russell saw it; but it had been no unhappiness to sour his mind, nor (she began pretty soon to suspect) to prevent his thinking of a second choice.Her satisfaction in Mr. Elliot outweighed all the plague of Mrs. Clay.

zh: 安妮几年前便意识到，她跟她的好朋友也会想法不一样。因此，看到拉塞尔夫人对埃利奥特先生极力寻求和解一事既不感到怀疑又不感到前后矛盾，看到她不去探究表面现象背后还有什么动机，安妮并不感到奇怪。在拉塞尔夫人看来，埃利奥特先生成熟后自然会感到，在所有明智的任务当中，最值得向往、最可取的做法是同一族之长保持良好的关系。这是时间对一个头脑本来清醒的年轻人最简单的影响过程，这种人只有在年轻时才会犯错误。然而安妮还是冒昧地笑了笑，最后提起了“伊丽莎白”。拉塞尔夫人一边听，一边望了她一眼，只是谨慎地回答说：“——伊丽莎白！很好。时间会解释一切的。”
en: It was now some years since Anne had begun to learn that she and her excellent friend could sometimes think differently; and it did not surprise her, therefore, that Lady Russell should see nothing suspicious or inconsistent, nothing to require more motives than appeared, in Mr. Elliot’s great desire of a reconciliation.In Lady Russell’s view, it was perfectly natural that Mr. Elliot, at a mature time of life, should feel it a most desirable object, and what would very generally recommend him among all sensible people, to be on good terms with the head of his family; the simplest process in the world of time upon a head naturally clear, and only erring in the heyday of youth.Anne presumed, however, still to smile about it, and at last to mention “Elizabeth.”Lady Russell listened, and looked, and made only this cautious reply:“—Elizabeth! very well; time will explain.”

zh: 安妮经过一番观察，觉得也只有等到将来，问题才能见分晓。现在她不能得出任何结论。在这家里，伊丽莎白是头号人物；她已经习惯于被人们称为“埃利奥特小姐”，任何过分的亲昵似乎都不可能。还要记住埃利奥特先生丧妻还不到七个月。在这一点上他推迟一点时间还情有可原。事实上，安妮每次看到埃利奥特先生帽子边上的黑纱就担心她对埃利奥特先生的这种想法是不可原谅的。因为虽说他的婚姻并不美满，到底还是维持了那么多年，她无法理解他会很快从婚姻结束这一可怕的经历中恢复过来。
en: It was a reference to the future, which Anne, after a little observation, felt she must submit to.She could determine nothing at present.In that house Elizabeth must be first; and she was in the habit of such general observance as “Miss Elliot,” that any particularity of attention seemed almost impossible.Mr. Elliot, too, it must be remembered, had not been a widower seven months.A little delay on his side might be very excusable.In fact, Anne could never see the crape round his hat, without fearing that she was the inexcusable one, in attributing to him such imaginations; for though his marriage had not been very happy, still it had existed so many years that she could not comprehend a very rapid recovery from the awful impression of its being dissolved.

zh: 不管结果如何，埃利奥特先生无疑是他们在巴斯遇到的最令人愉快的人：安妮没有见到任何可以与他相比的人；不时地同他谈谈莱姆是一种莫大的享受，他似乎也同安妮一样希望再到莱姆看看，更多地了解莱姆。他们多次谈起了初次见面时的细节。他让安妮意识到他曾经以最真诚的目光注视过她。她很熟悉这种目光；但还有另外一个人的目光使她不能忘怀。
en: However it might end, he was without any question their pleasantest acquaintance in Bath: she saw nobody equal to him; and it was a great indulgence now and then to talk to him about Lyme, which he seemed to have as lively a wish to see again, and to see more of, as herself.They went through the particulars of their first meeting a great many times.He gave her to understand that he had looked at her with some earnestness.She knew it well; and she remembered another person’s look also.

zh: 他们的想法并不总是一致的。安妮觉得埃利奥特先生比她更看重地位与社会关系。他热忱地为她父亲和姐姐分担对某一件事的忧虑，不仅仅是出于殷勤，而且他自己也很关心安妮觉得不值得为之大惊小怪的事情。巴斯的报纸有一天早晨刊登了达尔林普尔子爵的遗孀还有她的女儿——尊敬的卡特雷特小姐来到巴斯的消息。于是多少天来，卡姆登巷的轻松气氛被一扫而光；因为达尔林普尔（在安妮看来，这是非常不幸的）是埃利奥特家族的表亲；沃尔特爵士感到伤心的是，不知道该如何合适地去拜访她们。
en: They did not always think alike.His value for rank and connexion she perceived was greater than hers.It was not merely complaisance, it must be a liking to the cause, which made him enter warmly into her father and sister’s solicitudes on a subject which she thought unworthy to excite them.The Bath paper one morning announced the arrival of the Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple, and her daughter, the Honourable Miss Carteret; and all the comfort of No.—, Camden Place, was swept away for many days; for the Dalrymples (in Anne’s opinion, most unfortunately) were cousins of the Elliots; and the agony was how to introduce themselves properly.

zh: 安妮以前从未看到过她父亲和姐姐同贵族交往的情景，她必须承认她有些失望。父亲和姐姐对自己的社会地位看得很高，因此她原指望他们在这方面表现得更为得体一些，现在却降低到她以前从未有过的愿望，希望他们有较强的自尊心。因为她耳朵边整天听到的是“我们的表亲达尔林普尔夫人和卡特雷特小姐”，“我们的表亲达尔林普尔一家”。
en: Anne had never seen her father and sister before in contact with nobility, and she must acknowledge herself disappointed.She had hoped better things from their high ideas of their own situation in life, and was reduced to form a wish which she had never foreseen; a wish that they had more pride; for “our cousins Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret;” “our cousins, the Dalrymples,” sounded in her ears all day long.

zh: 沃尔特爵士同已故子爵见过一次面，但从未见过他家的其他成员；困难在于自从子爵去世后，所有礼节性的通信联系都已经中断，这是因为子爵去世的时候，沃尔特爵士正在生重病，于是很遗憾的是，凯林奇府有所疏忽。他们没往爱尔兰发信吊唁。这种疏忽后来又降临到失礼者的头上；因为可怜的埃利奥特夫人去世时，凯林奇府也没有接到唁函，因而他们完全有理由认为，达尔林普尔一家觉得他们的关系早已结束。现在的问题是如何纠正这一令人忧心的误会，使对方再承认他们是表亲关系。拉塞尔夫人和埃利奥特先生虽然表现得更为理智，但是并不认为这个问题不重要。“亲戚关系总是值得维持的，好的伴侣总是值得寻找的；达尔林普尔夫人在劳拉巷租了一幢房子，为期三个月，生活上十分讲排场。上一年她来过巴斯，拉塞尔夫人听说她是一位非常迷人的夫人。如果可能，最好是既不损害埃利奥特家族的尊严，又能恢复亲戚关系。”
en: Sir Walter had once been in company with the late viscount, but had never seen any of the rest of the family; and the difficulties of the case arose from there having been a suspension of all intercourse by letters of ceremony, ever since the death of that said late viscount, when, in consequence of a dangerous illness of Sir Walter’s at the same time, there had been an unlucky omission at Kellynch.No letter of condolence had been sent to Ireland.The neglect had been visited on the head of the sinner; for when poor Lady Elliot died herself, no letter of condolence was received at Kellynch, and, consequently, there was but too much reason to apprehend that the Dalrymples considered the relationship as closed.How to have this anxious business set to rights, and be admitted as cousins again, was the question: and it was a question which, in a more rational manner, neither Lady Russell nor Mr. Elliot thought unimportant.“Family connexions were always worth preserving, good company always worth seeking; Lady Dalrymple had taken a house, for three months, in Laura Place, and would be living in style.She had been at Bath the year before, and Lady Russell had heard her spoken of as a charming woman.It was very desirable that the connexion should be renewed, if it could be done, without any compromise of propriety on the side of the Elliots.”

zh: 不过，沃尔特爵士要选择自己的办法，最后他写了一封非常客气的信，向他尊贵的表亲做了大量解释，表示了遗憾和恳求。拉塞尔夫人和埃利奥特先生都不看好这封信；但是它却达到了预期的目的，他们接到了子爵夫人草草两三行的回信。“甚感荣幸，很乐意同你们见面。”难关渡过了，甜头开始了。他们到劳拉巷登门拜访，又把达尔林普尔子爵夫人和尊敬的卡特雷特小姐的名片摆到最显眼的地方，逢人便说“我们在劳拉巷的表亲”——“我们的表亲达尔林普尔夫人和卡特雷特小姐”。
en: Sir Walter, however, would choose his own means, and at last wrote a very fine letter of ample explanation, regret, and entreaty, to his right honourable cousin.Neither Lady Russell nor Mr. Elliot could admire the letter; but it did all that was wanted, in bringing three lines of scrawl from the Dowager Viscountess.“She was very much honoured, and should be happy in their acquaintance.”The toils of the business were over, the sweets began.They visited in Laura Place, they had the cards of Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple, and the Honourable Miss Carteret, to be arranged wherever they might be most visible: and “Our cousins in Laura Place,”—“Our cousin, Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret,” were talked of to everybody.

zh: 安妮感到羞愧。即使子爵夫人和她的女儿亲切和蔼，她也会为她们引起的骚动感到羞愧，何况她们没有什么了不起的。无论是风度、修养或是洞察力都没有出众的地方。达尔林普尔夫人之所以获得“一位迷人女人”的称号，是因为她总是笑容可掬，回起话来都礼貌周到。卡特雷特小姐更谈不上了，她相貌平平，行动笨拙，若不是因为出身高贵，卡姆登巷的人决不会容忍她的。
en: Anne was ashamed.Had Lady Dalrymple and her daughter even been very agreeable, she would still have been ashamed of the agitation they created, but they were nothing.There was no superiority of manner, accomplishment, or understanding.Lady Dalrymple had acquired the name of “a charming woman,” because she had a smile and a civil answer for everybody.Miss Carteret, with still less to say, was so plain and so awkward, that she would never have been tolerated in Camden Place but for her birth.

zh: 拉塞尔夫人承认她原本以为情况会好一些。不过，“她们还是值得相识”，安妮大胆地向埃利奥特先生谈了她对她们两个人的看法，他认为她们本身并不出众，但是他仍然认为，她们作为亲戚，作为愉快的朋友以及能够在其周围汇集一群好伙伴，她们自有其价值。安妮笑着说道：
en: Lady Russell confessed she had expected something better; but yet “it was an acquaintance worth having;” and when Anne ventured to speak her opinion of them to Mr. Elliot, he agreed to their being nothing in themselves, but still maintained that, as a family connexion, as good company, as those who would collect good company around them, they had their value.Anne smiled and said,

zh: “我认为，好朋友埃利奥特先生应该是聪明、见多识广、话题丰富的人，这才是我所认为的愉快的合作伙伴。”
en: “My idea of good company, Mr. Elliot, is the company of clever, well-informed people, who have a great deal of conversation; that is what I call good company.”

zh: “你错了，”他温柔地说道，“那不是愉快的朋友，而是最愉快的朋友。愉快的朋友要求出身高贵、有教养和举止优雅，受教育程度如何还不是非常重要。出身高贵和举止优雅却必不可少；但是有点知识对愉快的朋友来说不是危险的事情，相反倒很有好处。我的堂妹安妮摇头了。她不满意。她太挑剔了。亲爱的堂妹啊，”（坐到她身边），“你比我认识的任何姑娘都有权挑剔，可是这有什么用呢？能使你感到高兴吗？同劳拉的这些女士交往，尽可能地利用这种交往，不是更聪明一些吗？你相信我好了，她们今年冬天肯定会成为巴斯的第一流人物，社会地位就是社会地位。人们知道你们是她们的亲戚，这就有利于你们一家（应该说我们一家）确立大家都希望的重要地位。”
en: “You are mistaken,” said he gently, “that is not good company; that is the best.Good company requires only birth, education, and manners, and with regard to education is not very nice.Birth and good manners are essential; but a little learning is by no means a dangerous thing in good company; on the contrary, it will do very well.My cousin Anne shakes her head.She is not satisfied.She is fastidious.My dear cousin” (sitting down by her), “you have a better right to be fastidious than almost any other woman I know; but will it answer?Will it make you happy?Will it not be wiser to accept the society of those good ladies in Laura Place, and enjoy all the advantages of the connexion as far as possible?You may depend upon it, that they will move in the first set in Bath this winter, and as rank is rank, your being known to be related to them will have its use in fixing your family (our family let me say) in that degree of consideration which we must all wish for.”

zh: “是啊，”安妮叹气道，“人们确实会知道我们是她们的亲戚！”她突然想起来了，不想听到回答，因此她又接着说下去，“我的确认为为了获得这个交往，花费的力气太多了。我想，”（她微微一笑），“我的自尊心比你们哪一个都强。但是我承认，我们如此热切地要她们承认这种关系，的确让我很生气，而我们完全可以肯定，她们对这种关系完全不在乎。”
en: “Yes,” sighed Anne, “we shall, indeed, be known to be related to them!” then recollecting herself, and not wishing to be answered, she added, “I certainly do think there has been by far too much trouble taken to procure the acquaintance.I suppose” (smiling) “I have more pride than any of you; but I confess it does vex me, that we should be so solicitous to have the relationship acknowledged, which we may be very sure is a matter of perfect indifference to them.”

zh: “请原谅我，亲爱的堂妹，你小看了你们自己拥有的权利。也许在伦敦，按照你们目前安静的生活方式，情况或许会像你说得那样。但是在巴斯，沃尔特•埃利奥特爵士和他的一家总是值得结识，总是被认作相识的人。”
en: “Pardon me, dear cousin, you are unjust in your own claims.In London, perhaps, in your present quiet style of living, it might be as you say: but in Bath; Sir Walter Elliot and his family will always be worth knowing: always acceptable as acquaintance.”

zh: “好吧，”安妮说道，“我当然非常骄傲，骄傲到无法赏识那种完全取决于所处环境的受人欢迎方式。”
en: “Well,” said Anne, “I certainly am proud, too proud to enjoy a welcome which depends so entirely upon place.”

zh: “我喜欢你的气愤，”他说，“这很自然。但是你这是在巴斯，目的是要在这里定居，建立应该属于沃尔特•埃利奥特爵士的荣誉和尊严。你谈到了你很骄傲，我知道，人们也说我骄傲，而我也不希望自己并非如此；因为要是研究一下我们的骄傲，它们的目的是相同的，这一点我毫无疑问，虽然说似乎有点差别。有一点我敢肯定，我亲爱的堂妹，”（他继续说道，压低了声音，虽然房间里没有别的人），“有一点我敢肯定，我们肯定会有同感。我们一定会感到，如果你父亲的亲友中增加一位与他地位平等或地位高于他的人，也许有利于把他的心思从身份较低的人身上转移开去。”
en: “I love your indignation,” said he; “it is very natural.But here you are in Bath, and the object is to be established here with all the credit and dignity which ought to belong to Sir Walter Elliot.You talk of being proud; I am called proud, I know, and I shall not wish to believe myself otherwise; for our pride, if investigated, would have the same object, I have no doubt, though the kind may seem a little different.In one point, I am sure, my dear cousin,” (he continued, speaking lower, though there was no one else in the room) “in one point, I am sure, we must feel alike.We must feel that every addition to your father’s society, among his equals or superiors, may be of use in diverting his thoughts from those who are beneath him.”

zh: 他说话时朝克莱太太刚刚坐过的位子上瞥了一眼，这就充分表明他那句话的含义。虽然安妮不相信他们有着同样的自豪感，但是她却仍为埃利奥特先生不喜欢克莱太太而感到高兴。安妮凭着良心承认，他之所以希望鼓励她父亲结识一些显贵的人既然是为了打败克莱太太，因此也就完全可以谅解。
en: He looked, as he spoke, to the seat which Mrs. Clay had been lately occupying: a sufficient explanation of what he particularly meant; and though Anne could not believe in their having the same sort of pride, she was pleased with him for not liking Mrs. Clay; and her conscience admitted that his wishing to promote her father’s getting great acquaintance was more than excusable in the view of defeating her.

zh: 第十七章
en: CHAPTER 17

zh: 当沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白在劳拉巷拼命地推进他们的好运的时候，安妮正在与一位气质迥异的故友重叙友情。
en: While Sir Walter and Elizabeth were assiduously pushing their good fortune in Laura Place, Anne was renewing an acquaintance of a very different description.

zh: 她拜访了以前的老师，从她那里得知她有一位老同学住在巴斯，这位同学有两点很值得安妮关注，一是过去她对安妮很友好，二是她现在生活很悲惨。她原是汉密尔顿小姐，现在是史密斯夫人，曾在安妮一生中最需要帮助的时刻给了她友谊。那时安妮闷闷不乐地去上学，她为失去自己深爱的母亲而非常悲痛，又为离开家而难过，这对于一个十分敏感而又情绪低落的14岁小姑娘来说，在这种时刻一定会感到悲痛。汉密尔顿比她大三岁，由于没有近亲和固定的住所，所以还得在学校再呆上一年。她处处帮助安妮，对她十分体贴，大大减轻了安妮的痛苦，安妮每次想起这件事情就觉得十分感动。
en: She had called on her former governess, and had heard from her of there being an old school-fellow in Bath, who had the two strong claims on her attention of past kindness and present suffering.Miss Hamilton, now Mrs. Smith, had shewn her kindness in one of those periods of her life when it had been most valuable.Anne had gone unhappy to school, grieving for the loss of a mother whom she had dearly loved, feeling her separation from home, and suffering as a girl of fourteen, of strong sensibility and not high spirits, must suffer at such a time; and Miss Hamilton, three years older than herself, but still from the want of near relations and a settled home, remaining another year at school, had been useful and good to her in a way which had considerably lessened her misery, and could never be remembered with indifference.

zh: 汉密尔顿小姐离开学校后不久就结婚了，据说嫁给了一个有钱人，这就是安妮以前所知道的她的一切情况，现在她们的老师对她的情况作了比较确切的介绍，但是却与安妮听说的大为不同。
en: Miss Hamilton had left school, had married not long afterwards, was said to have married a man of fortune, and this was all that Anne had known of her, till now that their governess’s account brought her situation forward in a more decided but very different form.

zh: 她是个穷寡妇。她的丈夫一向挥霍成性，在大约两年前去世时，家境已经被他搞得一塌糊涂了。她既要应付种种困难，除了这些烦恼之外，她又得了严重的风湿病，结果影响了双腿，以致于现在成了瘸子。她正是为了治病来到了巴斯，现在住在温泉浴室附近的出租房间里，日子过得十分拮据，甚至连雇个佣人这么点享受也没有，当然也几乎是与世隔绝的。
en: She was a widow and poor.Her husband had been extravagant; and at his death, about two years before, had left his affairs dreadfully involved.She had had difficulties of every sort to contend with, and in addition to these distresses had been afflicted with a severe rheumatic fever, which, finally settling in her legs, had made her for the present a cripple.She had come to Bath on that account, and was now in lodgings near the hot baths, living in a very humble way, unable even to afford herself the comfort of a servant, and of course almost excluded from society.

zh: 她们的女老师相信，埃利奥特小姐的探望一定会使史密斯太太感到愉快，因此安妮立即前去探望。她回到家，没有提起她听到些什么，也没有提起她要出去干什么。在那里，这不会引起应有的兴趣。她只是和拉塞尔夫人商量了一下，拉塞尔夫人完全体谅她的心情，很高兴照她的意愿并将她送到史密斯太太住所附近的西门大楼。
en: Their mutual friend answered for the satisfaction which a visit from Miss Elliot would give Mrs. Smith, and Anne therefore lost no time in going.She mentioned nothing of what she had heard, or what she intended, at home.It would excite no proper interest there.She only consulted Lady Russell, who entered thoroughly into her sentiments, and was most happy to convey her as near to Mrs. Smith’s lodgings in Westgate Buildings, as Anne chose to be taken.

zh: 安妮去看望了史密斯太太，她们又重新恢复了交往，相互间的感情不仅重新燃起而且更加增进了。见面后的十分钟内，双方都有些尴尬和激动。她们阔别了12年，各自的形象同留在彼此脑海中的记忆有点不同了。12年的时光，安妮从一个充满青春活力、文静而又未发育完成的15岁少女变成了一位27岁的优雅可爱的女人，她面容美丽，只是不再年轻，举止谨慎得体，又总是很温柔。12年的时光，汉密尔顿从一个漂亮、发育良好、身体健康、对年长者的优越感充满信心的姑娘变成了一个贫穷、体弱、无助的寡妇，因此她把旧日受她保护的人的来访看作一种恩赐。但是这次会面中的尴尬气氛很快就过去了，留下来的只是对以往个人癖好的回忆和对流逝时光的畅谈带来的令人陶醉的温馨。
en: The visit was paid, their acquaintance re-established, their interest in each other more than re-kindled.The first ten minutes had its awkwardness and its emotion.Twelve years were gone since they had parted, and each presented a somewhat different person from what the other had imagined.Twelve years had changed Anne from the blooming, silent, unformed girl of fifteen, to the elegant little woman of seven-and-twenty, with every beauty except bloom, and with manners as consciously right as they were invariably gentle; and twelve years had transformed the fine-looking, well-grown Miss Hamilton, in all the glow of health and confidence of superiority, into a poor, infirm, helpless widow, receiving the visit of her former protegee as a favour; but all that was uncomfortable in the meeting had soon passed away, and left only the interesting charm of remembering former partialities and talking over old times.

zh: 安妮发现史密斯太太还跟过去几乎完全得到她信赖时一样通情达理，态度和蔼，而她喜欢交谈和开朗的性情则出乎安妮的意料。无论是过去的放荡——她的确历尽了沧桑——还是现有的节制，无论是疾病还是悲伤，看起来都没有使她变得性格内向或意志消沉。
en: Anne found in Mrs. Smith the good sense and agreeable manners which she had almost ventured to depend on, and a disposition to converse and be cheerful beyond her expectation.Neither the dissipations of the past—and she had lived very much in the world—nor the restrictions of the present, neither sickness nor sorrow seemed to have closed her heart or ruined her spirits.

zh: 第二次来访时，她谈得非常坦率，安妮也越发感到惊讶。她很难想象比史密斯太太更为凄凉的处境了。她非常爱她的丈夫：而他先她而去了。她过惯了富裕的生活：可是这一切都没有了。她没有孩子将她与生活和幸福再次联系起来，没有亲戚能帮她料理纷乱的家务事，她病弱的身体又使她难以支撑今后的生活。她的住处仅仅是一间嘈杂的客厅和后面一间昏暗的卧室，如果没有人搀扶，她还无法从一个房间走到另一个房间，整个房子里只有一个仆人可供使唤，因此除了让佣人把她送去温泉洗浴外，她从不出门。然而尽管如此，安妮有理由相信，史密斯太太的烦恼和消沉是短暂的，而忙碌和愉快却是长时间的。这怎么可能呢？安妮看着、观察着、思考着。她最后得出结论：这不仅仅是个性坚强或听天由命。逆来顺受者可能善于忍耐，深刻的理解力能使人表现果敢，但是史密斯太太还不止这些。她心理承受能力强，易于使自己得到慰藉，她能快速地将坏事变成好事，只要有事可做，便能从烦恼中解脱出来，这完全出于本性。这是上天给她最好的礼物；安妮认为她的朋友属于这样一种情况，上天仁慈的安排，几乎能抵消所有的缺陷。
en: In the course of a second visit she talked with great openness, and Anne’s astonishment increased.She could scarcely imagine a more cheerless situation in itself than Mrs. Smith’s.She had been very fond of her husband: she had buried him.She had been used to affluence: it was gone.She had no child to connect her with life and happiness again, no relations to assist in the arrangement of perplexed affairs, no health to make all the rest supportable.Her accommodations were limited to a noisy parlour, and a dark bedroom behind, with no possibility of moving from one to the other without assistance, which there was only one servant in the house to afford, and she never quitted the house but to be conveyed into the warm bath.Yet, in spite of all this, Anne had reason to believe that she had moments only of languor and depression, to hours of occupation and enjoyment.How could it be?She watched, observed, reflected, and finally determined that this was not a case of fortitude or of resignation only.A submissive spirit might be patient, a strong understanding would supply resolution, but here was something more; here was that elasticity of mind, that disposition to be comforted, that power of turning readily from evil to good, and of finding employment which carried her out of herself, which was from nature alone.It was the choicest gift of Heaven; and Anne viewed her friend as one of those instances in which, by a merciful appointment, it seems designed to counterbalance almost every other want.

zh: 史密斯太太告诉她，有一段时间她几乎完全失去了勇气。同刚到巴斯相比，她现在已经不认为自己是一个残废人了。那时她的确是一个可怜虫。她在路上受了凉，刚找到住所的时候，又卧床不起，她忍受着持续不断的严重病痛。那时她周围全是陌生人，她急需一名正式护士，而她的手头特别拮据，根本无法支付额外的开支。然而，她已经挺过来了，可以真心诚意地说，当时那种处境对她有好处。她感觉到自己遇到了好人，就越发感到宽慰。她见过的世面太多了，所以根本没想到会在某个地方突然遇见无私的友情，但是这次生病使她意识到，房东太太为了维护自己的人格，不会欺侮她。特别幸运的是，她遇到了一位好护士，这位职业护士是房东的妹妹，当她没活干的时候，她总是呆在姐姐家里，而当时正好闲着，可以及时地照顾她。“她呀，”史密斯太太说道，“不仅悉心地照顾我，实际上已经成为我一个非常珍贵的朋友。我的手刚能动弹，她就教我织毛衣，这给我带来了很大的乐趣。她还教我做小针袋、针垫和卡架，你看见我总是忙这些小玩意，这样就使我能够帮助临近的一两家十分贫穷的家庭。她有一大帮朋友，当然是由于职业的关系，他们都买得起这些小玩意，因此她就负责推销我的这些货物。她总是能找到合适的时机去推销。你知道，当人们刚摆脱严重病痛，或者正在幸福地恢复健康，每个人的心扉总是敞开的，鲁克护士完全懂得何时开口。她是一个精明、机智、通情达理的女人。她的行业有利于看透人的本性。她富有理性、善于观察，作为伴侣，她比成千上万只受过‘世界上最好的教育’，却不知道什么事情值得做的人强得多。如果你愿意，就当我们是聊天吧，但是只要鲁克护士有半小时的空闲时间，她就会对我说一些有趣而且有益的事情：一些使我能更好地了解同类的事情。人们都想听听周围的事情，熟悉一下人们表现无聊和愚蠢的最新方式。对于我这种孤苦伶仃的人来说，我向你保证，她的谈话是一种乐趣。”
en: There had been a time, Mrs. Smith told her, when her spirits had nearly failed.She could not call herself an invalid now, compared with her state on first reaching Bath.Then she had, indeed, been a pitiable object; for she had caught cold on the journey, and had hardly taken possession of her lodgings before she was again confined to her bed and suffering under severe and constant pain; and all this among strangers, with the absolute necessity of having a regular nurse, and finances at that moment particularly unfit to meet any extraordinary expense.She had weathered it, however, and could truly say that it had done her good.It had increased her comforts by making her feel herself to be in good hands.She had seen too much of the world, to expect sudden or disinterested attachment anywhere, but her illness had proved to her that her landlady had a character to preserve, and would not use her ill; and she had been particularly fortunate in her nurse, as a sister of her landlady, a nurse by profession, and who had always a home in that house when unemployed, chanced to be at liberty just in time to attend her.“And she,” said Mrs. Smith, “besides nursing me most admirably, has really proved an invaluable acquaintance.As soon as I could use my hands she taught me to knit, which has been a great amusement; and she put me in the way of making these little thread-cases, pin-cushions and card-racks, which you always find me so busy about, and which supply me with the means of doing a little good to one or two very poor families in this neighbourhood.She had a large acquaintance, of course professionally, among those who can afford to buy, and she disposes of my merchandise.She always takes the right time for applying.Everybody’s heart is open, you know, when they have recently escaped from severe pain, or are recovering the blessing of health, and Nurse Rooke thoroughly understands when to speak.She is a shrewd, intelligent, sensible woman.Hers is a line for seeing human nature; and she has a fund of good sense and observation, which, as a companion, make her infinitely superior to thousands of those who having only received ‘the best education in the world,’ know nothing worth attending to.Call it gossip, if you will, but when Nurse Rooke has half an hour’s leisure to bestow on me, she is sure to have something to relate that is entertaining and profitable: something that makes one know one’s species better.One likes to hear what is going on, to be au fait as to the newest modes of being trifling and silly.To me, who live so much alone, her conversation, I assure you, is a treat.”

zh: 安妮不想对这种乐趣吹毛求疵，回答道：“我完全相信这一点。那个阶层的女子有很多机会理解生活，如果她们聪明的话，那倒可能很值得听她们说说。她们见到的人性真是形形色色！她们明白的不仅仅是人性的愚蠢；因为她们偶尔也能在任何场所见到人性中极有趣、极感人的一面。她们一定见过不少热忱、无私、克制的情感，英勇、坚强、忍耐、听天由命的情感，以及种种使我们变得高尚的冲突和牺牲。一间病室常常能提供写出几部有价值的书的素材。”
en: Anne, far from wishing to cavil at the pleasure, replied, “I can easily believe it.Women of that class have great opportunities, and if they are intelligent may be well worth listening to.Such varieties of human nature as they are in the habit of witnessing!And it is not merely in its follies, that they are well read; for they see it occasionally under every circumstance that can be most interesting or affecting.What instances must pass before them of ardent, disinterested, self-denying attachment, of heroism, fortitude, patience, resignation: of all the conflicts and all the sacrifices that ennoble us most.A sick chamber may often furnish the worth of volumes.”

zh: “是的，”史密斯太太比较迟疑地说道，“有时会这样，不过恐怕这里的教育并不总像你描述的那样振奋。有时面对考验，人的本性可能会显得很伟大；但是一般来说，在病室里的人表现出来的是人性的软弱而不是人性的坚强。人们听到的是自私和焦躁，而不是宽容与刚毅。在这个世界上，真正的友谊太少了！不幸的是，”（低沉而颤抖地说）“等许多人要认认真真地思考一番时，已经为时太晚了。”
en: “Yes,” said Mrs. Smith more doubtingly, “sometimes it may, though I fear its lessons are not often in the elevated style you describe.Here and there, human nature may be great in times of trial; but generally speaking, it is its weakness and not its strength that appears in a sick chamber: it is selfishness and impatience rather than generosity and fortitude, that one hears of.There is so little real friendship in the world! and unfortunately” (speaking low and tremulously) “there are so many who forget to think seriously till it is almost too late.”

zh: 安妮懂得这种痛苦的感受。做丈夫的不成器，做妻子的便不得不生活在那样一群人中间，这就使她觉得世界比她想象得要糟糕得多。不过，对史密斯太太来说，这只不过是转瞬即逝的情绪。她摆脱了这种情绪，很快用一种不同的语气接着说道：
en: Anne saw the misery of such feelings.The husband had not been what he ought, and the wife had been led among that part of mankind which made her think worse of the world than she hoped it deserved.It was but a passing emotion however with Mrs. Smith; she shook it off, and soon added in a different tone—

zh: “我觉得我的朋友鲁克太太现在的处境，既不能给我提供有趣的事情也不能启发我。她只是在护理莫尔伯勒大厦的沃利斯太太。我觉得她只不过是一个时髦漂亮、挥霍无度的愚蠢女人。当然，她除了蕾丝和华美的服饰之外，没有什么可说的。我倒想从沃利斯太太身上捞点油水。她有的是钱，我打算让她把我现在手头上的所有高价东西全都买去。”
en: “I do not suppose the situation my friend Mrs. Rooke is in at present, will furnish much either to interest or edify me.She is only nursing Mrs. Wallis of Marlborough Buildings; a mere pretty, silly, expensive, fashionable woman, I believe; and of course will have nothing to report but of lace and finery.I mean to make my profit of Mrs. Wallis, however.She has plenty of money, and I intend she shall buy all the high-priced things I have in hand now.”

zh: 安妮去看望了她的朋友几次之后，卡姆登巷的人才知道有这么一个人。终于，他们不得不说起她了。一天上午，沃尔特爵士、伊丽莎白和克莱太太从劳拉巷回到家里，突然接到达尔林普尔夫人的邀请，请他们当晚去做客，可是安妮早已有约，当晚要去西门大厦。她并不为自己去不成感到抱歉。她肯定，他们之所以受到邀请是因为达尔林普尔夫人得了重感冒，没法出门，所以便想利用这一门攀上来的亲戚。安妮满怀高兴地谢绝了——“我已跟一个老同学约好今晚去陪她。”他们对安妮的事情并不怎么感兴趣，但是还是提了不少问题，想了解这位老同学到底是什么样的人。伊丽莎白大为蔑视，而沃尔特爵士则很严厉。
en: Anne had called several times on her friend, before the existence of such a person was known in Camden Place.At last, it became necessary to speak of her.Sir Walter, Elizabeth and Mrs. Clay, returned one morning from Laura Place, with a sudden invitation from Lady Dalrymple for the same evening, and Anne was already engaged, to spend that evening in Westgate Buildings.She was not sorry for the excuse.They were only asked, she was sure, because Lady Dalrymple being kept at home by a bad cold, was glad to make use of the relationship which had been so pressed on her; and she declined on her own account with great alacrity—“She was engaged to spend the evening with an old schoolfellow.”They were not much interested in anything relative to Anne; but still there were questions enough asked, to make it understood what this old schoolfellow was; and Elizabeth was disdainful, and Sir Walter severe.

zh: “西门大楼！”他说道，“安妮•埃利奥特小姐要去西门大楼看望谁啊？一位史密斯太太。一位守寡的史密斯太太，她的丈夫是谁呢？到处可遇见的五千个史密斯太太中的一个。她有什么魅力？她又老又多病。说真的，安妮•埃利奥特小姐，你的情趣还真特别啊！别人所厌恶的一切：低贱的朋友、简陋的房间、恶臭的空气、令人厌恶的关系，这些对你却颇有吸引力。不过，你当然可以推迟到明天再去看望这一位老太太。我想，她还有希望再活一天。她多大年纪了？40了？”
en: “Westgate Buildings!” said he, “and who is Miss Anne Elliot to be visiting in Westgate Buildings?A Mrs. Smith.A widow Mrs. Smith; and who was her husband?One of five thousand Mr. Smiths whose names are to be met with everywhere.And what is her attraction?That she is old and sickly.Upon my word, Miss Anne Elliot, you have the most extraordinary taste!Everything that revolts other people, low company, paltry rooms, foul air, disgusting associations are inviting to you.But surely you may put off this old lady till to-morrow: she is not so near her end, I presume, but that she may hope to see another day.What is her age?Forty?”

zh: “不，父亲，她还不到31岁，不过我想我的约会不能往后推，因为最近只有这一个晚上对她和我都合适。她明天就去洗温泉浴了，你知道，这一周剩余的时间我们都没有空。”
en: “No, sir, she is not one-and-thirty; but I do not think I can put off my engagement, because it is the only evening for some time which will at once suit her and myself.She goes into the warm bath to-morrow, and for the rest of the week, you know, we are engaged.”

zh: “不过，拉塞尔夫人对这种交往有什么看法？”伊丽莎白问道。
en: “But what does Lady Russell think of this acquaintance?” asked Elizabeth.

zh: “她认为没有什么可指责的，”安妮回答道，“相反，她还支持。在我去看望史密斯太太的时候，通常她还会送我过去。
en: “She sees nothing to blame in it,” replied Anne; “on the contrary, she approves it, and has generally taken me when I have called on Mrs. Smith.”

zh: “西门大厦的人见到一辆马车停在人行道附近，一定会大为惊讶，”沃尔特爵士说道，“的确，亨利•拉塞尔爵士的遗孀没有什么荣誉来炫耀她的徽章，不过那马车还是很漂亮的，毫无疑问，它是送一位埃利奥特小姐过来的。一位寡妇史密斯太太，住在西门大厦！一位三四十岁，勉强能活下来的可怜寡妇；一个普普通通的史密斯太太，一个平平常常的史密斯太太，安妮•埃利奥特小姐在世界上这么多人，这么多名门中就选中她做朋友，看得比她家在英格兰和爱尔兰的贵族亲戚还要重要！史密斯太太！就这么一个姓！”
en: “Westgate Buildings must have been rather surprised by the appearance of a carriage drawn up near its pavement,” observed Sir Walter.“Sir Henry Russell’s widow, indeed, has no honours to distinguish her arms, but still it is a handsome equipage, and no doubt is well known to convey a Miss Elliot.A widow Mrs. Smith lodging in Westgate Buildings!A poor widow barely able to live, between thirty and forty; a mere Mrs. Smith, an every-day Mrs. Smith, of all people and all names in the world, to be the chosen friend of Miss Anne Elliot, and to be preferred by her to her own family connections among the nobility of England and Ireland!Mrs. Smith!Such a name!”

zh: 他们说话的时候，克莱太太一直在场，现在觉得还是离开这间屋子好，安妮本来可以说很多话的，也确实想为她的朋友辩解几句，说她的朋友与他们的朋友没有什么差别，但是出于对父亲个人的尊重，她没有这么做。她没有回答。她让他父亲自己去想一想，史密斯太太不是巴斯唯一的年龄在30岁到40岁之间，没有多少钱养活自己，又不是出身名门的寡妇。
en: Mrs. Clay, who had been present while all this passed, now thought it advisable to leave the room, and Anne could have said much, and did long to say a little in defence of her friend’s not very dissimilar claims to theirs, but her sense of personal respect to her father prevented her.She made no reply.She left it to himself to recollect, that Mrs. Smith was not the only widow in Bath between thirty and forty, with little to live on, and no surname of dignity.

zh: 安妮去赴自己的约会，其他人去赴他们的约会。当然，第二天早晨，她听说他们度过了一个愉快的晚上。她是这一群人中唯一缺席的，因为沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白不仅本人为夫人阁下效劳，还高高兴兴地奉命为她邀集了其他人，费了好大力气去邀请拉塞尔夫人和埃利奥特先生。埃利奥特先生因此决定早点离开沃利斯上校，而拉塞尔夫人更是重新安排了她晚上所有的约会，以便能够拜访子爵夫人。安妮从拉塞尔夫人那里听来了关于这个晚上的全部情况。对她来说，最使她感兴趣的是，她的朋友和埃利奥特先生没少谈论她。他们希望她在场，为她感到惋惜，同时又为她去看望史密斯太太而不出席晚会而感到钦佩。安妮对这位疾病缠身、家道中落的老同学的亲切而富有同情心的看望似乎使埃利奥特先生感到很高兴。他认为她是一个与众不同的年轻女士。无论是性情、举止还是心灵，都是优秀女性的典范。他对安妮优点的谈论甚至还能使拉塞尔夫人感到满意。要不是拉塞尔夫人有意要引出这么多有趣的话题，安妮是不会了解这么多情况的，也不会知道她受到一位明智人这么高的评价。
en: Anne kept her appointment; the others kept theirs, and of course she heard the next morning that they had had a delightful evening.She had been the only one of the set absent, for Sir Walter and Elizabeth had not only been quite at her ladyship’s service themselves, but had actually been happy to be employed by her in collecting others, and had been at the trouble of inviting both Lady Russell and Mr. Elliot; and Mr. Elliot had made a point of leaving Colonel Wallis early, and Lady Russell had fresh arranged all her evening engagements in order to wait on her.Anne had the whole history of all that such an evening could supply from Lady Russell.To her, its greatest interest must be, in having been very much talked of between her friend and Mr. Elliot; in having been wished for, regretted, and at the same time honoured for staying away in such a cause.Her kind, compassionate visits to this old schoolfellow, sick and reduced, seemed to have quite delighted Mr. Elliot.He thought her a most extraordinary young woman; in her temper, manners, mind, a model of female excellence.He could meet even Lady Russell in a discussion of her merits; and Anne could not be given to understand so much by her friend, could not know herself to be so highly rated by a sensible man, without many of those agreeable sensations which her friend meant to create.

zh: 现在，拉塞尔夫人已经对埃利奥特先生形成了明确的看法。她相信，他一定会娶安妮为妻的，而且他也完全配得上她。她开始算计，看看要多少个星期他才能从丧妻这一束缚中摆脱出来，才能公开地施展他取悦于人的高超本领。她不愿意在事情只有一半把握时就对安妮说，她只肯稍微暗示一下以后会发生什么事情，埃利奥特先生这边可能会产生感情，如果这份感情是真心实意的，而且也得到了对方的回应的话，这样的结合倒是很美满。安妮听了以后，没有表示强烈的惊讶；她只是笑了笑，红着脸，轻轻地摇了摇头。
en: Lady Russell was now perfectly decided in her opinion of Mr. Elliot.She was as much convinced of his meaning to gain Anne in time as of his deserving her, and was beginning to calculate the number of weeks which would free him from all the remaining restraints of widowhood, and leave him at liberty to exert his most open powers of pleasing.She would not speak to Anne with half the certainty she felt on the subject, she would venture on little more than hints of what might be hereafter, of a possible attachment on his side, of the desirableness of the alliance, supposing such attachment to be real and returned.Anne heard her, and made no violent exclamations; she only smiled, blushed, and gently shook her head.

zh: “你很清楚，我绝不是一个媒人，”拉塞尔夫人说，“因为我深知人事多变，难以预测。我只是想说，万一埃利奥特先生有朝一日向你求婚，你也愿意答应他的请求，我认为你们完全可以幸福地生活在一起。人人都会觉得这是一门最合适的结合，而我则认为，这是最幸福的结合。”
en: “I am no match-maker, as you well know,” said Lady Russell, “being much too well aware of the uncertainty of all human events and calculations.I only mean that if Mr. Elliot should some time hence pay his addresses to you, and if you should be disposed to accept him, I think there would be every possibility of your being happy together.A most suitable connection everybody must consider it, but I think it might be a very happy one.”

zh: “埃利奥特先生是一位极其讨人喜欢的人，在很多方面我都很赞赏他，”安妮说道，“但是，我们可能不合适。”
en: “Mr. Elliot is an exceedingly agreeable man, and in many respects I think highly of him,” said Anne; “but we should not suit.”

zh: 拉塞尔夫人对这话并没有发表意见，只是回答说：“我承认如果能把你看作凯林奇未来的女主人，未来的埃利奥特夫人，能期望看到你能拥有你亲爱的母亲的地位，继承她的所有权利、声望与美德，对我将是莫大的满足。你的容貌和性情与你母亲一样，要是我能看到你能同她一样，有地位、有名誉、有家庭，在同一个地方主持家务并且赐福于人，而且比她更受尊重！那么我亲爱的安妮，那将会给我带来在我这个年纪不常感受到的快乐！”
en: Lady Russell let this pass, and only said in rejoinder, “I own that to be able to regard you as the future mistress of Kellynch, the future Lady Elliot, to look forward and see you occupying your dear mother’s place, succeeding to all her rights, and all her popularity, as well as to all her virtues, would be the highest possible gratification to me.You are your mother’s self in countenance and disposition; and if I might be allowed to fancy you such as she was, in situation and name, and home, presiding and blessing in the same spot, and only superior to her in being more highly valued!My dearest Anne, it would give me more delight than is often felt at my time of life!”

zh: 安妮不得不站起来，转过身去，走到远处一张桌子旁，靠在那里装作在忙什么事情，力图把刚才那番谈话引起的感情压制下去。一时间她的想象、她的心仿佛着了魔似的。一想到她将成为她母亲那样的人；想到“埃利奥特夫人”这个珍贵的头衔是她第一次将它复活；想到她要重新回到凯林奇，再次称它为家，她永久的家，这些对她来说是一时无法抵制的诱惑。拉塞尔夫人没有再说什么，她想让事情顺其自然。她认为，要是埃利奥特先生能够在这个时刻恰如其分地表白一番就好了！——总之，她以为安妮不相信会有这么一回事。安妮一想到埃利奥特先生自己来求婚的场景，她又镇静下来了。凯林奇和“埃利奥特夫人”的魅力也全部随之消失了。她决不会接受他的求婚。这不仅仅是因为她只钟情于一个人，对其他任何人都无法产生感情；而且她认认真真地考虑了这事的可能性，理智上是反对埃利奥特先生。
en: Anne was obliged to turn away, to rise, to walk to a distant table, and, leaning there in pretended employment, try to subdue the feelings this picture excited.For a few moments her imagination and her heart were bewitched.The idea of becoming what her mother had been; of having the precious name of “Lady Elliot” first revived in herself; of being restored to Kellynch, calling it her home again, her home for ever, was a charm which she could not immediately resist.Lady Russell said not another word, willing to leave the matter to its own operation; and believing that, could Mr. Elliot at that moment with propriety have spoken for himself!—she believed, in short, what Anne did not believe.The same image of Mr. Elliot speaking for himself brought Anne to composure again.The charm of Kellynch and of “Lady Elliot” all faded away.She never could accept him.And it was not only that her feelings were still adverse to any man save one; her judgement, on a serious consideration of the possibilities of such a case was against Mr. Elliot.

zh: 虽说他们已经结识了一个月，但是她并不满意地认为自己真正了解他的品质。他是一个明智的人，一个讨人喜欢的人，他能说会道，颇有见地，似乎也能像富有原则的人一样能够对事情做出恰当的判断，这一切都是明摆着的。他当然能够明辨是非，安妮还没有发现他明显地违背了哪一条道德职责。然而，安妮仍然不能对他的行动打包票。她即使不怀疑埃利奥特的现在，也怀疑他的过去。他偶尔提及旧时的朋友，提到过去的一些活动和追求，使安妮对他的过去抱有一些怀疑，觉得他过去的行为有些不好。安妮发现他曾经有一些坏习惯；星期天出去游玩是家常便饭；而且他的生活中有一段时间（可能还不短）至少他对一切正经事毫不关心；虽然现在他可能改变了很多，但是谁能对一个聪明、谨慎，到了这个年纪又懂得要有正派品格的人的真情实感作出担保呢？怎样才能确定他已经洗心革面了呢？
en: Though they had now been acquainted a month, she could not be satisfied that she really knew his character.That he was a sensible man, an agreeable man, that he talked well, professed good opinions, seemed to judge properly and as a man of principle, this was all clear enough.He certainly knew what was right, nor could she fix on any one article of moral duty evidently transgressed; but yet she would have been afraid to answer for his conduct.She distrusted the past, if not the present.The names which occasionally dropt of former associates, the allusions to former practices and pursuits, suggested suspicions not favourable of what he had been.She saw that there had been bad habits; that Sunday travelling had been a common thing; that there had been a period of his life (and probably not a short one) when he had been, at least, careless in all serious matters; and, though he might now think very differently, who could answer for the true sentiments of a clever, cautious man, grown old enough to appreciate a fair character?How could it ever be ascertained that his mind was truly cleansed?

zh: 埃利奥特先生理智、谈吐谨慎、举止优雅，但是他并不坦率。他对别人的好坏从来没有激动过，也从不表示强烈的喜怒。这对安妮来说是显然是个缺陷。她早期的印象是无法补救的。她比任何人都珍视直率、坦诚、热切的性格。激情和热忱仍然使她着迷。她认为有些人有时看起来显得心不在焉，说上几句草率的话，但她宁愿信赖这些人的真诚，而不愿相信那些思想从来不溜神、舌头从来不滑边的人。
en: Mr. Elliot was rational, discreet, polished, but he was not open.There was never any burst of feeling, any warmth of indignation or delight, at the evil or good of others.This, to Anne, was a decided imperfection.Her early impressions were incurable.She prized the frank, the open-hearted, the eager character beyond all others.Warmth and enthusiasm did captivate her still.She felt that she could so much more depend upon the sincerity of those who sometimes looked or said a careless or a hasty thing, than of those whose presence of mind never varied, whose tongue never slipped.

zh: 埃利奥特对谁都过于亲切。她父亲屋里人的性格各不相同，而他却都能使他们满意。他对谁都过于容忍，同每个人相处得太好了。他曾经比较坦率地同安妮谈起过克莱太太；他似乎对克莱太太是个什么样的人看得很清楚，因而很瞧不起她。可是克莱太太同其他人一样认为他很亲切。
en: Mr. Elliot was too generally agreeable.Various as were the tempers in her father’s house, he pleased them all.He endured too well, stood too well with every body.He had spoken to her with some degree of openness of Mrs. Clay; had appeared completely to see what Mrs. Clay was about, and to hold her in contempt; and yet Mrs. Clay found him as agreeable as any body.

zh: 同安妮相比，拉塞尔夫人看问题的深度或许不如她，或许比她更透彻，因为她看不出有他什么能引起不信任的地方。拉塞尔夫人想不出一个比埃利奥特先生更完美的人。她希望这个秋天能在凯林奇的教堂里见到埃利奥特先生同她心爱的安妮举行婚礼。没有比这更令她愉快的事情了。
en: Lady Russell saw either less or more than her young friend, for she saw nothing to excite distrust.She could not imagine a man more exactly what he ought to be than Mr. Elliot; nor did she ever enjoy a sweeter feeling than the hope of seeing him receive the hand of her beloved Anne in Kellynch church, in the course of the following autumn.

zh: 第十八章
en: CHAPTER 18

zh: 已经是2月初了。安妮已在巴斯呆了一个月，很渴望听到来自阿珀克罗斯和莱姆的消息。她想听的比玛丽在信中写的要多得多。安妮已经三个星期没有收到她的信了。她只知道亨里埃塔又回家了；而被认为恢复得很快的路易莎还留在莱姆。一天晚上，安妮正在一心惦念着他们的时候，收到了玛丽寄来的一封比平常都厚的信。使安妮更感到高兴与意外的是，克罗夫特将军与太太还向她表示问候。
en: It was the beginning of February; and Anne, having been a month in Bath, was growing very eager for news from Uppercross and Lyme.She wanted to hear much more than Mary had communicated.It was three weeks since she had heard at all.She only knew that Henrietta was at home again; and that Louisa, though considered to be recovering fast, was still in Lyme; and she was thinking of them all very intently one evening, when a thicker letter than usual from Mary was delivered to her; and, to quicken the pleasure and surprise, with Admiral and Mrs. Croft’s compliments.

zh: 克罗夫特夫妇一定在巴斯！安妮对此很感兴趣。安妮心里挂念着他们。
en: The Crofts must be in Bath!A circumstance to interest her.They were people whom her heart turned to very naturally.

zh: “这是怎么回事儿？”沃尔特爵士大声喊道。“克罗夫特夫妇已经来到了巴斯？是租下了凯林奇的克罗夫特夫妇吗？他们给你带什么来了？”
en: “What is this?” cried Sir Walter.“The Crofts have arrived in Bath?The Crofts who rent Kellynch?What have they brought you?”

zh: “阿珀克罗斯乡舍来的一封信，父亲。”
en: “A letter from Uppercross Cottage, Sir.”

zh: “啊！这些信是方便的护照。它们可以当作是介绍信。不过，不管怎样，我本来也应该去拜访一下克罗夫特将军。我知道应该怎么对待我的房客。”
en: “Oh! those letters are convenient passports.They secure an introduction.I should have visited Admiral Croft, however, at any rate.I know what is due to my tenant.”

zh: 安妮再也听不下去了。她简直弄不清楚可怜的将军的面容是如何从她脑海中消失的。她专心致志地看信。这封信是几天前开始写的。
en: Anne could listen no longer; she could not even have told how the poor Admiral’s complexion escaped; her letter engrossed her.It had been begun several days back.
“February 1st.

zh: ”我亲爱的安妮——我不想因为没有给你写信而表示歉意，因为我知道在巴斯这种地方，很少有人对信感兴趣。你一定非常快乐，不会关心阿珀克罗斯了。你知道得很清楚，这里也没有什么事情可以告诉你。我们过了一个很无聊的圣诞节。整个节日期间，马斯格罗夫先生和太太没有准备过一次晚宴。我又不把海特一家放在眼里。不过，节日总算结束了：我想，没有一个孩子经历过这么漫长的节日。我保证我没有过。昨天，大家都走了，只留下哈维尔家的孩子了。你要是听到他们根本没有回来过，一定感到惊讶。哈维尔太太一定是一个古怪的母亲，能和孩子分开这么长时间。这一点，我无法理解。在我看来，他们根本就不乖；但是马斯格罗夫太太看上去非常喜欢他们，对待他们即使没有比对自己的孙子更好，但也差不多了。前一阵，我们这里的天气多糟糕！巴斯有漂亮的人行道，人们可能没有这样的感觉。但是在乡下，情况可就大为不同了。自从1月的第二个星期以来，除了查尔斯•海特之外，没有一个人来看过我，而查尔斯来的次数太多，我又不欢迎他了。对你说句悄悄话，亨里埃塔没有跟路易莎一起在莱姆呆下去，我觉得可真遗憾。否则，可以使她见到海特的次数少些。马车今天就出发了，明天要把路易莎和哈维尔太太接回来。不过，他们回来后的第二天，我们才应邀跟他们一起吃饭。马斯格罗夫太太非常担心路易莎在路上会受累，其实一路上有人照顾着，不太可能累着。要是明天去那儿吃饭，我倒方便了很多。我很高兴你觉得埃利奥特先生亲切，我也希望能够与他结识。可是我可倒霉了：每当有好事，我总是沾不上边；我总是家里最后一个引人注意的人。克莱太太同伊丽莎白呆在一起的时间太长了！她从来没有想过要走吗？不过即使她把房间腾出来，我们或许也不会受到邀请。告诉我，你对这事怎么看。你知道，我并不希望他们邀请我的孩子们。我完全可以把他们留在老宅一个月或六个星期。我刚刚听说，克罗夫特夫妇马上要去巴斯，他们认为将军得了痛风。查尔斯完全是偶然听到的，他们没有客气地通知我一下，或是表示愿意帮忙捎点东西过去。我认为，他们同我们的邻里关系没有什么进展。我们根本见不到他们，这足以证明他们多么心不在焉。查尔斯问你们好，祝你们万事如意。你亲爱的
en: “My dear Anne,—I make no apology for my silence, because I know how little people think of letters in such a place as Bath.You must be a great deal too happy to care for Uppercross, which, as you well know, affords little to write about.We have had a very dull Christmas; Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove have not had one dinner party all the holidays.I do not reckon the Hayters as anybody.The holidays, however, are over at last: I believe no children ever had such long ones.I am sure I had not.The house was cleared yesterday, except of the little Harvilles; but you will be surprised to hear they have never gone home.Mrs. Harville must be an odd mother to part with them so long.I do not understand it.They are not at all nice children, in my opinion; but Mrs. Musgrove seems to like them quite as well, if not better, than her grandchildren.What dreadful weather we have had!It may not be felt in Bath, with your nice pavements; but in the country it is of some consequence.I have not had a creature call on me since the second week in January, except Charles Hayter, who had been calling much oftener than was welcome.Between ourselves, I think it a great pity Henrietta did not remain at Lyme as long as Louisa; it would have kept her a little out of his way.The carriage is gone　to-day, to bring Louisa and the Harvilles tomorrow.We are not asked to dine with them, however, till the day after, Mrs. Musgrove is so afraid of her being fatigued by the journey, which is not very likely, considering the care that will be taken of her; and it would be much more convenient to me to dine there to-morrow.I am glad you find Mr. Elliot so agreeable, and wish I could be acquainted with him too; but I have my usual luck: I am always out of the way when any thing desirable is going on; always the last of my family to be noticed.What an immense time Mrs. Clay has been staying with Elizabeth!Does she never mean to go away?But perhaps if she were to leave the room vacant, we might not be invited.Let me know what you think of this.I do not expect my children to be asked, you know.I can leave them at the Great House very well, for a month or six weeks.I have this moment heard that the Crofts are going to Bath almost immediately; they think the Admiral gouty.Charles heard it quite by chance; they have not had the civility to give me any notice, or of offering to take anything.I do not think they improve at all as neighbours.We see nothing of them, and this is really an instance of gross inattention.Charles joins me in love, and everything proper.Yours affectionately,

zh: “玛丽•马——
en: “Mary M—-.

zh: “我很遗憾地告诉你，我的身体很不好。杰迈玛刚告诉我，卖肉的说附近正流行咽喉炎。我看，我肯定会染上这个病，而我一染上咽喉炎，你知道，总是比别人严重。”
en: “I am sorry to say that I am very far from well; and Jemima has just told me that the butcher says there is a bad sore-throat very much about.I dare say I shall catch it; and my sore-throats, you know, are always worse than anybody’s.”

zh: 信的第一部分就这样结束了，后来玛丽把这一部分装进了一只信封，而在那封信里又另外写了这么多。
en: So ended the first part, which had been afterwards put into an envelope, containing nearly as much more.

zh: “我没有把信封上，因为我想告诉你路易莎路上的情况。我很高兴我没有封上，因为我还有好多话要说。首先，我昨天接到了克罗夫特太太的一张字条，说是他们愿意给你们捎东西。这确实是一张写得十分客气、十分友好的字条，是写给我的，理应如此。因此，我可以愿意把信写多长就写多长。将军的病看起来并不很重，我衷心地希望巴斯能够给他带来他所需要的一切。我真心欢迎他们再回来。我们的邻居中不能缺少这样友善的一家。不过，现在我要谈谈路易莎了。我有件事情要告诉你，你一定会大吃一惊。她和哈维尔太太星期二平安到家了，晚上我们去看望她时，惊讶地发现本威克舰长没有跟着一起来，因为他和哈维尔夫妇一起受到了邀请。你知道是什么原因吗？因为他不折不扣地爱上了路易莎，在得到马斯格罗夫先生的答复前，他不愿冒昧地来阿珀克罗斯。路易莎离开之前，他们已经谈好了，本威克舰长写了封信，托哈维尔上校带给她父亲。这件事千真万确，我以名誉担保！你不感到惊讶吗？要是你以前听到了什么风声，我至少会很吃惊的，因为我一点都不知道。马斯格罗夫太太郑重声明，她对此事毫不知情。不过，我们大家还是很高兴，因为虽说比不上嫁给温特沃思上校，但是却比嫁给查尔斯•海特好多了。马斯格罗夫先生已经写信表示同意，本威克舰长今天就要到这里来了。哈维尔太太说，她丈夫为他那可怜的妹妹感到十分难过。但是，他们俩人都非常喜欢路易莎。哈维尔太太和我的确都觉得，我们因为护理了她而更加喜爱她了。查尔斯想知道，温特沃思上校会说什么。不过，如果你还记得的话，我从不认为他爱上了路易莎，我从未发现这种迹象。你看，人们本以为本威克舰长是你的仰慕者，现在这事就这样了结了。我始终无法理解，查尔斯怎么会想到这方面去。我希望他现在会更加讨人喜欢了。当然，这对路易莎•马斯格罗夫不是一门非常美满的婚姻，不过这比嫁到海特家去强上百万倍。”
en: “I kept my letter open, that I might send you word how Louisa bore her journey, and now I am extremely glad I did, having a great deal to add.In the first place, I had a note from Mrs. Croft yesterday, offering to convey anything to you; a very kind, friendly note indeed, addressed to me, just as it ought; I shall therefore be able to make my letter as long as I like.The Admiral does not seem very ill, and I sincerely hope Bath will do him all the good he wants.I shall be truly glad to have them back again.Our neighbourhood cannot spare such a pleasant family.But now for Louisa.I have something to communicate that will astonish you not a little.She and the Harvilles came on Tuesday very safely, and in the evening we went to ask her how she did, when we were rather surprised not to find Captain Benwick of the party, for he had been invited as well as the Harvilles; and what do you think was the reason?Neither more nor less than his being in love with Louisa, and not choosing to venture to Uppercross till he had had an answer from Mr. Musgrove; for it was all settled between him and her before she came away, and he had written to her father by Captain Harville.True, upon my honour!Are not you astonished?I shall be surprised at least if you ever received a hint of it, for I never did.Mrs. Musgrove protests solemnly that she knew nothing of the matter.We are all very well pleased, however, for though it is not equal to her marrying Captain Wentworth, it is infinitely better than Charles Hayter; and Mr. Musgrove has written his consent, and Captain Benwick is expected to-day.Mrs. Harville says her husband feels a good deal on his poor sister’s account; but, however, Louisa is a great favourite with both.Indeed, Mrs. Harville and I quite agree that we love her the better for having nursed her.Charles wonders what Captain Wentworth will say; but if you remember, I never thought him attached to Louisa; I never could see anything of it.And this is the end, you see, of Captain Benwick’s being supposed to be an admirer of yours.How Charles could take such a thing into his head was always incomprehensible to me.I hope he will be more agreeable now.Certainly not a great match for Louisa Musgrove, but a million times better than marrying among the Hayters.”

zh: 玛丽不用担心她姐姐对这一消息会有什么思想准备。她一生中还从来没有这么惊讶过。本威克舰长和路易莎•马斯格罗夫！这简直奇妙地让人难以相信，安妮尽了最大的努力才勉强留在房间里，保持镇静，回答大家当时提出的一般性问题。幸好他们没有问太多问题。沃尔特爵士想知道的是，克罗夫特夫妇是否乘坐四驾马车，他们在巴斯的住址是否便于埃利奥特小姐和他自己登门拜访，但是除此之外，他就没有什么兴趣了。
en: Mary need not have feared her sister’s being in any degree prepared for the news.She had never in her life been more astonished.Captain Benwick and Louisa Musgrove!It was almost too wonderful for belief, and it was with the greatest effort that she could remain in the room, preserve an air of calmness, and answer the common questions of the moment.Happily for her, they were not many.Sir Walter wanted to know whether the Crofts travelled with four horses, and whether they were likely to be situated in such a part of Bath as it might suit Miss Elliot and himself to visit in; but had little curiosity beyond.

zh: “玛丽怎么样了？”伊丽莎白问了之后没等人回答，又说，“请问，是什么风把克罗夫特夫妇吹到巴斯来了？”
en: “How is Mary?” said Elizabeth; and without waiting for an answer, “And pray what brings the Crofts to Bath?”

zh: “他们是为将军而来的。据说他得了痛风。”
en: “They come on the Admiral’s account.He is thought to be gouty.”

zh: “痛风和衰老！”沃尔特爵士说道。“可怜的老绅士。”
en: “Gout and decrepitude!” said Sir Walter.“Poor old gentleman.”

zh: “他们在这里有熟人吗？”伊丽莎白问道。
en: “Have they any acquaintance here?” asked Elizabeth.

zh: “我不知道，不过我想，以克罗夫特将军的年龄和职业，他在这种地方应该不会没有熟人。”
en: “I do not know; but I can hardly suppose that, at Admiral Croft’s time of life, and in his profession, he should not have many acquaintance in such a place as this.”

zh: “我觉得，”沃尔特爵士冷冷地说，“克罗夫特将军在巴斯最出名的就是他是凯林奇府的租贷人。伊丽莎白，我们可以贸然地把他和他妻子引荐给子爵夫人吗？”
en: “I suspect,” said Sir Walter coolly, “that Admiral Croft will be best known in Bath as the renter of Kellynch Hall.Elizabeth, may we venture to present him and his wife in Laura Place?”

zh: “哦，不！我想不行。尽管我们同达尔林普尔虽说是表亲关系，但是我们还是应该小心谨慎，不要把她不一定喜欢的熟人带去，这会使她感到尴尬的。如果我们不是亲戚，那倒没什么。但是作为表亲，她对我们的每项建议都会谨慎考虑的。我们最好还是让克罗夫特夫妇去结交他们自己那个层次的朋友吧。还有几个外表奇特的人在这里四处游荡。我听说他们是海员。克罗夫特夫妇会同他们结交的。”
en: “Oh, no!I think not.Situated as we are with Lady Dalrymple, cousins, we ought to be very careful not to embarrass her with acquaintance she might not approve.If we were not related, it would not signify; but as cousins, she would feel scrupulous as to any proposal of ours.We had better leave the Crofts to find their own level.There are several odd-looking men walking about here, who, I am told, are sailors.The Crofts will associate with them.”

zh: 这就是沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白对这封信的兴趣。克莱太太倒是给了合乎礼节的关注，她询问了查尔斯太太和她那漂亮的小男孩。此后，安妮便脱身了。
en: This was Sir Walter and Elizabeth’s share of interest in the letter; when Mrs. Clay had paid her tribute of more decent attention, in an enquiry after Mrs. Charles Musgrove, and her fine little boys, Anne was at liberty.

zh: 安妮回到自己的房间里，尽力想个明白。查尔斯想知道温特沃思上校是怎么想的，这很自然！也许，温特沃思上校已经退出了，放弃了路易莎，也许他已经不再爱路易莎了。也许他发现他根本不爱路易莎。安妮无法想象他和他的朋友之间会发生背信弃义或举止轻浮或类似这样不妥当的事情。她无法想象他们之间的友谊会不公平地中断。
en: In her own room, she tried to comprehend it.Well might Charles wonder how Captain Wentworth would feel!Perhaps he had quitted the field, had given Louisa up, had ceased to love, had found he did not love her.She could not endure the idea of treachery or levity, or anything akin to ill usage between him and his friend.She could not endure that such a friendship as theirs should be severed unfairly.

zh: 本威克舰长和路易莎•马斯格罗夫。一个是兴致勃勃、能说会道的路易莎•马斯格罗夫，一个是忧郁、有思想、有感情、爱读书的本威克舰长，他们两个似乎一点也不般配。他们的思维方式相差甚远！哪里来的吸引力呢？答案很快就出现了。这是环境造成的。他们在一起生活了几个星期，他们一直住在同一个小屋里。自从亨里埃塔走了以后，他们肯定是相互依靠，路易莎病体刚刚开始恢复，处于一种需要别人关心的状态，而本威克舰长也不是不可安慰的。对于这一点，安妮过去不免有些察觉。不过她从当前事态的发展得出的结论，却与玛丽不同。当时的情况只能说明本威克舰长对安妮产生过几分柔情。不过，她并不想为了满足自己的虚荣心而从中大做文章，超过玛丽所允许的范围。她相信，任何一个比较讨人喜爱的年轻姑娘，只要倾听他的诉说，理解他的感情，都会博得他同样的赞美。他有一颗热情的心。他必定会爱上某个人。
en: Captain Benwick and Louisa Musgrove!The high-spirited, joyous-talking Louisa Musgrove, and the dejected, thinking, feeling, reading, Captain Benwick, seemed each of them everything that would not suit the other.Their minds most dissimilar!Where could have been the attraction?The answer soon presented itself.It had been in situation.They had been thrown together several weeks; they had been living in the same small family party: since Henrietta’s coming away, they must have been depending almost entirely on each other, and Louisa, just recovering from illness, had been in an interesting state, and Captain Benwick was not inconsolable.That was a point which Anne had not been able to avoid suspecting before; and instead of drawing the same conclusion as Mary, from the present course of events, they served only to confirm the idea of his having felt some dawning of tenderness toward herself.She did not mean, however, to derive much more from it to gratify her vanity, than Mary might have allowed.She was persuaded that any tolerably pleasing young woman who had listened and seemed to feel for him would have received the same compliment.He had an affectionate heart.He must love somebody.

zh: 安妮没有理由认为他们不幸福。路易莎一开始就很喜欢海军军官，不久他们就会变得更加相像。本威克上校很快就会变得快活起来，路易莎会努力成为司各特和拜伦勋爵的热衷者。不，她也许已经做到了，他们当然是通过诗歌而相爱的。一想到路易莎•马斯格罗夫已经变成了具有文学品味和多愁善感的人，她就觉得很有趣，不过她并不怀疑情况确实如此。在莱姆的那一天，在科布摔的那一跤，可能会影响她一生的健康、精神、勇气和性格，就像目前似乎已经彻底影响了她的命运一样。
en: She saw no reason against their being happy.Louisa had fine naval fervour to begin with, and they would soon grow more alike.He would gain cheerfulness, and she would learn to be an enthusiast for Scott and Lord Byron; nay, that was probably learnt already; of course they had fallen in love over poetry.The idea of Louisa Musgrove turned into a person of literary taste, and sentimental reflection was amusing, but she had no doubt of its being so.The day at Lyme, the fall from the Cobb, might influence her health, her nerves, her courage, her character to the end of her life, as thoroughly as it appeared to have influenced her fate.

zh: 整个事情的结论就是：如果说那位了解温特沃思上校人品的人会选择另外一个男人，那么他们的婚约也不会引起她持久的惊叹了。如果温特沃思上校也不曾因此失去朋友，当然也没有什么可遗憾的。不，安妮一想到温特沃思上校被解除了束缚而得到了自由，心跳不由得加速，脸上也泛起了红晕，这绝对不是因为遗憾。她有一些感情是她自己都羞于揣摩的。目前的感情近乎喜悦，莫名的喜悦！
en: The conclusion of the whole was, that if the woman who had been sensible of Captain Wentworth’s merits could be allowed to prefer another man, there was nothing in the engagement to excite lasting wonder; and if Captain Wentworth lost no friend by it, certainly nothing to be regretted.No, it was not regret which made Anne’s heart beat in spite of herself, and brought the colour into her cheeks when she thought of Captain Wentworth unshackled and free.She had some feelings which she was ashamed to investigate.They were too much like joy, senseless joy!

zh: 她渴望见到克罗夫特夫妇，但是见面时，他们显然还没有听说这个消息。双方都进行了礼节性的拜访和回访，提到了路易莎•马斯格罗夫，也提到了本威克舰长，但是他们脸上没露出一丝笑容。
en: She longed to see the Crofts; but when the meeting took place, it was evident that no rumour of the news had yet reached them.The visit of ceremony was paid and returned; and Louisa Musgrove was mentioned, and Captain Benwick, too, without even half a smile.
