zh: 使沃尔特爵士非常满意的是，克罗夫特夫妇住在盖伊街的房子里。他一点也不为这位朋友感到羞耻，实际上，他对将军的思考和议论远远超过将军对他的思考和议论。
en: The Crofts had placed themselves in lodgings in Gay Street, perfectly to Sir Walter’s satisfaction.He was not at all ashamed of the acquaintance, and did, in fact, think and talk a great deal more about the Admiral, than the Admiral ever thought or talked about him.

zh: 克罗夫特将军在巴斯的熟人要多少有多少，他们把同埃利奥特一家的交往仅仅看作是一种礼节，看来也根本不能给他们带来愉快。他们把在乡下的习惯也带来了，几乎是形影不离的。克罗夫特将军遵照医生的嘱咐，通过散步来消除痛风，克罗夫特夫人似乎要与他分担一切事情，为了对他病好，拼命地陪他散步。安妮走到哪里都能遇见他们。拉塞尔夫人的马车几乎每天早上都要带安妮出去。这时，安妮总会想起他们，也总是会见到他们。安妮了解克罗夫特夫妇的感情，觉得对她来说，这是最感人、最幸福的情景。她总是尽量看着他们，看见他们单独在一起时愉快地散步，便高兴地以为自己可能知道他们在谈论些什么。她还很高兴看到克罗夫特将军遇到老朋友时彼此亲切握手的场面。她喜欢观察他们夫妇在一群海军中热情谈话的情景，这时克罗夫特太太看上去跟她周围的军官一样机智而敏捷。
en: The Crofts knew quite as many people in Bath as they wished for, and considered their intercourse with the Elliots as a mere matter of form, and not in the least likely to afford them any pleasure.They brought with them their country habit of being almost always together.He was ordered to walk to keep off the gout, and Mrs. Croft seemed to go shares with him in everything, and to walk for her life to do him good.Anne saw them wherever she went.Lady Russell took her out in her carriage almost every morning, and she never failed to think of them, and never failed to see them.Knowing their feelings as she did, it was a most attractive picture of happiness to her.She always watched them as long as she could, delighted to fancy she understood what they might be talking of, as they walked along in happy independence, or equally delighted to see the Admiral’s hearty shake of the hand when he encountered an old friend, and observe their eagerness of conversation when occasionally forming into a little knot of the navy, Mrs. Croft looking as intelligent and keen as any of the officers around her.

zh: 安妮总是同拉塞尔夫人在一起，很少自己一个人出来散步。但是，事有碰巧，在克罗夫特夫妇到来的一星期或十天左右，一天上午在贫民区时，安妮离开了她的朋友，或者说离开了她朋友的马车，独自回卡姆登巷去。正当她走过米尔萨姆街的时候，幸运地遇见了将军。当时他正背着双手，独自站在一家版画店的橱窗前，专心致志地欣赏着版画。她就是从他身旁走过去，他也不会看得见，她只得拍他一下，喊他一声，才会引起他的注意。不过，他看到并认出了安妮时，言谈举止一如往常坦率友好。“哈！是你呀？谢谢你，谢谢你。你这么做正是把我当作朋友看待。你看，我正在看一幅画。我路过这一家店时总是要停下来。不过这是个什么玩意，像一艘船。你看看。你见过这样的船吗？那些杰出的画家肯定都是怪人，竟然会以为有人敢把生命托付给这样一艘不像样的破旧小船？不成想，还真有两个绅士悠然自得地呆在船上，望着周围的岩石和群山，好像不会马上翻船似的，其实，他们一定会翻船。我倒想知道这船是哪儿造的！”（爽朗地大笑）“乘坐这种船，我连洗马池都不敢过。好吧，”（转过脸去）“现在你要去哪儿？我能替你去，或陪你去吗？我能帮上什么忙吗？”
en: Anne was too much engaged with Lady Russell to be often walking herself; but it so happened that one morning, about a week or ten days after the Croft’s arrival, it suited her best to leave her friend, or her friend’s carriage, in the lower part of the town, and return alone to Camden Place, and in walking up Milsom Street she had the good fortune to meet with the Admiral.He was standing by himself at a printshop window, with his hands behind him, in earnest contemplation of some print, and she not only might have passed him unseen, but was obliged to touch as well as address him before she could catch his notice.When he did perceive and acknowledge her, however, it was done with all his usual frankness and good humour.“Ha! is it you?Thank you, thank you.This is treating me like a friend.Here I am, you see, staring at a picture.I can never get by this shop without stopping.But what a thing here is, by way of a boat!Do look at it.Did you ever see the like?What queer fellows your fine painters must be, to think that anybody would venture their lives in such a shapeless old cockleshell as that?And yet here are two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease, and looking about them at the rocks and mountains, as if they were not to be upset the next moment, which they certainly must be.I wonder where that boat was built!” (laughing heartily); “I would not venture over a horsepond in it.Well,” (turning away), “now, where are you bound?Can I go anywhere for you, or with you?Can I be of any use?”

zh: “不用了，谢谢你。如果你能陪我在咱们同路的这短短的一段距离里走走，我就已经很高兴了。我要回家去。”
en: “None, I thank you, unless you will give me the pleasure of your company the little way our road lies together.I am going home.”

zh: “我很乐意，非常乐意，多走一段也行。是的，是的，我们可以舒舒服服地在一起散散步，我一边走一边还要告诉你一件事。好了，挽着我的胳膊，这就对了。我身边要是没有一位女士，我会感到很不舒服的。天哪！那是什么船哪！”他们开始离开的时候，将军又朝那版画看了一眼。
en: “That I will, with all my heart, and farther, too.Yes, yes we will have a snug walk together, and I have something to tell you as we go along.There, take my arm; that’s right; I do not feel comfortable if I have not a woman there.Lord! what a boat it is!” taking a last look at the picture, as they began to be in motion.

zh: “你说有事情要告诉我，先生？”
en: “Did you say that you had something to tell me, sir?”

zh: “是的，有事，马上就告诉你。可是那儿来了一位朋友，是布里格登上校，我们照面的时候，我只说一句‘你好’。我不会停下来的。‘你好’。布里格登看到我不是同妻子在一起，眼睛都睁大了。我妻子真可怜，她的一只脚把她拴住了。她的一只脚后跟上长了个水疱，有三先令的硬币那么大。你如果朝马路对面看，你就会看到布兰德将军和他的弟弟走过来了。卑鄙的家伙，两个都是！我很高兴他们没有走在路的这边。索菲受不了他们。他们曾经给我耍了一个卑鄙的花招：把我手下最好的人拐走了。详细情况我下一次再告诉你。阿奇博尔德•德鲁老爵士和他的孙子走来了。看，他看到我们了。他冲你吻手呢，他把你当成我妻子了。啊！对那个年轻人来说，和平来得太早了。可怜的阿奇博尔德老爵士！埃利奥特小姐，你喜欢巴斯吗？这个地方非常适合我们。我们经常会遇见这个或那个老朋友。每天早晨，街上满是我们的朋友，当然聊起来没完没了。然后，我们干脆摆脱他们，把自己关在屋子里，缩在椅子上。我们就像在凯林奇一样舒服，甚至就像我们以前在北雅茅斯和迪尔一样。实话告诉你吧，我们在这里的房子使我们想起了我们当初在北雅茅斯的住房，但是我们并不是不喜欢这里。跟在北雅茅斯一样，这里的一只壁炉是透风的。”
en: “Yes, I have, presently.But here comes a friend, Captain Brigden; I shall only say, ‘How d’ye do?’ as we pass, however.I shall not stop.‘How d’ye do?’Brigden stares to see anybody with me but my wife.She, poor soul, is tied by the leg.She has a blister on one of her heels, as large as a three-shilling piece.If you look across the street, you will see Admiral Brand coming down and his brother.Shabby fellows, both of them!I am glad they are not on this side of the way.Sophy cannot bear them.They played me a pitiful trick once: got away with some of my best men.I will tell you the whole story another time.There comes old Sir Archibald Drew and his grandson.Look, he sees us; he kisses his hand to you; he takes you for my wife.Ah! the peace has come too soon for that younker.Poor old Sir Archibald!How do you like Bath, Miss Elliot?It suits us very well.We are always meeting with some old friend or other; the streets full of them every morning; sure to have plenty of chat; and then we get away from them all, and shut ourselves in our lodgings, and draw in our chairs, and are snug as if we were at Kellynch, ay, or as we used to be even at North Yarmouth and Deal.We do not like our lodgings here the worse, I can tell you, for putting us in mind of those we first had at North Yarmouth.The wind blows through one of the cupboards just in the same way.”

zh: 他们又往前走了一段路，安妮又大胆地催促将军告诉她什么事。她原以为走出米尔萨姆街，她的好奇心就会得到满足。但是她还得等待，因为在他们走到更加宽阔、更加安静的贝尔蒙特街以前，将军不愿意谈。因为安妮不是真正的克罗夫特太太，她就只好由着他了。两人一走上贝尔蒙特街，将军就开口了：
en: When they were got a little farther, Anne ventured to press again for what he had to communicate.She hoped when clear of Milsom Street to have her curiosity gratified; but she was still obliged to wait, for the Admiral had made up his mind not to begin till they had gained the greater space and quiet of Belmont; and as she was not really Mrs. Croft, she must let him have his own way. As soon as they were fairly ascending Belmont, he began—

zh: “好了，现在你会听到一件使你吃惊的事了。不过，首先你得告诉我，我要谈起的那位姑娘叫什么名字。你知道的，就是我们大家都非常关心的那位小姐。那个出了事的马斯格罗夫小姐。她的教名：我总是忘记她的教名。”
en: “Well, now you shall hear something that will surprise you.But first of all, you must tell me the name of the young lady I am going to talk about.That young lady, you know, that we have all been so concerned for.The Miss Musgrove, that all this has been happening to.Her Christian name: I always forget her Christian name.”

zh: 安妮一听就知道是谁，不过她不好意思显出一听就明白的样子。但是现在她可以放心地说出“路易莎”这个名字了。
en: Anne had been ashamed to appear to comprehend so soon as she really did; but now she could safely suggest the name of “Louisa.”

zh: “对，对，路易莎小姐，就是那个名字。我希望年轻小姐们不要起这么多动听的教名。要是她们都叫索菲之类的名字，我就永远都忘不了的。好了，你知道，我们都以为这位路易莎小姐要嫁给弗雷德里克。弗雷德里克追她很久了。大家唯一感到奇怪的是，他们在等什么，后来直到路易莎在莱姆出了这件事。那时确实很显然他们必须等路易莎的头脑恢复过来。可是，即使在那个时候，他们的举动也很反常。弗雷德里克没有呆在莱姆，反而到普利茅斯去了，然后又跑去看爱德华。我们从迈恩黑德回来的时候，他已经去爱德华那里了，到现在为止一直在那里呆着。自从11月份以来，我们就没有见到他的影子。连索菲都无法理解。但是现在，事情发生了极其奇怪的变化。因为这位年轻的小姐，就是这位马斯格罗夫，没有嫁给弗雷德里克，而是要嫁给詹姆斯•本威克。你认识詹姆斯•本威克吧？”
en: “Ay, ay, Miss Louisa Musgrove, that is the name.I wish young ladies had not such a number of fine Christian names.I should never be out if they were all Sophys, or something of that sort.Well, this Miss Louisa, we all thought, you know, was to marry Frederick.He was courting her week after week.The only wonder was, what they could be waiting for, till the business at Lyme came; then, indeed, it was clear enough that they must wait till her brain was set to right.But even then there was something odd in their way of going on.Instead of staying at Lyme, he went off to Plymouth, and then he went off to see Edward.When we came back from Minehead he was gone down to Edward’s, and there he has been ever since.We have seen nothing of him since November.Even Sophy could not understand it.But now, the matter has take the strangest turn of all; for this young lady, the same Miss Musgrove, instead of being to marry Frederick, is to marry James Benwick.You know James Benwick.”

zh: “有点。我与本威克舰长有点认识。”
en: “A little.I am a little acquainted with Captain Benwick.”

zh: 对了，路易莎就是要嫁给他。不，极有可能他们现在已经结婚了，因为我不知道他们还要等什么。”
en: “Well, she is to marry him.Nay, most likely they are married already, for I do not know what they should wait for.”

zh: “我认为本威克舰长是一个非常讨人喜欢的年轻人，”安妮说，“而且我觉得他的人品很好。”
en: “I thought Captain Benwick a very pleasing young man,” said Anne, “and I understand that he bears an excellent character.”

zh: “啊！是的，是的，詹姆斯•本威克是无可指责的。不错，他只是一位中校，去年夏天晋升的，现在就很难晋升了。不过除此之外，我不知道他还有什么缺点。我向你担保，他是一个优秀、心地善良的小伙子。也是一位积极、热忱的青年军官，这一点也许你想不到吧，因为从他那温和的举止上看不出来。”
en: “Oh! yes, yes, there is not a word to be said against James Benwick.He is only a commander, it is true, made last summer, and these are bad times for getting on, but he has not another fault that I know of.An excellent, good-hearted fellow, I assure you; a very active, zealous officer too, which is more than you would think for, perhaps, for that soft sort of manner does not do him justice.”

zh: “这你就错了，先生。我决不会根据本威克舰长的举止就觉得他缺乏斗志。我觉得他的举止特别讨人喜欢，我敢担保，他能使大家都感到愉快。”
en: “Indeed you are mistaken there, sir; I should never augur want of spirit from Captain Benwick’s manners.I thought them particularly pleasing, and I will answer for it, they would generally please.”

zh: “好了，好了，女士们最善于判断。但是我认为詹姆斯•本威克太柔了一些。可是这也许是我们的偏见，索菲和我都总觉得弗雷德里克的举止比他强。弗雷德里克身上某些方面更合我们的意。”
en: “Well, well, ladies are the best judges; but James Benwick is rather too piano for me; and though very likely it is all our partiality, Sophy and I cannot help thinking Frederick’s manners better than his.There is something about Frederick more to our taste.”

zh: 安妮一时不知道说什么才好。刚才她只是想反对大家普遍认为的斗志和温和水火不相容的观点，根本不是想说本威克的举止最为优雅。于是她迟疑了一会儿说：“我并不是想拿这两位朋友做比较。”但是将军打断了她的话：
en: Anne was caught.She had only meant to oppose the too common idea of spirit and gentleness being incompatible with each other, not at all to represent Captain Benwick’s manners as the very best that could possibly be; and, after a little hesitation, she was beginning to say, “I was not entering into any comparison of the two friends,” but the Admiral interrupted her with—

zh: “情况确实如此。它并不只是流言蜚语。我们是听弗雷德里克自己说的。昨天他姐姐收到了他的一封信，信中他把这事告诉了我们。他也是刚从哈维尔的信中得知，哈维尔是当场从阿珀克罗斯写给他的。我想他们都在阿珀克罗斯。”
en: “And the thing is certainly true.It is not a mere bit of gossip.We have it from Frederick himself.His sister had a letter from him yesterday, in which he tells us of it, and he had just had it in a letter from Harville, written upon the spot, from Uppercross.I fancy they are all at Uppercross.”

zh: 这是安妮抵挡不住的一次机会。因此她说：“我想，将军，我想温特沃思上校信中的语气没有使你和克罗夫特太太感到特别不安吧。去年秋天，他和路易莎之间看上去确实有些感情。不过我想双方可能觉得感情已经淡漠了，他们也没有什么大吵大闹。我希望他的信中没有流露出受委屈的情绪吧。”
en: This was an opportunity which Anne could not resist; she said, therefore, “I hope, Admiral, I hope there is nothing in the style of Captain Wentworth’s letter to make you and Mrs. Croft particularly uneasy.It did seem, last autumn, as if there were an attachment between him and Louisa Musgrove; but I hope it may be understood to have worn out on each side equally, and without violence.I hope his letter does not breathe the spirit of an ill-used man.”

zh: “一点没有，一点没有。从头到尾没有一句诅咒或怨言。”
en: “Not at all, not at all; there is not an oath or a murmur from beginning to end.”

zh: 安妮垂下眼帘，来掩饰她的笑容。
en: Anne looked down to hide her smile.

zh: “不，不。弗雷德里克不是一个抱怨和发牢骚的人。他很有志气，不会那么做。如果一个姑娘更喜欢另一个男人，那她嫁给那个人会更合适。”
en: “No, no; Frederick is not a man to whine and complain; he has too much spirit for that.If the girl likes another man better, it is very fit she should have him.”

zh: “当然。但是我的意思是，我希望从温特沃思上校给你们写信的方式来看，没有什么东西使你们觉得他认为自己受到了朋友的亏待，你知道，这种心情不需要说也能流露出来。他和本威克舰长之间如此深厚的友谊要是因为这件事而受到破坏，或者哪怕是损害，我将感到很遗憾。”
en: “Certainly.But what I mean is, that I hope there is nothing in Captain Wentworth’s manner of writing to make you suppose he thinks himself ill-used by his friend, which might appear, you know, without its being absolutely said.I should be very sorry that such a friendship as has subsisted between him and Captain Benwick should be destroyed, or even wounded, by a circumstance of this sort.”

zh: “是的，是的，我明白你的意思。不过信中根本没有这种情绪。他一点也没有讽刺挖苦本威克。他甚至没有说：‘我对此感到很奇怪，我有理由对此感到奇怪。’不，你从他的用词中都看不出他曾经看上过这位小姐。（她叫什么名字来着？）他非常大方地希望他们在一起能够幸福。而且我觉得字里行间没有什么不可原谅的怨恨的意思。”
en: “Yes, yes, I understand you.But there is nothing at all of that nature in the letter.He does not give the least fling at Benwick; does not so much as say, ‘I wonder at it, I have a reason of my own for wondering at it.’ No, you would not guess, from his way of writing, that he had ever thought of this Miss (what’s her name?)for himself.He very handsomely hopes they will be happy together; and there is nothing very unforgiving in that, I think.”

zh: 安妮并不完全接受将军极力想让安妮信服的一切，但是她已经不需要再继续追问下去了。因此，她只是泛泛地评论了几句，要不就是静静地听着，而将军也一心按照自己的思路说下去。
en: Anne did not receive the perfect conviction which the Admiral meant to convey, but it would have been useless to press the enquiry farther.She therefore satisfied herself with common-place remarks or quiet attention, and the Admiral had it all his own way.

zh: “可怜的弗雷德里克！”他最后说道。“现在他得重新和别的姑娘接触了。我想我们应该把他带到巴斯来。索菲应该写信给他，请他到巴斯来。我肯定，这里有足够多的漂亮姑娘。他再去阿珀克罗斯也没用了，因为我发现另一位马斯格罗夫小姐已经同她的表哥，那位年轻的教区长确定了关系。埃利奥特小姐，你不觉得我们最好请他到巴斯来吗？”
en: “Poor Frederick!” said he at last.“Now he must begin all over again with somebody else.I think we must get him to Bath.Sophy must write, and beg him to come to Bath.Here are pretty girls enough, I am sure.It would be of no use to go to Uppercross again, for that other Miss Musgrove, I find, is bespoke by her cousin, the young parson.Do not you think, Miss Elliot, we had better try to get him to Bath?”

zh: 第十九章
en: CHAPTER 19

zh: 就在克罗夫特将军一边与安妮散步，一边表示希望请温特沃思上校来巴斯的时候，温特沃思上校已经在来巴斯的路上了。克罗夫特太太还没来得及写信，他就到了。安妮下一次出去散步的时候就看见了他。
en: While Admiral Croft was taking this walk with Anne, and expressing his wish of getting Captain Wentworth to Bath, Captain Wentworth was already on his way thither.Before Mrs. Croft had written, he was arrived, and the very next time Anne walked out, she saw him.

zh: 当时，埃利奥特先生正陪着他的两个堂妹和克莱太太。他们在米尔萨姆街上。开始下雨了，雨不大，但是足以使女士们希望找个避雨处，也足以使埃利奥特小姐巴望停在不远处的达尔林普尔子爵夫人的马车送她回家。因此，埃利奥特小姐、安妮和克莱太太走进了莫兰商店，而埃利奥特先生则走到达尔林普尔夫人面前，请求她的帮助。他很快就回到他们中间，当然，事情办成了。达尔林普尔夫人非常乐意送他们回家，几分钟后就过来接他们。
en: Mr. Elliot was attending his two cousins and Mrs. Clay.They were in Milsom Street.It began to rain, not much, but enough to make shelter desirable for women, and quite enough to make it very desirable for Miss Elliot to have the advantage of being conveyed home in Lady Dalrymple’s carriage, which was seen waiting at a little distance; she, Anne, and Mrs. Clay, therefore, turned into Molland’s, while Mr. Elliot stepped to Lady Dalrymple, to request her assistance.He soon joined them again, successful, of course; Lady Dalrymple would be most happy to take them home, and would call for them in a few minutes.

zh: 子爵夫人阁下的车子是一辆四轮大马车，只能坐四个人，人多了就不舒服了。卡特雷特小姐同她母亲在一起，因此卡姆登巷的三位女士不能指望都坐上车去。埃利奥特小姐无疑是要坐上去的。无论谁有什么不便，她也不能承受不便，不过解决另外两个人的谦让问题却花费了一番功夫。雨很小，安妮极其恳切地希望能同埃利奥特先生一块在雨中走回去。不过，克莱太太也不在乎这点雨，她简直就不认为天在下雨，再说，她的靴子又很厚，比安妮小姐的厚多了！总之，她的这番客套使她显得同安妮小姐一样迫切希望同埃利奥特先生一块走回去。两位女士有礼貌而又坚决地相互谦让，只好由别人来进行裁决了。埃利奥特小姐坚持认为克莱太太有点感冒，而埃利奥特先生受到请求，说他堂妹安妮的靴子更厚一些。
en: Her ladyship’s carriage was a barouche, and did not hold more than four with any comfort.Miss Carteret was with her mother; consequently it was not reasonable to expect accommodation for all the three Camden Place ladies.There could be no doubt as to Miss Elliot.Whoever suffered inconvenience, she must suffer none, but it occupied a little time to settle the point of civility between the other two.The rain was a mere trifle, and Anne was most sincere in preferring a walk with Mr. Elliot.But the rain was also a mere trifle to Mrs. Clay; she would hardly allow it even to drop at all, and her boots were so thick! much thicker than Miss Anne’s; and, in short, her civility rendered her quite as anxious to be left to walk with Mr. Elliot as Anne could be, and it was discussed between them with a generosity so polite and so determined, that the others were obliged to settle it for them; Miss Elliot maintaining that Mrs. Clay had a little cold already, and Mr. Elliot deciding on appeal, that his cousin Anne’s boots were rather the thickest.

zh: 因此，大家决定让克莱太太上车。他们刚作出这样的决定，坐在窗口的安妮就清清楚楚地看到温特沃思上校正沿着大街走来。
en: It was fixed accordingly, that Mrs. Clay should be of the party in the carriage; and they had just reached this point, when Anne, as she sat near the window, descried, most decidedly and distinctly, Captain Wentworth walking down the street.

zh: 她的惊讶只有她自己觉察到，但是她立即感觉到自己是这个世界上最大的傻瓜，最不可理解、最荒唐的人！一时之间，她眼前什么也看不见了，心中一片慌乱。她六神无主，等她责备了自己一通并回过神来时，她发现其他人正在等着上车，埃利奥特先生（总是那样殷勤）刚刚去联盟街为克莱太太办事了。
en: Her start was perceptible only to herself; but she instantly felt that she was the greatest simpleton in the world, the most unaccountable and absurd!For a few minutes she saw nothing before her; it was all confusion.She was lost, and when she had scolded back her senses, she found the others still waiting for the carriage, and Mr. Elliot (always obliging) just setting off for Union Street on a commission of Mrs. Clay’s.

zh: 这时安妮非常想到门外去，看看是否还在下雨。她为什么要怀疑自己别有用心呢？温特沃思上校准是已经走得没踪影了。她离开了座位，想离开。她头脑中的一种想法不见得总比另一种想法更聪明，也不应该总是怀疑另一种想法比实际的更坏。他要看看天是否还在下雨。可是她马上就转回来了，因为温特沃思上校已经走进来了，他身边的一群绅士和淑女显然是他的熟人，他准是在米尔萨姆街上离这里不远的地方遇上的。他一见到安妮便显得十分震惊和困惑，安妮还从没见过他这种神态。他满脸通红。自从他们重新交往以后，安妮头一回感到自己没有他那么激动。她在最后几分钟里有了思想准备，便比他从容了一些。那种强烈惊讶产生的不可抗拒、令人眩晕和慌乱的最初效应已经消逝。不过，她仍然百感交集！是激动、痛苦、高兴，真是有点悲喜交加。
en: She now felt a great inclination to go to the outer door; she wanted to see if it rained.Why was she to suspect herself of another motive?Captain Wentworth must be out of sight.She left her seat, she would go; one half of her should not be always so much wiser than the other half, or always suspecting the other of being worse than it was.She would see if it rained.She was sent back, however, in a moment by the entrance of Captain Wentworth himself, among a party of gentlemen and ladies, evidently his acquaintance, and whom he must have joined a little below Milsom Street.He was more obviously struck and confused by the sight of her than she had ever observed before; he looked quite red.For the first time, since their renewed acquaintance, she felt that she was betraying the least sensibility of the two.She had the advantage of him in the preparation of the last few moments.All the overpowering, blinding, bewildering, first effects of strong surprise were over with her.Still, however, she had enough to feel!It was agitation, pain, pleasure, a something between delight and misery.

zh: 温特沃思上校跟安妮说了几句话，便转过身去了。他显得很尴尬。她既不能说他冷漠或友好，也不能说他窘迫。
en: He spoke to her, and then turned away.The character of his manner was embarrassment.She could not have called it either cold or friendly, or anything so certainly as embarrassed.

zh: 不过，过了一会儿，他又朝安妮走过来了，说了几句话。两人相互询问了共同感兴趣的问题，不过他们可能都没有听清楚对方说了些什么，安妮仍然觉得温特沃思上校没有以前那么洒脱了。以往他们常在一起，相互闲谈时表面上都很自然，也很平静，但是他现在却做不到了。时间改变了他，或者路易莎改变了他。温特沃思看上去有点不太好意思。他看上去很健康，不像经历过肉体或精神上的折磨。他谈起了阿珀克罗斯，谈起马斯格罗夫一家，甚至谈起了路易莎。在提到路易莎时，他脸上甚至掠过一副既俏皮又神气的表情。尽管如此，温特沃思上校仍然显得不太自然，有些拘束，无法装出泰然自若的样子。
en: After a short interval, however, he came towards her, and spoke again.Mutual enquiries on common subjects passed: neither of them, probably, much the wiser for what they heard, and Anne continuing fully sensible of his being less at ease than formerly.They had by dint of being so very much together, got to speak to each other with a considerable portion of apparent indifference and calmness; but he could not do it now.Time had changed him, or Louisa had changed him.There was consciousness of some sort or other.He looked very well, not as if he had been suffering in health or spirits, and he talked of Uppercross, of the Musgroves, nay, even of Louisa, and had even a momentary look of his own arch significance as he named her; but yet it was Captain Wentworth not comfortable, not easy, not able to feign that he was.

zh: 安妮发现伊丽莎白不肯同温特沃思上校打招呼时并不感到吃惊，但是心里很难过。她知道温特沃思上校看见了伊丽莎白，而且伊丽莎白也看见了他，双方都完全认出了对方。她相信温特沃思上校以为伊丽莎白会把他当作熟人打招呼的，所以正等着呢。但是安妮痛苦地看到，她姐姐坚定而冷漠地将脸转过去了。
en: It did not surprise, but it grieved Anne to observe that Elizabeth would not know him.She saw that he saw Elizabeth, that Elizabeth saw him, that there was complete internal recognition on each side; she was convinced that he was ready to be acknowledged as an acquaintance, expecting it, and she had the pain of seeing her sister turn away with unalterable coldness.

zh: 埃利奥特小姐正等得不耐烦的时候，达尔林普尔夫人的马车驶过来了。仆人过来通报。天又开始下雨了，总之，他们先是磨蹭了一下，忙了一阵，说了几句，这样一来，商店里的那些人都知道是达尔林普尔夫人的马车来送埃利奥特小姐回家。最后，埃利奥特小姐和她的朋友都走开了，只有仆人陪着她们上车（因为堂哥还没有回来），温特沃思上校望着他们，脸再次转向安妮，他虽然嘴上没说，但是举止上可以看出来，他愿意扶她上车。
en: Lady Dalrymple’s carriage, for which Miss Elliot was growing very impatient, now drew up; the servant came in to announce it.It was beginning to rain again, and altogether there was a delay, and a bustle, and a talking, which must make all the little crowd in the shop understand that Lady Dalrymple was calling to convey Miss Elliot.At last Miss Elliot and her friend, unattended but by the servant, (for there was no cousin returned), were walking off; and Captain Wentworth, watching them, turned again to Anne, and by manner, rather than words, was offering his services to her.

zh: “非常感谢你，”她回答说，“不过，我不和她们一起走。马车上坐不下这么多的人。我走回去，我喜欢走路。”
en: “I am much obliged to you,” was her answer, “but I am not going with them.The carriage would not accommodate so many.I walk: I prefer walking.”

zh: “可是天在下雨。”
en: “But it rains.”

zh: “哦！雨很小，我看这不算雨。”
en: “Oh! very little, Nothing that I regard.”

zh: 停了片刻后，他说：“虽然我昨天才到这里，我已经为在巴斯生活做好了准备，你看，”（指一下新伞）“如果你执意走路，我希望你能拿着这把伞。不过，我想我最好还是帮你雇一辆单座马车。”
en: After a moment’s pause he said: “Though I came only yesterday, I have equipped myself properly for Bath already, you see,” (pointing to a new umbrella); “I wish you would make use of it, if you are determined to walk; though I think it would be more prudent to let me get you a chair.”

zh: 安妮非常感激他，但还是谢绝了。她一再表示，眼下的雨算不了什么。又补充道：“我正在等埃利奥特先生。我想他一会儿就回来了。”
en: She was very much obliged to him, but declined it all, repeating her conviction, that the rain would come to nothing at present, and adding, “I am only waiting for Mr. Elliot.He will be here in a moment, I am sure.”

zh: 安妮刚说完，埃利奥特先生就走了进来。温特沃思上校完全记得他。他和那个站在莱姆台阶上用爱慕的眼光望着安妮走过的那个人毫无两样，只是在神态、表情和举止上表现出他拥有作为一个亲戚和朋友的特权。他匆匆忙忙地走进来，似乎看到的、想到的只是安妮，他为自己的耽搁表示歉意，对于让安妮久等感到内疚，只想在雨下大之前赶紧把安妮带走。转眼间，他们便一起离开了。安妮挽着他的胳膊，从温特沃思上校面前走过时，只是温情而又尴尬地匆匆望了他一眼，说了声“再见”。
en: She had hardly spoken the words when Mr. Elliot walked in.Captain Wentworth recollected him perfectly.There was no difference between him and the man who had stood on the steps at Lyme, admiring Anne as she passed, except in the air and look and manner of the privileged relation and friend.He came in with eagerness, appeared to see and think only of her, apologised for his stay, was grieved to have kept her waiting, and anxious to get her away without further loss of time and before the rain increased; and in another moment they walked off together, her arm under his, a gentle and embarrassed glance, and a “Good morning to you!” being all that she had time for, as she passed away.

zh: 等他们的身影消失之后，与温特沃思上校同行的女士们就纷纷议论开了。
en: As soon as they were out of sight, the ladies of Captain Wentworth’s party began talking of them.

zh: “我想，埃利奥特先生并不讨厌他的堂妹吧？”
en: “Mr. Elliot does not dislike his cousin, I fancy?”

zh: “啊！当然了，这是明摆着的。谁都会猜到将来会发生什么。他总是跟他们在一起，我想他有一半的时间是在她家里度过的。多么英俊的男子啊！”
en: “Oh! no, that is clear enough.One can guess what will happen there.He is always with them; half lives in the family, I believe.What a very good-looking man!”

zh: “是啊，阿特金森小姐曾经同他一起在沃利斯家一起吃过饭，说他是她遇到过的最讨人喜欢的男子。”
en: “Yes, and Miss Atkinson, who dined with him once at the Wallises, says he is the most agreeable man she ever was in company with.”

zh: “我觉得安妮•埃利奥特很漂亮。仔细看她的话，的确很漂亮。这么说似乎不大符合潮流，但是我承认，比起她姐姐，我更喜欢她。”
en: “She is pretty, I think; Anne Elliot; very pretty, when one comes to look at her.It is not the fashion to say so, but I confess I admire her more than her sister.”

zh: “哦！我也是。”
en: “Oh! so do I.”

zh: “我也是。她们两人之间是无法相比的。不过男人们都疯狂地追求埃利奥特小姐。安妮对他们来说太娇贵了。”
en: “And so do I. No comparison.But the men are all wild after Miss Elliot.Anne is too delicate for them.”

zh: 如果堂兄一声不吭地一直陪她走到卡姆登巷，安妮会对他感激不尽的。安妮从来没有觉得听他讲话这么困难，尽管他对安妮关怀备至、照顾周到，尽管他的话题基本上像往常一样，还是那么有趣：对拉塞尔夫人的赞美热情、公正而又有鉴赏力，对克莱太太的影射也十分在理。但是安妮这时一心只想着温特沃思上校。她无法想象他现在是种什么心情，他是否真正感到失望。不搞清楚这一点，她就无法平静下来。
en: Anne would have been particularly obliged to her cousin, if he would have walked by her side all the way to Camden Place, without saying a word.She had never found it so difficult to listen to him, though nothing could exceed his solicitude and care, and though his subjects were principally such as were wont to be always interesting: praise, warm, just, and discriminating, of Lady Russell, and insinuations highly rational against Mrs. Clay.But just now she could think only of Captain Wentworth.She could not understand his present feelings, whether he were really suffering much from disappointment or not; and till that point were settled, she could not be quite herself.

zh: 她希望自己能很快变得明智和理智起来。但是天哪！天哪！她必须承认自己现在还不明智。
en: She hoped to be wise and reasonable in time; but alas!alas! she must confess to herself that she was not wise yet.

zh: 还有个极其重要的情况需要她知道，那就是他要在巴斯呆多久。他没有说，或者是她自己想不起来了。不过，他更有可能要是来这里住上一阵子。如果是这样，鉴于在巴斯人人都可能相遇，拉塞尔夫人很有可能在某个地方遇见他。她还能想起他来吗？事情又会怎么样呢？
en: Another circumstance very essential for her to know, was how long he meant to be in Bath; he had not mentioned it, or she could not recollect it.He might be only passing through.But it was more probable that he should be come to stay.In that case, so liable as every body was to meet every body in Bath, Lady Russell would in all likelihood see him somewhere.Would she recollect him?How would it all be?

zh: 她已经不得不告诉拉塞尔夫人说，路易莎•马斯格罗夫要嫁给本威克舰长了。看到拉塞尔夫人吃惊的样子，安妮心里很不是滋味。现在拉塞尔夫人对事情还不是十分了解，要是再偶然遇见温特沃思上校，可能会加深她对温特沃思上校的偏见。
en: She had already been obliged to tell Lady Russell that Louisa Musgrove was to marry Captain Benwick.It had cost her something to encounter Lady Russell’s surprise; and now, if she were by any chance to be thrown into company with Captain Wentworth, her imperfect knowledge of the matter might add another shade of prejudice against him.

zh: 第二天早晨，安妮同她的朋友一道出去，在头一个小时，安妮一直提心吊胆地留意温特沃思上校，却没有看见他。但是，最后在她们沿着普尔蒂尼街往回走的时候，她看见他走在右手边的人行道上，他所处的位置隔着半条街也能看得见。他周围有很多人，很多群人朝着同一个方向走，但是，没错，就是他。安妮下意识地看了拉塞尔夫人一眼。但这并非由于她傻乎乎地认为拉塞尔夫人会像她一样，一眼就会认出温特沃思上校。不，除非他们迎面走过，拉塞尔夫人才会认出他。不过安妮还是焦急不安，不时地瞅瞅拉塞尔夫人。等到能看清楚上校的时候，安妮虽说不敢再看拉塞尔夫人了（她知道自己的神情不宜让别人看见），但她十分清楚，拉塞尔夫人的目光完全转移到了上校身上——总之，她在目不转睛地注视着他。她完全可以理解，上校在拉塞尔夫人心中一定有一种魅力，使得她的目光很难从他身上移开。她一定会感到很惊讶，八九年的时光过去了，他一直在异国他乡服役，竟然丝毫没有丧失一点魅力！
en: The following morning Anne was out with her friend, and for the first hour, in an incessant and fearful sort of watch for him in vain; but at last, in returning down Pulteney Street, she distinguished him on the right hand pavement at such a distance as to have him in view the greater part of the street.There were many other men about him, many groups walking the same way, but there was no mistaking him.She looked instinctively at Lady Russell; but not from any mad idea of her recognising him so soon as she did herself.No, it was not to be supposed that Lady Russell would perceive him till they were nearly opposite.She looked at her however, from time to time, anxiously; and when the moment approached which must point him out, though not daring to look again (for her own countenance she knew was unfit to be seen), she was yet perfectly conscious of Lady Russell’s eyes being turned exactly in the direction for him—of her being, in short, intently observing him.She could thoroughly comprehend the sort of fascination he must possess over Lady Russell’s mind, the difficulty it must be for her to withdraw her eyes, the astonishment she must be feeling that eight or nine years should have passed over him, and in foreign climes and in active service too, without robbing him of one personal grace!

zh: 拉塞尔夫人终于把头转过来了。“现在她会怎么议论他呢？”
en: At last, Lady Russell drew back her head.“Now, how would she speak of him?”

zh: “你大概很奇怪，”她说，“这么久我的眼睛一直在看什么吧。我在找艾丽西亚夫人和弗兰克兰太太昨晚告诉我的那些窗帘。她们说在这段街的这边有一家客厅的窗帘是巴斯最漂亮和挂得最得当的。不过她们记不清门牌号了，我一直在寻找，看是那一家。不过，我得承认我还没有看见她们所说的那种窗帘。”
en: “You will wonder,” said she, “what has been fixing my eye so long; but I was looking after some window-curtains, which Lady Alicia and Mrs. Frankland were telling me of last night.They described the drawing-room window-curtains of one of the houses on this side of the way, and this part of the street, as being the handsomest and best hung of any in Bath, but could not recollect the exact number, and I have been trying to find out which it could be; but I confess I can see no curtains hereabouts that answer their description.”

zh: 安妮叹了口气，脸上一红，带着怜悯和不屑的心情笑了一下，不知是笑她的朋友还是笑她自己。最使她感到愤怒的是，她浪费了那么多时间去揣摩和关注拉塞尔夫人的反应，竟然错过了观察温特沃思上校是否注意到了她们的时机。
en: Anne sighed and blushed and smiled, in pity and disdain, either at her friend or herself.The part which provoked her most, was that in all this waste of foresight and caution, she should have lost the right moment for seeing whether he saw them.

zh: 一两天过去了，什么事情也没有发生。温特沃思上校很可能去剧院或参加晚会了，这对埃利奥特一家来说不是很时髦，他们晚上唯一的乐趣就是参加高雅而无聊的家庭宴会，而且他们参加这种宴会的次数越来越多。安妮厌倦了这种死气沉沉地生活，又因不知道外界情况而感到腻烦，觉得自己比以前更坚强了，因为自己的意志力没有经受过什么考验，急切地盼望着举行音乐会的那个晚上。这场音乐会是为达尔林普尔夫人资助的那个人举办的。当然，他们必须参加。这的确将是一次非常好的音乐会，而且温特沃思上校非常喜欢音乐。要是能够再跟他谈上几分钟，安妮就觉得自己心满意足了。至于说敢不敢跟他说话，安妮觉得只要有机会，她就有这个勇气。以前伊丽莎白没有理睬他，拉塞尔夫人对他视而不见，这些倒使安妮增强了勇气。她觉得自己应该关心一下他。
en: A day or two passed without producing anything.The theatre or the rooms, where he was most likely to be, were not fashionable enough for the Elliots, whose evening amusements were solely in the elegant stupidity of private parties, in which they were getting more and more engaged; and Anne, wearied of such a state of stagnation, sick of knowing nothing, and fancying herself stronger because her strength was not tried, was quite impatient for the concert evening.It was a concert for the benefit of a person patronised by Lady Dalrymple.Of course they must attend.It was really expected to be a good one, and Captain Wentworth was very fond of music.If she could only have a few minutes conversation with him again, she fancied she should be satisfied; and as to the power of addressing him, she felt all over courage if the opportunity occurred.Elizabeth had turned from him, Lady Russell overlooked him; her nerves were strengthened by these circumstances; she felt that she owed him attention.

zh: 她曾经不很肯定地答应过史密斯夫人晚上要跟她在一块。不过，她匆匆去看了一下史密斯太太，说了声抱歉，今天不能久留了，答应明天一定再来多坐一会儿。史密斯太太非常和颜悦色地默许了。
en: She had once partly promised Mrs. Smith to spend the evening with her; but in a short hurried call she excused herself and put it off, with the more decided promise of a longer visit on the morrow.Mrs. Smith gave a most good-humoured acquiescence.

zh: “好极了，”她说，“不过你再来的时候一定要告诉我音乐会的详细情况。哪些人和你一块去？”
en: “By all means,” said she; “only tell me all about it, when you do come.Who is your party?”

zh: 安妮把所有人的名字说了一遍。史密斯太太没有说话，但是安妮起身离开的时候，她半认真、半开玩笑地说：“好吧，我衷心希望你们的音乐会成功。要是你明天能来，就一定得来。因为我有种预感，你可能不能总来看我了。”
en: Anne named them all.Mrs. Smith made no reply; but when she was leaving her said, and with an expression half serious, half arch, “Well, I heartily wish your concert may answer; and do not fail me to-morrow if you can come; for I begin to have a foreboding that I may not have many more visits from you.”

zh: 安妮吃了一惊，觉得有些莫名其妙。不过，她迟疑地站了一会儿，就不得不匆匆离开了，但是她心里并不感到遗憾。
en: Anne was startled and confused; but after standing in a moment’s suspense, was obliged, and not sorry to be obliged, to hurry away.

zh: 第二十章
en: CHAPTER 20

zh: 沃尔特爵士、他的两个女儿以及克莱太太是那天晚上宴会上来得最早的。由于还得等候达尔林普尔夫人，他们就在八角厅的炉火旁坐了下来。不过，他们刚一坐定，门又打开了，温特沃思上校独自走了进来。安妮离他最近，却仍向前走了一步，立即打了声招呼。他本来准备好鞠个躬然后继续往前走的，但是安妮温柔地说了声“你好！”使得他没能径直地朝前走去，而是在安妮旁边站住回问起她的情况，尽管安妮那令人生畏的父亲和姐姐就在身后。对于安妮来说，他们都在背后是有利的，因为她看不见他们的脸色，而且也有勇气做她认为是正确的事情。
en: Sir Walter, his two daughters, and Mrs. Clay, were the earliest of all their party at the rooms in the evening; and as Lady Dalrymple must be waited for, they took their station by one of the fires in the Octagon Room.But hardly were they so settled, when the door opened again, and Captain Wentworth walked in alone.Anne was the nearest to him, and making yet a little advance, she instantly spoke.He was preparing only to bow and pass on, but her gentle “How do you do?” brought him out of the straight line to stand near her, and make enquiries in return, in spite of the formidable father and sister in the back ground.Their being in the back ground was a support to Anne; she knew nothing of their looks, and felt equal to everything which she believed right to be done.

zh: 在他们说话的时候，安妮听见她父亲和伊丽莎白在窃窃私语。她听不清楚，但是她可以猜到他们说话的内容；温特沃思上校远远地鞠了个躬，安妮明白父亲经过思考已经打了个招呼，表示他们是认识的。她眼睛往旁边一瞥，正好看见伊丽莎白微微行了一个屈膝礼。这种表示虽然晚了些，而且态度勉强，也不太礼貌，但是总比毫无表示要强，安妮的心情也有所好转。
en: While they were speaking, a whispering between her father and Elizabeth caught her ear.She could not distinguish, but she must guess the subject; and on Captain Wentworth’s making a distant bow, she comprehended that her father had judged so well as to give him that simple acknowledgement of acquaintance, and she was just in time by a side glance to see a slight curtsey from Elizabeth herself.This, though late, and reluctant, and ungracious, was yet better than nothing, and her spirits improved.

zh: 然而，两人在谈了天气、巴斯和音乐会之后，接下来他们的话渐渐减少了，最后几乎无话可说了。安妮以为他随时都会走开，但是他没有。他看起来似乎并不急于离开她。过了一会儿，他又恢复了兴致，微笑着，脸上露出了淡淡的红晕，他说：
en: After talking, however, of the weather, and Bath, and the concert, their conversation began to flag, and so little was said at last, that she was expecting him to go every moment, but he did not; he seemed in no hurry to leave her; and presently with renewed spirit, with a little smile, a little glow, he said—

zh: “自从我们在莱姆的那天以后，我几乎没怎么见过你。我恐怕你那次一定是受惊了，虽然你当时没有吓晕过去，但是一定受惊得很厉害吧。”
en: “I have hardly seen you since our day at Lyme.I am afraid you must have suffered from the shock, and the more from its not overpowering you at the time.”

zh: 她向他保证说她没有受惊。
en: She assured him that she had not.

zh: “那是个可怕的时刻，”他说，“可怕的一天！”他用手揉了一下眼睛，仿佛回忆起这件事情来仍然非常痛苦，但是一会儿他又微微一笑，接着说道：“不过，那天的事情还是产生了一定的影响，应该说是绝非可怕的影响。当时你镇定自若地建议最好让本威克舰长去请外科医生时，你肯定想不到他会最终成为最关心路易莎恢复的人吧。”
en: “It was a frightful hour,” said he, “a frightful day!” and he passed his hand across his eyes, as if the remembrance were still too painful, but in a moment, half smiling again, added, “The day has produced some effects however; has had some consequences which must be considered as the very reverse of frightful.When you had the presence of mind to suggest that Benwick would be the properest person to fetch a surgeon, you could have little idea of his being eventually one of those most concerned in her recovery.”

zh: “我当然不可能想到。但是看起来——我倒是希望它会是一桩比较美满的婚姻。他们双方都有好的操守和好的性情。”
en: “Certainly I could have none.But it appears—I should hope it would be a very happy match.There are on both sides good principles and good temper.”

zh: “对啊，”他说，看样子并不十分爽快，“不过，我想他们的相似之处也就只有这些了。我全心全意地祝他们幸福，并为促进他们幸福的一切感到高兴。他们在家里没有遇到什么困难，没有反对，没有出尔反尔，也没有拖延。马斯格罗夫夫妇还是和往常一样，非常正直而友善，只是出于父母的真心，希望促进女儿的幸福。这一切都对他们的幸福有利，而且非常有利，或许比——”
en: “Yes,” said he, looking not exactly forward; “but there, I think, ends the resemblance.With all my soul I wish them happy, and rejoice over every circumstance in favour of it.They have no difficulties to contend with at home, no opposition, no caprice, no delays.The Musgroves are behaving like themselves, most honourably and kindly, only anxious with true parental hearts to promote their daughter’s comfort.All this is much, very much in favour of their happiness; more than perhaps—”

zh: 他打住了。他似乎想起了什么，只见安妮满脸通红，眼睛盯着地面，他仿佛感受到了这种强烈感情。不过，他清了清嗓子，接着说道：
en: He stopped.A sudden recollection seemed to occur, and to give him some taste of that emotion which was reddening Anne’s cheeks and fixing her eyes on the ground.After clearing his throat, however, he proceeded thus—

zh: “我承认他们彼此间有差距，而且差距很大，从某种层次上来说，不亚于心灵上的差距。我认为路易莎•马斯格罗夫是一位非常和善、十分温和的姑娘，并不缺乏理解力，但是本威克更胜一筹。他是个聪明人，博览群书。我承认，我觉得他爱上路易莎确实让我有点吃惊。假如是出于感激之情，假如是他以为路易莎看上了自己才使他爱上她，那就另当别论了。但是，我觉得没有理由这么认为。相反，他的感情看起来是完全出于本能，完全自发的，这使我感到惊讶。像他这样一个人，又处在那种情况！他的心受过刺激，受过创伤，几乎都碎了！范妮•哈维尔是一位杰出的女子，他对范妮的感情是真心实意的。一个男人是无法从对这么一个女子如此真挚的感情中恢复过来的。他不应该，他也做不到。”
en: “I confess that I do think there is a disparity, too great a disparity, and in a point no less essential than mind.I regard Louisa Musgrove as a very amiable, sweet-tempered girl, and not deficient in understanding, but Benwick is something more.He is a clever man, a reading man; and I confess, that I do consider his attaching himself to her with some surprise.Had it been the effect of gratitude, had he learnt to love her, because he believed her to be preferring him, it would have been another thing.But I have no reason to suppose it so.It seems, on the contrary, to have been a perfectly spontaneous, untaught feeling on his side, and this surprises me.A man like him, in his situation! with a heart pierced, wounded, almost broken!Fanny Harville was a very superior creature, and his attachment to her was indeed attachment.A man does not recover from such a devotion of the heart to such a woman.He ought not; he does not.”

zh: 这时，他或许是想到他的朋友已经恢复过来了，或许是想到了其他事情，反正他没有再说下去。尽管他说到后来声音很激动，尽管满屋人声嘈杂，而且还有人不断碰门和走路的窸窣声，安妮仍然听清楚了每一个字。她感到惊讶、感激、迷惑，呼吸变得急促起来，只觉得百感交集。要她讨论这个话题是不可能的。然而，她在停了一会儿之后，觉得有必要说几句，但又根本不想转变话题，只是使内容稍微偏离了一点而已：
en: Either from the consciousness, however, that his friend had recovered, or from other consciousness, he went no farther; and Anne who, in spite of the agitated voice in which the latter part had been uttered, and in spite of all the various noises of the room, the almost ceaseless slam of the door, and ceaseless buzz of persons walking through, had distinguished every word, was struck, gratified, confused, and beginning to breathe very quick, and feel an hundred things in a moment.It was impossible for her to enter on such a subject; and yet, after a pause, feeling the necessity of speaking, and having not the smallest wish for a total change, she only deviated so far as to say—

zh: “我想，你在莱姆呆了不少日子吧？”
en: “You were a good while at Lyme, I think?”

zh: “两个星期左右。我一直等到路易莎确定脱离了危险才离开。对这次不幸事件我深感内疚，无法很快平静下来。这都是我造成的，全都是我造成的。如果我不是那么软弱，她就不会那么固执。莱姆周围的风景非常好。我在那儿常常散步和骑马。我见到的越多，发现值得欣赏的风景点也越多。”
en: “About a fortnight.I could not leave it till Louisa’s doing well was quite ascertained.I had been too deeply concerned in the mischief to be soon at peace.It had been my doing, solely mine.She would not have been obstinate if I had not been weak.The country round Lyme is very fine.I walked and rode a great deal; and the more I saw, the more I found to admire.”

zh: “我真想再去莱姆看看。”安妮说。
en: “I should very much like to see Lyme again,” said Anne.

zh: “真的吗？我真没想到你会在莱姆发现了激起你这种感情的东西。你卷入了这么恐怖和痛苦的事情，一定感到思想紧张、精神疲惫！我本以为莱姆给你留下的最后印象一定是深恶痛绝的。”
en: “Indeed!I should not have supposed that you could have found anything in Lyme to inspire such a feeling.The horror and distress you were involved in, the stretch of mind, the wear of spirits!I should have thought your last impressions of Lyme must have been strong disgust.”

zh: “最后几个小时当然是非常痛苦的，”安妮回答道，“不过，痛苦过去以后再回想回想，却又常常感到很愉快。一个人不会因为在某个地方有过痛苦的经历而减少对那里的热爱，除非那里只有痛苦，除了痛苦之外一无所有，而莱姆决非是这种情况。我们只是在最后两个小时内感到焦虑和不安，在这之前大家有过很多欢乐的时刻。那里有那么多新奇而美好的事物！我很少旅行，因此每到一个新鲜的地方，对我来说都很有趣，不过莱姆确实很美。总之，”（她似乎回忆起了什么事情，脸上泛起了淡淡的红晕），“总的来说，我对这个地方的印象还是很不错的。”
en: “The last hours were certainly very painful,” replied Anne; “but when pain is over, the remembrance of it often becomes a pleasure.One does not love a place the less for having suffered in it, unless it has been all suffering, nothing but suffering, which was by no means the case at Lyme.We were only in anxiety and distress during the last two hours, and previously there had been a great deal of enjoyment.So much novelty and beauty!I have travelled so little, that every fresh place would be interesting to me; but there is real beauty at Lyme; and in short” (with a faint blush at some recollections), “altogether my impressions of the place are very agreeable.”

zh: 她话音刚落，入口的大门又打开了，出现的正是大家期待的那些人。人们高兴地喊了起来：“达尔林普尔夫人，达尔林普尔夫人。”沃尔特爵士和他家的两位女士非常热切而彬彬有礼地迎上前去。达尔林普尔夫人和卡特雷特小姐在埃利奥特先生和沃利斯上校的陪同下走进屋里——他们与夫人几乎同时到达。其他人都迎了上去，安妮觉得自己也必须迎上前去。她同温特沃思上校分开了。他们之间有趣的、引人入胜的谈话不得不暂时中断，但是这种苦恼同带来这一苦恼的欢乐比起来，是微不足道的！就在刚才的十分钟里，安妮进一步了解了他对路易莎的感情，也明白了他的各种心思，这些事情是她以前所不敢想的。因此她就听从人们的要求，以一种非常微妙而又颇为激动的心情，去适应当时应酬的需要。她对所有人都很友好。刚才了解到的一切促使她非常有礼貌、非常友善地对待每一个人，并怜悯所有的人，因为他们不像她那么幸福。
en: As she ceased, the entrance door opened again, and the very party appeared for whom they were waiting.“Lady Dalrymple, Lady Dalrymple,” was the rejoicing sound; and with all the eagerness compatible with anxious elegance, Sir Walter and his two ladies stepped forward to meet her.Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret, escorted by Mr. Elliot and Colonel Wallis, who had happened to arrive nearly at the same instant, advanced into the room.The others joined them, and it was a group in which Anne found herself also necessarily included.She was divided from Captain Wentworth.Their interesting, almost too interesting conversation must be broken up for a time, but slight was the penance compared with the happiness which brought it on!She had learnt, in the last ten minutes, more of his feelings towards Louisa, more of all his feelings than she dared to think of; and she gave herself up to the demands of the party, to the needful civilities of the moment, with exquisite, though agitated sensations.She was in good humour with all.She had received ideas which disposed her to be courteous and kind to all, and to pity every one, as being less happy than herself.

zh: 当安妮离开那些人，打算再同温特沃思上校交谈时，发现他已经走开了，兴奋的心情变略有减退。她正好看见他走进音乐厅。他走了，不见了，安妮一时感到有些遗憾。不过“我们还会再见面的。他会来找我的，在晚会结束前他会来找我的。现在，两人分开一会儿也许更好些。我需要点时间回想一下。”
en: The delightful emotions were a little subdued, when on stepping back from the group, to be joined again by Captain Wentworth, she saw that he was gone.She was just in time to see him turn into the Concert Room.He was gone; he had disappeared, she felt a moment’s regret.But “they should meet again.He would look for her, he would find her out before the evening were over, and at present, perhaps, it was as well to be asunder.She was in need of a little interval for recollection.”

zh: 不一会儿，拉塞尔夫人也来了，大家都到齐了，只等着依次进入音乐厅了。大家摆足架子，尽可能吸引别人的注目、窃窃私语和心神不宁。
en: Upon Lady Russell’s appearance soon afterwards, the whole party was collected, and all that remained was to marshal themselves, and proceed into the Concert Room; and be of all the consequence in their power, draw as many eyes, excite as many whispers, and disturb as many people as they could.

zh: 伊丽莎白和安妮•埃利奥特进入音乐厅时都感到无比幸福。伊丽莎白挽着卡特雷特小姐的手臂，望着前面达尔林普尔子爵遗孀的宽阔的背部，似乎自己没有什么奢望是不可企及的。而安妮——不过，要将她的幸福性质同她的姐姐相比，那对她来说是一种侮辱。一方面是出于自私的虚荣，另一方面是出于丰富的感情。
en: Very, very happy were both Elizabeth and Anne Elliot as they walked in.Elizabeth arm in arm with Miss Carteret, and looking on the broad back of the dowager Viscountess Dalrymple before her, had nothing to wish for which did not seem within her reach; and Anne—but it would be an insult to the nature of Anne’s felicity, to draw any comparison between it and her sister’s; the origin of one all selfish vanity, of the other all generous attachment.

zh: 安妮没有看到，也没有想到这间屋子的金碧辉煌。她的快乐是发自内心的。她的眼睛亮晶晶的、两颊发红，但她对此却毫无察觉。她脑子里只想着刚才的那半个小时，当他们朝座位走去时，安妮匆匆回想了一下当时的一幕。温特沃思上校选择的话题，他的谈吐，特别是他的举止和表情，使她只能产生一种看法。他似乎急切地要把他对路易莎弱点的看法告诉安妮，他对本威克舰长的惊讶，他对炽热初恋的感受，他说出口却没有说完的话语，他稍稍移开的眼睛以及那意味深长的目光，这一切的一切都表明他至少对安妮回心转意了。他的愤怒、怨恨和回避已经不复存在了。取而代之的不止是友谊与关切，还有往日的柔情。是的，还有几分往日的柔情。她不能不认为这种变化是意味深长的。他一定还爱着她。
en: Anne saw nothing, thought nothing of the brilliancy of the room.Her happiness was from within.Her eyes were bright and her cheeks glowed; but she knew nothing about it.She was thinking only of the last half hour, and as they passed to their seats, her mind took a hasty range over it.His choice of subjects, his expressions, and still more his manner and look, had been such as she could see in only one light.His opinion of Louisa Musgrove’s inferiority, an opinion which he had seemed solicitous to give, his wonder at Captain Benwick, his feelings as to a first, strong attachment; sentences begun which he could not finish, his half averted eyes and more than half expressive glance, all, all declared that he had a heart returning to her at least; that anger, resentment, avoidance, were no more; and that they were succeeded, not merely by friendship and regard, but by the tenderness of the past.Yes, some share of the tenderness of the past.She could not contemplate the change as implying less.He must love her.

zh: 她一心想着这些念头，脑海中浮现的是当时的种种情景，搅得她心慌意乱，使她没有能力去留心周围的事情。她在大厅走过时没有瞥见他，甚至并不想仔细地找他。等大家坐定，安排妥当以后，她环顾四周看他是否恰巧坐在附近，但是他不在，安妮没有看见他。这时，音乐会正好开始，她只得满足于暂时抑制一下内心的幸福。
en: These were thoughts, with their attendant visions, which occupied and flurried her too much to leave her any power of observation; and she passed along the room without having a glimpse of him, without even trying to discern him.When their places were determined on, and they were all properly arranged, she looked round to see if he should happen to be in the same part of the room, but he was not; her eye could not reach him; and the concert being just opening, she must consent for a time to be happy in a humbler way.

zh: 他们这一群人分别坐在两张相邻的长凳上，安妮坐在前排，埃利奥特先生在他的朋友沃利斯上校的安排下，十分巧妙地坐到了安妮的旁边。埃利奥特小姐感到非常满意，因为坐在她周围的都是她的表亲，而且她是沃利斯上校献殷勤的主要对象。
en: The party was divided and disposed of on two contiguous benches: Anne was among those on the foremost, and Mr. Elliot had manoeuvred so well, with the assistance of his friend Colonel Wallis, as to have a seat by her.Miss Elliot, surrounded by her cousins, and the principal object of Colonel Wallis’s gallantry, was quite contented.

zh: 安妮以十分愉快的心情对待这天晚上的节目，这是一种恰到好处的消遣：她能体会音乐的柔情，喜欢欢快的曲调，能领略精确的演奏技巧，对那些令人厌烦的部分也能忍受。她从来没有这么喜欢过一场音乐会，至少在上半场是如此。在上半场快结束时，趁着唱完一首意大利歌曲的间隙，她给埃利奥特先生解释歌词的内容。他们两人共看一份曲目单。
en: Anne’s mind was in a most favourable state for the entertainment of the evening; it was just occupation enough: she had feelings for the tender, spirits for the gay, attention for the scientific, and patience for the wearisome; and had never liked a concert better, at least during the first act.Towards the close of it, in the interval succeeding an Italian song, she explained the words of the song to Mr. Elliot.They had a concert bill between them.

zh: 她说：“这就是歌词的大意，或者更确切地说，这就是歌词的意思，因为意大利爱情歌曲的含义当然是无法言传的，不过这就是我所能说明白的歌词的意思。因为我不想对这个语言不懂装懂。我的意大利语学得很差。”
en: “This,” said she, “is nearly the sense, or rather the meaning of the words, for certainly the sense of an Italian love-song must not be talked of, but it is as nearly the meaning as I can give; for I do not pretend to understand the language.I am a very poor Italian scholar.”

zh: “是的，是的，我知道你学得很差。我知道你对此什么都不懂。你只有那么一点语言知识，只不过一看到这些倒装、变位、缩略的意大利语就可以译成清晰、易懂、优美的英语。你再也不用说你才疏学浅了。这就是充足的证据。”
en: “Yes, yes, I see you are.I see you know nothing of the matter.You have only knowledge enough of the language to translate at sight these inverted, transposed, curtailed Italian lines, into clear, comprehensible, elegant English.You need not say anything more of your ignorance.Here is complete proof.”

zh: “我不会对你这样客气的夸奖提出异议。不过，要是一个真正的专家来考我，那就糟了。”
en: “I will not oppose such kind politeness; but I should be sorry to be examined by a real proficient.”

zh: “我要不是成为了卡姆登巷的常客，就不会对安妮•埃利奥特小姐有所了解。我确实认为她过于谦虚，使人们对她的才智不甚了解，而她拥有高度修养，要是在另一位女士身上，这种谦虚就会不自然了。”
en: “I have not had the pleasure of visiting in Camden Place so long,” replied he, “without knowing something of Miss Anne Elliot; and I do regard her as one who is too modest for the world in general to be aware of half her accomplishments, and too highly accomplished for modesty to be natural in any other woman.”

zh: “真不敢当！真不敢当！你这么说可就过奖了。我忘了，下一个曲目是什么。”说着便看起曲目单。
en: “For shame! for shame! this is too much flattery.I forget what we are to have next,” turning to the bill.

zh: “也许，”埃利奥特先生低声说，“你还不知道，我在认识你以前就了解你的性格了。”
en: “Perhaps,” said Mr. Elliot, speaking low, “I have had a longer acquaintance with your character than you are aware of.”

zh: “真的！怎么会？我到巴斯来以后你才认识我，除非你以前在我家里听他们谈论起我。”
en: “Indeed!How so?You can have been acquainted with it only since I came to Bath, excepting as you might hear me previously spoken of in my own family.”

zh: “早在你来巴斯以前我就听说过你了。我听到过非常了解你的人谈起过你。我已经了解你的性格好多年了。你的人品，你的性情，你的修养。你的举止——都有人向我谈起过。”
en: “I knew you by report long before you came to Bath.I had heard you described by those who knew you intimately.I have been acquainted with you by character many years.Your person, your disposition, accomplishments, manner; they were all present to me.”

zh: 埃利奥特先生果然如愿以偿，激起了他希望激起的安妮的兴趣。没有人能够抵挡住这种神秘的魅力。某人在很早以前就在这位新朋友面前谈起过她，这是难以抵制的好奇。安妮非常好奇。她很吃惊，急切地询问他，但是毫无结果。他很乐意被安妮询问，但是就是不肯说。
en: Mr. Elliot was not disappointed in the interest he hoped to raise.No one can withstand the charm of such a mystery.To have been described long ago to a recent acquaintance, by nameless people, is irresistible; and Anne was all curiosity.She wondered, and questioned him eagerly; but in vain.He delighted in being asked, but he would not tell.

zh: “不，不，也许以后某个时间，但是现在不行。现在我不愿意说出人家的名字。不过我向你保证，这是真的。很多年前，我就听人谈起过安妮•埃利奥特小姐，这就使我非常敬重你的美德，并激发了想与你结识的强烈的好奇心。”
en: “No, no, some time or other, perhaps, but not now.He would mention no names now; but such, he could assure her, had been the fact.He had many years ago received such a description of Miss Anne Elliot as had inspired him with the highest idea of her merit, and excited the warmest curiosity to know her.”

zh: 安妮觉得只有温特沃思上校的哥哥，就是住在蒙克福德的温特沃思先生，才会在很多年以前这么夸赞过她。他也许见过埃利奥特先生，但是安妮没有这个勇气去问。
en: Anne could think of no one so likely to have spoken with partiality of her many years ago as the Mr. Wentworth of Monkford, Captain Wentworth’s brother.He might have been in Mr. Elliot’s company, but she had not courage to ask the question.

zh: “安妮•埃利奥特这个名字，”他说，“早就对我具有有趣的吸引力。它早就对我产生了魅力。如果我有胆量，我愿意说出我的心愿，我希望这个名字永远不要改变。“
en: “The name of Anne Elliot,” said he, “has long had an interesting sound to me.Very long has it possessed a charm over my fancy; and, if I dared, I would breathe my wishes that the name might never change.”

zh: 安妮觉得他是这么说的。但是她刚一听到话音，她的注意力就被她身后的其他人的谈话吸引住了，这个谈话使得其他的一切事情都变得无足轻重了。她的父亲和达尔林普尔夫人正在说话。
en: Such, she believed, were his words; but scarcely had she received their sound, than her attention was caught by other sounds immediately behind her, which rendered every thing else trivial.Her father and Lady Dalrymple were speaking.

zh: “一个英俊的男人，”沃尔特爵士说道，“一个非常英俊的男人。”
en: “A well-looking man,” said Sir Walter, “a very well-looking man.”

zh: ”确实是非常潇洒的男人！“达尔林普尔夫人说道。“风度比在巴斯常见的那些人出众得多。我想，他是爱尔兰人吧。”
en: “A very fine young man indeed!” said Lady Dalrymple.“More air than one often sees in Bath.Irish, I dare say.”

zh: “不，我只知道他的名字。他是位点头之交。他姓温特沃思，温特沃思海军上校。他姐夫是我在萨默塞特郡的房客——克罗夫特，租下了凯林奇。”
en: “No, I just know his name.A bowing acquaintance.Wentworth; Captain Wentworth of the navy.His sister married my tenant in Somersetshire, the Croft, who rents Kellynch.”

zh: 沃尔特爵士话刚说到这里，安妮的目光看到了正确的方向，发现温特沃思上校正站在不远处的一群人当中。当安妮的目光落到他身上时，他的目光似乎正从安妮身上移开。看上去是这样的。安妮似乎晚了一步。她大胆地注视了那么久，而他却没有再看她一眼。演出又开始了，安妮不得不将她的注意力转向乐队，往前看去。
en: Before Sir Walter had reached this point, Anne’s eyes had caught the right direction, and distinguished Captain Wentworth standing among a cluster of men at a little distance.As her eyes fell on him, his seemed to be withdrawn from her.It had that appearance.It seemed as if she had been one moment too late; and as long as she dared observe, he did not look again: but the performance was recommencing, and she was forced to seem to restore her attention to the orchestra and look straight forward.

zh: 等到她再次转眼看去时，他已经走开了。他即使想走到安妮身边，他也难以办到。她被这么多人团团围住，但她更想看到他的眼睛。
en: When she could give another glance, he had moved away.He could not have come nearer to her if he would; she was so surrounded and shut in: but she would rather have caught his eye.

zh: 埃利奥特先生的那番话使她感到苦恼。她不想同他再谈下去。她希望他坐得不要离她这么近。
en: Mr. Elliot’s speech, too, distressed her.She had no longer any inclination to talk to him.She wished him not so near her.

zh: 音乐会的上半场结束了。安妮希望现在能出现一些有利的变化。大家闲聊了一会儿，有些人想要去喝杯茶。安妮是其中为数不多的不想离开的人。她留在自己的座位上，拉塞尔夫人也没有离开。不过她很高兴摆脱了埃利奥特先生。她觉得不管拉塞尔夫人怎么想，要是温特沃思上校给她机会的话，她是不会不敢同温特沃思上校交谈的。她从拉塞尔夫人的表情上可以看出，她已经看到温特沃思上校了。
en: The first act was over.Now she hoped for some beneficial change; and, after a period of nothing-saying amongst the party, some of them did decide on going in quest of tea.Anne was one of the few who did not choose to move.She remained in her seat, and so did Lady Russell; but she had the pleasure of getting rid of Mr. Elliot; and she did not mean, whatever she might feel on Lady Russell’s account, to shrink from conversation with Captain Wentworth, if he gave her the opportunity.She was persuaded by Lady Russell’s countenance that she had seen him.

zh: 不过，温特沃思上校没有走过来。安妮有时以为她看见他在远处，可是他从没有过来。令人焦虑不安的休息时间白白过去了。其他人回来了，房间里又挤满了人，大家重新坐回凳子上，一个小时的愉快或者苦恼又将开始，另一个小时的音乐使人高兴或打哈欠，这就要看对音乐的欣赏是真还是假了。对于安妮来说，这大概是焦虑不安的一个小时。要是不再看上一眼温特沃思，要是不能再同他交换一个友好的眼神，安妮是无法平静地走出这个音乐厅的。
en: He did not come however.Anne sometimes fancied she discerned him at a distance, but he never came.The anxious interval wore away unproductively.The others returned, the room filled again, benches were reclaimed and repossessed, and another hour of pleasure or of penance was to be sat out, another hour of music was to give delight or the gapes, as real or affected taste for it prevailed.To Anne, it chiefly wore the prospect of an hour of agitation.She could not quit that room in peace without seeing Captain Wentworth once more, without the interchange of one friendly look.

zh: 大家重新入座的时候，发生了很多变化，而这些变化对安妮来说是有利的。沃利斯上校不肯再坐下来，埃利奥特小姐和卡特雷特小姐以不容推辞的口吻邀请埃利奥特先生坐在她们中间。由于其他人也动了动，安妮自己也使了一点小小的计谋，于是她能够坐到比以前离长凳末端更近的地方，这样更容易接近过往的人。她这样做时，难免又要把自己同无法模仿的拉罗尔斯小姐相比。可是安妮还是这样做了，而且没有什么更令人高兴的结果。不过由于坐在她周围的人不断地早早离开，在音乐会结束之前，安妮发现自己就坐在长凳的末端。
en: In re-settling themselves there were now many changes, the result of which was favourable for her.Colonel Wallis declined sitting down again, and Mr. Elliot was invited by Elizabeth and Miss Carteret, in a manner not to be refused, to sit between them; and by some other removals, and a little scheming of her own, Anne was enabled to place herself much nearer the end of the bench than she had been before, much more within reach of a passer-by.She could not do so, without comparing herself with Miss Larolles, the inimitable Miss Larolles; but still she did it, and not with much happier effect; though by what seemed prosperity in the shape of an early abdication in her next neighbours, she found herself at the very end of the bench before the concert closed.

zh: 再次见到温特沃思上校时，安妮就坐在这个位置，旁边还有一个空位。她看见温特沃思上校就在附近。他也看见了她。但是神情严肃，似乎有点迟疑，慢腾腾地走到可以同她说话的地方。她觉得一定是出了什么事情。变化是不容置疑的。他这时的神情同在八角厅时的截然不同。这是怎么回事？她想到了她父亲，想到了拉塞尔夫人。难道他们的眼色令人不快？他先是严肃地谈起了音乐会，就像在阿珀克罗斯的温特沃思上校一样。他承认自己有些失望，他原本期望能听到更好的歌声。总之，他承认演出结束时，他才不会感到遗憾。安妮回答时，倒为演唱会辩护了一番，不过为了照顾到他的情绪，说得非常委婉巧妙，他的脸色缓和了下来，答话时也有了笑容。他们又谈了几分钟，气氛逐渐好转。他甚至朝长凳上望去，仿佛发现了一个值得一坐的好位子。就在这时，有人碰了碰安妮的肩膀，这使得她不得不转过身去。原来是埃利奥特先生。他向安妮表示抱歉，但不得不请安妮再解释一下意大利语。卡特雷特小姐非常急切地想了解下一个演奏曲目的大致意思。安妮无法拒绝。但是从来没有这么难受地为礼貌作出牺牲。
en: Such was her situation, with a vacant space at hand, when Captain Wentworth was again in sight.She saw him not far off.He saw her too; yet he looked grave, and seemed irresolute, and only by very slow degrees came at last near enough to speak to her.She felt that something must be the matter.The change was indubitable.The difference between his present air and what it had been in the Octagon Room was strikingly great.Why was it?She thought of her father, of Lady Russell.Could there have been any unpleasant glances?He began by speaking of the concert gravely, more like the Captain Wentworth of Uppercross; owned himself disappointed, had expected singing; and in short, must confess that he should not be sorry when it was over.Anne replied, and spoke in defence of the performance so well, and yet in allowance for his feelings so pleasantly, that his countenance improved, and he replied again with almost a smile.They talked for a few minutes more; the improvement held; he even looked down towards the bench, as if he saw a place on it well worth occupying; when at that moment a touch on her shoulder obliged Anne to turn round.It came from Mr. Elliot.He begged her pardon, but she must be applied to, to explain Italian again.Miss Carteret was very anxious to have a general idea of what was next to be sung.Anne could not refuse; but never had she sacrificed to politeness with a more suffering spirit.

zh: 安妮虽尽可能地简短，但是还是不可避免地花去了好几分钟。等她脱出身来，能够像先前那样转身看时，她发现上校正走上前来，拘谨而匆匆地向她告别。“我得向你说晚安了。我要走了，我得尽快回家。”
en: A few minutes, though as few as possible, were inevitably consumed; and when her own mistress again, when able to turn and look as she had done before, she found herself accosted by Captain Wentworth, in a reserved yet hurried sort of farewell.“He must wish her good night; he was going; he should get home as fast as he could.”

zh: “难道这首歌不值得你留下来听一听吗？”安妮说道，她突然想到了什么，所以更加急切地鼓励他留下。
en: “Is not this song worth staying for?” said Anne, suddenly struck by an idea which made her yet more anxious to be encouraging.

zh: “不！”他令人吃惊地回答道，“这里没有什么值得我留下来的，”说完，马上走了出去。
en: “No!” he replied impressively, “there is nothing worth my staying for;” and he was gone directly.

zh: 嫉妒埃利奥特先生！显而易见，这是唯一的理由。温特沃思上校对她的感情产生了嫉妒！就在一周以前，甚至三个小时以前她都不能相信！一时之间，她非常高兴。可是，天哪！她脑海中接着又出现了很多不同的念头。如何才能消除这种嫉妒呢？怎样让他知道事情的真相呢？他们各自的处境都特别不利，怎样才能让他了解自己的真实感情呢？安妮一想起埃利奥特先生的殷勤就苦恼。这番殷勤带来的祸害真是不可估量。
en: Jealousy of Mr. Elliot!It was the only intelligible motive.Captain Wentworth jealous of her affection!Could she have believed it a week ago; three hours ago!For a moment the gratification was exquisite.But, alas!there were very different thoughts to succeed.How was such jealousy to be quieted?How was the truth to reach him?How, in all the peculiar disadvantages of their respective situations, would he ever learn of her real sentiments?It was misery to think of Mr. Elliot’s attentions.Their evil was incalculable.

zh: 第二十一章
en: CHAPTER 21

zh: 安妮高兴地想起她曾答应第二天早晨要去看望史密斯太太，这就意味着她可以在埃利奥特先生最可能来访的时候出门了，因为避开埃利奥特先生几乎成了她现在的首要目标。
en: Anne recollected with pleasure the next morning her promise of going to Mrs. Smith, meaning that it should engage her from home at the time when Mr. Elliot would be most likely to call; for to avoid Mr. Elliot was almost a first object.

zh: 她对埃利奥特先生还是很有好感的。尽管他的殷勤带来了麻烦，但是她还是感激他、尊重他，或许是同情他。她不由得想起他们见面时不同寻常的情况，想到从他本人的感情，从他对她的一见钟情，从种种情况看来，他似乎有理由赢得安妮的好感。总之，这件事非常不同寻常，既让人欢喜又让人痛苦。这太叫人遗憾了。要是这件事情中没有温特沃思上校，她会怎么想，这个问题不值得探究，因为事实上有温特沃思上校。不管眼下悬而未决的结局是好是坏，安妮永远钟情于温特沃思上校。她觉得他们的结合同他们彻底分手相比，不见得会使她与其他的男人更为疏远。
en: She felt a great deal of good-will towards him.In spite of the mischief of his attentions, she owed him gratitude and regard, perhaps compassion.She could not help thinking much of the extraordinary circumstances attending their acquaintance, of the right which he seemed to have to interest her, by everything in situation, by his own sentiments, by his early prepossession.It was altogether very extraordinary; flattering, but painful.There was much to regret.How she might have felt had there been no Captain Wentworth in the case, was not worth enquiry; for there was a Captain Wentworth; and be the conclusion of the present suspense good or bad, her affection would be his for ever.Their union, she believed, could not divide her more from other men, than their final separation.

zh: 从卡姆登巷到西门大楼的路上，安妮浮想联翩，心中充满着对崇高爱情和永恒忠贞的沉思，巴斯的街道上是不可能有过比这样更美好的情思。这几乎在一路上洒下了净化和芬芳。
en: Prettier musings of high-wrought love and eternal constancy, could never have passed along the streets of Bath, than Anne was sporting with from Camden Place to Westgate Buildings.It was almost enough to spread purification and perfume all the way.

zh: 她知道自己肯定会受到友善的接待。她的朋友今天早晨看起来似乎特别感激她的到来，虽说她们事先约好了，但是她似乎没想到安妮会来。
en: She was sure of a pleasant reception; and her friend seemed this morning particularly obliged to her for coming, seemed hardly to have expected her, though it had been an appointment.

zh: 史密斯太太马上要安妮谈谈音乐会的情况。安妮对音乐会的回忆相当愉快，这使得她谈起来富有表情、兴致勃勃。凡是能说的，安妮都高兴地告诉了史密斯太太，但是对于一个曾经到过那里的人，这还远远不够，也不能使史密斯太太这样一个好打听的人感到满意，因为对于晚会的全面成功和效果，她已经从一位洗衣女工和招待那里听到了比安妮说的更为详细的情况。她现在问的是与会者的某些具体情况，可是却得不到满意的回答。史密斯太太对巴斯的每一位不管是举足轻重还是声名狼藉的人都很熟悉。
en: An account of the concert was immediately claimed; and Anne’s recollections of the concert were quite happy enough to animate her features and make her rejoice to talk of it.All that she could tell she told most gladly, but the all was little for one who had been there, and unsatisfactory for such an enquirer as Mrs. Smith, who had already heard, through the short cut of a laundress and a waiter, rather more of the general success and produce of the evening than Anne could relate, and who now asked in vain for several particulars of the company.Everybody of any consequence or notoriety in Bath was well know by name to Mrs. Smith.

zh: “我断定，矮子杜兰德一家也去了，”她说，“他们张着嘴巴听音乐，就像是羽翼未丰的麻雀等着喂食。他们从不错过一次音乐会。”
en: “The little Durands were there, I conclude,” said she, “with their mouths open to catch the music, like unfledged sparrows ready to be fed.They never miss a concert.”

zh: “是的。我自己没有看见他们，不过我听埃利奥特先生说他们在音乐厅里。”
en: “Yes; I did not see them myself, but I heard Mr. Elliot say they were in the room.”

zh: “伊博森一家，他们去了吗？那两个新来的美人和高个子的爱尔兰军官，据说他在追求她们中的一个。他们也去了吗？”
en: “The Ibbotsons, were they there? And the two new beauties, with the tall Irish officer, who is talked of for one of them.”

zh: “我不知道。我想他们没去。”
en: “I do not know.I do not think they were.”

zh: “玛丽•麦克莱恩老妇人呢？我不必问起她。我知道她从不缺席，你肯定看见她了。她肯定在你们那个圈子里，因为你既然是同达尔林普尔夫人一块去的，你们肯定坐在乐队附近的贵宾席上。”
en: “Old Lady Mary Maclean?I need not ask after her.She never misses, I know; and you must have seen her.She must have been in your own circle; for as you went with Lady Dalrymple, you were in the seats of grandeur, round the orchestra, of course.”

zh: “不，我就怕坐在那儿。对我来说，不论从哪方面看都是极不愉快的。不过，幸好达尔林普尔夫人总是选择坐得远一些。我们的座位非常好，我是就听音乐而言。就看的方面来说，我就不能这么说了，因为我好像没看见什么。”
en: “No, that was what I dreaded.It would have been very unpleasant to me in every respect.But happily Lady Dalrymple always chooses to be farther off; and we were exceedingly well placed, that is, for hearing; I must not say for seeing, because I appear to have seen very little.”

zh: “哦！你见到的已经够你高兴的了。我能理解。即使是在人群中也能享受到某种家庭的乐趣，你已经享受到了这种乐趣。你们所在的圈子是很大的一群人，你不需要圈外的一切了。”
en: “Oh! you saw enough for your own amusement.I can understand.There is a sort of domestic enjoyment to be known even in a crowd, and this you had.You were a large party in yourselves, and you wanted nothing beyond.”

zh: “不过，我应该多看看四周的。”安妮说时也意识到了她当时实在没有必要向四处张望，她并不想看什么人。
en: “But I ought to have looked about me more,” said Anne, conscious while she spoke that there had in fact been no want of looking about, that the object only had been deficient.

zh: “不，不。你有更有意义的事情要干。你不用告诉我，你昨天晚上度过了一个愉快的夜晚。我从你的眼睛里看出来了。我完全看得出你的时光是怎么度过的：你总是有一些令人愉快的东西可以听。还有音乐会休息时间的聊天。”
en: “No, no; you were better employed.You need not tell me that you had a pleasant evening.I see it in your eye.I perfectly see how the hours passed: that you had always something agreeable to listen to.In the intervals of the concert it was conversation.”

zh: 安妮勉强一笑说道：“你从我眼睛里看出来了？”
en: Anne half smiled and said, “Do you see that in my eye?”

zh: “是的，确实如此。你的神情让我清楚地看出了这一点，你昨天晚上是同你认为的世界上最可爱的那个人呆在一起，即使是现在，这个人对你产生的兴趣也比世界上所有的人加在一起要多。”
en: “Yes, I do.Your countenance perfectly informs me that you were in company last night with the person whom you think the most agreeable in the world, the person who interests you at this present time more than all the rest of the world put together.”

zh: 一阵红晕涌上了安妮的脸颊。她什么也没有说出来。
en: A blush overspread Anne’s cheeks.She could say nothing.

zh: “情况既然如此，”史密斯太太停了一小会儿继续说道，“我希望你能理解我感谢你今天早晨来看我的心情了。你一定有很多更愉快的事情要做，可是你却来陪我，你真是太好了。”
en: “And such being the case,” continued Mrs. Smith, after a short pause, “I hope you believe that I do know how to value your kindness in coming to me this morning.It is really very good of you to come and sit with me, when you must have so many pleasanter demands upon your time.”

zh: 安妮一点也没有听进去。她还处在她朋友的洞察力带给她的惊讶和困惑中，她无法想象温特沃思上校的情况怎么会传到她的耳朵里。又沉默了一会儿后——
en: Anne heard nothing of this.She was still in the astonishment and confusion excited by her friend’s penetration, unable to imagine how any report of Captain Wentworth could have reached her.After another short silence—

zh: “请问，”史密斯太太说道，“埃利奥特先生知道你认识我吗？他知道我在巴斯吗？”
en: “Pray,” said Mrs. Smith, “is Mr. Elliot aware of your acquaintance with me?Does he know that I am in Bath?”

zh: “埃利奥特先生！”安妮重复地叫了一声，惊讶地抬起头来。她沉思了一会儿才知道自己刚才想错了。她顿时醒悟过来了。某种安全感使她恢复了勇气，她马上更加镇静地接着说道：“你认识埃利奥特先生吗？”
en: “Mr. Elliot!” repeated Anne, looking up surprised.A moment’s reflection shewed her the mistake she had been under.She caught it instantaneously; and recovering her courage with the feeling of safety, soon added, more composedly, “Are you acquainted with Mr. Elliot?”

zh: “我一向跟他很熟，”史密斯太太严肃地回答道，“不过，现在似乎不太往来了。我们已经很久没有见面了。”
en: “I have been a good deal acquainted with him,” replied Mrs. Smith, gravely, “but it seems worn out now.It is a great while since we met.”

zh: “这件事我一点儿也不知道。你以前从来没有提起过。我要是早知道的话，我一定会很高兴地向他谈起你。”
en: “I was not at all aware of this.You never mentioned it before.Had I known it, I would have had the pleasure of talking to him about you.”

zh: “说实话，”史密斯太太恢复了平常愉快的神情说，“这就是我希望的。我希望你能够向他谈起我。我需要你对他的影响。他可以帮我的大忙，我亲爱的埃利奥特小姐，如果你能够发发善心，把这件事当成自己的目标的话，一定会成功的。”
en: “To confess the truth,” said Mrs. Smith, assuming her usual air of cheerfulness, “that is exactly the pleasure I want you to have.I want you to talk about me to Mr. Elliot.I want your interest with him.He can be of essential service to me; and if you would have the goodness, my dear Miss Elliot, to make it an object to yourself, of course it is done.”

zh: “我非常乐意。我想你不会怀疑我愿意帮你，哪怕有一点用也行，”安妮回答道，“不过，我觉得你认为我有权对埃利奥特先生提出更高的要求，有权影响他，而实际情况并非如此。我想你一定是不知怎么地产生了这种想法。你应该仅仅把我看成是埃利奥特先生的亲戚。从这点出发，如果你认为他的堂妹可以向他要求点什么的话，就请你毫不犹豫地告诉我好了。”
en: “I should be extremely happy; I hope you cannot doubt my willingness to be of even the slightest use to you,” replied Anne; “but I suspect that you are considering me as having a higher claim on Mr. Elliot, a greater right to influence him, than is really the case.I am sure you have, somehow or other, imbibed such a notion.You must consider me only as Mr. Elliot’s relation.If in that light there is anything which you suppose his cousin might fairly ask of him, I beg you would not hesitate to employ me.”

zh: 史密斯太太用敏锐地目光看了她一眼，然后笑眯眯地说：
en: Mrs. Smith gave her a penetrating glance, and then, smiling, said—

zh: “我想，我有点操之过急了。请你原谅。我应该等你的正式通知的，不过现在，我亲爱的埃利奥特小姐，作为一个老朋友，请你务必给我点暗示，到底什么时候我才可以提这个要求。下星期？当然，下星期我大概可以认为一切都安排妥当了，就能够托埃利奥特先生的福为我自己谋点私利了。”
en: “I have been a little premature, I perceive; I beg your pardon.I ought to have waited for official information, But now, my dear Miss Elliot, as an old friend, do give me a hint as to when I may speak.Next week?To be sure by next week I may be allowed to think it all settled, and build my own selfish schemes on Mr. Elliot’s good fortune.”

zh: “不，”安妮回答道，“下星期不行，下下星期也不行，下下下星期也不行。我向你保证，你设想的那件事情哪一个星期也定不下来。我不会嫁给埃利奥特先生的。我倒想知道，你怎么会觉得我会嫁给他？”
en: “No,” replied Anne, “nor next week, nor next, nor next.I assure you that nothing of the sort you are thinking of will be settled any week.I am not going to marry Mr. Elliot.I should like to know why you imagine I am?”

zh: 史密斯太太又看到她态度十分认真，笑了笑，摇了摇头，然后嚷道：
en: Mrs. Smith looked at her again, looked earnestly, smiled, shook her head, and exclaimed—

zh: “现在，我多么希望我能够理解你！我多么希望我能知道你在想些什么！我非常清楚，时机一到，你就不会表现得这么残酷了。你知道，不到恰当的时间，我们女人从不想嫁人。女人总是这样，任何男人在提出求婚之前总会遭到拒绝。但是，你为什么要冷酷无情呢？虽然我不能称他为我现在的朋友，但请让我为我过去的朋友说几句好话。你在哪儿可以找到一个更合适的对象？你在哪儿能找到一个更有绅士风度、更可爱的男人呢？还是让我来介绍一下这位埃利奥特先生吧。我敢断定，你从沃利斯上校那里听到的都是关于他的好话。还有谁比沃利斯上校更了解他呢？”
en: “Now, how I do wish I understood you!How I do wish I knew what you were at!I have a great idea that you do not design to be cruel, when the right moment occurs.Till it does come, you know, we women never mean to have anybody.It is a thing of course among us, that every man is refused, till he offers.But why should you be cruel?Let me plead for my—present friend I cannot call him, but for my former friend.Where can you look for a more suitable match?Where could you expect a more gentlemanlike, agreeable man?Let me recommend Mr. Elliot.I am sure you hear nothing but good of him from Colonel Wallis; and who can know him better than Colonel Wallis?”

zh: “我亲爱的史密斯太太，埃利奥特先生的妻子死了才半年多一点。他不应该追求别的女人。”
en: “My dear Mrs. Smith, Mr. Elliot’s wife has not been dead much above half a year.He ought not to be supposed to be paying his addresses to any one.”

zh: “哦！如果这只是你的异议的话，”史密斯太太狡黠地嚷道，“那么埃利奥特先生就没问题了，我也不用再为他操心了。你们结婚的时候不要忘记告诉我就好了。让他知道我是你的朋友，那时他就会觉得我提的要求并不麻烦，现在他事多约会多，自然会尽量避免或摆脱这种麻烦，这也许是理所当然的。百分之九十九的人都会这么做。当然，他不会知道这件事对我有多么重要。好了，我亲爱的埃利奥特小姐，我希望而且相信你会非常幸福的。埃利奥特先生很有见识，会懂得你这样的女人的价值的。你的安宁不会像我这样遭到毁灭。在一切世事方面，你都将万无一失，你对他的性格也可以放心。他不会被引入歧途，也不会被别人误导走向毁灭。”
en: “Oh! if these are your only objections,” cried Mrs. Smith, archly, “Mr. Elliot is safe, and I shall give myself no more trouble about him.Do not forget me when you are married, that’s all.Let him know me to be a friend of yours, and then he will think little of the trouble required, which it is very natural for him now, with so many affairs and engagements of his own, to avoid and get rid of as he can; very natural, perhaps.Ninety-nine out of a hundred would do the same.Of course, he cannot be aware of the importance to me.Well, my dear Miss Elliot, I hope and trust you will be very happy.Mr. Elliot has sense to understand the value of such a woman.Your peace will not be shipwrecked as mine has been.You are safe in all worldly matters, and safe in his character.He will not be led astray; he will not be misled by others to his ruin.”

zh: “对，”安妮说道，“在这些方面我是完全相信我的堂兄的。他看起来性情冷静果断，绝不会受到不好的影响。我非常尊重他。从我所观察的一切来看，我没有理由不这么做。但是，我认识他的时间不长，而且我觉得他是一个不太容易了解的人。我这样说他，史密斯太太，能不能使你相信，他对我来说是无足轻重的？的确，我说这话时心里很冷静。不过，我保证，我对他毫无感情。要是他向我求婚的话（我没有理由认为他会这样做），我也不会答应他的。我向你保证，我不会这样做。我向你保证，埃利奥特先生与你所想的昨晚的音乐会带给我的那种愉快之间没有什么关系，不是埃利奥特先生。不是埃利奥特先生——”
en: “No,” said Anne, “I can readily believe all that of my cousin.He seems to have a calm decided temper, not at all open to dangerous impressions.I consider him with great respect.I have no reason, from any thing that has fallen within my observation, to do otherwise.But I have not known him long; and he is not a man, I think, to be known intimately soon.Will not this manner of speaking of him, Mrs. Smith, convince you that he is nothing to me?Surely this must be calm enough.And, upon my word, he is nothing to me.Should he ever propose to me (which I have very little reason to imagine he has any thought of doing), I shall not accept him.I assure you I shall not.I assure you, Mr. Elliot had not the share which you have been supposing, in whatever pleasure the concert of last night might afford: not Mr. Elliot; it is not Mr. Elliot that—”

zh: 她红着脸停下了，深悔自己把事情透露得太多了。不过说少了又不行。要是史密斯太太不知道她另有心上人的话，是不大可能相信埃利奥特先生遭到了失败。事实上，她当即认输了，而且装作没有听出什么弦外之音。安妮急于想避开史密斯太太的进一步追问，却急切地想知道为什么史密斯太太会认为她将要嫁给埃利奥特先生。她怎么会产生这样的想法，或者是从谁那里听说的。
en: She stopped, regretting with a deep blush that she had implied so much; but less would hardly have been sufficient.Mrs. Smith would hardly have believed so soon in Mr. Elliot’s failure, but from the perception of there being a somebody else.As it was, she instantly submitted, and with all the semblance of seeing nothing beyond; and Anne, eager to escape farther notice, was impatient to know why Mrs. Smith should have fancied she was to marry Mr. Elliot; where she could have received the idea, or from whom she could have heard it.

zh: “请告诉我，你最初是怎么产生这种想法的。”
en: “Do tell me how it first came into your head.”

zh: “我最初产生这种想法，”史密斯太太回答说，“是发现你们经常在一起，觉得这可能是最符合你们双方愿望的事情了。你可以相信，所有认识你们的人也都这么看。不过，我也是前两天才听说这件事。”
en: “It first came into my head,” replied Mrs. Smith, “upon finding how much you were together, and feeling it to be the most probable thing in the world to be wished for by everybody belonging to either of you; and you may depend upon it that all your acquaintance have disposed of you in the same way.But I never heard it spoken of till two days ago.”

zh: “真有人谈论这件事吗？”
en: “And has it indeed been spoken of?”

zh: “你昨天来的时候，有没有注意到给你开门的那个女人？”
en: “Did you observe the woman who opened the door to you when you called yesterday?”

zh: “没有。不是平常开门的斯皮德太太或女佣人吗？我没有看到什么特别的人。”
en: “No.Was not it Mrs. Speed, as usual, or the maid?I observed no one in particular.”

zh: “那是我的朋友鲁克太太，鲁克护士，顺便说一句，她非常好奇，想见见你，也很高兴能为你开门。她星期天才离开莫尔伯勒大厦，是她告诉我你即将同埃利奥特先生结婚的。她是听沃利斯太太亲口说的，看来消息还是挺有权威的。星期一的晚上她陪我坐了一个小时，把整个事情的来龙去脉都告诉了我。”“事情的来龙去脉，”安妮重复了一遍，笑了起来，“我想，对于这么一条毫无根据的小消息，她也没有什么可长篇大论的了。”
en: “It was my friend Mrs. Rooke; Nurse Rooke; who, by-the-bye, had a great curiosity to see you, and was delighted to be in the way to let you in.She came away from Marlborough Buildings only on Sunday; and she it was who told me you were to marry Mr. Elliot.She had had it from Mrs. Wallis herself, which did not seem bad authority.She sat an hour with me on Monday evening, and gave me the whole history.”“The whole history,” repeated Anne, laughing.“She could not make a very long history, I think, of one such little article of unfounded news.”

zh: 史密斯太太什么也没说。
en: Mrs. Smith said nothing.

zh: “不过，”安妮马上接着说下去，“尽管事实上我并不会嫁给埃利奥特先生，但我还是非常乐意尽我所能来帮助你。我要不要告诉他你在巴斯？要不要我给他捎个话？”
en: “But,” continued Anne, presently, “though there is no truth in my having this claim on Mr. Elliot, I should be extremely happy to be of use to you in any way that I could.Shall I mention to him your being in Bath?Shall I take any message?”

zh: “不，谢谢你。不，当然不用。刚才我可能太激动了，而且处于一种错误的印象，想要劝你关心一下那事。不过，现在不需要了。不，谢谢你，我没有什么事情要麻烦你了。”
en: “No, I thank you: no, certainly not.In the warmth of the moment, and under a mistaken impression, I might, perhaps, have endeavoured to interest you in some circumstances; but not now.No, I thank you, I have nothing to trouble you with.”

zh: “我记得你说过，你跟埃利奥特先生认识很多年了？”
en: “I think you spoke of having known Mr. Elliot many years?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “I did.”

zh: “我想，不会是在他结婚以前吧？”
en: “Not before he was married, I suppose?”

zh: “是的。我刚认识他的时候，他还没有结婚。”
en: “Yes; he was not married when I knew him first.”

zh: “你们——很熟吗？”
en: “And—were you much acquainted?”

zh: “非常熟。”
en: “Intimately.”

zh: “真的！那么请告诉我他那时是什么样子。我非常好奇，想知道埃利奥特先生年轻时是个什么样的人。他是不是同现在一个样？”
en: “Indeed!Then do tell me what he was at that time of life.I have a great curiosity to know what Mr. Elliot was as a very young man.Was he at all such as he appears now?”

zh: “这三年来，我一直没有见过埃利奥特先生，”史密斯太太回答时神情非常严肃，让人简直无法继续谈下去。安妮自己一无所获，反而好奇心更强了。两人都默不作声。史密斯太太显得心事重重。终于——
en: “I have not seen Mr. Elliot these three years,” was Mrs. Smith’s answer, given so gravely that it was impossible to pursue the subject farther; and Anne felt that she had gained nothing but an increase of curiosity.They were both silent: Mrs. Smith very thoughtful.At last—

zh: “请原谅，我亲爱的埃利奥特小姐，”她用她自然的热情口气大声说道，“请原谅我刚才给你的回答太简短了，不过我一直没拿定主意，我到底应该怎么办。我一直在犹豫不决，考虑我该怎么对你说才好。我有很多问题需要考虑。人们讨厌爱管闲事、搬弄是非、挑拨离间的人。连家庭关系中平静的表象也值得维持，尽管在这种关系中可能没有什么会是持久的。不过，我决定了。我认为我是对的。我觉得应该让你了解一下埃利奥特先生的本性。虽然现在我完全相信你丝毫没有想要嫁给他，但是谁也说不准今后会怎么样。你将来也许会对他产生不一样的感情。所以还是趁你现在还没有偏见的时候听一听真相吧。埃利奥特先生是个没有心肝和良心的人。他是个诡计多端、谨小慎微、冷酷无情的家伙。只考虑自己了，为了自己的利益和舒适，只要不有损于他的声誉，什么残酷无情或背信弃义的事情他都干得出来。他从来不考虑别人的感受。对于那些主要因为他而破产的人，他可以无动于衷地一脚踢开，而没有丝毫的懊悔之心。他完全没有任何正义感和同情心。唉！他的心是黑的，虚伪而又狠毒！”
en: “I beg your pardon, my dear Miss Elliot,” she cried, in her natural tone of cordiality, “I beg your pardon for the short answers I have been giving you, but I have been uncertain what I ought to do.I have been doubting and considering as to what I ought to tell you.There were many things to be taken into the account.One hates to be officious, to be giving bad impressions, making mischief.Even the smooth surface of family-union seems worth preserving, though there may be nothing durable beneath.However, I have determined; I think I am right; I think you ought to be made acquainted with Mr. Elliot’s real character.Though I fully believe that, at present, you have not the smallest intention of accepting him, there is no saying what may happen.You might, some time or other, be differently affected towards him.Hear the truth, therefore, now, while you are unprejudiced.Mr. Elliot is a man without heart or conscience; a designing, wary, cold-blooded being, who thinks only of himself; whom for his own interest or ease, would be guilty of any cruelty, or any treachery, that could be perpetrated without risk of his general character.He has no feeling for others.Those whom he has been the chief cause of leading into ruin, he can neglect and desert without the smallest compunction.He is totally beyond the reach of any sentiment of justice or compassion.Oh! he is black at heart, hollow and black!”

zh: 安妮听得目瞪口呆，发出了一声惊叹，使得史密斯太太顿了一下，接着又说下去，稍微平静了一点：
en: Anne’s astonished air, and exclamation of wonder, made her pause, and in a calmer manner, she added,

zh: “我的说法使你大吃一惊。你得原谅一个受到伤害而感到愤怒的女人。不过，我会尽量控制我自己的。我不想毁谤他。我只想告诉你我对他的了解。事实将会说明一切。他是我亲爱丈夫的密友，我的丈夫信任他，喜欢他，认为他同自己一样是个好人。他们的这种亲密关系在我们结婚之前就已经形成了。我发现他们是最亲密的朋友。因此我也非常喜欢埃利奥特先生，对他的评价很高。你知道，一个人在十九岁的时候考虑问题并不很认真。不过，当时我觉得埃利奥特先生的人品像其他人一样好，而且比其他人讨人喜欢，因此我们几乎总是呆在一起。我们主要住在城里，生活阔绰。他当时的情况比较差，也比较穷。他在坦普尔有住房，但这是他为了装点绅士的门面而做的一切。只要他愿意，随时可以住在我们家里；他总是受欢迎的；他就像我们的兄弟。我那可怜的查尔斯，是这世上最善良、最慷慨大方的人，他就是剩下最后四分之一便士，也会分给埃利奥特先生。我知道他的钱包是对埃利奥特先生敞开的，我知道他经常资助他。”
en: “My expressions startle you.You must allow for an injured, angry woman.But I will try to command myself.I will not abuse him.I will only tell you what I have found him.Facts shall speak.He was the intimate friend of my dear husband, who trusted and loved him, and thought him as good as himself.The intimacy had been formed before our marriage.I found them most intimate friends; and I, too, became excessively pleased with Mr. Elliot, and entertained the highest opinion of him.At nineteen, you know, one does not think very seriously; but Mr. Elliot appeared to me quite as good as others, and much more agreeable than most others, and we were almost always together.We were principally in town, living in very good style.He was then the inferior in circumstances; he was then the poor one; he had chambers in the Temple, and it was as much as he could do to support the appearance of a gentleman.He had always a home with us whenever he chose it; he was always welcome; he was like a brother.My poor Charles, who had the finest, most generous spirit in the world, would have divided his last farthing with him; and I know that his purse was open to him; I know that he often assisted him.”

zh: “想必大约就是在这个时期，”安妮说道，“埃利奥特先生总是使我感到特别好奇。这肯定就是我父亲和姐姐刚刚认识他的时候。我自己从来没有见过他，只是听说过他。但是我无论如何也没法把他当时对我父亲和姐姐的态度以及他以后的婚姻状况同他现在的态度协调起来。这似乎表明他是另外一种人。”
en: “This must have been about that very period of Mr. Elliot’s life,” said Anne, “which has always excited my particular curiosity.It must have been about the same time that he became known to my father and sister.I never knew him myself; I only heard of him; but there was a something in his conduct then, with regard to my father and sister, and afterwards in the circumstances of his marriage, which I never could quite reconcile with present times.It seemed to announce a different sort of man.”

zh: “这些事我全知道，这些我全了解，”史密斯太太大声嚷道。“他同你父亲和姐姐结识，是在我认识他之前，但我常听他谈起他们。我知道他们邀请他、鼓励他，我也知道他不肯去。也许我可以给你提供一些你意想不到的事情。至于他的婚姻，我当时了解得一清二楚。我知道他追求什么，也知道他反对什么。他把他的打算和计划都告诉了我这个朋友。虽然我之前并不认识他的妻子，确实她的低微社会地位使我不可能同她结识。不过我对她后来的情况了解得一清二楚，至少知道她去世之前的前两年的生活。我可以回答你想提出的任何问题。”
