en: “I know it all, I know it all,” cried Mrs. Smith.“He had been introduced to Sir Walter and your sister before I was acquainted with him, but I heard him speak of them for ever.I know he was invited and encouraged, and I know he did not choose to go.I can satisfy you, perhaps, on points which you would little expect; and as to his marriage, I knew all about it at the time.I was privy to all the fors and againsts; I was the friend to whom he confided his hopes and plans; and though I did not know his wife previously, her inferior situation in society, indeed, rendered that impossible, yet I knew her all her life afterwards, or at least till within the last two years of her life, and can answer any question you may wish to put.”

zh: “不，”安妮说道，“我对她没有什么特别要问的。我一直知道他们并不是一对幸福的夫妻。不过我想知道，他那个时候为什么蔑视同我父亲的交往。我父亲的确想给他友好、妥善的照顾。为什么埃利奥特先生不愿意与我父亲交往？”
en: “Nay,” said Anne, “I have no particular enquiry to make about her.I have always understood they were not a happy couple.But I should like to know why, at that time of his life, he should slight my father’s acquaintance as he did.My father was certainly disposed to take very kind and proper notice of him.Why did Mr. Elliot draw back?”

zh: “埃利奥特先生，”史密斯太太回答道，“那个时候他只有一个目标：发财致富，而且想通过比继承遗产更快的捷径实现。他决定通过婚姻来实现。他决定至少不能让草率的婚姻来损害这个目标。我知道他认为（当然我无法判断这是否正确）你父亲和姐姐对他这么客气，一再地发出邀请，是想让他这继承人同年轻的埃利奥特小姐结婚，而这样的婚姻不可能满足他对财富和自立的思想。我向你保证，这是他不愿意同你们家往来的动机。他把事情都告诉了我。他对我没有隐瞒。奇怪的是，我在巴斯刚同你分手，结婚后遇到的第一个主要的熟人就是你的堂兄，而且时时听他说起你的父亲和姐姐。他描述了一位埃利奥特小姐，而我内心却非常想念另一位埃利奥特小姐。”
en: “Mr. Elliot,” replied Mrs. Smith, “at that period of his life, had one object in view: to make his fortune, and by a rather quicker process than the law.He was determined to make it by marriage.He was determined, at least, not to mar it by an imprudent marriage; and I know it was his belief (whether justly or not, of course I cannot decide), that your father and sister, in their civilities and invitations, were designing a match between the heir and the young lady, and it was impossible that such a match should have answered his ideas of wealth and independence.That was his motive for drawing back, I can assure you.He told me the whole story.He had no concealments with me.It was curious, that having just left you behind me in Bath, my first and principal acquaintance on marrying should be your cousin; and that, through him, I should be continually hearing of your father and sister.He described one Miss Elliot, and I thought very affectionately of the other.”

zh: “也许，”安妮突然想到了一点，高声说道，“你时常向埃利奥特先生谈起我吧？”
en: “Perhaps,” cried Anne, struck by a sudden idea, “you sometimes spoke of me to Mr. Elliot?”

zh: “当然啦，常常谈起。我常常夸奖我心爱的安妮•埃利奥特，而且担保你是一个与众不同的人，不同于——”
en: “To be sure I did; very often.I used to boast of my own Anne Elliot, and vouch for your being a very different creature from—”

zh: 史密斯太太及时打住了。
en: She checked herself just in time.

zh: “这就解释了埃利奥特先生昨天晚上讲的话，”安妮高声说道。“这就好解释了。我听说他以前经常听别人谈起我。我无法理解这究竟是怎么回事。只要事情一涉及个人，就会产生多么荒唐的想象啊！而且总会出错！不过，请原谅我。我打断了你的话。这么说，埃利奥特先生那时完全是为了钱而结婚的？也许，这个情况使你开始认清了他的真面目。”
en: “This accounts for something which Mr. Elliot said last night,” cried Anne.“This explains it.I found he had been used to hear of me.I could not comprehend how.What wild imaginations one forms where dear self is concerned!How sure to be mistaken!But I beg your pardon; I have interrupted you.Mr. Elliot married then completely for money?The circumstances, probably, which first opened your eyes to his character.”

zh: 这时，史密斯太太犹豫了一会儿。“哎！这种事情太常见了。人生在世，一个男人或女人为了钱而结婚的事情太常见了，不会使人对此产生应有的惊讶。我当时很年轻，只跟年轻人来往，我们是一群粗心大意的快乐年轻人，没有任何严格的行为准则。我们活着就是为了享乐。现在我可不这么想了。时间、疾病和忧愁使我产生了别的想法。不过我必须承认，我当时觉得埃利奥特先生的行为没有什么可指责的。‘为自己寻找最好的出路’，被当成了一种职责。”
en: Mrs. Smith hesitated a little here.“Oh! those things are too common.When one lives in the world, a man or woman’s marrying for money is too common to strike one as it ought.I was very young, and associated only with the young, and we were a thoughtless, gay set, without any strict rules of conduct.We lived for enjoyment.I think differently now; time and sickness and sorrow have given me other notions; but at that period I must own I saw nothing reprehensible in what Mr. Elliot was doing.‘To do the best for himself,’ passed as a duty.”

zh: “可是她不是一个出身低贱的女人吗？”
en: “But was not she a very low woman?”

zh: “是的。对此我表示过反对，但是埃利奥特先生并不尊重我的意见。钱，钱，他要的只是钱。她父亲是个牧场主，她祖父曾经是个屠夫，但是这都无所谓。她是一位漂亮的女人，受过体面的教育，是由几个表亲带出来的，偶然遇到了埃利奥特先生，并且爱上了他。而埃利奥特先生对她的出身毫不计较，也不顾忌。他竭尽全力地弄清楚了她的财产的真实数字，然后才答应娶她。你相信我好了，埃利奥特先生目前可能对他的社会地位非常看重，但是年轻的时候，他对此却毫不重视。他有可能得到凯林奇府，但是他把家族的荣誉视为粪土。我经常听他宣称，要是准男爵这个称号可以出售，任何人只要出五十英镑就可以买去，包括族徽和徽文，姓氏和仆人的制服。不过我说的这些话是否有重复过去听他说的一半那么多，我还不敢肯定。那不太公平，你应该有证据，我的话口说无凭，不过你会看到证据的。”
en: “Yes; which I objected to, but he would not regard.Money, money, was all that he wanted.Her father was a grazier, her grandfather had been a butcher, but that was all nothing.She was a fine woman, had had a decent education, was brought forward by some cousins, thrown by chance into Mr. Elliot’s company, and fell in love with him; and not a difficulty or a scruple was there on his side, with respect to her birth.All his caution was spent in being secured of the real amount of her fortune, before he committed himself.Depend upon it, whatever esteem Mr. Elliot may have for his own situation in life now, as a young man he had not the smallest value for it.His chance for the Kellynch estate was something, but all the honour of the family he held as cheap as dirt.I have often heard him declare, that if baronetcies were saleable, anybody should have his for fifty pounds, arms and motto, name and livery included; but I will not pretend to repeat half that I used to hear him say on that subject.It would not be fair; and yet you ought to have proof, for what is all this but assertion, and you shall have proof.”

zh: “我亲爱的史密斯太太，我确实不需要什么证据，”安妮大声说。“你说的这一切与埃利奥特先生几年前表现出来的样子毫不矛盾。相反，这都证实了我们过去听到的和想到的。我更想知道的是，他现在为什么变得这么不一样了。”
en: “Indeed, my dear Mrs. Smith, I want none,” cried Anne.“You have asserted nothing contradictory to what Mr. Elliot appeared to be some years ago.This is all in confirmation, rather, of what we used to hear and believe.I am more curious to know why he should be so different now.”

zh: “不过我倒想拿出证据来给你看看，要是你能打铃叫一下玛丽。等一等，我想你更愿意亲自到我的卧室去，把那只小小的镶花的小匣子拿来，你能在壁橱的上格找到它。”
en: “But for my satisfaction, if you will have the goodness to ring for Mary; stay: I am sure you will have the still greater goodness of going yourself into my bedroom, and bringing me the small inlaid box which you will find on the upper shelf of the closet.”

zh: 安妮看到她的朋友执意要她去一趟，就按她的愿望去了。小匣子拿来了，就放在史密斯太太跟前，她一边叹了口气，一边把它打开，说：
en: Anne, seeing her friend to be earnestly bent on it, did as she was desired.The box was brought and placed before her, and Mrs. Smith, sighing over it as she unlocked it, said—

zh: “这里面装满了我丈夫的文件。这仅仅是我丈夫去世时我不得不查阅的文件中的一小部分。我要找的这封信是我们结婚以前埃利奥特先生写给我丈夫的，它恰巧给保存下来了。为什么会保存，人们简直无法想象。我丈夫像别的男人一样，对这些东西都漫不经心，非常随便。我开始检查他的信件的时候，我发现它夹在到处散放着的比它更没有价值的信件中间，而许多真正重要的信件和备忘录却被毁掉了。就是这封。我当时没有把它烧掉，因为我当时对埃利奥特先生已经不太满意，我决定把有关以前我们亲密关系的证据都留下来。现在我又有一个理由为能够提供这封信而感到高兴了。”
en: “This is full of papers belonging to him, to my husband; a small portion only of what I had to look over when I lost him.The letter I am looking for was one written by Mr. Elliot to him before our marriage, and happened to be saved; why, one can hardly imagine.But he was careless and immethodical, like other men, about those things; and when I came to examine his papers, I found it with others still more trivial, from different people scattered here and there, while many letters and memorandums of real importance had been destroyed.Here it is; I would not burn it, because being even then very little satisfied with Mr. Elliot, I was determined to preserve every document of former intimacy.I have now another motive for being glad that I can produce it.”

zh: 这封信是早在1803年7月从伦敦寄往“坦布里奇韦尔斯，查尔斯•史密斯先生收”的：
en: This was the letter, directed to “Charles Smith, Esq. Tunbridge Wells,” and dated from London, as far back as July, 1803:—

zh: “亲爱的史密斯：来信收到。你的好意几乎使我感激涕零。但愿大自然造就更多像你这样的好心人，但我在世上活了23年了，还没有遇见过像你这样的好心人。相信我，目前我不需要你的帮助，因为我又有钱了。为我高兴吧。我已经摆脱了沃尔特爵士和埃利奥特小姐。他们回凯林奇去了，几乎逼着我发誓这个夏天去拜访他们。不过我第一次去凯林奇的时候要带上一个勘探员，好弄清楚怎样才能在拍卖时卖个最好的价钱。不过，准男爵并不是不可能再娶。他可真够愚蠢的。然而，要是他再娶，他们倒不会再来打搅我，这完全可以抵得上那份继承权。他比去年更糟糕了。
en: “Dear Smith,—I have received yours.Your kindness almost overpowers me.I wish nature had made such hearts as yours more common, but I have lived three-and-twenty years in the world, and have seen none like it.At present, believe me, I have no need of your services, being in cash again.Give me joy: I have got rid of Sir Walter and Miss.They are gone back to Kellynch, and almost made me swear to visit them this summer; but my first visit to Kellynch will be with a surveyor, to tell me how to bring it with best advantage to the hammer.The baronet, nevertheless, is not unlikely to marry again; he is quite fool enough.If he does, however, they will leave me in peace, which may be a decent equivalent for the reversion.He is worse than last year.

zh: “我希望除了埃利奥特之外，我姓什么都可以。我讨厌这个姓氏。谢天谢地，我可以不用沃尔特这个名字！我希望你永远不要用我的中间名字‘沃’来羞辱我。我今后永远是你忠实的——威廉•埃利奥特。”
en: “I wish I had any name but Elliot.I am sick of it.The name of Walter I can drop, thank God! And I desire you will never insult me with my second W. again, meaning, for the rest of my life, to be only yours truly,—Wm.Elliot.”

zh: 读着这样的信，安妮不得不感到脸红。史密斯太太看到安妮通红的脸，说：
en: Such a letter could not be read without putting Anne in a glow; and Mrs. Smith, observing the high colour in her face, said—

zh: “我知道，信里的用词非常无礼。虽然我已经忘记了具体的措辞，但是我对这封信的大意还有个完整的印象。不过，这可以使你看清他的为人。看看他对我可怜的丈夫说的话。还有比这更有力的证据吗？”
en: “The language, I know, is highly disrespectful.Though I have forgot the exact terms, I have a perfect impression of the general meaning.But it shows you the man.Mark his professions to my poor husband.Can any thing be stronger?”

zh: 看到埃利奥特用这样的言辞侮辱她的父亲，安妮无法从震惊与屈辱中立刻摆脱出来。安妮不得不想到，她看这封信是违背道德的，人们无法拿着这样的证词去判断或了解一个人，私人信件是不容许别人过目的。然后，她恢复了平静，把刚才拿在手上苦思冥想的信还给史密斯太太，说道：
en: Anne could not immediately get over the shock and mortification of finding such words applied to her father.She was obliged to recollect that her seeing the letter was a violation of the laws of honour, that no one ought to be judged or to be known by such testimonies, that no private correspondence could bear the eye of others, before she could recover calmness enough to return the letter which she had been meditating over, and say—

zh: “谢谢你。这个证据无疑很充分，证实了你刚才所说的一切。但是现在他又为什么同我们交往呢？”
en: “Thank you.This is full proof undoubtedly; proof of every thing you were saying.But why be acquainted with us now?”

zh: “这我也能解释，”史密斯太太笑着喊道。
en: “I can explain this too,” cried Mrs. Smith, smiling.

zh: “你真能解释吗？”
en: “Can you really?”

zh: “是的。我已经让你看清了埃利奥特先生十二年前的为人，我也会让你看清他现在的为人。我没法再拿出书面证据，不过，我给你的口头证据完全像你要求的那么可靠。我要告诉你，他现在想要什么，他现在在做什么。他现在不是一个伪君子了。他确实想娶你。他目前对你们家的关注是非常真诚的：完全是发自内心的。我要告诉你我的消息的权威来源：他的朋友沃利斯上校。”
en: “Yes.I have shewn you Mr. Elliot as he was a dozen years ago, and I will shew him as he is now.I cannot produce written proof again, but I can give as authentic oral testimony as you can desire, of what he is now wanting, and what he is now doing.He is no hypocrite now.He truly wants to marry you.His present attentions to your family are very sincere: quite from the heart.I will give you my authority: his friend Colonel Wallis.”

zh: “沃利斯上校！你认识他？”
en: “Colonel Wallis!you are acquainted with him?”

zh: “不认识。消息不是这么直接传到我耳朵里的。它转了一两个弯，不过没有什么影响。泉水就像源头一样清洁，它带上的垃圾很容易在转弯时撇掉。埃利奥特先生毫无保留地向沃利斯上校谈了他对你的看法。我想沃利斯上校本人是一位通情达理、谨慎而又有眼力的人，但是沃利斯上校有一位非常美丽却很愚蠢的妻子，而他把他不该说的事情全部都告诉了妻子。她身体处在恢复期，精力充沛，就把这一切都告诉了她的护士。而这位护士又知道我认识你，自然就把事情全部告诉了我。星期一的晚上，我的好朋友鲁克太太就把莫尔伯勒的许多秘密都告诉了我。所以你瞧，我先前说我知道事情的来龙去脉时，并不像你想象的那么夸大其词。”
en: “No.It does not come to me in quite so direct a line as that; it takes a bend or two, but nothing of consequence.The stream is as good as at first; the little rubbish it collects in the turnings is easily moved away.Mr. Elliot talks unreservedly to Colonel Wallis of his views on you, which said Colonel Wallis, I imagine to be, in himself, a sensible, careful, discerning sort of character; but Colonel Wallis has a very pretty silly wife, to whom he tells things which he had better not, and he repeats it all to her.She in the overflowing spirits of her recovery, repeats it all to her nurse; and the nurse knowing my acquaintance with you, very naturally brings it all to me.On Monday evening, my good friend Mrs. Rooke let me thus much into the secrets of Marlborough Buildings.When I talked of a whole history, therefore, you see I was not romancing so much as you supposed.”

zh: “我亲爱的史密斯太太，你这话的权威性还不足。这不能够说明问题。埃利奥特先生对我有什么看法，绝对不可能是他努力同我父亲和解的原因。和解发生在我来巴斯之前。我来的时候，发现他们的关系极为友好。”
en: “My dear Mrs. Smith, your authority is deficient.This will not do.Mr. Elliot’s having any views on me will not in the least account for the efforts he made towards a reconciliation with my father.That was all prior to my coming to Bath.I found them on the most friendly terms when I arrived.”

zh: “我知道，我完全知道，但是——”
en: “I know you did; I know it all perfectly, but—”

zh: “说真的，史密斯太太，我们不能期望通过这种方式了解真实情况。中间经过这么多人，有人出于愚蠢，有人出于无知，都会给曲解了，经过这些人传来传去，事实或看法就很难剩下什么真实性的内容了。”
en: “Indeed, Mrs. Smith, we must not expect to get real information in such a line.Facts or opinions which are to pass through the hands of so many, to be misconceived by folly in one, and ignorance in another, can hardly have much truth left.”

zh: “你只要听我讲就行了。你通过听我讲述一些能让你自己立刻加以反驳或证实的细节，你就能很快对我的话的总体可信程度作出判断。没有人认为你是他的第一个诱惑。他在来到巴斯以前确实见到过你而且很倾慕你，但是还不知道你是谁。至少告诉我情况的那些人是这么说的。这是真的吗？去年夏天或秋天，他见过你，用她自己的话来说，‘是在西边什么地方’，当时又不知道那是你，是不是？”
en: “Only give me a hearing.You will soon be able to judge of the general credit due, by listening to some particulars which you can yourself immediately contradict or confirm.Nobody supposes that you were his first inducement.He had seen you indeed, before he came to Bath, and admired you, but without knowing it to be you.So says my historian, at least.Is this true?Did he see you last summer or autumn, ‘somewhere down in the west,’ to use her own words, without knowing it to be you?”

zh: “他确实见过我。到目前为止，都是正确的。是在莱姆。当时我碰巧在莱姆。”
en: “He certainly did.So far it is very true.At Lyme.I happened to be at Lyme.”

zh: “好的，”史密斯太太得意洋洋地继续说道，“既然第一点是肯定的，那就证明我的朋友是可信的。埃利奥特先生那时在莱姆见到了你，而且非常喜欢你，后来在卡姆登巷再见到你，知道你是埃利奥特小姐时，他非常高兴。我深信，从那时起，他去登门拜访便有了双重动机。但是他还有一个动机，是早就有的，现在我就来解释。如果你知道我说的情况有什么虚假或不真实的地方，就打断我好了。我了解的情况是这样的，你姐姐的朋友，就是我曾经听你提起过的跟你们住在一起的夫人，早在九月份（总之他们刚来的时候）就与埃利奥特小姐和沃尔特爵士一起到巴斯来了，而且从那时起一直呆在这里。她是一个八面玲珑、善于献媚的漂亮女人，人虽穷嘴却巧。总的来说，她的处境和举止给沃尔特爵士的熟人留下了一个大致的印象，就是她想成为埃利奥特夫人；同样使大家感到惊讶的是，埃利奥特小姐显然看不到这个危险。”
en: “Well,” continued Mrs. Smith, triumphantly, “grant my friend the credit due to the establishment of the first point asserted.He saw you then at Lyme, and liked you so well as to be exceedingly pleased to meet with you again in Camden Place, as Miss Anne Elliot, and from that moment, I have no doubt, had a double motive in his visits there.But there was another, and an earlier, which I will now explain.If there is anything in my story which you know to be either false or improbable, stop me.My account states, that your sister’s friend, the lady now staying with you, whom I have heard you mention, came to Bath with Miss Elliot and Sir Walter as long ago as September (in short when they first came themselves), and has been staying there ever since; that she is a clever, insinuating, handsome woman, poor and plausible, and altogether such in situation and manner, as to give a general idea, among Sir Walter’s acquaintance, of her meaning to be Lady Elliot, and as general a surprise that Miss Elliot should be apparently, blind to the danger.”

zh: 说到这里，史密斯太太停了片刻。见安妮没有什么可说的，便接着说下去：
en: Here Mrs. Smith paused a moment; but Anne had not a word to say, and she continued—

zh: “早在你回家之前，认识你们家的人就有了这种看法。沃利斯上校虽说那时没有去拜访卡姆登巷，但他很注意你父亲，觉察到了这个情况。他很关心埃利奥特先生，因此对府上的一切也很留意，恰巧埃利奥特先生在圣诞前夕要来巴斯小住上一两天，沃利斯上校便告诉了他一些情况，于是人们这些情况开始流传了。你要明白，随着时间的推移，埃利奥特先生对准男爵的价值的看法发生了重大的变化。在血统和亲戚方面，他完全判若两人。他早就已经有足够的钱供他挥霍，既然在贪婪和享乐方面他没有什么可追求的，那么他逐渐懂得要把自己的幸福寄托在他要继承的社会地位上面。我想他和我不再往来之前就有了这样的想法，不过现在这个想法已经根深蒂固了。他不能够容忍不能成为威廉爵士这个想法。因此你可以猜到，他从他朋友那里听到这个消息后不可能很愉快，你也可以猜到这消息产生的结果。他决定尽快回到巴斯，在这里住上一段时间，目的是恢复以前的交往，恢复他在你家中的地位，以便弄清他现在处境的危险程度，如果危险很大，他就设法打败那个女人。这是两位朋友一致认为的唯一可行办法。沃利斯上校竭尽全力地给予帮助。埃利奥特先生把沃利斯上校引荐给你的家人，也把沃利斯太太引荐给你的家人，把每个人引荐给你的家人。于是，埃利奥特先生回来了。而且正如你知道的那样，他的请求得到了原谅，被你的家人重新接纳。在这里他还有一个坚定不移的目标，也是唯一的目标（直到你的到来为他增添了另一个动机），就是盯住沃尔特爵士和克莱太太。他不放过与他们在一起的机会，硬是夹在他们之间，不断地登门拜访。不过在这方面我没有必要细说。你可以想象一个狡猾的人会使出怎样的伎俩。也许这么一开导，你就可以回想起你见到他做过的一些事情。”
en: “This was the light in which it appeared to those who knew the family, long before you returned to it; and Colonel Wallis had his eye upon your father enough to be sensible of it, though he did not then visit in Camden Place; but his regard for Mr. Elliot gave him an interest in watching all that was going on there, and when Mr. Elliot came to Bath for a day or two, as he happened to do a little before Christmas, Colonel Wallis made him acquainted with the appearance of things, and the reports beginning to prevail.Now you are to understand, that time had worked a very material change in Mr. Elliot’s opinions as to the value of a baronetcy.Upon all points of blood and connexion he is a completely altered man.Having long had as much money as he could spend, nothing to wish for on the side of avarice or indulgence, he has been gradually learning to pin his happiness upon the consequence he is heir to.I thought it coming on before our acquaintance ceased, but it is now a confirmed feeling.He cannot bear the idea of not being Sir William.You may guess, therefore, that the news he heard from his friend could not be very agreeable, and you may guess what it produced; the resolution of coming back to Bath as soon as possible, and of fixing himself here for a time, with the view of renewing his former acquaintance, and recovering such a footing in the family as might give him the means of ascertaining the degree of his danger, and of circumventing the lady if he found it material.This was agreed upon between the two friends as the only thing to be done; and Colonel Wallis was to assist in every way that he could.He was to be introduced, and Mrs. Wallis was to be introduced, and everybody was to be introduced.Mr. Elliot came back accordingly; and on application was forgiven, as you know, and re-admitted into the family; and there it was his constant object, and his only object (till your arrival added another motive), to watch Sir Walter and Mrs. Clay.He omitted no opportunity of being with them, threw himself in their way, called at all hours; but I need not be particular on this subject.You can imagine what an artful man would do; and with this guide, perhaps, may recollect what you have seen him do.”

zh: “是的，”安妮说，“你告诉我的一切都符合我已经知道或可以想象的情况。施展诡计的细节总是令人讨厌。那些自私狡诈的小动作从来就让人恶心，不过我没有听到真正让我吃惊的事情。我知道有些人听到你这样议论埃利奥特先生会大吃一惊，会难以置信。不过我并不满足于对他的一知半解。我总想知道隐藏在他行为的表面现象下的某种其他的动机。我倒想知道他现在如何看待他一直担心的那件事的可能性。他是否认为危险已经减少。”
en: “Yes,” said Anne, “you tell me nothing which does not accord with what I have known, or could imagine.There is always something offensive in the details of cunning.The manoeuvres of selfishness and duplicity must ever be revolting, but I have heard nothing which really surprises me.I know those who would be shocked by such a representation of Mr. Elliot, who would have difficulty in believing it; but I have never been satisfied.I have always wanted some other motive for his conduct than appeared.I should like to know his present opinion, as to the probability of the event he has been in dread of; whether he considers the danger to be lessening or not.”

zh: “我想，他觉得是减少了，”史密斯太太回答道，“他认为克莱太太怕他，知道他看透了她，不像他不在的时候那样胆大妄为了。不过既然他迟早总要离开的，而克莱太太现在还保持着她的影响，我看不出埃利奥特先生有什么可长久保险的。护士告诉我，沃利斯太太有个好笑的主意，就是在你和埃利奥特先生结婚的时候，要在婚约中加上一条：你父亲不能与克莱太太结婚。看来这一计策也只有沃利斯太太才想得出来。不过我那明智的鲁克太太看出了其中的荒谬。‘不过，说真的，太太，’她说，‘这不能阻止他去娶别人啊。’而且的确说真的，我觉得鲁克护士并不从心底里坚决反对沃尔特爵士再娶。你知道，应该允许她成为男婚女嫁的赞成者。而且（既然涉及到个人利益）谁能说她没有不着边际的幻想，希望通过沃利斯太太的推荐，可能服侍下一位埃利奥特夫人呢？”
en: “Lessening, I understand,” replied Mrs. Smith.“He thinks Mrs. Clay afraid of him, aware that he sees through her, and not daring to proceed as she might do in his absence.But since he must be absent some time or other, I do not perceive how he can ever be secure while she holds her present influence.Mrs. Wallis has an amusing idea, as nurse tells me, that it is to be put into the marriage articles when you and Mr. Elliot marry, that your father is not to marry Mrs. Clay.A scheme, worthy of Mrs. Wallis’s understanding, by all accounts; but my sensible nurse Rooke sees the absurdity of it.‘Why, to be sure, ma’am,’ said she, ‘it would not prevent his marrying anybody else.’And, indeed, to own the truth, I do not think nurse, in her heart, is a very strenuous opposer of Sir Walter’s making a second match.She must be allowed to be a favourer of matrimony, you know; and (since self will intrude) who can say that she may not have some flying visions of attending the next Lady Elliot, through Mrs. Wallis’s recommendation?”

zh: “我非常高兴能够知道这一切，”安妮沉思了一会儿，说道，“从某些方面来说，今后与他相处会使我感到痛苦，不过我更知道该怎么办了。我的行为方式将会更为直率。显然埃利奥特先生是个虚伪、做作、世故的人，除了自私自利以外，他从来没有过更好的处世原则。”
en: “I am very glad to know all this,” said Anne, after a little thoughtfulness.“It will be more painful to me in some respects to be in company with him, but I shall know better what to do.My line of conduct will be more direct.Mr. Elliot is evidently a disingenuous, artificial, worldly man, who has never had any better principle to guide him than selfishness.”

zh: 但是关于埃利奥特先生的事情还没有讲完。刚才史密斯太太说着说着便偏离了自己最初的方向，而安妮只顾担心自己家的情况，忘记了史密斯太太最初对他不满的那些暗示。不过安妮的注意力现在集中到对史密斯太太最初暗示的解释上来了。安妮听着她的倾诉，这些即使不能证明史密斯太太对埃利奥特先生的满腔怨恨是正当的，也能证明他对史密斯太太态度非常冷酷、不公正而且没有同情心。
en: But Mr. Elliot was not done with.Mrs. Smith had been carried away from her first direction, and Anne had forgotten, in the interest of her own family concerns, how much had been originally implied against him; but her attention was now called to the explanation of those first hints, and she listened to a recital which, if it did not perfectly justify the unqualified bitterness of Mrs. Smith, proved him to have been very unfeeling in his conduct towards her; very deficient both in justice and compassion.

zh: 安妮了解到（埃利奥特先生的婚姻并没有损害到他与史密斯夫妇之间的亲密关系）他们还是跟往常一样经常在一起，埃利奥特先生还怂恿他的朋友挥霍远超出其财力许可的程度。史密斯太太不愿意责怪自己，也不忍心责怪自己的丈夫。不过安妮看得出他们的收入从来就不够维持他们阔绰的生活，总的来说他们从一开始就挥霍无度。从他妻子对他的描述中，安妮可以看出史密斯先生感情丰富、性格随和、大大咧咧、没有很强的判断力，但是比他的朋友埃利奥特先生可爱得多，而且与他大不相同，被他牵着鼻子走，可能还受到他的蔑视。埃利奥特先生通过结婚而富裕起来，想要在不使自己的声誉受损的情况下（尽管挥霍无度，但是他已是一位谨慎的人），来满足自己所有的享乐和虚荣心。他开始富起来，正如他朋友应当发现自己在穷下去，可是他似乎根本不关心他朋友的经济能力，相反竭力怂恿他挥霍，结果只能是破产。就这样，史密斯夫妇破产了。
en: She learned that (the intimacy between them continuing unimpaired by Mr. Elliot’s marriage) they had been as before always together, and Mr. Elliot had led his friend into expenses much beyond his fortune.Mrs. Smith did not want to take blame to herself, and was most tender of throwing any on her husband; but Anne could collect that their income had never been equal to their style of living, and that from the first there had been a great deal of general and joint extravagance.From his wife’s account of him she could discern Mr. Smith to have been a man of warm feelings, easy temper, careless habits, and not strong understanding, much more amiable than his friend, and very unlike him, led by him, and probably despised by him.Mr. Elliot, raised by his marriage to great affluence, and disposed to every gratification of pleasure and vanity which could be commanded without involving himself, (for with all his self-indulgence he had become a prudent man), and beginning to be rich, just as his friend ought to have found himself to be poor, seemed to have had no concern at all for that friend’s probable finances, but, on the contrary, had been prompting and encouraging expenses which could end only in ruin; and the Smiths accordingly had been ruined.

zh: 丈夫死得真是时候，也省得了解事情的全部情况。在这之前他们夫妇也曾想求助于朋友的友谊，但是他们领略够了其中的难处，因而也知道最好不要考验埃利奥特先生的友情。但是直到史密斯先生去世的时候，人们才了解他们的家境败落到了何种程度。史密斯先生出于感情而不是理智上的原因，相信埃利奥特先生对他的敬重，指定他作遗嘱的执行人。但是埃利奥特先生不肯干，他的拒绝给史密斯太太带来了一大堆的困难和痛苦，又加上她当时心情本来就十分悲痛，因而她现在提起来也不能不感到痛苦，而听的人也不能不感到相应的愤怒。
en: The husband had died just in time to be spared the full knowledge of it.They had previously known embarrassments enough to try the friendship of their friends, and to prove that Mr. Elliot’s had better not be tried; but it was not till his death that the wretched state of his affairs was fully known.With a confidence in Mr. Elliot’s regard, more creditable to his feelings than his judgement, Mr. Smith had appointed him the executor of his will; but Mr. Elliot would not act, and the difficulties and distress which this refusal had heaped on her, in addition to the inevitable sufferings of her situation, had been such as could not be related without anguish of spirit, or listened to without corresponding indignation.

zh: 史密斯太太给安妮看了当时埃利奥特就此事写的几封信，那是他当时对史密斯太太紧急求助的回信，从信中可以看出他决议不肯介入这些无益的麻烦。信中那些冷冰冰的客套话，表明他毫不关心他的态度会给史密斯太太带来多么沉重的打击。这是忘恩负义和毫无人性的可怕写照，安妮刹那间觉得这比罪恶昭彰的公然犯罪更要可恶。安妮听到的事情太多了。过去在她们的谈话中只是隐约提到的一些凄惨场景的细节和一个接一个灾难的细枝末节，现在都很自然地吐露了出来。安妮能够完全理解这种感情上的发泄，只是她对朋友平时那种镇静的心态感到更为惊讶。
en: Anne was shewn some letters of his on the occasion, answers to urgent applications from Mrs. Smith, which all breathed the same stern resolution of not engaging in a fruitless trouble, and, under a cold civility, the same hard-hearted indifference to any of the evils it might bring on her.It was a dreadful picture of ingratitude and inhumanity; and Anne felt, at some moments, that no flagrant open crime could have been worse.She had a great deal to listen to; all the particulars of past sad scenes, all the minutiae of distress upon distress, which in former conversations had been merely hinted at, were dwelt on now with a natural indulgence.Anne could perfectly comprehend the exquisite relief, and was only the more inclined to wonder at the composure of her friend’s usual state of mind.

zh: 在史密斯太太的一连串抱怨中，有一件事情使安妮感到特别恼火。她有充分的理由相信，她丈夫在西印度群岛有份财产，多年来一直被扣押着，以便偿还本身的债务，只要采取适当的措施，就可能归还给她。这产业虽然不大，但足以使她相对富裕一点。但是没有人去活动。埃利奥特先生什么也不肯做，史密斯夫人本人一方面因为体弱多病而难以奔走，另一方面又没有钱去雇人代劳。她甚至没有可以帮她出出主意的亲戚，又请不起律师。这就使得她手头更为拮据。她以为自己本该生活得好一点，只要适当地花点小力气就能办得到，她担心拖延下去使她要回财产的希望会越来越小，因而心中十分难受。
en: There was one circumstance in the history of her grievances of particular irritation.She had good reason to believe that some property of her husband in the West Indies, which had been for many years under a sort of sequestration for the payment of its own incumbrances, might be recoverable by proper measures; and this property, though not large, would be enough to make her comparatively rich.But there was nobody to stir in it.Mr. Elliot would do nothing, and she could do nothing herself, equally disabled from personal exertion by her state of bodily weakness, and from employing others by her want of money.She had no natural connexions to assist her even with their counsel, and she could not afford to purchase the assistance of the law.This was a cruel aggravation of actually straitened means.To feel that she ought to be in better circumstances, that a little trouble in the right place might do it, and to fear that delay might be even weakening her claims, was hard to bear.

zh: 正是在这一点上，她本希望安妮做做埃利奥特先生的工作。起初，她以为两人会结婚，曾经担心会因此失去自己的朋友。但是后来她确定埃利奥特先生不会帮她的帮，因为他甚至不知道她在巴斯，便马上想到要是他心爱的女人能施加点影响，还是能帮上她的忙的。于是她曾在尽可能尊重埃利奥特先生人格的前提下设法尽快地引起安妮的兴趣，但是安妮否定了所谓的婚约，这样一来，事情的面貌就变了。这样一来，史密斯太太丧失了这一新产生的希望，无法在她最关心的事情上取得成功。不过她至少能够以自己的方式来讲述整个事情，因而获得一点安慰。
en: It was on this point that she had hoped to engage Anne’s good offices with Mr. Elliot.She had previously, in the anticipation of their marriage, been very apprehensive of losing her friend by it; but on being assured that he could have made no attempt of that nature, since he did not even know her to be in Bath, it immediately occurred, that something might be done in her favour by the influence of the woman he loved, and she had been hastily preparing to interest Anne’s feelings, as far as the observances due to Mr. Elliot’s character would allow, when Anne’s refutation of the supposed engagement changed the face of everything; and while it took from her the new-formed hope of succeeding in the object of her first anxiety, left her at least the comfort of telling the whole story her own way.

zh: 安妮听了关于埃利奥特先生的这番全面描述之后，不禁对在她们刚开始谈话时史密斯太太对埃利奥特先生的赞扬表示惊讶。“你当时似乎是在推崇和赞扬他啊！”
en: After listening to this full description of Mr. Elliot, Anne could not but express some surprise at Mrs. Smith’s having spoken of him so favourably in the beginning of their conversation.“She had seemed to recommend and praise him!”

zh: “亲爱的，”史密斯太太回答说，“我没有别的办法啊。我以为你必然会嫁给他，尽管他还没有向你求婚，我只能把他当作你丈夫来谈论，怎么能告诉你实情呢。我谈到幸福的字眼时，我的心里在为你流血。不过他聪明而又讨人喜欢，同你这样的女子生活在一起，也不是完全没有希望。他对他第一个妻子非常不好。他们生活在一起很不愉快。不过她十分无知，为人轻浮，不值得尊重，他也从来没有爱过她。我但愿你的命运会好些。”
en: “My dear,” was Mrs. Smith’s reply, “there was nothing else to be done.I considered your marrying him as certain, though he might not yet have made the offer, and I could no more speak the truth of him, than if he had been your husband.My heart bled for you, as I talked of happiness; and yet he is sensible, he is agreeable, and with such a woman as you, it was not absolutely hopeless.He was very unkind to his first wife.They were wretched together.But she was too ignorant and giddy for respect, and he had never loved her.I was willing to hope that you must fare better.”

zh: 安妮刚在心里承认有可能被人劝说而嫁给埃利奥特先生，就因想到有可能产生的悲惨结局而感到不寒而栗。她极有可能会听从拉塞尔夫人的劝说。如果是这样，那么等到时间将这一切都暴露出来的时候就已经太晚了，那岂不是非常可悲吗？
en: Anne could just acknowledge within herself such a possibility of having been induced to marry him, as made her shudder at the idea of the misery which must have followed.It was just possible that she might have been persuaded by Lady Russell!And under such a supposition, which would have been most miserable, when time had disclosed all, too late?

zh: 不能再让拉塞尔夫人蒙在鼓里了。她们谈了大半个上午，而这次重要谈话得出的一个结论是，安妮完全可以把埃利奥特先生对史密斯太太的所作所为都告诉拉塞尔夫人。
en: It was very desirable that Lady Russell should be no longer deceived; and one of the concluding arrangements of this important conference, which carried them through the greater part of the morning, was, that Anne had full liberty to communicate to her friend everything relative to Mrs. Smith, in which his conduct was involved.

zh: 第二十二章
en: CHAPTER 22

zh: 安妮回到家，仔细想着她所听到的一切。通过对埃利奥特先生的了解，安妮有点感到宽慰。她对这个人再也没有什么温情可言了。他在自身不受欢迎的莽撞方面与温特沃思上校恰好相反。安妮一想到昨天晚上他居心不良的大献殷勤和他可能已经造成的无法弥补的灾祸，就感到无比气愤，但是头脑还是清醒的。她对他的怜悯已经消失。不过，这是唯一让她感到宽慰的地方。在其他方面，她看看四周或展望未来，发现还有更多值得怀疑和忧虑的地方。她担心拉塞尔夫人会感到失望与痛苦；担心她的父亲和姐姐会蒙受屈辱，她痛苦地预见很多不幸的后果，但是不知道如何避开哪怕是其中的一种。她非常庆幸自己看清了埃利奥特先生。她从未想到自己会因为没有怠慢史密斯太太这样的老朋友而得到报答，可这一报答却自然而然地出现了！史密斯太太能把别人不会告知她的情况全都告诉了他。这些情况能不能告诉她的家人呢？但现在这只不过是想想罢了。她必须同拉塞尔夫人谈谈，把情况告诉她，与她商量商量，然后尽她自己最大的努力静观事态的发展。毕竟她最需要镇静的是不能向拉塞尔夫人提起那桩心事。在这方面只能完全由她一个人承担焦虑和担忧。
en: Anne went home to think over all that she had heard.In one point, her feelings were relieved by this knowledge of Mr. Elliot.There was no longer anything of tenderness due to him.He stood as opposed to Captain Wentworth, in all his own unwelcome obtrusiveness; and the evil of his attentions last night, the irremediable mischief he might have done, was considered with sensations unqualified, unperplexed.Pity for him was all over.But this was the only point of relief.In every other respect, in looking around her, or penetrating forward, she saw more to distrust and to apprehend.She was concerned for the disappointment and pain Lady Russell would be feeling; for the mortifications which must be hanging over her father and sister, and had all the distress of foreseeing many evils, without knowing how to avert any one of them.She was most thankful for her own knowledge of him.She had never considered herself as entitled to reward for not slighting an old friend like Mrs. Smith, but here was a reward indeed springing from it!Mrs. Smith had been able to tell her what no one else could have done.Could the knowledge have been extended through her family?But this was a vain idea.She must talk to Lady Russell, tell her, consult with her, and having done her best, wait the event with as much composure as possible; and after all, her greatest want of composure would be in that quarter of the mind which could not be opened to Lady Russell; in that flow of anxieties and fears which must be all to herself.

zh: 回到家里，她发现她如愿以偿地避开了埃利奥特先生。因为今天上午他确实来拜访过他们，而且坐了很长时间。安妮刚刚在暗自庆幸，觉得放心了，却又听说他晚上又要过来。
en: She found, on reaching home, that she had, as she intended, escaped seeing Mr. Elliot; that he had called and paid them a long morning visit; but hardly had she congratulated herself, and felt safe, when she heard that he was coming again in the evening.

zh: “我一点儿也不想请他来，”伊丽莎白装作漫不经心地说，“但是他给了那么多暗示。至少克莱太太是这么说的。”
en: “I had not the smallest intention of asking him,” said Elizabeth, with affected carelessness, “but he gave so many hints; so Mrs. Clay says, at least.”

zh: “真的，我真是那样说的。我一生中没有见到还有人这么渴望得到别人邀请。可怜的人！我真为他感到难过。因为你狠心的姐姐看起来如此冷酷无情。”
en: “Indeed, I do say it.I never saw anybody in my life spell harder for an invitation.Poor man!I was really in pain for him; for your hard-hearted sister, Miss Anne, seems bent on cruelty.”

zh: “哦！”伊丽莎白嚷道，“这种把戏我看得多了，不会一下子被一位绅士的暗示搞得不知所措的。不过，我发现他为今天上午没有见到我父亲而感到非常遗憾时，我就马上让步了，因为我确实不想错失一个让他和沃尔特爵士在一起的机会。看起来他们在一起是大有益处的。两个人的举止都那么优雅。埃利奥特先生是多么毕恭毕敬地仰视父亲。”
en: “Oh!” cried Elizabeth, “I have been rather too much used to the game to be soon overcome by a gentleman’s hints.However, when I found how excessively he was regretting that he should miss my father this morning, I gave way immediately, for I would never really omit an opportunity of bring him and Sir Walter together.They appear to so much advantage in company with each other.Each behaving so pleasantly.Mr. Elliot looking up with so much respect.”

zh: “太令人高兴了！”克莱太太嘴里虽在喊，但是却不敢朝安妮望上一眼。“真像一对父子！亲爱的埃利奥特小姐，我可以说他们像一对父子吗？”
en: “Quite delightful!” cried Mrs. Clay, not daring, however, to turn her eyes towards Anne.“Exactly like father and son!Dear Miss Elliot, may I not say father and son?”

zh: “啊！我没有禁止任何人说话。你愿意这么想就这么想吧！不过，说实话，我并不觉得他的殷勤超过了其他人。”
en: “Oh!I lay no embargo on any body’s words.If you will have such ideas!But, upon my word, I am scarcely sensible of his attentions being beyond those of other men.”

zh: “我亲爱的埃利奥特小姐！”克莱太太高声嚷道，举起双手，翻起双眼，把她剩下的惊叹淹没在一阵适宜的沉默之中。
en: “My dear Miss Elliot!” exclaimed Mrs. Clay, lifting her hands and eyes, and sinking all the rest of her astonishment in a convenient silence.

zh: “好啦，我亲爱的佩内洛普，你不用对他这么大惊小怪。你知道，我的确邀请了他。我带着微笑把他送走了。当我发现他明天的确一整天要去桑贝里庄园见朋友，我就对他发了善心。”
en: “Well, my dear Penelope, you need not be so alarmed about him.I did invite him, you know.I sent him away with smiles.When I found he was really going to his friends at Thornberry Park for the whole day to-morrow, I had compassion on him.”

zh: 安妮很佩服克莱太太的高超演技，她居然能对那个实际上必然会妨碍她实现主要目标的人的期待和到来，表现得如此愉快。克莱太太不可能不讨厌见到埃利奥特先生，可她却能装出一副彬彬有礼、心平气和的神情，看来她同沃尔特爵士在一起的时间减少到一半，她倒很满意。
en: Anne admired the good acting of the friend, in being able to shew such pleasure as she did, in the expectation and in the actual arrival of the very person whose presence must really be interfering with her prime object.It was impossible but that Mrs. Clay must hate the sight of Mr. Elliot; and yet she could assume a most obliging, placid look, and appear quite satisfied with the curtailed license of devoting herself only half as much to Sir Walter as she would have done otherwise.

zh: 对于安妮本人来说，一看到埃利奥特先生本人进屋，她就非常不快。再看到他走过来同自己讲话，更是感到痛苦。她以前也常常觉得埃利奥特先生不可能总是这么真诚，但是现在她发现他处处不真诚。他对她父亲的殷勤和尊重与他以前的话语对照起来，简直令人作呕。一想起他对史密斯太太的无情无义，安妮几乎没法看他现在的这副笑脸和温情，没法听他那些假仁假义的言论。
en: To Anne herself it was most distressing to see Mr. Elliot enter the room; and quite painful to have him approach and speak to her.She had been used before to feel that he could not be always quite sincere, but now she saw insincerity in everything.His attentive deference to her father, contrasted with his former language, was odious; and when she thought of his cruel conduct towards Mrs. Smith, she could hardly bear the sight of his present smiles and mildness, or the sound of his artificial good sentiments.

zh: 安妮决定在态度上不要变化得太突然，以免引起他的异议。她的主要目标是避开他的种种询问或对她进行奉承。但是她只想在彼此关系允许的范围内对他冷淡，而且要尽量不动声色地从前一阵逐步发展起来的不必要的亲密关系中摆脱出来。因此，她比头天晚上更加谨慎与冷漠。
en: She meant to avoid any such alteration of manners as might provoke a remonstrance on his side.It was a great object to her to escape all enquiry or eclat; but it was her intention to be as decidedly cool to him as might be compatible with their relationship; and to retrace, as quietly as she could, the few steps of unnecessary intimacy she had been gradually led along.She was accordingly more guarded, and more cool, than she had been the night before.

zh: 埃利奥特先生想再次激发安妮的好奇心，使她急于了解他过去是如何以及从哪儿听别人赞扬她的，他非常希望再一次听到安妮的恳求，但是这一法宝不灵了。他觉得必须有社交场合的热烈和动人的气氛，才能燃起他这位谦逊的堂妹的虚荣心。他觉得至少在眼下其他人都非常需要他去应酬时，他要是冒险去做这样的尝试是不行的。他没有想到，现在这个话题对他已经十分不利，因为一提这事，安妮马上就联想到他那些最不能宽恕的言行。
en: He wanted to animate her curiosity again as to how and where he could have heard her formerly praised; wanted very much to be gratified by more solicitation; but the charm was broken: he found that the heat and animation of a public room was necessary to kindle his modest cousin’s vanity; he found, at least, that it was not to be done now, by any of those attempts which he could hazard among the too-commanding claims of the others.He little surmised that it was a subject acting now exactly against his interest, bringing immediately to her thoughts all those parts of his conduct which were least excusable.

zh: 安妮发现埃利奥特先生明天早晨一早确实要离开巴斯，而且一去就是两天多，总算比较满意。他回来的那天晚上还要应邀来卡姆登，不过从周四到周六晚上他是肯定不会来了。安妮眼前总是有个克莱太太已经够让人讨厌的了，再加上这么个更虚伪的伪君子，就把那么点宁静感和舒适感都破坏无遗了。一想到这些人在不断地欺骗她的姐姐和父亲，一想到父亲和姐姐将面临的种种屈辱，安妮就感到非常羞愧！克莱太太的自私心理不像埃利奥特先生那么复杂，也不那么令人恶心。安妮宁愿马上对克莱太太同父亲的婚姻妥协，哪怕它会带来各种不幸，也要阻止埃利奥特先生尽力为防止这桩婚事而施展的诡计。
en: She had some satisfaction in finding that he was really going out of Bath the next morning, going early, and that he would be gone the greater part of two days.He was invited again to Camden Place the very evening of his return; but from Thursday to Saturday evening his absence was certain.It was bad enough that a Mrs. Clay should be always before her; but that a deeper hypocrite should be added to their party, seemed the destruction of everything like peace and comfort.It was so humiliating to reflect on the constant deception practised on her father and Elizabeth; to consider the various sources of mortification preparing for them!Mrs. Clay’s selfishness was not so complicate nor so revolting as his; and Anne would have compounded for the marriage at once, with all its evils, to be clear of Mr. Elliot’s subtleties in endeavouring to prevent it.

zh: 星期五的早晨，安妮打算一早就去拉塞尔夫人家，把那些要紧的事情告诉她。她本想一吃过早饭就动身，但是克莱太太为了讨好伊丽莎白，也要出去替她办事。于是安妮决定等一会儿再走，免得跟她结伴同行。因此，等她看到克莱太太走远了以后，她才说上午要去里弗斯街。
en: On Friday morning she meant to go very early to Lady Russell, and accomplish the necessary communication; and she would have gone directly after breakfast, but that Mrs. Clay was also going out on some obliging purpose of saving her sister trouble, which determined her to wait till she might be safe from such a companion.She saw Mrs. Clay fairly off, therefore, before she began to talk of spending the morning in Rivers Street.

zh: “很好，”伊丽莎白说道，“我没有什么东西好送去的，就代我问声好吧。啊！你不妨把她偏要借给我的那本讨厌的书带回去，就假装说我已经看完了。我的确不能总是自寻烦恼地看些新版的诗集和议论国家大事的书籍。拉塞尔夫人总是拿些新书来烦我。这话你不必告诉她，不过我觉得她那天晚上穿得真难看。我过去一直以为她穿衣服的品味很高雅，但是那天在音乐会上，我真为她感到害臊。她一副一本正经而又做作的神情，而且坐得那么笔直！当然请替我转达对她最亲切的问候。”
en: “Very well,” said Elizabeth, “I have nothing to send but my love.Oh! you may as well take back that tiresome book she would lend me, and pretend I have read it through.I really cannot be plaguing myself for ever with all the new poems and states of the nation that come out.Lady Russell quite bores one with her new publications.You need not tell her so, but I thought her dress hideous the other night.I used to think she had some taste in dress, but I was ashamed of her at the concert.Something so formal and arrange in her air!and she sits so upright!My best love, of course.”

zh: “也带我问好，”沃尔特爵士接着说道，“最亲切的问候。你就告诉她，说我打算不久就去拜访她。话说得客气点，我只不过想去留一下名片。上午去拜访她那样的女人是不恰当的，因为这时候她还没怎么打扮。她只要略施脂粉，就不怕让人看见了。不过我上次去拜访的时候，我注意到她马上放下了窗帘。”
en: “And mine,” added Sir Walter.“Kindest regards.And you may say, that I mean to call upon her soon.Make a civil message; but I shall only leave my card.Morning visits are never fair by women at her time of life, who make themselves up so little.If she would only wear rouge she would not be afraid of being seen; but last time I called, I observed the blinds were let down immediately.”

zh: 正当她父亲说话的时候，有人敲门。会是谁呢？安妮想起埃利奥特先生事先说过他随时可能来访，如果不是知道他在七英里以外的地方赴约，安妮还会以为是他呢。大家像往常一样琢磨了一阵后，便听到了一阵像往常一样的脚步声，“查尔斯•马斯格罗夫先生和太太”便被引进了屋。
en: While her father spoke, there was a knock at the door.Who could it be?Anne, remembering the preconcerted visits, at all hours, of Mr. Elliot, would have expected him, but for his known engagement seven miles off.After the usual period of suspense, the usual sounds of approach were heard, and “Mr. and Mrs. Charles Musgrove” were ushered into the room.

zh: 他们的出现引起了极强烈的震惊，但是安妮见到他们确实非常高兴。另外两位也不感到十分遗憾，也就摆出合乎礼节的欢迎姿态。等到弄清楚这两位亲家并不打算来此居住时，沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白顿时热忱大增，并表示要竭力地尽主人之谊。他们陪马斯格罗夫太太来巴斯小住几天，住在白哈特旅馆。大家很快把这些事情弄清楚了。后来沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白把玛丽领到另一间客厅，高兴地听着她的赞美之词，安妮才从查尔斯那儿得知了他们来巴斯的真实情况，解释一下玛丽刚才做出的那些故弄玄虚而又自鸣得意的暗示，还有他们到底来了哪些人这个显得十分混乱的问题。
en: Surprise was the strongest emotion raised by their appearance; but Anne was really glad to see them; and the others were not so sorry but that they could put on a decent air of welcome; and as soon as it became clear that these, their nearest relations, were not arrived with an views of accommodation in that house, Sir Walter and Elizabeth were able to rise in cordiality, and do the honours of it very well.They were come to Bath for a few days with Mrs. Musgrove, and were at the White Hart.So much was pretty soon understood; but till Sir Walter and Elizabeth were walking Mary into the other drawing-room, and regaling themselves with her admiration, Anne could not draw upon Charles’s brain for a regular history of their coming, or an explanation of some smiling hints of particular business, which had been ostentatiously dropped by Mary, as well as of some apparent confusion as to whom their party consisted of.

zh: 安妮这才知道，他们一行除了查尔斯夫妇之外，还有马斯格罗夫太太、亨里埃塔和哈维尔上校。查尔斯清楚地谈了事情的原委，安妮从他的叙述中发现这事的发展过程颇为特别。这件事情最先是由哈维尔上校引起的，他想来巴斯办点事情。他早在一个星期之前就开始提起这事了。由于狩猎时节已过，查尔斯想找点事做，便提议要跟他一块来，而且哈维尔太太看来非常赞成，觉得对她丈夫有好处。但是玛丽不肯一个人留下来，对这件事情大为不快，所以有一两天事情似乎悬而未决，或者几乎要告吹了。但是后来，查尔斯的父亲和母亲采纳了这个想法。他母亲在巴斯有几位好朋友，很想去看看。而大家也认为对亨里埃塔来说，这是一个为她自己和妹妹置办结婚礼服的好机会。总之大家最后都成了他母亲的随行人员，哈维尔上校便舒服和安心多了。而为了大家方便些，他和玛丽也来了。他们是头天深夜到达的。哈维尔太太、她的孩子们和本威克舰长，同马斯格罗夫先生和路易莎一起留在阿珀克罗斯。
en: She then found that it consisted of Mrs. Musgrove, Henrietta, and Captain Harville, beside their two selves.He gave her a very plain, intelligible account of the whole; a narration in which she saw a great deal of most characteristic proceeding.The scheme had received its first impulse by Captain Harville’s wanting to come to Bath on business.He had begun to talk of it a week ago; and by way of doing something, as shooting was over, Charles had proposed coming with him, and Mrs. Harville had seemed to like the idea of it very much, as an advantage to her husband; but Mary could not bear to be left, and had made herself so unhappy about it, that for a day or two everything seemed to be in suspense, or at an end.But then, it had been taken up by his father and mother.His mother had some old friends in Bath whom she wanted to see; it was thought a good opportunity for Henrietta to come and buy wedding-clothes for herself and her sister; and, in short, it ended in being his mother’s party, that everything might be comfortable and easy to Captain Harville; and he and Mary were included in it by way of general convenience.They had arrived late the night before.Mrs. Harville, her children, and Captain Benwick, remained with Mr. Musgrove and Louisa at Uppercross.

zh: 安妮唯一感到吃惊的是，事情发展得如此迅速，竟然已经到了谈论亨里埃塔结婚礼服的时候。她原以为他们经济上有很大的困难，一时还结不了婚。可是她从查尔斯那里得知，不久以前，（玛丽上次给她写信之后），查尔斯•海特应一个朋友邀请，为一名在多年后才能享受继承权的少年管理财产。凭着这份收入，加上在管理期限结束前查尔斯•海特几乎肯定可以获得一笔更为长期的收入，因此两家同意了这对年轻人的愿望，因此他们的婚礼可能同路易莎的一样来得快，在几个月内就要举行。“那可真是个美差，”查尔斯补充道，“离阿珀克罗斯只不过二十五英里，在一个美丽的乡村，是多塞特郡的一个很美的地方。它位于国王一些最好的狩猎保护区的中心，周围有三个大业主，他们一个比一个谨慎戒备。查尔斯•海特可以弄到专门的拜访信去拜访至少其中的两个。但他对此没有给予应有的重视，”默斯格罗夫说，“查尔斯对运动根本不感兴趣。这就是他最大的缺点。”
en: Anne’s only surprise was, that affairs should be in forwardness enough for Henrietta’s wedding-clothes to be talked of.She had imagined such difficulties of fortune to exist there as must prevent the marriage from being near at hand; but she learned from Charles that, very recently, (since Mary’s last letter to herself), Charles Hayter had been applied to by a friend to hold a living for a youth who could not possibly claim it under many years; and that on the strength of his present income, with almost a certainty of something more permanent long before the term in question, the two families had consented to the young people’s wishes, and that their marriage was likely to take place in a few months, quite as soon as Louisa’s.“And a very good living it was,” Charles added: “only five-and-twenty miles from Uppercross, and in a very fine country: fine part of Dorsetshire.In the centre of some of the best preserves in the kingdom, surrounded by three great proprietors, each more careful and jealous than the other; and to two of the three at least, Charles Hayter might get a special recommendation.Not that he will value it as he ought,” he observed, “Charles is too cool about sporting.That’s the worst of him.”

zh: “我真的非常高兴，”安妮大声说道，“能有这种事真让我特别高兴。她们两姐妹应该同样得到幸福，她们的关系一向很好，一个人的光辉前景不应该给另一个人的未来生活带来暗淡的色彩——她们应该拥有同样幸福而舒适的生活。我希望你父母对这两门婚事都很满意。”
en: “I am extremely glad, indeed,” cried Anne, “particularly glad that this should happen; and that of two sisters, who both deserve equally well, and who have always been such good friends, the pleasant prospect of one should not be dimming those of the other—that they should be so equal in their prosperity and comfort.I hope your father and mother are quite happy with regard to both.”

zh: “哦！是的。要是这两位女婿再富裕一点，我父亲会更高兴的，不过他也没有别的什么可挑剔的。钱，你知道，这可得花钱了——一下子嫁两个女儿——这不可能是一件轻而易举的事，这使他在很多事情上变得拮据。不过我并不是说做女儿的没有权利得到钱。她们理当得到女儿的那一份。而且我可以肯定地说，父亲对我一向非常仁慈和大方。玛丽不大喜欢亨里埃塔的婚事。你知道，她一向如此。但是，她小看了查尔斯•海特，也对温思罗普庄园估计不够。我无法使她理解这宗产业的价值。随着时间的推移，这会是一桩很般配的婚事。我一向喜欢查尔斯•海特，现在我也不会改变自己的看法的。”
en: “Oh! yes. My father would be well pleased if the gentlemen were richer, but he has no other fault to find.Money, you know, coming down with money—two daughters at once—it cannot be a very agreeable operation, and it streightens him as to many things.However, I do not mean to say they have not a right to it.It is very fit they should have daughters’ shares; and I am sure he has always been a very kind, liberal father to me.Mary does not above half like Henrietta’s match.She never did, you know.But she does not do him justice, nor think enough about Winthrop.I cannot make her attend to the value of the property.It is a very fair match, as times go; and I have liked Charles Hayter all my life, and I shall not leave off now.”

zh: “像马斯格罗夫先生和太太这样优秀的父母，”安妮说道，“会为他们女儿的婚事感到高兴的。我想他们在尽一切力量为他们的子女创造幸福。在他们的影响下，年轻人是多么幸福！你父母好像根本没有那种会把老少两辈引入歧途和痛苦的不切实际的奢望。我想你们觉得路易莎现在已经完全复原了吧？”
en: “Such excellent parents as Mr. and Mrs. Musgrove,” exclaimed Anne, “should be happy in their children’s marriages.They do everything to confer happiness, I am sure.What a blessing to young people to be in such hands!Your father and mother seem so totally free from all those ambitious feelings which have led to so much misconduct and misery, both in young and old.I hope you think Louisa perfectly recovered now?”

zh: 查尔斯犹犹豫豫地说：“是的，我想是这样。她好多了，但是却变了。她不跑也不跳，不笑也不跳舞，跟以前完全不一样了。要是门关的声音响一些，她就会吓一跳，像小鸟掉在水里似的扑腾。本威克整天坐在她的身边，给她读诗，或者在她耳边窃窃私语。
en: He answered rather hesitatingly, “Yes, I believe I do; very much recovered; but she is altered; there is no running or jumping about, no laughing or dancing; it is quite different.If one happens only to shut the door a little hard, she starts and wriggles like a young dab-chick in the water; and Benwick sits at her elbow, reading verses, or whispering to her, all day long.”

zh: 安妮忍不住笑了。“我知道这不合你的意，”安妮说道，“不过，我确实相信他是一位优秀的年轻人。”
en: Anne could not help laughing.“That cannot be much to your taste, I know,” said she; “but I do believe him to be an excellent young man.”

zh: “他当然优秀。没人会怀疑这一点。我想你不会以为我气量如此狭窄，要求每个人都有跟我一样的追求和乐趣。我十分看重本威克，只要有人能让他开口说话，他就会滔滔不绝。读书对他没有害处，因为他既读书又打仗。他是个勇敢的小伙子。上个周一，我对他有了更多的了解。那天上午，我们在我父亲的大谷仓里开展了一场精彩的逮鼠大战。他干得非常出色，从此我更加喜欢他了。”
en: “To be sure he is.Nobody doubts it; and I hope you do not think I am so illiberal as to want every man to have the same objects and pleasures as myself.I have a great value for Benwick; and when one can but get him to talk, he has plenty to say.His reading has done him no harm, for he has fought as well as read.He is a brave fellow.I got more acquainted with him last Monday than ever I did before.We had a famous set-to at rat-hunting all the morning in my father’s great barns; and he played his part so well that I have liked him the better ever since.”

zh: 说到这里，他们的谈话被打断了，因为查尔斯不得不跟着其他人去欣赏镜子与瓷器了。不过安妮听到的一切，足以使她了解阿珀克罗斯的现状，也对那里的喜事感到高兴。然而高兴之余，她又叹了一口气，但是她的叹气声中丝毫没有嫉妒的意思。如果可能，她当然愿意像他们那样幸福，但是她不想损害他们的幸福。
en: Here they were interrupted by the absolute necessity of Charles’s following the others to admire mirrors and china; but Anne had heard enough to understand the present state of Uppercross, and rejoice in its happiness; and though she sighed as she rejoiced, her sigh had none of the ill-will of envy in it.She would certainly have risen to their blessings if she could, but she did not want to lessen theirs.

zh: 总之，这次拜访是在愉快的气氛中度过的。玛丽兴致很高，喜欢这种快乐的气氛和换换环境。这次出门，她乘坐的是婆婆家的驷马马车，又完全不依赖娘家，因此感到非常满意。于是她完全有情绪来欣赏一切她理应欣赏的东西，而且当他们把这房子的优越性详细地介绍给她的时候，她也欣然地应承几句。她对父亲和姐姐没有什么要求，他们那漂亮的客厅也给她脸上添足了光彩。
en: The visit passed off altogether in high good humour.Mary was in excellent spirits, enjoying the gaiety and the change, and so well satisfied with the journey in her mother-in-law’s carriage with four horses, and with her own complete independence of Camden Place, that she was exactly in a temper to admire everything as she ought, and enter most readily into all the superiorities of the house, as they were detailed to her.She had no demands on her father or sister, and her consequence was just enough increased by their handsome drawing-rooms.

zh: 伊丽莎白一时之间感到十分难受。她觉得应该邀请马斯格罗夫太太和其随行人来共进晚餐，但是家里换了风格，减少了佣人，这样的晚餐势必会露馅，而让那些身份比凯林奇的埃利奥特家族低的人看出来，真叫伊丽莎白难以忍受。这是礼仪与虚荣之间的斗争，但是虚荣占了上风，于是伊丽莎白又高兴起来了。她内心里这样说服自己：“那是陈腐的观念，乡下人好客，但是我们不请人吃饭，在巴斯没有人这样做。艾丽西亚夫人从不请客，甚至自己亲妹妹一家已经在这里住了一个月，她也没有请过他们。而且我敢说这对于马斯格罗夫太太也不方便，会打乱她的安排。我敢肯定，她宁愿不来，她跟我们在一起会不自在的。我想请他们来参加一次晚会，这样会更好，更新奇也更有趣。他们以前还从没见过这样的两间客厅。他们明天晚上会很乐意过来的。那会是一次正式的晚会，规模很小，但是却非常讲究。”伊丽莎白对此感到满意，当她当场向玛丽和查尔斯发出邀请，并许诺要邀请其他人时，玛丽同样心满意足。她还特意要求玛丽见见埃利奥特先生，并要把她引荐给达尔林普尔夫人和卡特雷特小姐，而幸运的是，她们答应要来。玛丽还没有受到过这样令人感激的招待。埃利奥特小姐当天上午将荣幸地去拜访马斯格罗夫太太，而安妮直接就跟查尔斯和玛丽去看望她和亨里埃塔了。
en: Elizabeth was, for a short time, suffering a good deal.She felt that Mrs. Musgrove and all her party ought to be asked to dine with them; but she could not bear to have the difference of style, the reduction of servants, which a dinner must betray, witnessed by those who had been always so inferior to the Elliots of Kellynch.It was a struggle between propriety and vanity; but vanity got the better, and then Elizabeth was happy again.These were her internal persuasions: “Old fashioned notions; country hospitality; we do not profess to give dinners; few people in Bath do; Lady Alicia never does; did not even ask her own sister’s family, though they were here a month: and I dare say it would be very inconvenient to Mrs. Musgrove; put her quite out of her way.I am sure she would rather not come; she cannot feel easy with us.I will ask them all for an evening; that will be much better; that will be a novelty and a treat.They have not seen two such drawing rooms before.They will be delighted to come to-morrow evening.It shall be a regular party, small, but most elegant.”And this satisfied Elizabeth: and when the invitation was given to the two present, and promised for the absent, Mary was as completely satisfied.She was particularly asked to meet Mr. Elliot, and be introduced to Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret, who were fortunately already engaged to come; and she could not have received a more gratifying attention.Miss Elliot was to have the honour of calling on Mrs. Musgrove in the course of the morning; and Anne walked off with Charles and Mary, to go and see her and Henrietta directly.

zh: 她本想同拉塞尔夫人谈谈的，但是眼下只能放弃这个计划。他们三个一起到里弗斯街呆了几分钟，安妮心想，把原本想讲的话推迟一天也没关系，于是便匆匆赶往白哈特旅馆去看望她的旧友和去年秋天的伙伴们，通过多次的接触，她对他们怀有炽热的友情。
en: Her plan of sitting with Lady Russell must give way for the present.They all three called in Rivers Street for a couple of minutes; but Anne convinced herself that a day’s delay of the intended communication could be of no consequence, and hastened forward to the White Hart, to see again the friends and companions of the last autumn, with an eagerness of good-will which many associations contributed to form.

zh: 他们在屋里见到了马斯格罗夫太太和她的女儿，而且只有她们母女俩，安妮受到了她们的热情款待。亨里埃塔因为最近有了喜事，内心充满了新鲜的幸福感，因此对原来就喜欢的每一个人都充满了关心和兴趣。马斯格罗夫太太之所以对安妮这么真诚，是因为安妮在她们困难时曾经帮助过她们。安妮更加喜欢这发自内心的、热情而真挚的招待，因为令人伤心的是，她在家里享受不到这种幸福。她们恳求安妮尽量多地同她们呆在一起，请她天天过来，整天呆在这里，简直要把她当作家庭的一员。作为回报，安妮自然同往常一样关心和帮助她们。查尔斯走了以后，安妮便听马斯格罗夫太太谈起了路易莎的境况，听亨里埃塔谈自己的情况，并就某些事情谈了自己的意见，还介绍了一些商店的情况。在安妮需要帮助时，她还要停下谈话给她帮忙，从给她换绸带到算账、给她找钥匙、整理小饰物，还要设法使她相信没有人亏待她。玛丽坐在窗口前，俯瞰着矿泉厅的入口，同往常一样感到很有趣，但是仍不免想到自己受到了别人的亏待。
en: They found Mrs. Musgrove and her daughter within, and by themselves, and Anne had the kindest welcome from each.Henrietta was exactly in that state of recently-improved views, of fresh-formed happiness, which made her full of regard and interest for everybody she had ever liked before at all; and Mrs. Musgrove’s real affection had been won by her usefulness when they were in distress.It was a heartiness, and a warmth, and a sincerity which Anne delighted in the more, from the sad want of such blessings at home.She was entreated to give them as much of her time as possible, invited for every day and all day long, or rather claimed as part of the family; and, in return, she naturally fell into all her wonted ways of attention and assistance, and on Charles’s leaving them together, was listening to Mrs. Musgrove’s history of Louisa, and to Henrietta’s of herself, giving opinions on business, and recommendations to shops; with intervals of every help which Mary required, from altering her ribbon to settling her accounts; from finding her keys, and assorting her trinkets, to trying to convince her that she was not ill-used by anybody; which Mary, well amused as she generally was, in her station at a window overlooking the entrance to the Pump Room, could not but have her moments of imagining.

zh: 这个上午必然十分混乱。一大家人住在一个旅馆里，一定会出现变化多端的不安定局面。隔五分钟就会收到一张便条，再隔五分钟就是一个包裹。安妮在那儿呆了不到半个小时，他们那间宽敞的餐厅似乎就坐满了一半。一群忠实的老朋友坐在马斯格罗夫太太四周，查尔斯带着哈维尔上校和温特沃思上校回来了。温特沃思上校的出现只不过使安妮惊讶了片刻。安妮不可能如此健忘，竟想不到他们共同好友的到来会很快又把他们俩人带到了一起。他们之间的最后一次非常重要的谈话打开了他感情的闸门，安妮从中得出了一个可喜的结论。但是从他的表情看来，安妮又有点担心，觉得他还抱着曾促使他匆匆离开音乐会的那种不幸的念头。看样子他并不想走到安妮跟前来同她交谈。
en: A morning of thorough confusion was to be expected.A large party in an hotel ensured a quick-changing, unsettled scene.One five minutes brought a note, the next a parcel; and Anne had not been there half an hour, when their dining-room, spacious as it was, seemed more than half filled: a party of steady old friends were seated around Mrs. Musgrove, and Charles came back with Captains Harville and Wentworth.The appearance of the latter could not be more than the surprise of the moment.It was impossible for her to have forgotten to feel that this arrival of their common friends must be soon bringing them together again.Their last meeting had been most important in opening his feelings; she had derived from it a delightful conviction; but she feared from his looks, that the same unfortunate persuasion, which had hastened him away from the Concert Room, still governed.He did not seem to want to be near enough for conversation.

zh: 安妮尽力保持镇定，让事情顺其自然，她竭力想往合乎情理的方面想：“当然，如果我们双方的感情依旧的话，那么我们不久就会了解对方。我们不是小孩子了，不会无理取闹了，不会由于一时的冲突而误入歧途，也不会不负责任地把自己的幸福当儿戏。”然而，过了一会儿，安妮觉得在目前的情况下，他们呆在一起似乎只能使他们陷于极为有害的疏忽和误解。
en: She tried to be calm, and leave things to take their course, and tried to dwell much on this argument of rational dependence:—“Surely, if there be constant attachment on each side, our hearts must understand each other ere long.We are not boy and girl, to be captiously irritable, misled by every moment’s inadvertence, and wantonly playing with our own happiness.”And yet, a few minutes afterwards, she felt as if their being in company with each other, under their present circumstances, could only be exposing them to inadvertencies and misconstructions of the most mischievous kind.

zh: “安妮，”玛丽仍然站在窗口喊道，“我敢肯定站在柱廊底下的是克莱太太，还有个男的跟她在一起。我看见他们刚从巴斯街转弯过来。他们好像谈得很火热。那是谁呢？过来告诉我。天哪！我想起来了。是埃利奥特先生。”
en: “Anne,” cried Mary, still at her window, “there is Mrs. Clay, I am sure, standing under the colonnade, and a gentleman with her.I saw them turn the corner from Bath Street just now.They seemed deep in talk.Who is it?Come, and tell me.Good heavens!I recollect.It is Mr. Elliot himself.”

zh: “不，”安妮大喊道，“我向你保证，不可能是埃利奥特先生。他今天上午九点刚刚离开巴斯，直到明天才回来。”
en: “No,” cried Anne, quickly, “it cannot be Mr. Elliot, I assure you.He was to leave Bath at nine this morning, and does not come back till to-morrow.”

zh: 她说话的时候，觉得温特沃思上校在看她，这种感觉使她既苦恼又尴尬，让她怀疑自己说得太多了，尽管话很简单。
en: As she spoke, she felt that Captain Wentworth was looking at her, the consciousness of which vexed and embarrassed her, and made her regret that she had said so much, simple as it was.

zh: 玛丽最气愤别人认为她不了解自己的堂兄，便十分激动地谈起了自己家族的相貌特征，越发肯定那就是埃利奥特先生，再一次叫安妮自己过去看看，但是安妮根本就没想动，尽量表现出冷淡和漠不关心的样子。然而一看到两三位女客相互笑了笑，会意地交换眼神，仿佛她们很了解其中的奥妙似的，安妮就又感到苦恼。显然关于她的某种流言已经传播开来了。接下来大家沉默了一会儿，似乎要确保这流言会传得更广。
en: Mary, resenting that she should be supposed not to know her own cousin, began talking very warmly about the family features, and protesting still more positively that it was Mr. Elliot, calling again upon Anne to come and look for herself, but Anne did not mean to stir, and tried to be cool and unconcerned.Her distress returned, however, on perceiving smiles and intelligent glances pass between two or three of the lady visitors, as if they believed themselves quite in the secret.It was evident that the report concerning her had spread, and a short pause succeeded, which seemed to ensure that it would now spread farther.

zh: “快来呀，安妮，”玛丽嚷道，“你自己过来看看。你再不过来就来不及了。他们要分别了，他们正在握手。他转身了。难道我不认识埃利奥特先生！你好像把在莱姆的事情全忘了。”
en: “Do come, Anne” cried Mary, “come and look yourself.You will be too late if you do not make haste.They are parting; they are shaking hands.He is turning away.Not know Mr. Elliot, indeed!You seem to have forgot all about Lyme.”

zh: 为了让玛丽平息下来，也许是为了掩饰自己的尴尬，安妮平静地走到了窗口前。她来得正是时候，看清了那确实是埃利奥特先生，这在刚才她还一直不肯相信呢。他朝一边走不见了，而克莱太太则快步朝另一个方向走掉了。安妮看到这两个有着完全对立的利益关系的人居然会有一副友好商谈的样子，她不得不感到吃惊，但她压制住自己的惊讶，平静地说道：“是的，那确实是埃利奥特先生。我想他改变了他的出发时间，如此而已，或者是我自己弄错了，我可能没有听清楚。”说完回到自己的座位，镇静下来，心想自己对这件事情的处理还不错，不禁有些欣慰。
en: To pacify Mary, and perhaps screen her own embarrassment, Anne did move quietly to the window.She was just in time to ascertain that it really was Mr. Elliot, which she had never believed, before he disappeared on one side, as Mrs. Clay walked quickly off on the other; and checking the surprise which she could not but feel at such an appearance of friendly conference between two persons of totally opposite interest, she calmly said, “Yes, it is Mr. Elliot, certainly.He has changed his hour of going, I suppose, that is all, or I may be mistaken, I might not attend;” and walked back to her chair, recomposed, and with the comfortable hope of having acquitted herself well.

zh: 客人们都告辞了，查尔斯客气地将他们送走后，在他们身后做了个鬼脸，责备他们不该来，开始说道：
en: The visitors took their leave; and Charles, having civilly seen them off, and then made a face at them, and abused them for coming, began with—

zh: “好了，妈妈，我为你做了件你会喜欢的事情。我到戏院去了一趟，订了明晚的包厢。我是个好儿子吧？我知道你喜欢看戏，那个包厢可以坐下我们大家。它能容纳九个人。我已经约好了温特沃思上校。我想安妮也会愿意跟我们一起去的。我们大家都喜欢看戏。我干得不错吧，妈妈？”
en: “Well, mother, I have done something for you that you will like.I have been to the theatre, and secured a box for to-morrow night.A’n’t I a good boy?I know you love a play; and there is room for us all.It holds nine.I have engaged Captain Wentworth.Anne will not be sorry to join us, I am sure.We all like a play.Have not I done well, mother?”

zh: 马斯格罗夫太太刚刚笑眯眯地表示，要是亨里埃塔和其他人都喜欢看戏的话，她非常乐意去，这时玛丽急急忙忙地打断了，她嚷道：
en: Mrs. Musgrove was good humouredly beginning to express her perfect readiness for the play, if Henrietta and all the others liked it, when Mary eagerly interrupted her by exclaiming—

zh: “天哪，查尔斯！你怎么能想出这种事来？订下了明晚的包厢！你忘了我们明天晚上已经与卡姆登巷约好了吗？你忘了他们特意邀请我们去见见达尔林普尔夫人和她的女儿，还有埃利奥特先生，这些都是我们家族的重要亲戚，特意要把我们介绍给他们？你怎么能这么健忘呢？”
en: “Good heavens, Charles!how can you think of such a thing?Take a box for to-morrow night!Have you forgot that we are engaged to Camden Place to-morrow night?and that we were most particularly asked to meet Lady Dalrymple and her daughter, and Mr. Elliot, and all the principal family connexions, on purpose to be introduced to them?How can you be so forgetful?”

zh: “算了！算了！”查尔斯回答道，“晚会有什么意思？这根本不值得放在心上。要是你父亲想见见我们的话就请我们去吃晚饭了。你要想去你就去吧，反正我要去看戏。”
en: “Phoo!phoo!” replied Charles, “what’s an evening party?Never worth remembering.Your father might have asked us to dinner, I think, if he had wanted to see us.You may do as you like, but I shall go to the play.”

zh: “啊！我说，查尔斯，你要是这么做就太可恶了，你答应要去的。”
en: “Oh!Charles, I declare it will be too abominable if you do, when you promised to go.”

zh: “不，我没有答应。我只是干笑了一声，欠了欠身，说了句‘很高兴’。我没有答应。”
en: “No, I did not promise.I only smirked and bowed, and said the word ‘happy.’There was no promise.”

zh: “但是你必须得去，查尔斯。你要是不去，我是不会原谅你的。人家要我们去，是特意为我们介绍的。达尔林普尔一家与我们家一向有着密切的关系。无论双方发生什么事情，都会及时通报给对方。你知道，我们是非常近的亲戚。埃利奥特先生也是，你尤其应该与他结交！你应该关注一下埃利奥特先生。你想想，他是我父亲的继承人，是埃利奥特家族未来的代表。”
en: “But you must go, Charles.It would be unpardonable to fail.We were asked on purpose to be introduced.There was always such a great connexion between the Dalrymples and ourselves.Nothing ever happened on either side that was not announced immediately.We are quite near relations, you know; and Mr. Elliot too, whom you ought so particularly to be acquainted with!Every attention is due to Mr. Elliot.Consider, my father’s heir: the future representative of the family.”

zh: “不要跟我讲什么继承人和家族代表，”查尔斯嚷道，“我可不是那种放着当政的权贵不予理睬，反而去巴结那些新兴权贵的人。我要是看在你父亲的面子上都不想去，反而为了他的继承人而去的话，我会觉得很可耻。埃利奥特先生对我来说算得了什么？”听到这冒失的话，安妮觉得很痛快，只见温特沃思上校全神贯注地看着听着，而那最后一句话使他把那询问的目光从查尔斯身上转移到了安妮身上。
en: “Don’t talk to me about heirs and representatives,” cried Charles.“I am not one of those who neglect the reigning power to bow to the rising sun.If I would not go for the sake of your father, I should think it scandalous to go for the sake of his heir.What is Mr. Elliot to me?”The careless expression was life to Anne, who saw that Captain Wentworth was all attention, looking and listening with his whole soul; and that the last words brought his enquiring eyes from Charles to herself.

zh: 查尔斯和玛丽还是这么争论着。查尔斯半严肃半开玩笑地坚持去看戏，而玛丽始终很认真很激烈地反对去看戏。而且她不忘说明，尽管自己决定要去卡姆登巷，但是如果他们要撇开她而去看戏的话，她会觉得自己受到了亏待。这时马斯格罗夫太太插话了。
en: Charles and Mary still talked on in the same style; he, half serious and half jesting, maintaining the scheme for the play, and she, invariably serious, most warmly opposing it, and not omitting to make it known that, however determined to go to Camden Place herself, she should not think herself very well used, if they went to the play without her.Mrs. Musgrove interposed.

zh: “我们还是把看戏的时间往后推一推吧。查尔斯，你最好回去把包厢换成星期二的。一家人分成两处，会令人遗憾的，何况如果安妮小姐父亲那里有晚会，她也不会去的。我敢肯定，要是安妮小姐不能跟我们一块去的话，亨里埃塔和我都不会想去看戏的。”
en: “We had better put it off.Charles, you had much better go back and change the box for Tuesday.It would be a pity to be divided, and we should be losing Miss Anne, too, if there is a party at her father’s; and I am sure neither Henrietta nor I should care at all for the play, if Miss Anne could not be with us.”

zh: 安妮确实很感谢马斯格罗夫太太的这番好意，而且也很高兴这给她提供了一个可以果断决定的机会：
en: Anne felt truly obliged to her for such kindness; and quite as much so for the opportunity it gave her of decidedly saying—

zh: “要是只依照我的意愿的话，太太，家里的晚会（要不是照顾玛丽的想法的话）根本不是障碍。我并不喜欢这类晚会，很愿意去看戏，何况还是同你们一起去。不过，也许还是不要这么做好。”她把话说了出来，可是话说完了，她又有点忐忑不安，因为知道有人在听，她甚至不敢去看看这话产生了什么效果。
en: “If it depended only on my inclination, ma’am, the party at home (excepting on Mary’s account) would not be the smallest impediment.I have no pleasure in the sort of meeting, and should be too happy to change it for a play, and with you.But, it had better not be attempted, perhaps.”She had spoken it; but she trembled when it was done, conscious that her words were listened to, and daring not even to try to observe their effect.

zh: 大家很快一致同意改在星期二。只有查尔斯还在利用这件事逗着他妻子，坚持说就算没有人想去，他明天也要去看戏。
en: It was soon generally agreed that Tuesday should be the day; Charles only reserving the advantage of still teasing his wife, by persisting that he would go to the play to-morrow if nobody else would.

zh: 温特沃思上校离开座位，走到壁炉前。他的目的或许是为了不那么明显地从那里坐到安妮身边去。
en: Captain Wentworth left his seat, and walked to the fire-place; probably for the sake of walking away from it soon afterwards, and taking a station, with less bare-faced design, by Anne.

zh: “你在巴斯的时间不长，”他说，“还不太懂得享受这里晚会的乐趣。”
en: “You have not been long enough in Bath,” said he, “to enjoy the evening parties of the place.”

zh: “哦！不。对我来说，晚会一般没有什么吸引力。我不会打牌。”
en: “Oh! no. The usual character of them has nothing for me. I am no card-player.”

zh: “我知道你以前不打。你过去不喜欢打牌。但是时间会使人发生很多变化的。”
en: “You were not formerly, I know.You did not use to like cards; but time makes many changes.”

zh: “我可没变多少，”安妮大声说，又停住了，生怕会造成什么误会。过了一会儿，温特沃思上校似乎触景生情，说道：“确实过去很久了！八年半过去了！”
en: “I am not yet so much changed,” cried Anne, and stopped, fearing she hardly knew what misconstruction.After waiting a few moments he said, and as if it were the result of immediate feeling, “It is a period, indeed!Eight years and a half is a period.”

zh: 他原本是不是想深入地谈谈，这只能由安妮在比较平静的时候再去思考了。而在当时温特沃思上校的话音未落，亨里埃塔却扯起了别的事情，使安妮吃了一惊。亨里埃塔想趁着眼下这段空闲时间出去走走，便招呼她的同伴们不要耽搁，免得又有人来。
en: Whether he would have proceeded farther was left to Anne’s imagination to ponder over in a calmer hour; for while still hearing the sounds he had uttered, she was startled to other subjects by Henrietta, eager to make use of the present leisure for getting out, and calling on her companions to lose no time, lest somebody else should come in.

zh: 他们只好准备出发。安妮说她已经准备好了，并且尽量装出一副准备就绪的样子。但是她觉得要是亨里埃塔知道她离开座位时心里的遗憾与犹豫时，一定会同情她的，因为亨里埃塔本人对她的表兄十分喜欢，也对他的爱情非常放心。
en: They were obliged to move.Anne talked of being perfectly ready, and tried to look it; but she felt that could Henrietta have known the regret and reluctance of her heart in quitting that chair, in preparing to quit the room, she would have found, in all her own sensations for her cousin, in the very security of his affection, wherewith to pity her.

zh: 不过，他们的准备工作突然停下来了。他们听到了一阵令人厌烦的脚步声，又有客人来了，门一打开，是沃尔特爵士和埃利奥特小姐，他们的到来使大家心里凉了半截。安妮马上产生了一种压抑感，不管往哪里看，她看到的都是同样的神情。屋内那种舒适、自由、快乐的气氛顿时消失了，取而代之的是冷淡的镇静与坚定的沉默或者是乏味的谈话，以此来迎合她父亲与姐姐冷漠的高雅。看到这种情况，真让人感到羞耻！
en: Their preparations, however, were stopped short.Alarming sounds were heard; other visitors approached, and the door was thrown open for Sir Walter and Miss Elliot, whose entrance seemed to give a general chill.Anne felt an instant oppression, and wherever she looked saw symptoms of the same.The comfort, the freedom, the gaiety of the room was over, hushed into cold composure, determined silence, or insipid talk, to meet the heartless elegance of her father and sister.How mortifying to feel that it was so!

zh: 安妮留神的目光对一个细节比较满意。他们又同温特沃思上校打了个招呼，伊丽莎白比以前还有礼貌了。她甚至同他寒暄了一次，而且朝他看过不止一次。实际上，伊丽莎白正在琢磨着一个重大措施。随之而来的事情就说明了这一点。她花了几分钟说了一些得体的废话，便开始发出邀请，就算是对马斯格罗夫一家应有的全部礼遇了。“明天晚上，同朋友们见见面，不是正式的晚会。”她把这一切说得非常得体，在把带来的印有“埃利奥特小姐恭请光临”字样的请帖放在桌上时，她朝大家有礼貌地泛泛一笑，又专门朝温特沃思上校笑了一下，送上一份请帖。原来她在巴斯待的时间一长，自然知道像温特沃思上校这样有风度和相貌的人士的重要性。过去的事算不了什么。现在的问题是，温特沃思上校会在她的客厅中走来走去。这张请帖就是特意送给他的。然后沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白起身告辞了。
en: Her jealous eye was satisfied in one particular.Captain Wentworth was acknowledged again by each, by Elizabeth more graciously than before.She even addressed him once, and looked at him more than once.Elizabeth was, in fact, revolving a great measure.The sequel explained it.After the waste of a few minutes in saying the proper nothings, she began to give the invitation which was to comprise all the remaining dues of the Musgroves.“Tomorrow evening, to meet a few friends: no formal party.”It was all said very gracefully, and the cards with which she had provided herself, the “Miss Elliot at home,” were laid on the table, with a courteous, comprehensive smile to all, and one smile and one card more decidedly for Captain Wentworth.The truth was, that Elizabeth had been long enough in Bath to understand the importance of a man of such an air and appearance as his.The past was nothing.The present was that Captain Wentworth would move about well in her drawing-room.The card was pointedly given, and Sir Walter and Elizabeth arose and disappeared.

zh: 这段打扰虽然很令人不快，却很短暂，当他们一出去，房门关上以后，屋里的大多数人又恢复了原来的自在和兴奋，只有安妮例外。她一心想着她刚才非常惊讶地看到她姐姐发出邀请的情景，想着温特沃思上校接受邀请时的神情。那种迟疑的神态与其说是感激不如说是惊奇，与其说是接受邀请不如说是客气的表示收到请帖。安妮了解他，她看到了他眼中的轻蔑，绝不敢相信他会决定接受这次邀请，把它看作对过去一切无礼行为的补偿。安妮的情绪低沉了下来。他们走了以后，他手中还拿着那张请帖，仿佛在深思什么。
en: The interruption had been short, though severe, and ease and animation returned to most of those they left as the door shut them out, but not to Anne.She could think only of the invitation she had with such astonishment witnessed, and of the manner in which it had been received; a manner of doubtful meaning, of surprise rather than gratification, of polite acknowledgement rather than acceptance.She knew him; she saw disdain in his eye, and could not venture to believe that he had determined to accept such an offering, as an atonement for all the insolence of the past.Her spirits sank.He held the card in his hand after they were gone, as if deeply considering it.

zh: “你们只要想一想伊丽莎白把所有人都邀请到了！”玛丽低声说道，不过大家都能听得到。“怪不得温特沃思上校那么高兴！你看他拿着请帖都不肯放下了。”
en: “Only think of Elizabeth’s including everybody!” whispered Mary very audibly.“I do not wonder Captain Wentworth is delighted!You see he cannot put the card out of his hand.”

zh: 安妮看到了他的目光，发现他两颊绯红，嘴角掠过一丝轻蔑的表情，安妮转过身去，免得再看到或听到使她烦恼的事情。
en: Anne caught his eye, saw his cheeks glow, and his mouth form itself into a momentary expression of contempt, and turned away, that she might neither see nor hear more to vex her.

zh: 大家散开了。男人们有他们自己的消遣，女人们则接着做她们自己的事，安妮跟她们在一起时，他们再也没有见过面。大家诚恳地要求安妮回来吃晚饭，同他们度过这一天余下的时光。可是安妮精神紧张了那么久，现在觉得没有精力了。她只适合回家，那样她就肯定可以想怎么安静就怎么安静了。
en: The party separated.The gentlemen had their own pursuits, the ladies proceeded on their own business, and they met no more while Anne belonged to them.She was earnestly begged to return and dine, and give them all the rest of the day, but her spirits had been so long exerted that at present she felt unequal to more, and fit only for home, where she might be sure of being as silent as she chose.

zh: 安妮答应第二天再来陪他们一上午，然后就疲惫不堪地走回卡姆登巷去，结束了这劳累的一天。这天晚上，她在家里只是听着伊丽莎白和克莱太太忙着安排第二天的晚会，反复清点邀请的人物，不断改进各种装饰的细节，想把这次晚会办成巴斯同类晚会中最体面的一次。与此同时，安妮一直在暗自反复琢磨温特沃思上校是否会来。他们认为他肯定会来，可是对安妮来说，这一令人痛苦的悬念从未停止过五分钟。她大体上觉得他会来，因为她总觉得他应该来，但是她不能把这事看成是某种毫无疑问的必须做到或无条件的行动，因为她脑海中总会出现一些完全相反的设想。
en: Promising to be with them the whole of the following morning, therefore, she closed the fatigues of the present by a toilsome walk to Camden Place, there to spend the evening chiefly in listening to the busy arrangements of Elizabeth and Mrs. Clay for the morrow’s party, the frequent enumeration of the persons invited, and the continually improving detail of all the embellishments which were to make it the most completely elegant of its kind in Bath, while harassing herself with the never-ending question, of whether Captain Wentworth would come or not?They were reckoning him as certain, but with her it was a gnawing solicitude never appeased for five minutes together.She generally thought he would come, because she generally thought he ought; but it was a case which she could not so shape into any positive act of duty or discretion, as inevitably to defy the suggestions of very opposite feelings.

zh: 安妮从这种焦躁不安的沉思中醒来，只让克莱太太知道，就在人们认为埃利奥特先生离开巴斯三个小时之后，她看见他们两人在一起。本来安妮曾期待着，想看看克莱太太本人会不会透露这次会面的事，可是她什么也没说，于是安妮决定亲自把这事提出来。她发现克莱太太在听的时候面有愧色。这种愧色转瞬即逝。但是安妮却觉得她从克莱太太的的神情中看出：或是由于他们之间某种错综复杂的勾结，或是摄于埃利奥特先生的专横，她只得乖乖听他说教（或许有半个小时）以及不准她在沃尔特爵士身上打主意。可是克莱太太却煞有介事地惊呼了一声：
en: She only roused herself from the broodings of this restless agitation, to let Mrs. Clay know that she had been seen with Mr. Elliot three hours after his being supposed to be out of Bath, for having watched in vain for some intimation of the interview from the lady herself, she determined to mention it, and it seemed to her there was guilt in Mrs. Clay’s face as she listened.It was transient: cleared away in an instant; but Anne could imagine she read there the consciousness of having, by some complication of mutual trick, or some overbearing authority of his, been obliged to attend (perhaps for half an hour) to his lectures and restrictions on her designs on Sir Walter.She exclaimed, however, with a very tolerable imitation of nature:—

zh: “噢！天哪！真的。你只要想想，使我非常吃惊的是，我在巴斯街上遇见了埃利奥特先生。我从来没有这么吃惊过。他掉过头来，陪我走到矿泉厅。他遇到什么事情，所以没有去桑贝里，我确实忘了是什么原因，因为我当时急于赶路，没有怎么注意他说什么。我只听说他决定不耽误他回来的时间。他想知道明天他最早什么时候能来拜访。他满脑子的明天，我一回来，得知你们增加了邀请的人数和今天发生过的种种事情，我也是满脑子想着明天，要不然，我决不会把遇见到他的事情忘得一干二净。”
en: “Oh! dear! very true.Only think, Miss Elliot, to my great surprise I met with Mr. Elliot in Bath Street.I was never more astonished.He turned back and walked with me to the Pump Yard.He had been prevented setting off for Thornberry, but I really forget by what; for I was in a hurry, and could not much attend, and I can only answer for his being determined not to be delayed in his return.He wanted to know how early he might be admitted to-morrow.He was full of ‘to-morrow,’ and it is very evident that I have been full of it too, ever since I entered the house, and learnt the extension of your plan and all that had happened, or my seeing him could never have gone so entirely out of my head.”

zh: 第二十三章
en: CHAPTER 23

zh: 安妮同史密斯太太的谈话才过去一天，就发生了使安妮更加焦虑的事情。现在除了埃利奥特先生的行为可能在某方面造成的影响之外，安妮对他的行为根本不在乎。因此第二天早晨，她就依旧理所当然地推迟去里弗斯街澄清事实。她已经答应了从早饭到晚饭都陪着马斯格罗夫太太了。她信守自己的诺言，而埃利奥特先生的品性，就像伊斯兰教山鲁佐德王妃的脑袋，再保全一天。
en: One day only had passed since Anne’s conversation with Mrs. Smith; but a keener interest had succeeded, and she was now so little touched by Mr. Elliot’s conduct, except by its effects in one quarter, that it became a matter of course the next morning, still to defer her explanatory visit in Rivers Street.She had promised to be with the Musgroves from breakfast to dinner.Her faith was plighted, and Mr. Elliot’s character, like the Sultaness Scheherazade’s head, must live another day.

zh: 不过安妮不能准时赴约，因为天气不好，她望着雨为她的朋友难过，也为自己不安，然后再试着走出去。她到达白哈特旅馆，走进她要去的那个房间时，发现自己并不是准时到的，也不是第一个到的。比她早到的就有好几个人，马斯格罗夫太太在跟克罗夫特太太聊天，哈维尔上校在与温特沃思上校说话。她很快就听说，玛丽和亨里埃塔因为等不及，天一晴就出去了，不过很快就会回来的。他们还严格指令马斯格罗夫太太留住安妮，一定等她们回来。安妮只好遵命，坐了下来，她表面上装得镇静自若，自己内心却顿时陷入了种种焦虑之中，她原以为这天上午她只不过会稍稍不安而已。可是一点也没有耽搁，一点也没有浪费时间。她当即就陷入了这种痛苦的幸福，或者说是这幸福的痛苦之中。她走进屋子才两分钟，温特沃思上校说道：
en: She could not keep her appointment punctually, however; the weather was unfavourable, and she had grieved over the rain on her friends’ account, and felt it very much on her own, before she was able to attempt the walk.When she reached the White Hart, and made her way to the proper apartment, she found herself neither arriving quite in time, nor the first to arrive.The party before her were, Mrs. Musgrove, talking to Mrs. Croft, and Captain Harville to Captain Wentworth; and she immediately heard that Mary and Henrietta, too impatient to wait, had gone out the moment it had cleared, but would be back again soon, and that the strictest injunctions had been left with Mrs. Musgrove to keep her there till they returned.She had only to submit, sit down, be outwardly composed, and feel herself plunged at once in all the agitations which she had merely laid her account of tasting a little before the morning closed.There was no delay, no waste of time.She was deep in the happiness of such misery, or the misery of such happiness, instantly.Two minutes after her entering the room, Captain Wentworth said—

zh: “现在，哈维尔，你要是把纸笔给我，我们就马上写刚才谈到的那封信吧。”
en: “We will write the letter we were talking of, Harville, now, if you will give me materials.”

zh: 纸笔就在手边，放在另一张桌子上。温特沃思上校走过去，几乎是背朝着大家，专心致志地写了起来。
en: Materials were at hand, on a separate table; he went to it, and nearly turning his back to them all, was engrossed by writing.

zh: 马斯格罗夫太太正在向克罗夫特太太讲述她大女儿的婚约经过，还是用这么令人不舒服的语气，装作是在窃窃私语，实际上却让人完全听得到。安妮觉得自己不该去听她们的谈话，可是哈维尔上校似乎若有所思，不想说话，因此安妮不可避免地听到不想听的细节，比如，“马斯格罗夫先生怎么和我妹夫海特一再见面一再商量这事；我妹夫海特某天说了什么；马斯格罗夫先生第二天提了什么建议；我妹妹又提出了什么建议；年轻人想要什么；我起先说什么也不同意，但是后来经过劝说，又觉得这样倒也不错。”还有很多同样坦率地谈话。这些细枝末节，即使说得非常动听，非常文雅，也只能引起一些与这件事情有切身利害关系的人的关注，何况好心的马斯格罗夫太太还没有这种本事。克罗夫特太太听得津津有味，她不论说什么，也是都很有分寸的。安妮希望两位绅士能一心忙自己的事情，顾不上听这些谈话。
en: Mrs. Musgrove was giving Mrs. Croft the history of her eldest daughter’s engagement, and just in that inconvenient tone of voice which was perfectly audible while it pretended to be a whisper.Anne felt that she did not belong to the conversation, and yet, as Captain Harville seemed thoughtful and not disposed to talk, she could not avoid hearing many undesirable particulars; such as, “how Mr. Musgrove and my brother Hayter had met again and again to talk it over; what my brother Hayter had said one day, and what Mr. Musgrove had proposed the next, and what had occurred to my sister Hayter, and what the young people had wished, and what I said at first I never could consent to, but was afterwards persuaded to think might do very well,” and a great deal in the same style of open-hearted communication: minutiae which, even with every advantage of taste and delicacy, which good Mrs. Musgrove could not give, could be properly interesting only to the principals.Mrs. Croft was attending with great good-humour, and whenever she spoke at all, it was very sensibly.Anne hoped the gentlemen might each be too much self-occupied to hear.

zh: “就这样，夫人，事事都考虑到了，”马斯格罗夫太太大声地说着悄悄话，“尽管我们原想要另一种方式，不过总的来说，我们觉得再拖下去也不是办法，因为查尔斯•海特非常希望结婚，亨里埃塔也同样心急火燎。所以，我们觉得最好还是让他们俩立刻成亲，尽量像他们之前的很多人那样把婚事办得最体面。我说过，不管怎么样，这总比订了婚而长时间不结婚要好。”
en: “And so, ma’am, all these thing considered,” said Mrs. Musgrove, in her powerful whisper, “though we could have wished it different, yet, altogether, we did not think it fair to stand out any longer, for Charles Hayter was quite wild about it, and Henrietta was pretty near as bad; and so we thought they had better marry at once, and make the best of it, as many others have done before them.At any rate, said I, it will be better than a long engagement.”

zh: “这正是我想说的，”克罗夫特太太大声说道，“我觉得与其让年轻人订了婚长时间不结婚，倒不如让他们凭一小笔收入安安家，然后去共同克服一些困难。我总觉得没有相互间——”
en: “That is precisely what I was going to observe,” cried Mrs. Croft.“I would rather have young people settle on a small income at once, and have to struggle with a few difficulties together, than be involved in a long engagement.I always think that no mutual—”

zh: “哦！亲爱的克罗夫特太太，”马斯格罗夫太太不等对方说完就嚷道，“我最讨厌年轻人订婚之后长时间不结婚。我就是一贯反对我的孩子们这么做。我过去常说，如果他们肯定能够在六个月甚至一年之内结婚，而不是长时间的订婚的话，那么订婚对他们来说也是件大好事，可是长期订婚——”
en: “Oh! dear Mrs. Croft,” cried Mrs. Musgrove, unable to let her finish her speech, “there is nothing I so abominate for young people as a long engagement.It is what I always protested against for my children.It is all very well, I used to say, for young people to be engaged, if there is a certainty of their being able to marry in six months, or even in twelve; but a long engagement—”

zh: “是啊，亲爱的太太，”克罗夫特太太说道，“或者是那种不牢靠的婚约，可能拖的时间很长。要是一开始不知道他们什么时候才有能力结婚，那是很不可靠，很不明智的。我认为所有做父母的都应该尽量阻止这种婚约。”
en: “Yes, dear ma’am,” said Mrs. Croft, “or an uncertain engagement, an engagement which may be long.To begin without knowing that at such a time there will be the means of marrying, I hold to be very unsafe and unwise, and what I think all parents should prevent as far as they can.”

zh: 听到这里，安妮意外地感到这番谈话很有意思。她觉得这种看法对她也很适用，浑身顿时紧张起来。同时她的眼睛本能地朝远处的桌子瞥了一下，只见温特沃思上校停住了笔，抬起头，愣愣地听着，随即转脸又快又颇有意味地看了安妮一眼。
en: Anne found an unexpected interest here.She felt its application to herself, felt it in a nervous thrill all over her; and at the same moment that her eyes instinctively glanced towards the distant table, Captain Wentworth’s pen ceased to move, his head was raised, pausing, listening, and he turned round the next instant to give a look, one quick, conscious look at her.
