zh: 两位夫人继续谈着，一再强调着那些她们两人都同意的真理，而且还列举了她们所看到的反面例子造成的不利影响，以此来证明她们的观点。但是安妮什么也听不清楚了，她们的话只在她耳朵嗡嗡作响，她心里十分慌乱。
en: The two ladies continued to talk, to re-urge the same admitted truths, and enforce them with such examples of the ill effect of a contrary practice as had fallen within their observation, but Anne heard nothing distinctly; it was only a buzz of words in her ear, her mind was in confusion.

zh: 哈维尔上校刚才确实什么话也没听见，现在离开座位，走到窗口，尽管安妮是完全心不在焉的，但是安妮看起来是在看他。安妮渐渐意识到他是在邀请她到他身边去。他微笑地望着安妮，向她微微点点头，意思是说：“到我这儿来，我有话要对你说。”虽然他们之间的交情还不那么深，但他那自然、大方而又友好的态度，表达了一位老朋友的真情，因而更加显得盛情难却了。安妮站起身来，走到他身边。哈维尔上校站立的窗口在房间的另一端，与两位太太的座位遥遥相望，虽说靠近温特沃思上校的桌子，但是并不是很近。等安妮走到哈维尔上校身旁，他的脸上又恢复了那种严肃、沉思的神情，似乎这才是他本来的面目。
en: Captain Harville, who had in truth been hearing none of it, now left his seat, and moved to a window, and Anne seeming to watch him, though it was from thorough absence of mind, became gradually sensible that he was inviting her to join him where he stood.He looked at her with a smile, and a little motion of the head, which expressed, “Come to me, I have something to say;” and the unaffected, easy kindness of manner which denoted the feelings of an older acquaintance than he really was, strongly enforced the invitation.She roused herself and went to him.The window at which he stood was at the other end of the room from where the two ladies were sitting, and though nearer to Captain Wentworth’s table, not very near.As she joined him, Captain Harville’s countenance re-assumed the serious, thoughtful expression which seemed its natural character.

zh: “看这儿，”他一面说着，一面打开他手中的一个小包，拿出一张小小的微型画像，“你知道这是谁吗？”
en: “Look here,” said he, unfolding a parcel in his hand, and displaying a small miniature painting, “do you know who that is?”

zh: “当然是本威克上校。”
en: “Certainly: Captain Benwick.”

zh: “对，你也许能猜到这是给谁的。不过，”（用低沉的语气）“这不是为她画的。埃利奥特小姐，你还记得我们一起在莱姆时替他感到难过吗？当时我一点没想到——不过无关紧要了。这是在好望角画的。他在好望角遇到一位聪明年轻的德国画家，为了实现对我可怜妹妹的诺言，他让那位画家替他画了幅肖像，要带回来给我妹妹。现在我却负责装帧好送给另一个人。他给了我这么一个任务！不过他还能委托谁呢？但愿我能够体谅他。实际上，把画像交给另外一个人，我并不感到难过。他主动要求这么干的。”（说着望了温特沃思上校一眼）“他正在为此事写信呢。”他嘴唇颤抖了一下，补充道，“可怜的范妮！她可不会这么快就忘记本威克！”
en: “Yes, and you may guess who it is for.But,” (in a deep tone,) “it was not done for her.Miss Elliot, do you remember our walking together at Lyme, and grieving for him?I little thought then—but no matter.This was drawn at the Cape.He met with a clever young German artist at the Cape, and in compliance with a promise to my poor sister, sat to him, and was bringing it home for her; and I have now the charge of getting it properly set for another!It was a commission to me!But who else was there to employ?I hope I can allow for him.I am not sorry, indeed, to make it over to another.He undertakes it;” (looking towards Captain Wentworth,) “he is writing about it now.”And with a quivering lip he wound up the whole by adding, “Poor Fanny! she would not have forgotten him so soon!”

zh: “没错，”安妮以一种低沉而充满感情的声音回答道。“这一点我不难相信。”
en: “No,” replied Anne, in a low, feeling voice.“That I can easily believe.”

zh: “这不是她的本性。她爱本威克。”
en: “It was not in her nature.She doted on him.”

zh: “这是违背任何一个曾经真心相爱的女人的本性的。”
en: “It would not be the nature of any woman who truly loved.”

zh: 哈维尔上校微笑了一下，似乎在说，“你能保证所有女人都如此吗？”安妮笑盈盈地回答了这个问题：“是的。我们当然不会像你们忘记我们那样那么快地忘记你们。或许与其说这是我们的优点，倒不如说我们命该如此。我们难以控制自己。我们住在家里，生活平静，活动空间有限，总是受到感情的折磨。你们男人不得不努力工作。你们总有事业，有追求，有这样那样的事情，你们很快就会卷入世俗事务中去，而不断的工作和变动很快就会淡化你们的各种感觉。”
en: Captain Harville smiled, as much as to say, “Do you claim that for your sex?” and she answered the question, smiling also, “Yes.We certainly do not forget you as soon as you forget us.It is, perhaps, our fate rather than our merit.We cannot help ourselves.We live at home, quiet, confined, and our feelings prey upon us.You are forced on exertion.You have always a profession, pursuits, business of some sort or other, to take you back into the world immediately, and continual occupation and change soon weaken impressions.”

zh: “就算你说得不错，世俗事务对男人有此作用（不过，我并不认为你是对的），可是这话对本威克并不适用。没有人强迫他去做任何事情。当时天下太平了，他马上回到岸上，从那以后他一直同我们住在一起，生活在我们小小的家庭圈子里。”
en: “Granting your assertion that the world does all this so soon for men (which, however, I do not think I shall grant), it does not apply to Benwick.He has not been forced upon any exertion.The peace turned him on shore at the very moment, and he has been living with us, in our little family circle, ever since.”

zh: “的确，”安妮说道，“的确是这样。我没有想到这一点，不过现在我们能说什么呢，哈维尔上校？如果这种变化不是来自外界环境，那就一定是来自内心。本威克舰长之所以发生变化，肯定是出于本性，出于男人的本性。”
en: “True,” said Anne, “very true; I did not recollect; but what shall we say now, Captain Harville?If the change be not from outward circumstances, it must be from within; it must be nature, man’s nature, which has done the business for Captain Benwick.”

zh: “不，不，不是男人的本性。”说男人的本性没有女人坚贞，忘掉他们所爱或者曾经爱过的人，我不能同意。我认为恰恰相反。我认为我们的身体与精神是完全一致的，因为我们的身体最强壮，感情也就最强烈，能够忍受最痛苦的困境，渡过最强烈的风暴。”
en: “No, no, it is not man’s nature.I will not allow it to be more man’s nature than woman’s to be inconstant and forget those they do love, or have loved.I believe the reverse.I believe in a true analogy between our bodily frames and our mental; and that as our bodies are the strongest, so are our feelings; capable of bearing most rough usage, and riding out the heaviest weather.”

zh: “你们的感情可能是最强烈的，”安妮回答道，“但是用同样的推理方法，我们也可以说我们的感情是最温柔的。男人是比女人更加强壮，但并不比女人长寿，这恰好表明我对男女感情本质的看法。不，要不然的话，你们会感到很痛苦。你们要同种种困难、困苦和危险作斗争。你们总是在辛勤劳动，面对各种危险和艰难。你们离开了家庭、故土和朋友。时间、健康或者生命都不能说是你们自己的。这确实太苦了。”（用颤抖的声音），“如果这些再加上女人的感情。”
en: “Your feelings may be the strongest,” replied Anne, “but the same spirit of analogy will authorise me to assert that ours are the most tender.Man is more robust than woman, but he is not longer lived; which exactly explains my view of the nature of their attachments.Nay, it would be too hard upon you, if it were otherwise.You have difficulties, and privations, and dangers enough to struggle with.You are always labouring and toiling, exposed to every risk and hardship.Your home, country, friends, all quitted.Neither time, nor health, nor life, to be called your own.It would be hard, indeed” (with a faltering voice), “if woman’s feelings were to be added to all this.”

zh: “在这个问题上我们永远也不会达成一致，”哈维尔上校刚开始说，温特沃思上校坐着的那块一直很安静的地方发出了一点响声，引起了他们的注意。那只不过是他的钢笔掉在了地上，可是安妮惊讶地发现他离她比她原本想象的要近。她有点怀疑，钢笔之所以掉在地上，是因为他在注意他们，想听清楚他们的谈话，不过安妮觉得，他不可能听清的。
en: “We shall never agree upon this question,” Captain Harville was beginning to say, when a slight noise called their attention to Captain Wentworth’s hitherto perfectly quiet division of the room.It was nothing more than that his pen had fallen down; but Anne was startled at finding him nearer than she had supposed, and half inclined to suspect that the pen had only fallen because he had been occupied by them, striving to catch sounds, which yet she did not think he could have caught.

zh: “你的信写好了吗？”哈维尔上校说。
en: “Have you finished your letter?” said Captain Harville.

zh: “还没全写好，还剩几句。再有五分钟我就可以写完了。”
en: “Not quite, a few lines more.I shall have done in five minutes.”

zh: “我这边倒不着急。你一写好，我就可以走。我正处在理想抛锚地，”（朝安妮笑了笑，）“供应充足，什么也不缺。根本不急于起航。好了，埃利奥特小姐，”（压低了他的声音，）“正如我刚才所说的，在这个问题上，我想我们永远也不会达成一致。大概任何男人和女人都不会的。不过请允许我指出，种种史实都与你的观点背道而驰——所有的故事、散文和诗歌。要是我有本威克那样的记忆力，我马上就可以引出五十个事例来证明我的观点。我觉得我一生中很少看过有哪一本书不讲到女人是反复无常的。诗歌和谚语都说女人水性杨花。不过，你也许会说，那些都是男人写的。”
en: “There is no hurry on my side.I am only ready whenever you are.I am in very good anchorage here,” (smiling at Anne,) “well supplied, and want for nothing.No hurry for a signal at all.Well, Miss Elliot,” (lowering his voice,) “as I was saying we shall never agree, I suppose, upon this point.No man and woman, would, probably.But let me observe that all histories are against you—all stories, prose and verse.If I had such a memory as Benwick, I could bring you fifty quotations in a moment on my side the argument, and I do not think I ever opened a book in my life which had not something to say upon woman’s inconstancy.Songs and proverbs, all talk of woman’s fickleness.But perhaps you will say, these were all written by men.”

zh: “也许我会这样说的。是的，是的，请你不要在书中找例子了。男人们在讲述他们的故事方面比我们强多了。他们受的教育比我们高，笔杆子还握在他们手里。我不认为书本可以证明一切问题。”
en: “Perhaps I shall.Yes, yes, if you please, no reference to examples in books.Men have had every advantage of us in telling their own story.Education has been theirs in so much higher a degree; the pen has been in their hands.I will not allow books to prove anything.”

zh: “但是我们怎样才能证明一切问题呢？”
en: “But how shall we prove anything?”

zh: “我们永远也说不清楚。在这个问题上我们永远也弄不出个结果来。这种意见分歧是永远也无法说清楚的。我们大概从一开始就有一些偏爱各自的同类，并在这种偏爱的基础上寻找发生在我们圈子内的事情来说明自己的观点。这些事情有很多（也许正是这些给我们印象最深刻的事情），要是不泄露别人的秘密或者不说些不该说的话，是无法说的。”
en: “We never shall.We never can expect to prove any thing upon such a point.It is a difference of opinion which does not admit of proof.We each begin, probably, with a little bias towards our own sex; and upon that bias build every circumstance in favour of it which has occurred within our own circle; many of which circumstances (perhaps those very cases which strike us the most) may be precisely such as cannot be brought forward without betraying a confidence, or in some respect saying what should not be said.”

zh: “啊！”哈维尔上校大声叫道，情绪十分激动，“一个男人最后看一眼自己的妻子和孩子，眼巴巴地望着把他们送走的小船，直到看不见为止，转身走开时说道，‘天晓得我们还会不会再见面！’我要能使你理解他当时的痛苦心情就好了。还有，我真希望你能够知道，当他确实再见到他们；经过了也许是十二个月的离别，他回来了，但得停泊在另一个港口，并企图自欺欺人地说，‘他们要到某一天才能来到，’实际上却一直希望他们提前十二个小时到达，直到他终于看到妻儿来了，而且提前了几个小时，就像上帝给他们插上了翅膀，他那时的欢乐心情我要是能向你讲清楚就好了！要是我能够把这一切都向你解释清楚，把一个男人为了他们生命中的宝贝能够承受和能够做到的努力，并且以此为荣都向你解释清楚，该有多好！你知道，我说得只是有良心的男人！”说着，他激动地用手按了按自己的心。
en: “Ah!” cried Captain Harville, in a tone of strong feeling, “if I could but make you comprehend what a man suffers when he takes a last look at his wife and children, and watches the boat that he has sent them off in, as long as it is in sight, and then turns away and says, ‘God knows whether we ever meet again!’And then, if I could convey to you the glow of his soul when he does see them again; when, coming back after a twelvemonth’s absence, perhaps, and obliged to put into another port, he calculates how soon it be possible to get them there, pretending to deceive himself, and saying, ‘They cannot be here till such a day,’ but all the while hoping for them twelve hours sooner, and seeing them arrive at last, as if Heaven had given them wings, by many hours sooner still!If I could explain to you all this, and all that a man can bear and do, and glories to do, for the sake of these treasures of his existence!I speak, you know, only of such men as have hearts!” pressing his own with emotion.

zh: “哦！”安妮急切地说道，“我希望我能公正地对待你和与你相似的人们的感情。但愿我不会低估我的同胞热烈而真挚的感情！如果我竟敢说，只有女人才懂得真正的爱情和坚贞，那我就活该受人鄙视。不，我相信你们在婚后生活中能表现出的种种伟大而善良的感情。我相信你们能做出种种重大努力，在家庭生活中能尽量克制，只要——如果允许我这么说的话——只要你们有一个目标。我是说只要你们所爱的女人还活着，而且是为你们活着。我认为女性的特权（这并不值得羡慕，你们不必贪图这一点），就是爱得最长久，甚至在爱情和希望已破灭时仍是如此。”
en: “Oh!” cried Anne eagerly, “I hope I do justice to all that is felt by you, and by those who resemble you.God forbid that I should undervalue the warm and faithful feelings of any of my fellow-creatures!I should deserve utter contempt if I dared to suppose that true attachment and constancy were known only by woman.No, I believe you capable of everything great and good in your married lives.I believe you equal to every important exertion, and to every domestic forbearance, so long as—if I may be allowed the expression—so long as you have an object.I mean while the woman you love lives, and lives for you.All the privilege I claim for my own sex (it is not a very enviable one; you need not covet it), is that of loving longest, when existence or when hope is gone.”

zh: 安妮一时之间再也无法说下去。她的心情过于激动，呼吸过于急促了。
en: She could not immediately have uttered another sentence; her heart was too full, her breath too much oppressed.

zh: “你是个好人，”哈维尔上校大声说道，十分亲切地把手放在她的手臂上。“我争不过你。只要我一想起本威克，我就无话可说了。”
en: “You are a good soul,” cried Captain Harville, putting his hand on her arm, quite affectionately.“There is no quarrelling with you.And when I think of Benwick, my tongue is tied.”

zh: 这时他们的注意力被吸引到别人那里了。克罗夫特太太正要告辞。
en: Their attention was called towards the others.Mrs. Croft was taking leave.

zh: “我想，弗雷德里克，我们就在这里分手吧，”她说，“我要回家了，你和你朋友还有事要办。今天晚上我们可能会在你们的晚会上再次愉快地见面的。”（转向安妮。）“昨天我们收到了你姐姐的请帖，我知道弗雷德里克也接到了，尽管我没有看到。弗雷德里克，你是不是同我们一样，没有什么别的约会吧？”
en: “Here, Frederick, you and I part company, I believe,” said she.“I am going home, and you have an engagement with your friend.To-night we may have the pleasure of all meeting again at your party,” (turning to Anne.)“We had your sister’s card yesterday, and I understood Frederick had a card too, though I did not see it; and you are disengaged, Frederick, are you not, as well as ourselves?”

zh: 温特沃思上校正匆匆地叠信，既像是不能作出全面回答，又像是不愿意作出全面回答。
en: Captain Wentworth was folding up a letter in great haste, and either could not or would not answer fully.

zh: “是的，”他说，“的确如此，我们就在这里分手，但是哈维尔和我随后就来。哈维尔，你要是准备好了，我再过半分钟就行了。我知道你早就想走。再过半分钟我就陪你回去。”
en: “Yes,” said he, “very true; here we separate, but Harville and I shall soon be after you; that is, Harville, if you are ready, I am in half a minute.I know you will not be sorry to be off.I shall be at your service in half a minute.”

zh: 克罗夫特太太走了，温特沃思上校匆匆封好信，的确忙完了，甚至显得坐立不安，似乎急着要走。安妮不知道这是什么意思。哈维尔上校十分友好地对安妮说了声“再见，上帝保佑你！”可是温特沃思上校却一句话也没说，连看也没看她一眼。他看没看她一眼就从房间走了出去。
en: Mrs. Croft left them, and Captain Wentworth, having sealed his letter with great rapidity, was indeed ready, and had even a hurried, agitated air, which shewed impatience to be gone.Anne knew not how to understand it.She had the kindest “Good morning, God bless you!” from Captain Harville, but from him not a word, nor a look!He had passed out of the room without a look!

zh: 然而安妮刚刚走进温特沃思上校刚刚写信的桌子，就听到了有脚步声走回来。房门打开了，回来的正是温特沃思上校。他请大家原谅，说是忘记了拿手套，接着马上穿过房间走到书桌前，背对着马斯格罗夫太太从散乱的信纸下面抽出一封信，放在安妮面前，用深情、恳切的目光盯着她看了一会儿，然后匆匆拿起手套，又走出屋子。马斯格罗夫太太几乎还没有发觉他进来，可见动作之神速！
en: She had only time, however, to move closer to the table where he had been writing, when footsteps were heard returning; the door opened, it was himself.He begged their pardon, but he had forgotten his gloves, and instantly crossing the room to the writing table, he drew out a letter from under the scattered paper, placed it before Anne with eyes of glowing entreaty fixed on her for a time, and hastily collecting his gloves, was again out of the room, almost before Mrs. Musgrove was aware of his being in it: the work of an instant!

zh: 这一刹那在安妮心中激起的万千思绪，几乎难以形容。这封信显然是温特沃思上校刚才匆匆叠起的那封，信上“安妮•埃利奥特小姐收”的几个字写得很难辨认。安妮刚才以为他只不过是在给本威克舰长写信，原来也给她写了一封！这封信决定着这个世界能赋予她的一切。世界上什么事情都可能发生，什么事情都比悬念易于应付。马斯格罗夫太太在她那桌旁忙着一些琐事。安妮借着这一有利时机，于是一屁股坐进温特沃思上校刚才坐过的椅子，靠着他靠过和写过信的地方，贪婪地读着下面的文字：
en: The revolution which one instant had made in Anne, was almost beyond expression.The letter, with a direction hardly legible, to “Miss A. E.—,” was evidently the one which he had been folding so hastily.While supposed to be writing only to Captain Benwick, he had been also addressing her!On the contents of that letter depended all which this world could do for her.Anything was possible, anything might be defied rather than suspense.Mrs. Musgrove had little arrangements of her own at her own table; to their protection she must trust, and sinking into the chair which he had occupied, succeeding to the very spot where he had leaned and written, her eyes devoured the following words:

zh: “我再也不能默默地听下去了。我必须要用我力所能及的方法来同你谈谈。你刺伤了我的心灵。我是既有痛苦又有希望。请别对我说为时太晚，也别说这种珍贵的感情已经一去不复返了。我再次向你求婚，比起八年半前几乎被你撕碎的心，现在我的心更加属于你。你不能说男人比女人健忘，也不能说男人的爱情消亡得更早。　我除了你之外，再也没有爱过别人。我或许曾经不公正，或许意志软弱，满腔怨恨，但是我从来没有朝三暮四。我到巴斯来只是为了你。为了你一个人，我搜索枯肠。难道你还没有看出来吗？难道你还不理解我的心吗？我觉得你对我的感情一定非常了解，要是我能同样看出你的真实情感，我连这十天也等不了了。我简直写不下去了。时刻响在我耳边的一切，使我不能自持。你虽然压低了声音，但我能从你的声音里分辨出别人听不出的口气。你善良，你出类拔萃！你的确能公正地对待男人。你确实相信男人也有忠贞不渝的爱情。请相信我最热诚、最坚定不移的爱情。弗•温。
en: “I can listen no longer in silence.I must speak to you by such means as are within my reach.You pierce my soul.I am half agony, half hope.Tell me not that I am too late, that such precious feelings are gone for ever.I offer myself to you again with a heart even more your own than when you almost broke it, eight years and a half ago.Dare not say that man forgets sooner than woman, that his love has an earlier death.I have loved none but you.Unjust I may have been, weak and resentful I have been, but never inconstant.You alone have brought me to Bath.For you alone, I think and plan.Have you not seen this?Can you fail to have understood my wishes?I had not waited even these ten days, could I have read your feelings, as I think you must have penetrated mine.I can hardly write.I am every instant hearing something which overpowers me.You sink your voice, but I can distinguish the tones of that voice when they would be lost on others.Too good, too excellent creature!You do us justice, indeed.You do believe that there is true attachment and constancy among men.Believe it to be most fervent, most undeviating, in F. W.

zh: “我不知道我的命运如何，我必须走了。不过，我会尽快回来，或者是找到你们大家。一句话，一个眼神，就足以决定我今晚是到你父亲府上还是永远不去。”
en: “I must go, uncertain of my fate; but I shall return hither, or follow your party, as soon as possible.A word, a look, will be enough to decide whether I enter your father’s house this evening or never.”

zh: 安妮看到这样一封信，心里是不会马上平静下来的。要是有半个小时的独处和思考，安妮或许会平静下来。可是仅仅过了十分钟，她的思绪便被打断了，由于她的处境的种种限制，心里不可能平静下来。每时每刻都在增加她的激动不安。一种巨大的幸福感使她喜不自禁。她满怀激动的第一个阶段还没有过去，查尔斯、玛丽和亨里埃塔就都进来了。
en: Such a letter was not to be soon recovered from.Half and hour’s solitude and reflection might have tranquillized her; but the ten minutes only which now passed before she was interrupted, with all the restraints of her situation, could do nothing towards tranquillity.Every moment rather brought fresh agitation.It was overpowering happiness.And before she was beyond the first stage of full sensation, Charles, Mary, and Henrietta all came in.

zh: 这时，安妮不得不竭力克制，装出一副泰然自若的样子。但是过了一会儿之后，她就再也坚持不下去了。她再也听不进别人的谈话，迫不得已，只好推说身体不适，请他们原谅。这时，他们也看得出安妮似乎很不舒服，都很吃惊和关心，怎么也不肯把她留下后径自出去。这太可怕了。他们只要一走，把她留在安静的房间里，她就会恢复过来。但是他们一个个站在或等在她的周围，把她弄得心烦意乱。她不得已，只好说她要回家了。
en: The absolute necessity of seeming like herself produced then an immediate struggle; but after a while she could do no more.She began not to understand a word they said, and was obliged to plead indisposition and excuse herself.They could then see that she looked very ill, were shocked and concerned, and would not stir without her for the world.This was dreadful.Would they only have gone away, and left her in the quiet possession of that room it would have been her cure; but to have them all standing or waiting around her was distracting, and in desperation, she said she would go home.

zh: “对了，亲爱的，”马斯格罗夫太太大声喊道，“赶紧回家，好好休息一下，晚上好能参加晚会。要是萨拉能在这儿照顾你就好了，可惜我自己不是医生。查尔斯，打电话叫轿子。她肯定不能走路。”
en: “By all means, my dear,” cried Mrs. Musgrove, “go home directly, and take care of yourself, that you may be fit for the evening.I wish Sarah was here to doctor you, but I am no doctor myself.Charles, ring and order a chair.She must not walk.”

zh: 但是她绝对不能坐轿回去。那比什么都糟糕！这将使她失去独自安静地走回去同温特沃思上校说两句话的机会（她感到很有把握遇到他），这是她无法忍受的。安妮诚恳地说她不愿意坐车，马斯格罗夫太太只想到路易莎的不适，便带着几分忧虑自我安慰道，安妮的不舒服并不是由于摔过跤引起的。安妮最近没有摔倒过，头上没有受伤。她完全确信安妮没有摔过跤之后，才放心地让安妮走回家，相信到晚上安妮会有所好转。
en: But the chair would never do.Worse than all!To lose the possibility of speaking two words to Captain Wentworth in the course of her quiet, solitary progress up the town (and she felt almost certain of meeting him) could not be borne.The chair was earnestly protested against, and Mrs. Musgrove, who thought only of one sort of illness, having assured herself with some anxiety, that there had been no fall in the case; that Anne had not at any time lately slipped down, and got a blow on her head; that she was perfectly convinced of having had no fall; could part with her cheerfully, and depend on finding her better at night.

zh: 安妮不想放过任何可能的预防措施，她犹豫了一会儿，说道：
en: Anxious to omit no possible precaution, Anne struggled, and said—

zh: “太太，我怕这事没有完全说清楚。请你转告其他几位先生，我们希望今晚见到你们所有的人。我担心会有什么差错，所以希望你特别转告哈维尔上校和温特沃思上校，说我们希望见到他们两位。”
en: “I am afraid, ma’am, that it is not perfectly understood.Pray be so good as to mention to the other gentlemen that we hope to see your whole party this evening.I am afraid there had been some mistake; and I wish you particularly to assure Captain Harville and Captain Wentworth, that we hope to see them both.”

zh: “哦！亲爱的，这一点大家都很清楚，我向你保证。哈维尔上校一心一意想要去呢。”
en: “Oh! my dear, it is quite understood, I give you my word.Captain Harville has no thought but of going.”

zh: “你真这样认为？但是我有些担心。他们要是不去，我会感到很遗憾。你能答应我见到他们的时候再提一下吗？我想今天上午你会再见到他们两个人的。请答应我吧。”
en: “Do you think so?But I am afraid; and I should be so very sorry.Will you promise me to mention it, when you see them again?You will see them both this morning, I dare say.Do promise me.”

zh: “你既然这么要求，我当然转告。查尔斯，如果你在什么地方看到哈维尔上校，记得把安妮小姐的话转告给他。不过，说真的，亲爱的，你不用担心。我敢担保，哈维尔上校一定会去的。我看，温特沃思上校也会去的。”
en: “To be sure I will, if you wish it.Charles, if you see Captain Harville anywhere, remember to give Miss Anne’s message.But indeed, my dear, you need not be uneasy.Captain Harville holds himself quite engaged, I’ll answer for it; and Captain Wentworth the same, I dare say.”

zh: 安妮不能再说什么了。可是她内心预感到，要是事不凑巧，也许会影响她这十全十美的幸福。不过，这个念头不会持续多久。即使温特沃思上校本人不来卡姆登巷，她也可以托哈维尔上校捎个易懂的口信过去。可是当时又出现了一件伤脑筋的事情。查尔斯出于真切的关心和善良的本性，要送安妮回家，怎么拦也拦不住。这简直有点残酷了。但她又不能老是不领情。查尔斯本来同枪店约好了，但是为了陪安妮回家，他就牺牲了这次约会。所以安妮同查尔斯一起走了，脸上装出一副感激的表情。
en: Anne could do no more; but her heart prophesied some mischance to damp the perfection of her felicity.It could not be very lasting, however.Even if he did not come to Camden Place himself, it would be in her power to send an intelligible sentence by Captain Harville.Another momentary vexation occurred.Charles, in his real concern and good nature, would go home with her; there was no preventing him.This was almost cruel.But she could not be long ungrateful; he was sacrificing an engagement at a gunsmith’s, to be of use to her; and she set off with him, with no feeling but gratitude apparent.

zh: 他们走到联盟街，听到身后有一阵急促的脚步声，这阵熟悉的脚步声使安妮对温特沃思上校的出现略略有了些思想准备。他追上了他们俩，但似乎又有点犹豫不决，是同他们一起走呢，还是就从他们身旁走过去呢。他什么也没说，只是看着安妮。安妮能够控制自己，可以任他看着，而不感到厌恶。这时，安妮先前苍白的面颊变得绯红，先前迟疑的动作现在也变得果断了。温特沃思上校在安妮身边走着。一会儿，查尔斯突然产生了一个念头，说道：
en: They were on Union Street, when a quicker step behind, a something of familiar sound, gave her two moments’ preparation for the sight of Captain Wentworth.He joined them; but, as if irresolute whether to join or to pass on, said nothing, only looked.Anne could command herself enough to receive that look, and not repulsively.The cheeks which had been pale now glowed, and the movements which had hesitated were decided.He walked by her side.Presently, struck by a sudden thought, Charles said—

zh: “温特沃思上校，你走那一条路？是只去盖伊街，还是要再往前走？”
en: “Captain Wentworth, which way are you going?Only to Gay Street, or farther up the town?”

zh: “我也不知道，”温特沃思上校惊讶地回答道。
en: “I hardly know,” replied Captain Wentworth, surprised.

zh: “你要去贝尔蒙特街吗？你要到卡姆登巷附近吗？因为要是这样的话，我就没有顾虑地请你代替我将安妮送回家。她今天上午太累了，走这么远的路没有人照顾可不行，我得去市场上那个家伙的店里。他答应给我看一支他要出售的好枪，他说过要尽可能地在打包之前留给我看看。要是我现在不回去，我就没有机会了。从他的描述来看，非常像我的一支二号双筒枪，就是有一天你拿着在温思罗普附近打猎的那一支。”
en: “Are you going as high as Belmont?Are you going near Camden Place?Because, if you are, I shall have no scruple in asking you to take my place, and give Anne your arm to her father’s door.She is rather done for this morning, and must not go so far without help, and I ought to be at that fellow’s in the Market Place.He promised me the sight of a capital gun he is just going to send off; said he would keep it unpacked to the last possible moment, that I might see it; and if I do not turn back now, I have no chance.By his description, a good deal like the second size double-barrel of mine, which you shot with one day round Winthrop.”

zh: 不可能有反对意见。有的只是恰如其分的欣然同意，是做给公众看的乐于助人的顺从。他敛起笑容，心中却暗自狂喜。半分钟以后，查尔斯又走到了联盟街的另一头，另外两个人就一起往前走去。不久，他们彼此间商量了商量，决定朝相对安静而比较偏僻的砾石小路走去。在那里，他们可以尽情地交谈，使这一刻成为名副其实的幸福时刻，并把它变成他们今后生活中永恒的回忆。在那里他们重温了当初的情愫和诺言，当年这些情愫和诺言似乎一度使一切都显得万无一失，但是随之而来的却是这么多年的分离与隔阂。现在他们又重新回到了过去，也许，重新团聚比当初预期的更为幸福。他们了解彼此的性格、忠心和情意，他们的感情更为亲切，更为可靠，更为坚定，更有利于作出抉择，作出的抉择也更有道理。然后，他们沿着缓坡慢慢地往上走去，全然不注意周围的人群，既看不见闲逛的政客、忙碌的管家、调情的姑娘，也看不见保姆和儿童，他们尽情沉浸于对往事的回忆与反省里，尤其是对不久以前发生的引人入胜的、趣味无穷情况的解释中。他们回顾了上星期的种种细微的变化，谈到了昨天和今天，简直有说不完的话。
en: There could not be an objection.There could be only the most proper alacrity, a most obliging compliance for public view; and smiles reined in and spirits dancing in private rapture.In half a minute Charles was at the bottom of Union Street again, and the other two proceeding together: and soon words enough had passed between them to decide their direction towards the comparatively quiet and retired gravel walk, where the power of conversation would make the present hour a blessing indeed, and prepare it for all the immortality which the happiest recollections of their own future lives could bestow.There they exchanged again those feelings and those promises which had once before seemed to secure everything, but which had been followed by so many, many years of division and estrangement.There they returned again into the past, more exquisitely happy, perhaps, in their re-union, than when it had been first projected; more tender, more tried, more fixed in a knowledge of each other’s character, truth, and attachment; more equal to act, more justified in acting.And there, as they slowly paced the gradual ascent, heedless of every group around them, seeing neither sauntering politicians, bustling housekeepers, flirting girls, nor nursery-maids and children, they could indulge in those retrospections and acknowledgements, and especially in those explanations of what had directly preceded the present moment, which were so poignant and so ceaseless in interest.All the little variations of the last week were gone through; and of yesterday and today there could scarcely be an end.

zh: 安妮没有误解他。对埃利奥特先生的嫉妒成了他绊脚石，引起了他的猜疑与痛苦。他在巴斯第一次见到安妮时，这种嫉妒心便开始作祟，后来收敛了一小段时间，接着又回来作祟，破坏了那次音乐会。在最后的24个小时内，这种嫉妒心左右着温特沃思上校的一言一行，左右着他避而不谈或不做某事。但是安妮的神情、话语或者行动偶尔也引起了一些较乐观的希望。当安妮同哈维尔上校说话时，他听到了她的感情和语气，嫉妒心最终被克服了。于是在这种不可抗拒的感情和语气左右下，他抓起了一张纸，倾吐了自己的衷肠。
en: She had not mistaken him.Jealousy of Mr. Elliot had been the retarding weight, the doubt, the torment.That had begun to operate in the very hour of first meeting her in Bath; that had returned, after a short suspension, to ruin the concert; and that had influenced him in everything he had said and done, or omitted to say and do, in the last four-and-twenty hours.It had been gradually yielding to the better hopes which her looks, or words, or actions occasionally encouraged; it had been vanquished at last by those sentiments and those tones which had reached him while she talked with Captain Harville; and under the irresistible governance of which he had seized a sheet of paper, and poured out his feelings.

zh: 对于信中所写的一切，他没有什么要收回或者加以解释的。他一再表白除了安妮之外他没有爱过任何人。从来没有人能取代过安妮。他甚至认为，他从没有见过能比得上安妮的女人。的确，他不得不承认：他的忠贞不渝是无意识的，不，是无意中形成的。他本来打算忘掉她，而且以为自己已经忘掉了。他一度以为自己对她已经淡漠，但这只不过是一时生气罢了。他曾对她的美德作出过不公正的评价，因为他曾经遭到了这些美德的伤害。现在安妮的性格在他心中是完美的，刚柔适中，可爱至极。不过他不得不承认，他只是在阿珀克罗斯才懂得公正地看待安妮，也只有在莱姆，他才开始了解自己。在莱姆，他得到了不止一次的教训。埃利奥特先生路过时那种爱慕的眼神至少唤醒了他，而在科布和在哈维尔上校家的种种情景使他坚定了安妮的卓越不凡。
en: Of what he had then written, nothing was to be retracted or qualified.He persisted in having loved none but her.She had never been supplanted.He never even believed himself to see her equal.Thus much indeed he was obliged to acknowledge: that he had been constant unconsciously, nay unintentionally; that he had meant to forget her, and believed it to be done.He had imagined himself indifferent, when he had only been angry; and he had been unjust to her merits, because he had been a sufferer from them.Her character was now fixed on his mind as perfection itself, maintaining the loveliest medium of fortitude and gentleness; but he was obliged to acknowledge that only at Uppercross had he learnt to do her justice, and only at Lyme had he begun to understand himself.At Lyme, he had received lessons of more than one sort.The passing admiration of Mr. Elliot had at least roused him, and the scenes on the Cobb and at Captain Harville’s had fixed her superiority.

zh: 至于他先前试图追求路易莎•马斯格罗夫（出于嗔怒与傲慢），他坚决表示他一直认为那是不可能的。他并不喜欢，也不可能喜欢路易莎。不过直到那天，直到那天以后他有空闲静心思考时，他才懂得安妮杰出完美的心灵是路易莎望尘莫及的，才了解安妮的心已彻底地征服了他。那时，他才懂得区分坚持原则与一意孤行，区分掉以轻心的鲁莽与深思熟虑的坚定。那时，他才看到一切都在提升他对失去的姑娘的评价。他开始痛惜自己的傲慢、愚蠢和疯狂的怨恨，正是这一切才使他又一次邂逅安妮的时候没有努力去再次赢得她。
en: In his preceding attempts to attach himself to Louisa Musgrove (the attempts of angry pride), he protested that he had for ever felt it to be impossible; that he had not cared, could not care, for Louisa; though till that day, till the leisure for reflection which followed it, he had not understood the perfect excellence of the mind with which Louisa’s could so ill bear a comparison, or the perfect unrivalled hold it possessed over his own.There, he had learnt to distinguish between the steadiness of principle and the obstinacy of self-will, between the darings of heedlessness and the resolution of a collected mind.There he had seen everything to exalt in his estimation the woman he had lost; and there begun to deplore the pride, the folly, the madness of resentment, which had kept him from trying to regain her when thrown in his way.

zh: 从那时起，他一直悔恨交加。他刚刚从路易莎摔伤后最初几天的惊恐与自责中摆脱出来，刚刚开始觉得自己又有活力了，却又开始意识到自己虽有活力却失去了自由。
en: From that period his penance had become severe.He had no sooner been free from the horror and remorse attending the first few days of Louisa’s accident, no sooner begun to feel himself alive again, than he had begun to feel himself, though alive, not at liberty.

zh: “我发现，”他说，“哈维尔认为我已经订婚了！哈维尔上校和他妻子都不怀疑我们是相爱的。我感到非常吃惊。在某种程度上，我本可以马上反驳这一点。可是转念一想，别人可能也有这种想法——她的家人，也许还有她自己——于是我再也不能自己做主了。要是路易莎希望如此的话，那么我在道义上是属于她的。我太粗心了。我以前没有严肃地考虑过这个问题。我没有想到，我同她的过分亲近竟会有造成这么多不好后果的危险。我没有权利去尝试是否能够爱上两姐妹中的一个，这么做，即使不会造成别的不良影响，至少也会有引起不愉快的流言的危险。我完全错了，必须自食其果。”
en: “I found,” said he, “that I was considered by Harville an engaged man!That neither Harville nor his wife entertained a doubt of our mutual attachment.I was startled and shocked.To a degree, I could contradict this instantly; but, when I began to reflect that others might have felt the same—her own family, nay, perhaps herself—I was no longer at my own disposal.I was hers in honour if she wished it.I had been unguarded.I had not thought seriously on this subject before.I had not considered that my excessive intimacy must have its danger of ill consequence in many ways; and that I had no right to be trying whether I could attach myself to either of the girls, at the risk of raising even an unpleasant report, were there no other ill effects.I had been grossly wrong, and must abide the consequences.”

zh: 总之，他发觉得太晚了，他已经陷下去了。如果路易莎对他的感情就如哈维尔夫妇估计的那样，那么就在他完全弄清楚了自己根本不喜欢路易莎的时候，他却必须认定自己同她拴在了一起。因此，他决定离开莱姆，到别的地方等待路易莎完全康复。他非常想通过某种适当的方式来淡化路易莎对他可能有的感情和猜测，因此他去了哥哥家，打算过一段时间再回凯林奇，以便见机行事。
en: He found too late, in short, that he had entangled himself; and that precisely as he became fully satisfied of his not caring for Louisa at all, he must regard himself as bound to her, if her sentiments for him were what the Harvilles supposed.It determined him to leave Lyme, and await her complete recovery elsewhere.He would gladly weaken, by any fair means, whatever feelings or speculations concerning him might exist; and he went, therefore, to his brother’s, meaning after a while to return to Kellynch, and act as circumstances might require.

zh: “我在爱德华家呆了六个小时，”他说，“看到他很幸福。我却不能有其他的乐趣。我不配得到任何欢乐。他特别问起了你，甚至还问起你的容貌有没有发生变化。他没想到，在我眼中，你永远不会变样。”
en: “I was six weeks with Edward,” said he, “and saw him happy.I could have no other pleasure.I deserved none.He enquired after you very particularly; asked even if you were personally altered, little suspecting that to my eye you could never alter.”

zh: 安妮笑了笑，没有说话。他的这种错误是令人欣慰的，不应当受到责备。一个女人活到二十八岁，还听别人说没有失去早年的青春魅力，当然感到很高兴。不过同他以前说过的话相比，安妮更觉得这种敬意的价值不知高了多少，因为她觉得这是他炽烈的爱情恢复的后果，而不是原因。
en: Anne smiled, and let it pass.It was too pleasing a blunder for a reproach.It is something for a woman to be assured, in her eight-and-twentieth year, that she has not lost one charm of earlier youth; but the value of such homage was inexpressibly increased to Anne, by comparing it with former words, and feeling it to be the result, not the cause of a revival of his warm attachment.

zh: 他一直呆在希罗普郡，为自己盲目的骄傲和错误的估计而追悔莫及，直到传来路易莎同本威克订婚这一令人吃惊的喜讯，他才一下子摆脱了同路易莎的关系。
en: He had remained in Shropshire, lamenting the blindness of his own pride, and the blunders of his own calculations, till at once released from Louisa by the astonishing and felicitous intelligence of her engagement with Benwick.

zh: “这样一来，”他说，“结束了我最糟糕的处境。现在我至少可以踏上幸福之路，我可以努力，做点什么。但是过去那样无所作为的长期等待，而且只等待不幸，这真叫人感到可怕。听到消息的五分钟后，我就说‘我星期三就要去巴斯，’而且我确实来了。我认为值得一来，而且是带着某种希望来的，这难道不是情有可原吗？你还单身。你可能还同我一样，保留着以往的感情。碰巧我又知道了一件使我受到鼓舞的事情。我从不怀疑别人爱上你，追求你，但是我确实知道你曾经拒绝过一个人，至少是条件比我好的人。我忍不住常常问自己，‘这是为了我吗？’”
en: “Here,” said he, “ended the worst of my state; for now I could at least put myself in the way of happiness; I could exert myself; I could do something.But to be waiting so long in inaction, and waiting only for evil, had been dreadful.Within the first five minutes I said, ‘I will be at Bath on Wednesday,’ and I was.Was it unpardonable to think it worth my while to come?and to arrive with some degree of hope?You were single.It was possible that you might retain the feelings of the past, as I did; and one encouragement happened to be mine.I could never doubt that you would be loved and sought by others, but I knew to a certainty that you had refused one man, at least, of better pretensions than myself; and I could not help often saying, ‘Was this for me?’”

zh: 他们在米尔萨姆街的第一次见面就有好多话可以说，而且谈到音乐会时可说的就更多了。那天晚上似乎充满了奇妙的时刻。安妮在把八宝厅走上前来跟他说话的时刻；埃利奥特先生进来把她拉走的时刻；后来又有一两次，忽而重新浮现出希望，忽而愈发感到失望。两个人兴致勃勃地谈论不停。
en: Their first meeting in Milsom Street afforded much to be said, but the concert still more.That evening seemed to be made up of exquisite moments.The moment of her stepping forward in the Octagon Room to speak to him: the moment of Mr. Elliot’s appearing and tearing her away, and one or two subsequent moments, marked by returning hope or increasing despondency, were dwelt on with energy.

zh: 他大声说道：“看到你坐在一群不会对我表示好感的人中间，看到你堂兄坐在你身边，又说又笑，觉得你们才是天造地设的一对，我心中该有多么懊恼！想到这是有可能对你产生影响的每一个人的必然的愿望，对我又是种什么滋味！即使你自己的感情勉强或者冷漠，可是支持他的力量多大啊！我看上去傻乎乎的，难道这不足以愚弄我吗？我怎么能眼看着这一切而不感到痛苦呢？一看到坐在你身后的那位朋友，回想起以前曾经发生的事，深知这位朋友对你的影响，又想到她的劝说曾经造成的后果所留下的无法抹去，无法改变的印象——这一切难道不都是对我不利的吗？”
en: “To see you,” cried he, “in the midst of those who could not be my well-wishers; to see your cousin close by you, conversing and smiling, and feel all the horrible eligibilities and proprieties of the match!To consider it as the certain wish of every being who could hope to influence you!Even if your own feelings were reluctant or indifferent, to consider what powerful supports would be his!Was it not enough to make the fool of me which I appeared?How could I look on without agony?Was not the very sight of the friend who sat behind you, was not the recollection of what had been, the knowledge of her influence, the indelible, immoveable impression of what persuasion had once done—was it not all against me?”

zh: “你早就应该看清楚了，”安妮回答道。“你现在早就不应该怀疑我了。情况大不相同了，我的年龄也大不相同了。如果说我曾经错误地听信了别人的劝导，请记住，他们的这种劝导是从安全的角度出发，不想让我承担风险。当初我听从他们的劝导，是因为我觉得那是一种责任，但是这次却无法求助于责任感。我要是嫁给一个对我冷漠的人，将会招致种种风险，违背一切责任。”
en: “You should have distinguished,” replied Anne.“You should not have suspected me now; the case is so different, and my age is so different.If I was wrong in yielding to persuasion once, remember that it was to persuasion exerted on the side of safety, not of risk.When I yielded, I thought it was to duty, but no duty could be called in aid here.In marrying a man indifferent to me, all risk would have been incurred, and all duty violated.”

zh: “或许我早就应该这么考虑了，”他回答道，“可是我做不到。我当时还不能从对你的性格的进一步了解中得到启示。我还不能把这种了解化为行动，多年来使我痛苦的往日情感把这种了解压倒、埋葬和湮没了。我只能把你当作因听从劝导而抛弃我的人，你受别人的影响，却不肯受我的影响。我看见你同那个在痛苦年代里引导过你的人呆在一起。我没有理由认为，现在她的影响已经减弱了。此外，还应该考虑习惯的力量。”
en: “Perhaps I ought to have reasoned thus,” he replied, “but I could not.I could not derive benefit from the late knowledge I had acquired of your character.I could not bring it into play; it was overwhelmed, buried, lost in those earlier feelings which I had been smarting under year after year.I could think of you only as one who had yielded, who had given me up, who had been influenced by any one rather than by me.I saw you with the very person who had guided you in that year of misery.I had no reason to believe her of less authority now.The force of habit was to be added.”

zh: “我本以为，”安妮说道，“我对你的态度可能使你免去许多或全部怀疑的。”
en: “I should have thought,” said Anne, “that my manner to yourself might have spared you much or all of this.”

zh: “不，不！你的态度很可能是同别人订婚以后表现出的从容大度而已。我抱着这样的信念离开了你。但是，我还是决定要再见你。到了第二天早上，我的精神又振作了起来，我觉得我还有理由呆在这儿。”
en: “No, no! your manner might be only the ease which your engagement to another man would give.I left you in this belief; and yet, I was determined to see you again.My spirits rallied with the morning, and I felt that I had still a motive for remaining here.”

zh: 最终安妮又回到家了，一家人谁都想象不到她有多么幸福。这次谈话驱散了当天上午的所有诧异、悬念和其他所有痛苦，她带着无比幸福的心情走进家门，以致害怕这种幸福不能持久，因而又不得不去寻找那些转瞬即逝的令人担心的原因。在这种极度幸福的时刻，只要稍微严肃而愉快地思索一下，就能排除一切担忧。因此，当安妮走进自己的房间时，她已充满了欢快的心情，变得坚强而无畏了。
en: At last Anne was at home again, and happier than any one in that house could have conceived.All the surprise and suspense, and every other painful part of the morning dissipated by this conversation, she re-entered the house so happy as to be obliged to find an alloy in some momentary apprehensions of its being impossible to last.An interval of meditation, serious and grateful, was the best corrective of everything dangerous in such high-wrought felicity; and she went to her room, and grew steadfast and fearless in the thankfulness of her enjoyment.

zh: 夜幕降临了，客厅里灯火辉煌，宾主聚集一堂。所谓的晚会，只不过是一次牌会，仅仅是以前少有往来的客人和常客之间的交往而已。这是一次极普通的晚会，想要进行亲密的交谈，就嫌人太多，要使活动丰富多彩，又嫌人太少。但是安妮从来没有见到过比这次更短的晚会了。她感情丰富，感到非常幸福，显得容光焕发，妩媚可爱。她受到比她想象的和期望的还要多的仰慕，而她对周围的每个人也非常亲切和宽容。埃利奥特先生也来了。安妮躲开他，但是也同情他。对于沃利斯夫妇，她为能结识他们而感到兴奋。达尔林普尔夫人和卡特雷特小姐——她们很快就会成为对她无碍的表亲了。她不去理会克莱太太，对她父亲和姐姐在公开场合的举止也没有什么可羞愧的。她与马斯格罗夫一家非常随便而愉快地闲谈着；与哈维尔上校是一种兄妹间的情真意切的交谈；她曾打算同拉塞尔夫人谈话，但是几次都被一种美妙的情感所打断；对克罗夫特将军和太太，她非常非常热诚，兴致勃勃，但是出于同样美妙的感情，她尽量加以掩饰；对于温特沃思上校，她总时不时地同他谈上一会儿，总是希望多谈几次，而且一直意识到他就在旁边。
en: The evening came, the drawing-rooms were lighted up, the company assembled.It was but a card party, it was but a mixture of those who had never met before, and those who met too often; a commonplace business, too numerous for intimacy, too small for variety; but Anne had never found an evening shorter.Glowing and lovely in sensibility and happiness, and more generally admired than she thought about or cared for, she had cheerful or forbearing feelings for every creature around her.Mr. Elliot was there; she avoided, but she could pity him.The Wallises, she had amusement in understanding them.Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret—they would soon be innoxious cousins to her.She cared not for Mrs. Clay, and had nothing to blush for in the public manners of her father and sister.With the Musgroves, there was the happy chat of perfect ease; with Captain Harville, the kind-hearted intercourse of brother and sister; with Lady Russell, attempts at conversation, which a delicious consciousness cut short; with Admiral and Mrs. Croft, everything of peculiar cordiality and fervent interest, which the same consciousness sought to conceal; and with Captain Wentworth, some moments of communications continually occurring, and always the hope of more, and always the knowledge of his being there.

zh: 就在一次短暂的接触中，两人表面上在欣赏着陈列得很优美的温室植物，这时安妮说道：
en: It was in one of these short meetings, each apparently occupied in admiring a fine display of greenhouse plants, that she said—

zh: “我一直在考虑我们过去的事情，希望能公正地判断是非，我是就我自己而言。应该说，我虽然经受了很多痛苦，但是当时我听从朋友的劝告，是正确的，是完全正确的，将来你会比现在更喜欢我的这位朋友。对于我来说，她就像是母亲一样。不过，请不要误解我。我并不是说她的劝告没有错。也许在这种情况下，劝告好坏与否，要由事态发展来决定。至于我个人，在任何类似情况下，都决不会提出这样的劝告。不过我的意思是说，我听从她的劝告是正确的，如果我不听她的劝告，那么继续保持婚约使我遭受的痛苦比结束婚约更严重，因为我会受到良心的责备。如果我们承认，在人的身上存在着这样一种情感的话，那我就没有什么可谴责自己的。如果我说错的话，那么强烈的责任感是女人一份不错的嫁妆。”
en: “I have been thinking over the past, and trying impartially to judge of the right and wrong, I mean with regard to myself; and I must believe that I was right, much as I suffered from it, that I was perfectly right in being guided by the friend whom you will love better than you do now.To me, she was in the place of a parent.Do not mistake me, however.I am not saying that she did not err in her advice.It was, perhaps, one of those cases in which advice is good or bad only as the event decides; and for myself, I certainly never should, in any circumstance of tolerable similarity, give such advice.But I mean, that I was right in submitting to her, and that if I had done otherwise, I should have suffered more in continuing the engagement than I did even in giving it up, because I should have suffered in my conscience.I have now, as far as such a sentiment is allowable in human nature, nothing to reproach myself with; and if I mistake not, a strong sense of duty is no bad part of a woman’s portion.”

zh: 温特沃思上校看看她，看看拉塞尔夫人，然后又看看她，似乎在冷静地思索，回答道：
en: He looked at her, looked at Lady Russell, and looking again at her, replied, as if in cool deliberation—

zh: “现在我还不能原谅她。不过，今后她有希望得到宽恕。我相信我很快就会宽恕她的。不过我也在考虑过去的事情，一个问题油然而生，除了那位夫人之外，我是否可能还有另外一个敌人？那就是我自己。请你告诉我，要是我在一八零八年带着几千英镑回到英国并被派往‘拉克尼亚’号后给你写信，你会回信吗？总之，在那种情况下，你会恢复婚约吗？”
en: “Not yet.But there are hopes of her being forgiven in time.I trust to being in charity with her soon.But I too have been thinking over the past, and a question has suggested itself, whether there may not have been one person more my enemy even than that lady?My own self.Tell me if, when I returned to England in the year eight, with a few thousand pounds, and was posted into the Laconia, if I had then written to you, would you have answered my letter?Would you, in short, have renewed the engagement then?”

zh: “我会吗！”这就是安妮的全部回答，但是语气却十分坚决。
en: “Would I!” was all her answer; but the accent was decisive enough.

zh: “仁慈的上帝！”他喊道，“你会的！倒不是我没有想到这一点，我并非不希望我的一切成就能配上这一最高奖赏。可是我的自尊心很强，太强了，不愿意再次求婚。我不理解你。我闭上了我的眼睛，不想理解你，也不想公正地看待你。想到这一点，我可以原谅任何人，就是不能原谅我自己。六年的分离和痛苦本来可以避免的。这种想法也是一种痛苦，对我来说也是一种新的痛苦。过去我总是满意地认为，我享受的一切幸福都是我挣来的。我总是自恃劳苦功高，理所当然应该得到报答。就像其他受到挫折的伟人一样，”他微笑着继续说道，“我必须使我的思想顺从命运的安排。我应该学会享受我本配不上的幸福。”
en: “Good God!” he cried, “you would!It is not that I did not think of it, or desire it, as what could alone crown all my other success; but I was proud, too proud to ask again.I did not understand you.I shut my eyes, and would not understand you, or do you justice.This is a recollection which ought to make me forgive every one sooner than myself.Six years of separation and suffering might have been spared.It is a sort of pain, too, which is new to me.I have been used to the gratification of believing myself to earn every blessing that I enjoyed.I have valued myself on honourable toils and just rewards.Like other great men under reverses,” he added, with a smile.“I must endeavour to subdue my mind to my fortune.I must learn to brook being happier than I deserve.”

zh: 第二十四章
en: CHAPTER 24

zh: 谁还会对事态的发展产生怀疑呢？无论哪对年轻人，只要他们决定结婚，肯定会坚定不移地去实现这个目标，哪怕他们很穷，或者很不明智，或者婚姻对彼此的最终幸福毫无必要。得出这样的结论或许是不道德的，但是我相信这是真理。如果这些人能够成功，那位温特沃思上校和安妮•埃利奥特小姐，思想既成熟，又有明辨是非的优点，他们之间还有一笔自主的财产，怎么会抵挡不住种种的反对意见呢？实际上，他们已经冲破的阻力远比他们遇到的多，因为除了缺少亲切与热情之外，也没有什么事情使他们苦恼。沃尔特爵士没有反对，伊丽莎白只不过看上去冷淡和漠不关心而已。温特沃思上校拥有25000镑财产，赫赫的优点与功绩使他在海军中获得了很高的职位，他已不再是小人物了。现在，人们认为他完全有资格去向一位愚蠢的、挥霍无度的准男爵的女儿求婚，何况这位准男爵无才无德，无法维持上天赋予他的地位，目前只能给予他女儿将来应该继承的一万英镑财产的一小部分。
en: Who can be in doubt of what followed?When any two young people take it into their heads to marry, they are pretty sure by perseverance to carry their point, be they ever so poor, or ever so imprudent, or ever so little likely to be necessary to each other’s ultimate comfort.This may be bad morality to conclude with, but I believe it to be truth; and if such parties succeed, how should a Captain Wentworth and an Anne Elliot, with the advantage of maturity of mind, consciousness of right, and one independent fortune between them, fail of bearing down every opposition?They might in fact, have borne down a great deal more than they met with, for there was little to distress them beyond the want of graciousness and warmth.Sir Walter made no objection, and Elizabeth did nothing worse than look cold and unconcerned.Captain Wentworth, with five-and-twenty thousand pounds, and as high in his profession as merit and activity could place him, was no longer nobody.He was now esteemed quite worthy to address the daughter of a foolish, spendthrift baronet, who had not had principle or sense enough to maintain himself in the situation in which Providence had placed him, and who could give his daughter at present but a small part of the share of ten thousand pounds which must be hers hereafter.

zh: 沃尔特爵士虽然不喜欢安妮，虚荣心又没有得到满足，因而并不为这件事情真心地感到高兴，但是他确实认为这桩婚事对安妮是不错的。相反，他见到温特沃思上校的次数多了，白天反复打量他，仔细对他进行了观察，为他的相貌大为打动，觉得他那仪表堂堂的相貌确实抵得上安妮的高贵家世。这一切，再加上他那动听的姓名，最后使沃尔特爵士欣然拿起笔，在那本荣誉册中加上了这桩婚事。
en: Sir Walter, indeed, though he had no affection for Anne, and no vanity flattered, to make him really happy on the occasion, was very far from thinking it a bad match for her.On the contrary, when he saw more of Captain Wentworth, saw him repeatedly by daylight, and eyed him well, he was very much struck by his personal claims, and felt that his superiority of appearance might be not unfairly balanced against her superiority of rank; and all this, assisted by his well-sounding name, enabled Sir Walter at last to prepare his pen, with a very good grace, for the insertion of the marriage in the volume of honour.

zh: 在这些亲朋好友中，只有一个人的反对可能会引起真正的焦虑，那就是拉塞尔夫人。安妮知道拉塞尔夫人在了解了埃利奥特先生的真面目并放弃他之后，不仅肯定会感到有些痛苦，而且要经过一番努力才能真正认识并公正地对待温特沃思上校。不过，拉塞尔夫人现在不得不这么做了。她必须认识到，她对两个人的判断都错了，她对两个人的外表产生了错觉。因为温特沃思上校的举止不符合她的心意，她就过早地认为他的举止反映了一种危险的鲁莽性格。因为埃利奥特先生的举止稳妥得体，彬彬有礼，善于阿谀奉承，投她所好，她就过早地把他看作是教养有素和思想成熟的必然结果。拉塞尔夫人所能做的就是承认她过去完全错了，需要接受新的观点并迎合新的希望。
en: The only one among them, whose opposition of feeling could excite any serious anxiety was Lady Russell.Anne knew that Lady Russell must be suffering some pain in understanding and relinquishing Mr. Elliot, and be making some struggles to become truly acquainted with, and do justice to Captain Wentworth.This however was what Lady Russell had now to do.She must learn to feel that she had been mistaken with regard to both; that she had been unfairly influenced by appearances in each; that because Captain Wentworth’s manners had not suited her own ideas, she had been too quick in suspecting them to indicate a character of dangerous impetuosity; and that because Mr. Elliot’s manners had precisely pleased her in their propriety and correctness, their general politeness and suavity, she had been too quick in receiving them as the certain result of the most correct opinions and well-regulated mind.There was nothing less for Lady Russell to do, than to admit that she had been pretty completely wrong, and to take up a new set of opinions and of hopes.

zh: 有些人观察力敏锐，善于识别人的性格，具有天然的洞察力，总之，其他人的经验是无法与之相比的，拉塞尔夫人在这方面的悟性远远没有她的年轻朋友有天赋。不过她是一个非常善良的女性，如果说她的第二目标是通情达理和明确判断，那么她的第一目标便是看着安妮能够得到幸福。她爱安妮胜过爱自己的才能。当最初的尴尬消失之后，她就发现，她可以毫不困难地像母亲一样来对待那个能保证她心爱的孩子得到幸福的孩子。
en: There is a quickness of perception in some, a nicety in the discernment of character, a natural penetration, in short, which no experience in others can equal, and Lady Russell had been less gifted in this part of understanding than her young friend.But she was a very good woman, and if her second object was to be sensible and well-judging, her first was to see Anne happy.She loved Anne better than she loved her own abilities; and when the awkwardness of the beginning was over, found little hardship in attaching herself as a mother to the man who was securing the happiness of her other child.

zh: 在一家人里，或许只有玛丽才会对这件事情感到最为满意。有个姐姐要结婚是光荣的，她还得意地认为是她秋天把安妮留在家里，才有力地促成了这桩婚事。因为她自己的姐姐要比丈夫的妹妹好，她十分乐意地认为温特沃思上校比本威克舰长和查尔斯•海特都富有。或许，当他们再次相会时，看到安妮又恢复了优先权，成为一个很漂亮的四轮马车的女主人时，她心里会有些难过，但是她可以聊以自慰的是，她可以寄希望于未来。安妮没有阿珀克罗斯大宅，没有地产，不可能当一家之主。只要不让温特沃思上校当上准男爵，她是不愿意与安妮换个位置的。
en: Of all the family, Mary was probably the one most immediately gratified by the circumstance.It was creditable to have a sister married, and she might flatter herself with having been greatly instrumental to the connexion, by keeping Anne with her in the autumn; and as her own sister must be better than her husband’s sisters, it was very agreeable that Captain Wentworth should be a richer man than either Captain Benwick or Charles Hayter.She had something to suffer, perhaps, when they came into contact again, in seeing Anne restored to the rights of seniority, and the mistress of a very pretty landaulette; but she had a future to look forward to, of powerful consolation.Anne had no Uppercross Hall before her, no landed estate, no headship of a family; and if they could but keep Captain Wentworth from being made a baronet, she would not change situations with Anne.

zh: 要是大姐伊丽莎白对她的处境同样满意就好了，因为不大可能再发生什么变化了。不久她就痛苦地看着埃利奥特先生离开了，从此再也没有出现一个有相当地位的人来唤起哪怕是与埃利奥特先生一同消逝的那种渺茫的希望。
en: It would be well for the eldest sister if she were equally satisfied with her situation, for a change is not very probable there.She had soon the mortification of seeing Mr. Elliot withdraw, and no one of proper condition has since presented himself to raise even the unfounded hopes which sunk with him.

zh: 埃利奥特先生听到他堂妹安妮订婚的消息，感到十分意外。这打乱了他建立幸福家庭的美好设想，打破了他利用女婿的权利来监视沃尔特爵士，让他不再做续娶的美梦。不过，他虽然受到了挫折，感到失望，但还能为维护自己的利益和享受而做些事情。他很快便离开了巴斯。过了不久，克莱太太也走了，人们后来听说克莱太太在伦敦做了他的姘头。显而易见，埃利奥特先生过去如何一直在玩弄两面手法，他如何下定决心，不让一个狡猾的女人毁了自己的继承权。
en: The news of his cousins Anne’s engagement burst on Mr. Elliot most unexpectedly.It deranged his best plan of domestic happiness, his best hope of keeping Sir Walter single by the watchfulness which a son-in-law’s rights would have given.But, though discomfited and disappointed, he could still do something for his own interest and his own enjoyment.He soon quitted Bath; and on Mrs. Clay’s quitting it soon afterwards, and being next heard of as established under his protection in London, it was evident how double a game he had been playing, and how determined he was to save himself from being cut out by one artful woman, at least.

zh: 克莱太太的感情压倒了她的利益，为了这个年轻人，她放弃了进一步施展阴谋去征服沃尔特爵士的计划。不过，她有感情，也有能力，所以目前还难以确定他们俩究竟谁的狡猾会占上风。埃利奥特先生虽阻止她成为沃尔特爵士的妻子，不知道他自己是否会被连哄带骗地最终娶她做威廉爵士夫人。
en: Mrs. Clay’s affections had overpowered her interest, and she had sacrificed, for the young man’s sake, the possibility of scheming longer for Sir Walter.She has abilities, however, as well as affections; and it is now a doubtful point whether his cunning, or hers, may finally carry the day; whether, after preventing her from being the wife of Sir Walter, he may not be wheedled and caressed at last into making her the wife of Sir William.

zh: 毫无疑问，沃尔特爵士和伊丽莎白失去这一伙伴、发现她欺骗了他们后，感到非常震惊和羞愧。当然，他们可以到高贵的表亲那里寻求安慰，但是他们总也一定感到，总是去奉承和迎合别人，却没有人来奉承和迎合自己，那只有一半的乐趣。
en: It cannot be doubted that Sir Walter and Elizabeth were shocked and mortified by the loss of their companion, and the discovery of their deception in her.They had their great cousins, to be sure, to resort to for comfort; but they must long feel that to flatter and follow others, without being flattered and followed in turn, is but a state of half enjoyment.

zh: 早在拉塞尔夫人刚刚打算要像她应该做的那样去爱护温特沃思上校时，安妮就感到大为满意。她对自己未来的幸福生活没有遗憾，只是感到无法为温特沃思上校提供一个通情达理的人所能珍惜的亲戚。在这一方面，安妮感到十分自卑。财产上的差距没什么，她对此倒一点都不感到遗憾。但是家里人不能恰当地对待和评价温特沃思上校，没有尊重，没有和谐也没有善意，无以报答安妮从温特沃思上校兄弟姐妹那里受到的重视和诚心诚意的欢迎。这是安妮深感切肤之痛的根源，否则她会感到异常幸福的。在这个世界上，安妮只能给温特沃思上校的朋友圈增加两个人：拉塞尔夫人和史密斯太太。不过，他倒是很愿意同他们两个交往。尽管拉塞尔夫人以前有过这样那样的过失，但是他却能真心实意地敬重她。他除了不能说拉塞尔夫人过去将他们拆散是正确的以外，在其他方面，他几乎愿意处处替她说好话。至于史密斯太太，她有种种长处，很快就能赢得他永久的好感。
en: Anne, satisfied at a very early period of Lady Russell’s meaning to love Captain Wentworth as she ought, had no other alloy to the happiness of her prospects than what arose from the consciousness of having no relations to bestow on him which a man of sense could value.There she felt her own inferiority very keenly.The disproportion in their fortune was nothing; it did not give her a moment’s regret; but to have no family to receive and estimate him properly, nothing of respectability, of harmony, of good will to offer in return for all the worth and all the prompt welcome which met her in his brothers and sisters, was a source of as lively pain as her mind could well be sensible of under circumstances of otherwise strong felicity.She had but two friends in the world to add to his list, Lady Russell and Mrs. Smith.To those, however, he was very well disposed to attach himself.Lady Russell, in spite of all her former transgressions, he could now value from his heart.While he was not obliged to say that he believed her to have been right in originally dividing them, he was ready to say almost everything else in her favour, and as for Mrs. Smith, she had claims of various kinds to recommend her quickly and permanently.

zh: 史密斯太太不久前对安妮做了足够多的好事，他们的婚姻不仅没有使她失去一个朋友，反而使她有了两个好友。她是他们定居以后的第一个来访者。温特沃思上校不仅为她收回她丈夫在西印度群岛的财产出点子，还为她写信，为她四处奔走，帮她闯过一道道具体而琐碎的难关，他以一个无所畏惧的坚定朋友的奔走与努力，充分报答了史密斯太太过去给予的或者打算给予他妻子的帮助。
en: Her recent good offices by Anne had been enough in themselves, and their marriage, instead of depriving her of one friend, secured her two.She was their earliest visitor in their settled life; and Captain Wentworth, by putting her in the way of recovering her husband’s property in the West Indies, by writing for her, acting for her, and seeing her through all the petty difficulties of the case with the activity and exertion of a fearless man and a determined friend, fully requited the services which she had rendered, or ever meant to render, to his wife.

zh: 史密斯太太的收入增加了，健康状况好转了，又赢得了这些经常往来的朋友，因为她并没有丧失快乐和爽朗的性格。只要她保持这些主要的美德，她甚至可以藐视更多的荣华富贵。她即使家财万贯，非常健康，也仍会感到幸福。她的幸福来源于她热烈的情绪，就像她朋友安妮的幸福来源于她热情的内心。安妮十分温柔，完全赢得了温特沃思上校的钟情。只有他的职业才使得安妮的朋友希望她不要那么温柔，唯恐将来的战争会使她的快乐黯然失色。她为做一个水兵的妻子而感到自豪，但是她必须为属于这一职业而付出担惊受怕的代价。如果可能的话，这种职业在家庭中的重要性比在国家中的重要性更为显著。
en: Mrs. Smith’s enjoyments were not spoiled by this improvement of income, with some improvement of health, and the acquisition of such friends to be often with, for her cheerfulness and mental alacrity did not fail her; and while these prime supplies of good remained, she might have bid defiance even to greater accessions of worldly prosperity.She might have been absolutely rich and perfectly healthy, and yet be happy.Her spring of felicity was in the glow of her spirits, as her friend Anne’s was in the warmth of her heart.Anne was tenderness itself, and she had the full worth of it in Captain Wentworth’s affection.His profession was all that could ever make her friends wish that tenderness less, the dread of a future war all that could dim her sunshine.She gloried in being a sailor’s wife, but she must pay the tax of quick alarm for belonging to that profession which is, if possible, more distinguished in its domestic virtues than in its national importance.
